column10: nice game

TL:DR It's a good amount of content for the price. Solid Linux support. Unbalanced late game.

I've of two minds on this game. On one hand there is a lot of classes and skills. But on the other hand the best plan for the harder curse levels/overlord is to push as much dps as possible. There is no damage mitigation that can save you. Just keep dodging and pick the best runes/skills to max your dmg potential. The problem is that this tends to funnel you into just a few different meta games and this sadly makes 90% of all those classes and skills feel lack luster. I quickly found my goto skills/runes and just copied those to every class. Your reward is a few more passives shared across all classes and a few situational rune unlocks. In fact unlocking every class fully increases the pool of skills and makes it harder to get the skills you want. This is a problem for many 'survivor-like' games, but it's pretty pronounced here with the shear number.

I feel like there needs to be some (more) tools to limit the skill pool as they continue to add more. Maybe more banishes or a way to filter types/elements?

All in all I feel like this is pretty mid. Not bad enough to downvote so I'll recommend considering it's early access. Will adjust later.

So for example you disable it, when there are so many enemies and enemy abilities going on the map it can make the game less fun, for me that is the case. I have read the other comments about this game being grindy. It can be depending on what you want to do in the game which I find excellent. 

In the start menu it shows you your skill breakdown with DPS on the attacks you choose. You need to be strategic about it, this makes it go a lot faster if you pick the right things. 

I don't find it boring, I find I fun, I want to see what the next weapon will do for my character, what prestige is going to unlock, etc. 

The necromancer is the easy button if you pick the right skills. 

It's a fun game. No more grindy than the rest of them.

I got this today and I already have 14 hours in it. Fantastic fun and visually appealing with a banging soundtrack. For the first time in ages I've actually turned off videos on my second monitor so I can focus on the game. Bright colours, pretty lights, great music and regular dopamine hits are a great combo.

I can't say too much else about the gameplay yet since I feel like I've barely done anything but I do have one potential criticism that doesn't appeal to me as a new player. 

It feels like this game will be grindy. Please don't make us grind so many different weapon materials. If this were a live service game with a subscription or (god forbid) micro transactions then I'd understand the appeal of a grind to keep players in the game or to avoid buying materials with real money but since it was a one time payment I don't think you need to pad out the playtime like this. A good game doesn't overstay it's welcome.

I have some suggestions on alternative methods that require less grinding.

1. Weapons could be unlocked when you hit prestige milestones, unlocking new playstyles as you play the game. This does have drawbacks such as making you play said class instead of grinding the materials with any class for variety but if you enjoy the class it shouldn't be an issue.

2. Drastically lower the material costs. You get around 250 basic ore from a successful run and it doesn't increase at higher difficulties from what I've seen. The second unlockable weapon on Barbarian will be 6 or 7 cave ruins for the basic ore alone. Even if the material cost was just halved it'd make the grind see less daunting to a new player.

3. Have the weapons be looked behind an achievement. This could encourage exploring higher difficulties or even descending into the void to unlock a new weapon. The obvious drawback is the difficulty but it'll be a reward for getting good at a class. 

Just some thoughts. I love this game so far though

Edit: This game is just fantastic. The classes have good variety and the class specific skill trees are really nice. My biggest gripe is that the challenge increase as you apply more curses is more tedious then fun. The attack spam isn't hard to dodge if your quick but not being able to get close to bosses in melee is making runs really annoying.

All in all, great game

This game is like right on the cusp of fun. I find myself coming back to it but I think that has more to do with my compulsion to check all the boxes and fill all the bars and less to do with whether or not the game is actually enjoyable to play.

+5% bonus to a generic stat is not a fun, interesting, engaging, nor meaningful choice. I thought the games industry figured this out back when it figured out escort missions are objectively bad.

The graphics are barely serviceable. The classes seem like they're different on the surface, but playing any of them for more than 30 minutes reveals they're all the same thing. Even unlocking their 'unique' abilities is a joke because they all boil down to the same mechanic: gather some meta-resource and then get a temporary buff.

There's so much crap on the screen at any one time that an option had to be added to reduce the opacity of the effects on the screen so you can see the telegraphed danger zones on the ground. When you have to add a feature like that into the game, it should clue you in that there's a fundamental flaw with the way you've designed it.

The game mechanics are so shallow that no matter what build you pick you eventually hit a wall where you're just moving around the screen dodging red zones on the ground. Everything else just falls away at that point. I understand this genre is kind of passive compared to other types of games, but this feels extreme.

I think overall i give it a D+ grade, mostly because for all it's attempts to seem rich and engaging, I think my frustration with it comes from the illusion it puts on about being much deeper than it is. There's a million things to unlock! but they're all the same.

The progression is fun, grinding for currencies to unlock metaprogression is cool, but late-game, you find some semi-broken build, go for that build every time, and the entirety of the game is just grind out as many crystals from boss kills as possible before you inevitably get 1-2 shot by the constant wave of red ground hazards. There's no avoiding it after a while. The ground is just a chaos of one-shot mechanics that you'll eventually run into. The game is literally dash to avoid red circles and lines on the ground until eventually you don't. It's a fun game otherwise. You can really feel the power spike once you unlock certain spells and runes, which is great. I just wish there was more to late-game waves other than try not to get one shot by red circles.

This game does not respect your time. It is much too grindy, without the reward of expanding the gameplay loop as you get stronger. The increase in power between each run is tiny, as upgrades are too expensive and give too little power. There are much more fun alternatives within the genre for less money.

So far, I really like this game! Everything you expect from an action RPG / Vampire Survivors’ clone : unlockable assymetric characters, weapon crafting, skill tree, runes, etc. Comes with a lot of grinding, but since runs are fairly quick (from 20 minutes down to less than 10 the more powerful you get) it doesn’t bother me.
There’s no storyline and no in-game tutorial, so you have to figure out everything for yourself, but there’s not much deepness so it doesn’t get confusing.
Don’t know why this is still in Early Access.
Also, I don’t know if it would please hardcore gamers who can spend 20+ hours a week in it, because there doesen’t seem to have much more to offer than grinding and unlocking stuff, but it’s still fun and satisfying, and you get lots of stuff for the price.

Look, at first i thought this game would be up my ally. After several hours that statement was wrong. It really pisses me off how Bosses are actually untouchable in this game. For some reason if you approach to boss in melee range he then either will smack ground with AOE which is about 5 meters in length or will dump out ground hazards at your spot and hazards do not disappear while boss is alive. Which leads you as player to run around the map and if that was not enough other bosses have sun beam  that spreads across entire map. One boss casting this sun beam is stationary other one is following you wherever you go. It does not matter if there are obstacles or walls in the map these beams go through. You can't even concentrate on single boss because you have to watch if there are creeps that shoot projectiles at you because that happens all the time, cant even stand still for a second when you already get targeted by something you dont even see on your screen because they shoot projectiles across map. Very fking fun devs.

Now, the enemy types in this game look VERY FAMILIAR like very, as if they are copied from other game, i dunno but i think it might be Dota 2.  This is what i noticed. Scorpion channels ability "shakes up ground" that looked very familiar. In dota there is hero called Sand King (scorpion) who has ultimate ability called Epicenter that after 2 second channel damages ground around you.
Next enemy creep - snake that casts poison in straight direction. In dota there is called Venomancer (snake) who has ability called Venomous Gale and also can be cast in straight direction.
Next enemy, this one is boss - I dunno what is this type but to me it looks like steel golem who casts saw in straight direction. In dota there is hero called Timbersaw who has ultimate called Chakram and also does the same thing.
Enemy Boss with sun beam ability. In dota there is hero called Phoenix that has Sun ray and also can cast long beam for a great distance.

Talking about the originality. Bah.

About status effect also sounds very familiar - Hemorrhage that deals X damage over 10 seconds. For every meter that target moves, there is a 40 % chance that the target will take an extra damage. But in dota there is hero called Bloodseeker who has ultimate called Rupture with this effect "Causes an enemy unit's skin to rupture, dealing massive damage. If the unit moves while under the effect of Rupture, it takes a percentage of the distance traveled as damage. The damage is dealt through magic immunity and is not lethal."

This game has been playable (and purchasable) for years, and yet after 19 hours, I STILL ran into a Cloud Sync bug with Steam (no, not a Steam Deck) that has apparently been known about for years. So now I can either stop playing or play and risk losing all my progress. Seeing as I lost my progress once already (very early on) to the same bug, I refuse to do it again after dumping so much time into it.

Until they can adequately fix progress-erasing bugs, your money is better spent elsewhere. It's a lot easier to uninstall it and play something that better respects my time.

Pretty good game however there are some things the devs should fix before releasing it. Firstly would be the material system, in my experience I've always had a bottle neck of materials. I would have tons of gold or rubies but a lack of another material that I needed. They also haven't added a use for legendary materials and I really wish I could trade them for stuff I actually need. Secondly is the skill tree and that it takes to long to complete with small rewards that don't feel as if they contribute much (at least to me) . Once you hit level 20 on any character you unlock their ultimate ability were every so often you can enter this mode. So realistically once you have hit level 70 (for the final weapon) there is no need to play the character, unless you want to grind materials or skill tree points. Another thing is that there is to much grinding, you have to grind curse levels so you can level up your characters quicker and you have to grind the materials for their weapon of that character (which you don't even know what materials you need for the weapon until you can unlock, so now you can't prepare for it) and then the skill tree. The final issue is the music that makes me want to rip my ears of because I've been listen to it for the thousandth time. Please hire a real sound designer. But other than it ends up pretty enjoyable most of the time. PS please make the legendary weapons actually match the characters specialised skill unlike their epic counter parts.
its good

interesting foundation for a vs clone, but it completely falls apart due to really, REALLY bad balancing. if you want a good VSclone that does it right, and IMHO better than VS, then try Army of Ruin or, more recently, Halls of Torment.

the first few hours are ok, but pretty soon the game becomes unplayable due to the clutter on the screen, that's when you find the GFX setting that lets you set a transparency value for the effects, eventually it becomes clear that the only valid setting for the transparency slider is 100%... multicast, attack speed and +1 units, etc will make any value over 100% transparency unplayable, eventually the game is about how many +X casts you get, not even about %s anymore, the game quickly degenerates into a game where the damage output doesn't matter (you cant see it anyway) and the input of damage is an insta gib, you just die if you are touched, so all you do is dash around while everything dies, that's it. you can get to that point by the time you uncover 5% of the talent tree and not even one of the extra weapons... they are all pointless, and the talents are all meaningless, it doesn't matter, just put points and don't bother thinking since all that matters is how may hits you get to proc adding debuffs...


i tried really hard to find any semblance of skill based gameplay (50+hours), but there's none here, just stay away from the bad circles, and hopefully everything dies, after the 10hrs mark of /played every map is the same, you NEVER lose due to a bad play of poor choice, you lose just because  a wave of monsters spawned and your 342095 casts deleted it too fast, so you trigger a force spawn of a wave that kills you due to positioning,  you get a bunch of red circles and... woops, you cant dash all the way out of the bad pools of whatever it is, since all the gfx are set to 100% transparency... so i cant even see.

they recently added more meaningless talents, so yay... more clicking. and the grinding is VERY annoying, 99% of the stuff you unlock is actually worse than you you start with and when its better its maybe the second or third upgrade, spending tens of hours to unlock a max upgrade is a waste of time, they are all bad. and i get it, they cant BE better, because the base game already breaks, you don't need more damage, more casts, and say you do get those "better" kills or stats... whats the point? you cant even see it.

i tried to push my way trough the grinding, but i cant bring myself to do it, its just too boring, and there's zero skill involved, even the randomness is removed since not getting your dream pick of skills is very rare.


Army of Ruin does the VS clone thing way better, because it shows restraint, yes you can (eventually) make some crazy builds, but it remains grounded and death comes due to poor movement, bad CD management, or just pushing you luck to try to force a specific build with rerolls or banishes. Halls of Torment is even better than VS, and it allows for a lot of build theorycrafting and gathering the items to make the build possible is fun and not too frustrating.

Soulstone Survivors is seriously a blast to play. It's got this awesome mix of intense action and strategy that really sets it apart in the world of action roguelites. Playing as a Void Hunter, you're thrown into this epic adventure, battling through waves of enemies and facing off against some seriously tough bosses. What's cool is how the game focuses on leveling up your skills, crafting killer weapons, and unlocking new abilities, adding a real sense of progress to the whole experience.

The combination of RPG elements and roguelite mechanics keeps things fresh every time you play. There's always something new to discover, whether it's upgrading your character's skills, trying out different characters, or tinkering with your gear to get that perfect setup. And let me tell you, every decision you make counts towards becoming an absolute powerhouse.

What I love most is how Soulstone Survivors manages to pack in so much depth without feeling overwhelming. It's a game that's easy to pick up and play, but there's always something to master. Whether you're a seasoned RPG player or just diving into the genre, this game has something for everyone. Plus, the action is non-stop and the progression system keeps you hooked for hours on end. Trust me, Soulstone Survivors is a total game-changer in the world of action RPGs, and it's an absolute must-play for anyone looking for an adventure-packed challenge

The game is a convoluted mess. 
Its a weird amalgamation of different mechanics that aren't balanced. 
The basic gameplay loop is pretty boring with most skills being useless and only a few being good or outright OP. Also theres just too many, like way to many. Each run is very random and its not guaranteed that you get the build you wanted, which wouldn't be a problem if skills were properly balanced. 
The maps are boring and repetitive and theres only 5. Three of them have an extra mechanic which are pretty fucking boring and only ad a boss at the end which is almost impossible if you don't have the right build.
If you are like me and like to 100% games, i can't recommend this game.  The game has 270 achievements, 255 of them you'll get within the first 50-60 hours, the last 15 will take another 50-100 hours atleast. And its just grind to get the characters to max level, which is reduntant at that point because you've already done everything the game has to offer MULTIPLE TIMES.

A game that begins well but quickly becomes a painful slog as the only way the developers seem to know how to make the game more difficult is by littering the ground with red circles that will destroy you in seconds. The developers have acknowledged that this is a terrible system and have claimed to be working on changing things but approaching 6 months without a single meaningful change to the obnoxious amount of projectiles and enemy spawns doesn't fill me with hope. Outside of the general bland difficulty settings, there are very few abilities in the game that feel meaningful or fun to use. Elemental effects are interesting in theory until you realize that your burn proc's are ticking for 400 damage against a boss with 17 Million HP and an ever growing wave of enemies is slowly choking you out.

The game have many class, big skill tree.

Now comes the bad part.
Although have many class, the spells pool are mostly the same. And most of them are useless. Only 3-4 combos are OP. and for buffs and totems, multicast seems useless after you reach 100% of it, which is quite easy to reach.
The skill tree is big but it's just repetitively giving the same stats, only more expensive.
But that's minor comparing what's I'm about to say,
The game raising difficulty by monsters attack more often and hit harder. As the game goes harder or longer, you only get annoyed instead of joy or satisfaction. To a point you have to keep walking and dodge 100% focus, not the fun kind.

Now some details, for the spells, even you are lucky enough to get your perfect combo and passive, it's still almost impossible to beat the 4th cycle. The boss HP jumps like 8 times each cycle. DPS is not much of a problem if you get the perfect combo. The defense is, boss attack will 1 shot you. If invest heavy in defence, you might be able to catch the first hit but hardly the followings, and the DPS is going to be a big problem in this case. Plus lack of healing methods.

I can't recommend this game in good conscience. There are just too many games that do Soulstone Survivor's concept way better. Brotato, Vampire Survivors, 20 Minutes Till Dawn. The problem I have with Soulstone Survivors isn't that it isn't original, it's that it can't really compete against better versions of itself.

When playing Soulstone Survivors, I feel my mind slowly rotting from over stimulation. With games like Brotato, I actually enjoy walking around killing enemies, upgrading my character, meanwhile with this game, it just feels like mindless sludge.

With Soulstone Survivors, it feels like i'm forced to just surrender my brain into being turned into slush just to unlock new characters in hopes to make the game feel somewhat fresh. It can be really difficult to unlock some characters and weapons since they cost so much, which makes you play more, turning your brain into soup.

This is all just my opinion though and I know that many other people love this game and that is fine. It's just not for me.

If I could provide a "Maybe," I would. Due to its price, and the fact that I have put 40 hours into it, I will say it is a "yes."

I've become a big bullet hell player over the last year. Vampire Survivors hooked me on Game Pass. Then, I picked up Halls of Torment here on Steam. I played both games to 100% completion (until new achievements were added).

Soulstone Survivors does not capture the fun those two did. It's alright, as I unlocked each map tier and maxed one toon. However, I can't see myself pushing through with everything else. [b][h1]Soulstone Survivors[/h1][/b]Soulstone Survivors was one of the earliest popular titles in the bullet heaven genre and as of now one of the most polished I have played. I believe the devs were already working on game called Rogue Soulstone and pivoted with the rise of this sub-genre and it took off to the point where they suspended development on the original game to focus on this.

I didn't pick it up until 2023's bullet-heaven fest and even though it's above the general price of games in this genre I think the content that's here is definitely worth the asking price and it goes on sale pretty frequently.

[b][h2]Gameplay[/h2][/b]You start the game with 1 character unlocked but there are currently 14 available in the game with more to come. You select 1 of 5 maps, the only real difference is the placement of obstacles, the majority of the damage I took while playing was down to getting stuck on these. As you play you will unlock higher difficulty modifiers for each map which reward you with extra soulstones and resources.

The enemies here are not your typical "walk into you to damage" as with a lot of other bullet-heavens, all enemies have their own attack patterns. After you defeat a certain number of enemies Lords (Bosses) will spawn, the faster you defeat enemies the lower health the Lords will have. There are only 7 Lords in the game and they can all spawn on any map, I kinda wish each map had their own map-specific bosses with different type weaknesses as that would give more reason to play different maps other than materials.

You have 6 slots to take skills, and there are a lot of skills in the game. One thing I love is that you continue to get offered new skills when you are capped, allowing you to keep switching them out until you finish your build. The only real issue I have with the skills is that everything else feels weak in comparison to the electric ones, to the point where there isn't much reason to experiment, since Lords have more health the longer it takes you to kill the enemies, you want to take stronger skills or you are always fighting an uphill battle.

I really love the use of endless mode in this game, I don't usually as I feel they are kind of pointless, but here you are given the option of boss rush and regular endless. Both of these allow you to farm different materials and are vital in upgrading your skill tree and weapons.

There are 3 types of meta-progression in the game, weapon upgrades, runes and the skill tree. Weapon upgrades are my least favourite as they simple add some positive and negative stats and give you different starting skills that you inevitably replace anyway. Runes are unlockable bonuses and you can have up to 7 equipped. The skill tree is absolutely huge, this allows you to unlock an active ability for every character as well as a tonne of stats, some of these abilities are weaker than others though and I would love to see them buffed.

Regardless of all these positives, there is one big issue that I and a lot of others have had and this progress loss, a game or PC crash will completely wipe the soulstones you have collected in a session as they only upload to steam cloud upon game close, this basically meant I had to restart after every run to ensure I wouldn't lose anything. A simple fix in my opinion would be some form of profile system that automatically saves while playing.

[b][h2]Achievements (256/256)[/h2][/b]The achievements are really easy, if you're good enough it's practically just playing 1-3 matches with each character and upgrading all of their unlockable weapons as well as a few other "beat x on y difficulty" which are trivial if you put a lot of upgrades into one character.

[b][h2]Music/sound[/h2][/b]I think some of the songs in this game are an absolute jam.

[b][h2]Settings/Accessibility/Misc[/h2][/b]There are a tonne of visual settings but I will consolodate my favourites. You can view damaging effects on healthbars, customise crosshair and reduce opacity of skill effects (you cannot see the screen in a long game) so extremely welcome. Completely customisable key binds, mouse control and controller support. A bunch of languages are supported.

[b][h2]TL;DR[/h2][/b]One of the most polished bullet-heavens, with frequent updates and a responsive dev team. Unique gameplay with a fun and useful endless mode. A huge skill tree adding a tonne of replayability. A lot of achievements tied to unlocks but are fairly easy to work through.

UPDATE: so a while passed since my review and my opinion has changed, quite positively actually. Most of the issues I brought up in my review have been or will be fixed. I also highly appreciate the very transparent and humble dev talks. As I see things now, the game is a 8.5/10 maybe even more and it is only getting better. Big ups from me!

So where do I begin, guess I will start with the TL;DR : I wish Steam had a scoring system, this game IMO as of right now is about a 5.5 maybe 6/10 at most, but, even thou you probably have heard this a million times, I actually mean it, it has THE MOST potential out of any survivors like in the genre as it combines elements of ARPGs like Diablo and whatnot with the Survivors elements and they fit VERY well. BUT in the mean time, this game has A LOOOOOOT of problems that hold it back hard.

So lets start with the review:

The Good:
- A lot of characters with a lot of cool abilities.
- Each character has a multitude of weapons that once unlocked give abilities and power ups for the characters, making the sense of PERMANENT progression feel good.
- The Rune system is great even thou it has some issues.
- The skilltree is a bit lackluster but very good idea nonetheless.
- Game looks and feels amazing (when it works).
- The music is great.
- Each character also has 3-4 abilities which you keep unlocking as you level them up, also these abilities are globally unlocked for all the other characters.

The Meh:
- A lot of abilities are copy pasted with just different aliments to them ( for ex. Chaos Bolt, Lighting Bolt, whatever bolt, all look and do the same thing with a bit of a color variation and aliment they inflict). Not a huge problem as the game does have plenty of unique abilities but even so, thought it is worth mentioning.
- Many abilities have the same effects which in certain cases reduces their uniqueness (but not always).
- Most of the ingame level upgrades are pretty much just number increases, nothing very interesting, there are a few more unique upgrades but even those are VERY meh. Not a huge negative as this game has a huge amount of abilities to choose from, so its more of a different mentality compared to other survivor like games but it would be nice to see some cool upgrades that do more than increase this or that.
- Has plenty of maps but as of right now, the way the game works, none really bring anything besides different materials to farm (which as of right now are mostly useless and made for future content). As for the bosses or mobs, all are the same from what I could tell. Still, a nice addition to at least freshen up the playthroughs I guess.

The Bad: (Honestly it has so many issues I will probably miss a lot of them so keep that in mind):
- The balancing is utter garbage 
- Some characters are so clearly better than others its not even funny, for example you have a class like the Assassin which I LOVE in concept but it is absolute trash in high difficulties (ill get to that later) and than you have something like the Chaos Sorcerer class which completely trivializes the game with zero effort.
- Performance even thou its better now, it is still terrible ( and NO I do NOT care you can make your abilities invisible, that is unacceptable and why the fuck would I play it if I cannot even see my cool stuff).
- The way this game scales difficulty with curses is hands down, and I swear I am not exagerating, the WORST I have seen by a mile in any survivor like game. I cannot understand how or who thought it would be a good idea to make difficulty literally mean completely cluttering your screen with non stop area abilities, breaking performance, having a insane amount of enemies swarm you, multiply bosses numbers ( yes you heard that right, even one boss clutters the shit out of the screen, imagine 3-4-5 AT ONCE and they never despawn, so if you do not kill them fast enough, haha, tough luck, the next batch spawns with them, at some point your screen will literally be only bosses and you moving with 1 fps no matter your hardware ), the towers shooting shit are a incredibly dumb idea since this game already has a massive clutter issue so they should be removed asap its a fucking nobrainer, at some point in difficulty you start having a invincible dude following you and pretty much destroying you if he touches you (so imagine the delight when you cant see shit on screen and have 10 fps how fun it is to run from him) and there is much much more but I think you got the idea.
- The variety of builds quickly becomes a novel concept as you start to realise the only viable way to go is pretty much to pick as many aliments as possible in your build as the mobs scale way harder than you in the later part of the run and only aliments scale enough to kill them. So basically with a VERY few exceptions, you will end up with the same build all the time making choices of skills and upgrades pretty irrelevant in high difficulties.
- Some skills are cool in concept but just dont work (like the new random portal, makes you feel like you are using flicker strike from POE, all cool, but also pretty much kills you without fail all the time eventually as it will tp you inside the area of bosses) and some skills simply get so laughably outclassed by others it just makes no sense to get them (for example, anything that DOES NOT scale with aliments, so just pure damage or scaling with armor, hp and whatnot are utterly useless as they will NEVER scale enough to do damage in the late game so they are rendered virtually unusable) and some skills just do not work as in high curse endgame you have to nonstop dash and stay at a distance or ur fucked, so anything close range is pretty much gonna kill you, so again, useless.
- A lot of runes do nothing and will never be used, even thou as I said, it is a cool concept.

Conclusion: As you can probably see I have written a lot more in the negative part, but make no mistake, I do like this game and want it to get better, but there are just so many issues right now that I had do mention at least a few of them. I feel like the developer has in his head a lot of cool concepts and ideas but they just cannot seem to put them in practice at all and I am a bit irritated that instead of fixing the vast amount of severe problems the game has, they keep adding new content that is mostly rendered USELESS as well because of the issues.
I am very lenient on indie games and this is a early project so I will give it the benefit of the doubt and I still think there are enough hours to get in the game to make your money worth (thou that is mostly because of how survivor games work not necessarily the game itself) and for that reason I will give it a positive review, BUT when the game releases, and if it still has these problems, I shall change and update it accordingly.

Thanks.

After jumping into this genre of Survivor games sort of kickstarted by Vampire Survivors I've tried this and Death Must Die.

This game is a lot of fun and I like the depth of systems, builds, and characters available to play. Right now there are quite a few characters in the game already, and I've enjoyed most of the ones I've tried. You can get some pretty cool builds going with stacking damage over time effects, cleaving the hell out of everything, or even running around with a zoo following you. Some of these are stronger than others, but who cares as long as each of them is fun.

There are 5 stages with stacking difficulty levels allowing you to get materials to craft yourself weapons for each of your characters, giving them a few abilities as well. Once each of these abilities are unlocked you can also use them on other characters if you want to do some goofy stuff. I also really enjoy the built in mechanics for most of the characters but some are much clunkier than others. 

The Barbarian for instance simply kills a set amount of enemies and he gets Bloodlusted, increasing his movespeed, armor, and damage by a percent of each of these. The Beastmaster however, can follow a trail of tracks on the ground to potentially summon a pack of raptors to fight for a moment or so. The problem with this though, is at any given time the ground is covered in about a million red indicators that you probably shouldn't walk over unless you want to end your run prematurely. Because of this, it's very easy to get baited into following the tracks as the Beastmaster and end up dying for it, which brings me to my next point...

Visual clarity. You have the option to turn down the opacity on all of your animations on the fly with a hotkey. This is such a good quality of life option. This isn't where my issue lies though. The problem isn't so much SEEING the bad on the ground, it's simply that at a certain point there is so MUCH bad on the ground that you can't actually play the game and spend your time constantly dodging. This isn't that big of a deal against trash mob enemies, but when there are multiple bosses (3 or 4), or even a couple of elites you can't even really get close to them to begin to even damage them because the amount of clutter on the ground simply will not allow you to because as one of the big red circles is disappearing, 2 more are spawning in it's place. 

My suggestion for this, if anyone who works on the game ever happens to read this, is to simply stop allowing as many normal/elite enemies to spawn during boss rounds, or slow down the interval at which they spawn during bosses. This is what Death Must Die does and it makes boss fights feel much more fair. It also doesn't help that as you're fighting bosses (that you can't get next to because of all the bad) you're inadvertently killing more trash, thus spawning EVEN MORE BOSSES, to where you can potentially end up with like 5, 6, 7, or 8 of them on your screen. 

Please for the love of god stop counting the enemies killed accumulation difficulties with 3 or more bosses. This isn't making the game more difficult so much as it's making the game into a slog, and a chore to even get through when you're a few stages into an endless run. The bosses are ALREADY ramping up health, damage, movespeed, AND attack speed (including channeling their abilities within their indicators to the point that you have to react to them very quickly) to the point that they're difficult on their own without 500 smaller enemies cluttering the field.

That rant aside though, the game does have a really good progression tree and a Rune system that's well thought out. The unlock progression for characters does feel good and each of the characters having a cosmetic option (though I'd like to see more) is cool. 

Overall I do enjoy the depth that this game offers and runs are in general pretty fun. Each of the characters brings enough diversity that you can theory craft a lot of different builds and feel rewarded for it. 

Given the current state of the game and it's potential I'd give it an 8/10.

TL;DR: A great take on the survivors style that has some awesome visuals and skills. It will give you something (or lots of things) to grind for and will probably keep you engaged for a while. It has great performance and is fairly priced. I believe their are a few things that could be improved upon such as the "endless" mode, but these things are more my personal preference and i would still highly recommend this game.

 Pros:
1. Great graphics
2. great performance (im on a 3060 with 16 gb ram) i haven't had a crash yet
3. awesome skills that have cool synergies
4. an expansive skill tree to unlock perma buffs
5. characters have unique skills they can unlock later on that offer a new way to play that character (such as an enraged mechanic or the ability to summon trebuchets)
6. a fun and engaging grind (this could be considered a con i suppose but as someone who enjoys fun achievement/ level grinds, this game offers both)
7. lots of debuffs and dots that can be inflicted on every enemy (including bosses)
8. a good but small soundtrack
9. you can increase/ decrease the visibility of your skills with the d-pad on controller
10. a small and seemingly committed dev team to support

Cons:
1. Their are only 5 maps to play on (as of now)
2. The game lacks a true endless mode like vampire survivors (their is an endless mode that scales the enemies dramatically. so while you spend the first 10-15 minutes getting op, you really only get another 15-20 minutes of enjoying your op-ness until your going to get one shot or the bosses become too tanky to justify continuing.)
3. you only get a handfull of banishes while the skills in the skill pool are continually increasing. 
4. armor power and block power seem pretty weak due to the scaling. (ive tested armor/block power quite a bit and I have better matches when i just focus on my offensive skills and increasing my health here and there.)
too easy. fun, but i don't see it getting any more difficult or interesting.

Awesome survivor game overall. 

The controls, mechanics, animations, and sound are extremely well polished now as of 2024. Game plays very smooth for the most part. Depending on your skill choices, the enemies on screen, and your graphics setting, you might hit some frame drops when it gets really crazy. I haven't had any crashes or severe performance issues since the initial months of release. 

Also as of 2024, this game is now arguably the most in-depth survivor game on the market. The only real competitor to this is the actual original Vampire Survivors. Soulstone has a good roster of characters each with their own different weapon choices(that must be crafted with special materials). There is also a large collection of skills that only some classes have access to unless you use a special rune to unlock all of them. Which brings me to the runes. While they are a little bit lacking in my opinion, the rune system does add an extra layer of depth to the game play. You can load a set of runes that change how your character performs or how skills are distributed during the match. The most recent addition was the overhaul to the class skill trees. While the skill tree doesn't provide game breaking talents or anything, it is yet again another extra layer of depth. You have to really work to get through all of the skill trees to unlock the special alternate outfit for each class as well. All of this provides you with incentives to grind the endgame so that each match has a sense of purpose. 

The core of this game is now set after the much more rustic early access version.

So what are the cons?

- Red circles galore. Enemies and towers will constantly launch aerial projectiles at you which are indicated by a red circle on the ground. On the higher difficulties, you pretty much spend 99% of the time dodging red circles unless you're just wiping out the entire screen before anything can attack. This makes boss fights extremely frustrating especially if your playing with the curses that summon multiple bosses at a time. Melee classes need to invest heavily into movement speed and adding area to their attacks to extend it's reach or you will never be able to get close enough and stay in range long enough to make a dent on the boss. So yes, I spend the majority of the time just circling a boss(or bosses) dodging red circles and just praying my damage will eventually wear them down. The developers have acknowledged that this is among their top player complaints that they would like to change so there is reason to be optimistic for a change. 

- Environmental collision. This one irks me a lot because it is somehow responsible for more than half of my deaths. The dash in this game is very good...almost too good that if you accidentally dash into a wall, tree, or even worse...some kind of enclosed corner, it takes a while to recover from this. You will essentially be vulnerable during this time. Remember the red circles? If you collide with the environment during a dash while red circles are chasing you, it's almost certain death depending on the level of difficulty you're on. At the very least, we should be able to dash through trees (the worse offenders). This of course can all be avoided by simply getting good and just having absolute awareness of your surroundings. It's just that sometimes in the middle of all the chaos on screen, you will accidentally dash into a tree and that could be your death.

- Defensive traits. While the offensive stats and traits are excellent in this game, I feel that the defensive side is sorely lacking. You can invest heavily into armor, blocking, and HP but you will still very likely get 1-2 shotted against bosses and elite champions beyond the first level (if you are climbing infinite portals). There are a couple of niche defensive skills like the fire shield that seems pretty worthless unless you devote a dozen level up upgrades to it during the course of a run and even then, it's still lackluster.

Recommended? Yes. This is now a well polished product with tons of content and depth to unlock/explore. Only when you start to really dig into the endgame will you find some annoying flaws.

This game does nothing better than the other superior games in the genre. It is grindy in a nonrewarding manner, repetitive, boring, and has an uninspiring generic graphical style. Let's compare it to the other games in this genre:

*Where as Vampire Survivors makes you look forward to each increase in power you can buy with gold and you feel yourself getting stronger over time, this game instead will barely make you notice them and have you start off the game so powerful that the tiny increases you grind HOURS for feel worthless. 

*Death Must Die makes each run exciting with its powerful items that can drop and random shrines you can find, where as this game will make you dread pressing the "play" button because each run is exactly the same.

*Unlike this game, Halls of Torment makes its grindyness feel worth it by making achievements actually require different builds and strategy that vary in difficulty, which I look forward to with each update they release that brings a new challenge. 

*HoloCure has a similar large roster of characters, but their characters actually changes how you play each game slightly. This game will have you ignore most characters specialities, because they often require you to stand idle or make bad movements, which is an awful design in a game where the ground is littered in red circles that will 2-3 shot you and go off nearly instantly in late game, even if you go full defensive cards. The biggest change you will notice is by playing the death knight, which removes your dash, making the end game strategy of spamming dashes impossible.

Please just play any of the above instead, or try some of the following: Keeper's Toll, 20 Minutes Till Dawn, hell even low quality coomer games such as Beautiful Mystic Survivors, Kagura Survivors: Endless Night or Wedding Witch is a better experience than this game.

The game bascially REQUIRES you to disable all your spell animations because it is so awfully designed that they end up filling your entire screen, making it impossible to see anything that's happening and will strain your eyes incredibly with prolonged sessions.

The game has hundreds of interruptions because you reach levels in the 100's each run and each time you level up, your choices boils down to "pick highest rarity card" which gives a boring stat increase, unless its one of the few impactful cards such as +dashes and movement speed. Theres a reason other games autopick this stuff for you once you have established your build...

There was 0 challenge in my entire 95 hours playing this. Or let me rephrase that: the only challenge this game offers is trying not to get 1-4 shotted while you get distracted by the content on your second monitor, as you try to kill the boredom of playing this game.

Pros:
- Lots of different characters with different gameplay identities, some considerably more challenging than others.
- Different spell paths letting you play in different ways depending on the upgrades you choose.

Cons:
- The runes system means you go into each run with a specific build in mind, limiting the freedom of choice within the run itself.
- Very grindy. Each character has several different weapons where you have to famr materials in specific maps, and very extensive skill trees where you need lots of playtime to finish each tree.
- Somewhat samey. There is a very shallow pool of boss mobs, and you play around each boss much in the same way.
Uh, Twig Sigmund here. Just callin' to inform ya that, uh, your refrigerator's been runnin' wild over here for the past 45-90 minutes. Better head on over and catch it, big fella.

[h1] Soulstone Survivors [/h1] 

A great fantasy roguelite with a vast array of characters, skills, and spells to learn and try with each of your runs. Master your build and cheese every level to grind out resources as you slay your enemies over, and over, and over again. This game, though cartoony, looks great. The soundtrack is incredible, and the game-play itself is tight and easy to learn and master using a x-box controller. Soulstone Survivors has a unique way of hooking you in almost instantly. I was certainly no exception to this, and twenty-seven hours were gone in a flash. In those twenty-seven hours, I had an absolute blast, but just as quickly as I was hooked, I found myself burnt out and ready to move on. Regardless, for an early access title, the time spent was absolutely well worth it.

How ever, I couldn't help but feel that there were a few things lacking. The game, like most roguelites, is highly repetitive and becomes more and more grindy the closer to end-game you get. That's to be expected, but a little more variety wouldn't go amiss. The Curses feature adds an extra challenge to your run, but you'll find yourself fighting the same mobs and bosses, listening to the same soundtrack, running the same build, while moving in the same circular pattern, all for that next upgrade. I deeply enjoyed experimenting with the various classes you could unlock with new builds here and there, but I had wished that there were more than a small handful of boss fights to learn. Additionally, this game would benefit greatly with a co-op feature. I would have loved to play this game with a friend.

Do take the above paragraph with a grain of salt. This game is in early access, and thus, not yet complete. On a positive note, the developers and community managers are active in engaging with the player base. They have released roadmaps and the game has received updates since its released, with more still to come. With that said, Soulstone Survivors has had a great start, and the potential to be something great when given enough time in the oven to cook. Do give this game a try, it is absolutely worth the $10 dollars.
Love this game. Plus the publisher is make consistence updates with new features.

This game needs a lot of rebalancing work. At the start its fun but the further you go it just burns you out. All champions feel more or less the same except they have different starter abilities - which you can circumvent with "Runes". There is no real interesting combination strategy with your abilities because the buffs and debuffs they require also can be randomly applied by any spell (yes, cauterize spells can apply poison). The best build ends up using a rune that allows you to stack similar abilities and just fill your bar up with 6x Whirlwind...

The difficulty scale is also very short in which the game becomes impossible after ~5 cycles of extending a run. But you havent earned any real amount of currency for your talent tree upgrades AT ALL with that gameplay. I've been trying to maximize the income of the main BASIC currency of the game (which for some reason requires you to play on a very low difficulty rather than a high difficulty you'd expect!) and still when I get back to the menu to spend the BASIC currency I end up only buying 3 or 4 talents.... There are thousands of them! Seriously, BUFF minor soulstones! Meanwhile I got all the other materials overflowing, so the discrepancy is enormous...

Also, for a game about dodging hit indicators, its a real shame that most of the boss hit indicators dont even match the hitbox of their attacks... Pretty frustrating experience all in all.

Luckily theres one good thing about this game; the soundtrack is an absolute BOP!

After playing it for quite a long time, I feel I have to finally give this game a thumbs down.
The endgame is just not very fun.  It's very repetitive.

Every run with every character feels pretty much the same.  I could go for a bleed build or a poison build or a summoning build or an all fire build.  They all feel pretty much the same in the end.  I am picking the same generic passives on level up for every build.  The ones that are good are good for every build; and the ones that are bad are bad for every build.

What makes matters worse is that I can't even see what I'm doing.  I have to turn off my ability graphics so I can see the 1000 enemy AOE attacks that are being fired at me every moment.  I could be shooting fire or swinging an axe or spitting poison - I can't actually see it and they all do the same thing after a while anyways.

I don't see this changing any time soon, either.  It seems like most new content is just adding new weapons for the classes.  This lets classes branch out into other builds, but since all builds feel the same anyways, it doesn't really matter much.  It just changes which active skills you plan to take before ending up in the exact same gameplay.

So overall... I can't recommend this game.  There are so many others in this genre, and most of the others I have played are simply more engaging and more fun.

This is, by far, the best of the Vampire Survivors-likes I've played. I actually played this game before Vampire Survivors, but as an introduction to the genre of games it really sold the idea and concept well. The first time I started the game I was a bit bemused, "Oh, this is a game in the modern age people enjoy? How quaint."

Versus hours and hours later when I'm trying (and failing) to complete the entirety of the game have I finally realized the appeal.

The game loop is straightforward, the difficulty scales well, and the customization of your character feels enjoyable. I won't argue that all the abilities are equally balanced, or even all the characters are - I don't think that to be the case. But I will say that I found enjoyment from the differences between each character choice.

Overall, I'd say this game was worth the price point I purchased it at, and I certainly gained enjoyment from it.

One of the most polished of the survivors-likes with a huge amount of content, specifically abilities and meta progression.

The harder difficulties (or ascension levels if we can call it that) tends to make it less fun though, with most of the difficulty increases causing more and more ground aoes to the ridiculous point where you are just mashing dodge and running around as fast as you can. I personally think it makes the game too chaotic rather than hard or fun and I tended to enjoy the early progression over the later. You can play without those ascension options but you cannot progress any more unlocks without the crafting materials from it unfortunately. In addition defensive options and stats are basically worthless.

Nice game with good ideas but many things to improve.

What I liked :
- the ability to go on with all your progress for another run (or more if you choose to) at the end. This is really fun, being able to get even stronger and get a spell to max aoe to hit almost all the map with it at the same moment.
- skill tree. Nothing more to say, I just like big skill trees and completing them.
- weapons crafting and runes

What could use a rework :
- you can basically put your brain on pause while playing. You just need to run in circles while aiming with your mouse, and that's it. It would be more intersting if there were less spells and really unique ones, and if they were not cast automatically.
- too many upgrades for the same purpose. You can upgrade cast speed and mutli-cast, damage in general and damage for each spell, aoe in general and aoe for each spell... 
- you can be fast, strong, resistant, apply several effects and get high hp at the same time. Nothing really pushes you to choose one type of upgrade or another.
- aside from spells, heroes are not really unique. You get to unlock a special ability for each hero in the skill tree but it's just another way to deal more damage. The way you use spells even turns barbarian, swordmen, etc into ranged fighters. Which makes being high hp and stacking armor points kind of useless. 
- same problem with maps, they only bring different materials to farm, but enemies are basically the same, they just have a different skin. Bosses are the same too.

I still recommend it for those who have some time to kill, one run lasts less than 15 minutes, just don't expect strategy and having to optimise your build. It's a good one overall.
I hope they will try to make character building system trickier and add more "non-damage upgrade" ways to get stronger.

Cheap but cheapo. Not much in terms of diversity, you play the same game 10000 times, it's not vampire survivors. It's mindless and the grind is incredibly high with little payoff. The developers failed to understand what makes games like this fun. Its the sense of progression, you don't just make me grind for 5 weeks, you give me more game play to unlock as I play. You give me valuable stuff to unlock not just another color of the same spell or whatever useless talent that adds 1% more crit or whatever. In Vampire survivors you unlock stuff constantly, stuff that changes your gameplay, that changes the stages, yes there is some grind too but nah this game simply doesn't capture the feeling that led people to these sort of games. I like this game, but the high curse gameplay has an area of effect (AOE) problem. There are AOEs for enemies you kill, and many enemies have AOEs of their own. Bosses have huge AOEs, and many of those ignore walls. Additionally, some of these bosses have AOEs that persist on the ground for far too long. There is an invincible enemy that always goes after you, and if it gets too close, it triggers an AOE. If you want your players to be on the move, you should reward them when they do so and not punish them if they don't. You've already added something that rewards players for moving; most characters have a skill that gives them some kind of buff or other advantages. That's a great way to motivate players to move. Expand on that or add more systems like that.

I really do like this game, but it is very frustrating in many areas.
I'm gonna start off with the good stuff though.
The music works pretty well for the most part, being pretty catchy and fitting the gameplay very well.
Another thing is the characters that you can play as, being pretty well designed and creative, with a lot of awesome skills, weapons, and trees.
However, while there is a lot of creativity in the characters, it is very obvious that the focus was put on to them and practically nothing else.
The levels have no uniqueness to them other than how they look and some of their wall placements, so there is no reason to pick one over another. You would think that the reason to do so would be the enemies, but the enemies for each area are barely unique at all as the reasons for why they are unique(if there is any, I'm just assuming they have some differences but I genuinely can't tell) make the smallest of differences. And whats even worse is that unlike most games, there aren't any unique bosses to each area, and it is the same 7 cycled through randomly, which removes even more reason for you to have preferences of map. Having some sort of creativity in the boss design and enemy design would go a long way in fleshing out this game.
While I do have problems with these, they alone wouldn't ruin the experience in any way, I mean my review is recommending the game. There is enough variety with what character you play and what weapon and runes you pick. It would just be nice if they were improved to make the game that much better.
The biggest problem lies with the difficulty curve. The game starts off pretty fine and does a good job of laying out the mechanics to newer players well without making it feel overwhelming, and for a while the curses do a good job of making the game more difficult in interesting ways. However, once you get to Curse Level IV, you realize that the developers stopped figuring out creative ways of adding difficulty and just started throwing more stuff on the screen for the sake of it. You notice it at IV, but its not too bad because the concept of 3 bosses is still sort of interesting. But Level V and Level VI don't have anything interesting going on and it makes me wonder why they even bothered with going past IV.

Final Conclusion:
The game is pretty solid with a lot of fun, but the longer you play the game the more you notice it's problems, and I feel that instead of adding more classes, skins, and weapons, they should focus on trying to add more uniqueness to the enemies, bosses, levels, and curses.

I just can't recommend this game in the current state that it is in. It plays fine, and the concept is absolutely amazing and fresh! However the grind is insufferable in this game, and I am saying this as someone that genuinely likes to grind in games.

To give a better look into what I mean; This game has a lot of different characters, which is genuinely nice as they do feel like they play different due to their abilities and starter attacks. This on itself, mixed with the 'rune' system is genuinely a lot of fun! The problem comes in when you realize EVERY CHARACTER NEEDS TO BE LEVELED SEPARATELY, AND EVERY CHARACTER HAS A DIFFERENT SKILL TREE YOU HAVE TO BUY SKILLS FOR!
At first I really liked the idea, but quickly it just dawned on me how every separate grind just felt horrid and unfun. New character? XP/Money/Resources won't be gained quick enough. Focusing on a single of the 3 requirements? Feels like wasting time due to dividing the work. Grinding Money/Resources with a leveled and strong character? MASSIVE waste for the XP that goes absolutely nowhere.

I really hope to see some massive re-balance before the full release of this game, as this is just an absolute joke... Allowing for more cross-progression between classes, and evening out the xp/money/resource gain would go a long way, or maybe just a bigger damage/survivability increase for lower level classes to not have the game feel like it kicks you in the nuts every time you play a unleveled/low level class would be HUGE.

Will keep my eye on this game some more, but man does this game just feel horrid after the praise I heard for it...

I just brought and played this game for 9 hours straight.

Slow to start, but easily the best "survivors" type game I've played.

There's a good many characters, each with different play styles from bow archer to heavy armor and healing paladins to minion spawning necromancers and elemental mages. Each character can level up with gameplay and forge 3 additional weapons with different abilities and play styles for that character. Think your fire casting mage now does aoe damage around them, for example. 

There is also a "runes" (character enhancement) system that allows collecting materials in games (smashing rocks of minerals, primarily) which are spent out of game to enhance individual character stats or global stats for all characters. Each character has 20+ enhancements to unlock after unlocking all global ones first and some of them heavily change the way you play by fleshing out that class better. 

BUT - the game has really slow progression early on and a few of the materials you need to craft better weapons are way less abundant than they should be. It often takes several runs on a specific map to collect enough of a resource and you will likely have to target maps for a couple runs to have enough for a new weapon (of the 3 craftable per character, so often enough it becomes a chore). 

I find the offering at this price to be well worth the purchase and easily recommend it as one of the best in the "survivors" genre.

It’s so satisfying once it gets going. The first exposure to the game is a bit overwhelming with all the different screens (characters, crafting, runes, skill trees, etc). The first game is slow as you bonk each creature with your weapon. However once you get going and start being able to unlock part of the skill tree and more characters, progress through the maps, and add more curses to raise the difficulty - it’s a blast to play. The gameplay loop is satisfying. Being able to see how far I can progress, earn resources, and then being able to invest those into making my characters stronger or reaching milestones to unlock more things is something that I enjoy doing. Each run has felt substantial.

Once you clear a map you can increase the difficulty by enabling curses. Each level of the map provides more curses and more bonuses. When you clear a map of it’s Lords you can keep going “deeper”, making it harder, requiring more Lords to kill. So far I’ve been able to get to 25 Lords, where 5 will spawn at a time. It gets so intense when there number of creatures have already been killed that new Lords are spawning as soon as the existing ones were killed. I love it!

One important tip, once you start getting to the point of multiple Lords you will want to go into the graphics setting to make your attacks more transparent so you can see where the enemy attacks are going to land. Otherwise it’s going to get difficult to see everything.

The game runs amazing on the Steam Deck!

If you like Vampire Survivors and Death must Die, I would highly recommend this game!

Much like the other games, you have multiple characters to choose from such as a barbarian (starting character), Pyromancer, Legionnaire, Chaoswalker, Assassin, and Beast Master to name a few. Each class comes with a different set of abilities that are available to them at the start.

There are a total of five stages that you can choose from. You pick a stage to start with and once you clear the that stage by slaying all the Lords (bosses), you are able to advance to another round. You can choose from two different modes by beating the first stage; Overlord (red portal) and what I call the Infinite mode (purple portal). The Overlord portal increases the number of bosses to correspond with the level of the dungeon you are on. Example: Stage 2 yields two bosses per spawn, stage 3 spawns 3 bosses at a time and so on. Upon every completion of the first stage you unlock curses which add new features to the dungeon.

You are also able to craft gear (only weapons) with the materials that drop from the stages via the ores that randomly spawn on the stage. Each weapon comes with a different starting skill and all, but the starting weapon, has a special skill that can also be unlocked.

You have skill points that can be used to increase stats and gain extra abilities and buffs. You also get to use the Rune system and skill system that gives you, yet, more buffs and features that you can mix and match with the class you choose to fight with.

There are a few cons, the biggest one (in my opinion) is the amount of visual clutter from all the abilities. There's also the fact of the five stages get stale as you get into longer and longer times of surviving. The materials that you can get per map seem minuscule as you get into the 3rd and 4th weapons of each character. You spend more time running around the map, killing the little mobs and slowly whittling the bosses down to stay on the stage to gather materials. You can also get stuck on environmental assets like the trees and stones. Just watch where you are running and dashing to!

Overall I would give this game an A+. With only 21 hours at the time of this writing, I can say I still get excited to open the game, pick a character to level and have at it!

Among the more in-depth and mechanically complex Bullet Heaven titles I have played, Soulstone Survivors is fast, hectic and visually intense- to the point where there are keyboard shorts to increase or decrease the intensity of on-screen spell effects.

This is largely due to the heavy use of telegraphed enemy attacks that do high damage, especially from elite enemies and bosses. Unlike Vampire Survivors or Army of Ruin, it isn't really possible to stand still and simply annihilate everything before it gets to you, at least not that I've seen. Movement speed and deft use of dodge charges are required to stay alive in SS, though some characters can tank damage a little better then others- The Paladin and the Legionnaire are two examples. There can get to be a crazy amount of enemy telegraphs on screen, especially when playing on increased difficulties.

SS has a large amount of playable characters (14 so far, with apparently more to come) and build options, including more different damage types and debuffs then I think I've seen in any game, and a large circular skill tree that greatly expands once you've purchases all of the initial center nodes and reach level 20 with characters. Characters also have individual experience levels that unlock new starting weapons and additional active skills. Characters are limited to specific types of skills they can use initially, and some characters have pretty big boosts or penalties to certain stats- the oddest one by far is the Death Knight, who starts with a huge movement speed bonus and immunity to stuns, but cannot dodge, totally changing how he is played compared to the rest of the cast.

On top of that, there is a system of perks, called "runes" here, that you can use to further boost or specialize your setup, though you must first unlock "runic power" to be able to use them. 5 Runic Power points are obtained from the skill tree, while the other 5 are tied to achievements, for 10 total. Among other things, you can increase your dash distance or chance to multi-cast (i.e., have a skill fire more once per activiation) or add up to 5 skills from a given type your character would not normally have show up in their upgrade pool.

SS stands out in a genre that quickly exploded in popularity after the success of Vampire Survivors. I've played a number of these games at this point, including the mobile game Magic Survival that inspired them, and I would put this one on par with my other favorites, namely Army of Ruin and Star Survivor. Be aware however that it is unusually demanding of hardware for the genre, and you shouldn't feel bad if you have to turn down the graphics settings for it to run properly.

A fun game let down by it's balance and mechanics.

While the first 10-25 hours of this game is fun; once you progress far enough you realize the danger of the enemies is primarily area effect damage. The game clearly shows these areas in red circles and your main survival tactic is avoiding these red circles.

The problem however; the bosses spawn these so fast and in such an extreme amount that the only viable build on the highest levels is indirect damage builds. The bosses don't move fast, creating a dead zone around is. So usually you want animals, critters, minions, pets or other such effects work for you. Those builds are fun; and actually extremely powerfull to grind at the hardest difficulties.

But there it ends; any short-range build is simply not viable at the harder difficulties. I tried maxing damage output to kill bosses as fast as possible, but those builds are just too vulnerable and the area-damage spam of bosses and the many enemies become impossible to avoid once 5 bosses spawn at once. You must always run and avoid the killzone.

The viability difference between the various builds is just too large; making it feel pointless to try and experiment with other builds. A couple of spells work; the majority doesn't at the highest difficulties.
This is a really fun game with immense potential I Hope they keep adding more characters, more skills and maps and this game will go a long way. Great Job by the developers.

If you like this genre of game, you'll enjoy this. Serious balancing issues, though. A lot of the upgrades are completely useless. Just about all of the builds that rely on status effects like Burn, Bleed, or Poison are pointless and unusable for end game content; all of the damage over time debuffs do so little damage as to be laughable. Enemies quickly scale up to over 100k health, but almost all DoTs only do a couple hundred per tick. Armor and Blocking are also a waste; if 100 Blocking gives me less than 10% chance, the offer to waste a level up on 4 more is frustrating. Elites and Bosses basically one-shot you in the harder modes, making Armor buffs pointless. This game is good, but it could be so much better with a little more balancing.

There is some depths to it for sure, especially with all the runes you unlock through progressing the class-specific skill trees. Many of the runes are a little simplistic and just grant extra damage, but theres also a few interesting ones that you can build around. There is a lot of time to be sunk into this, since it takes time to progress the skill trees. Only issue that as of now, there is little variety in terms of gameplay. You basically just farm materials, try to get your skilltree up, craft the weapon and unlock everything, so this can get a bit grindy/repetitive. Really hoping for new modes/ways to play the game in the future, but again, considering the price, you really can't complain – theres a lot of content to play around with.

Fantastic game! Like many others, I came here from VS, because [i]a VS party don't stop[/i]! Out of the [i]tons[/i] of VS-like games, SS stands out for sure.

At first I was a little put off by the difference in graphics, after all that pixel graphics formula is just what the doctor ordered in VS. But the different style quickly grew on me, especially once I figured out the game's particularities. Now I like both for what they are, this game's graphics work great [i]here[/i], and I hugely enjoy the pixel graphics in VS when I'm spending time [i]there[/i].

There is a learning curve, I wouldn't say very steep, but if you don't come to it after playing a bunch of other VS games, you may be somewhat confused. Even I was a bit unclear on how to progress at times. Hopefully the dev team adds in a mini tutorial for some of the basics. Right now, it is an EA title, and I'm expecting a lot more to come.

I didn't expect to be mentioning the dev team here, but it's definitely an added bonus to see the team and see how enthusiastic they are about making this game. They seem very dedicated, which is always a great sign. I enjoy being part of something like this — there are many games out there, and picking the ones you give your [limited] time to, in addition to $, needs to be carefully weighed ;)

I enjoyed the game overall but leaving a negative review because I want these fixed before I can recommend this to others.

The game has some build diversity, but because of poor optimization you do have to turn the settings down to minimum, so visually, it looks like you are playing the same build. 

There are also some balancing issues. There are alot of status effects, but many are undertuned.

Also, this is saying alot, but it has visual clutter worse than path of exile. You can't see a thing unless you turn down visibility to bare minimum, which takes away the enjoyment of the game.

Lastly, the game offscreens you alot. This is the thing that takes me out of the game completely. Bosses have too many AOE attacks that shoots you across the map it makes the experience really a slog. And bosses leave too many effects on ground that last WAY too long. And they just keep building up. Even if you kill the bosses they are still on the ground.
If you like Vampire Survivors, Hades, ARPG's, and/or Roguelikes at beyond reasonable prices, this is an easy recommend.

Like Vampire Survivors on steroids
Lots of things to unlock and endless hours of bullet-hell fun!

SPOILER ALERT:

Likes - How i could just get the action i wanted from the get-go and also receive game changing power-ups.  How there is a Hero tree that allows you to strengthen your hero for the next fight so you don't always feel like you are starting from square 1, allowing you to achieve higher feats as well. How there are so many heroes to play and so many playstyles even in this games early stage. How you could ADJUST the effects on your screen with a slider in the settings or keys on your keyboard to increase or decrease the visibility of it (I think that's a huge quality of life option which should exist in every game). How every hero has a build behind them, in-game power-ups alone are not enough to make you unstoppable, it requires some theorycrafting (Weapons, runes, character tree) to make yourself almost Godly, so every character can be overpowered in their own way. NOT PAY TO WIN. 

Dislikes - How you cannot see what materials you need to gather prior to unlocking a new weapon to craft (I know it's a game intention but i kinda don't like that the more i play the game xD).  Not too many maps but i know more will be coming soon. There are only 2 gamemodes on top of starting a fresh fight, but of course, as was mentioned in a video a developer made, there will be more gamemodes to come. Game doesn't reward with anything other than currency and materials, i honestly would love it if items dropped, even if they were rare.  Character visual customisation would need more attention, because there is only a default skin and an armoured skin for every character, not talking about the weapons cuz that's the only thing that we have for decent customisation.

Mention -  I don't know if the game is supposed to be solo only, but i just feel the need to have some sort of playerbase presence like leaderboards or maybe co-op gameplay of hard stages or something, but i guess it's fine the way it is.

Conclusion: Absolutely recommend this to y'all magic freaks out there, because it's got LOADS of visuals and cool eye candy. Power-ups that give you a slight dopamine rush everytime you see them. It's still in its' early stage but still has a lot of gameplay mechanics to pick from that just keeps dragging you in for more and more rounds, in other words, addicting. Despite all of what i said in my Dislikes, it's totally playable and they nailed the genre, probably the best of its' kind out there. This is a promising game.

Soulstone Survivors is geniunely one of the better vampire survivor esque titles, it has decent artstyle, crafting system sounds cool on paper as does the skill tree. However, the execution of some things is geniunely bad.
- There's always a point where game becomes unplayable due to amount of particles and effects on the screen, this grinds the fps to a halt even on lowest settings possible (my specs before someone calls out Potato PC: i5-12400, RTX 3060, 32 GB of ram)
- The skill trees lack any meaningful variety. They are boring and uninspired, and don't justify the repetitive grind behind them.
- There should be more character skills for to correlate the weapons. The pyromancer's character skill is worse instantly the moment you pick staff 3 or especially 4.
- Higher difficulties boil down to running around in circles, kiting enemies and very later on praying you don't get stuck on something you couldn't see due to shit on a screen (which you can't exactly turn off, you can turn off only your effects). Also the enemies instead of getting harder patterns or something along those lines, only become damage sponges. Any ways of melting through them get nerfed every so often.
- Polish translation is awful. The grammar is off quite often and the way some things are phrased, despite being grammatically correct, give away that they were machine translated.

With experience of Vampire Survivors, 20 Minutes till dawn, Hades and Death must die, here goes my review for this game:

TL;DR: Visually beautiful game, which doesn't offer a great challenge.

PROS:
- Visually beautiful, colorful 3D game
- Large skill tree
- Many different characters
- Large variety of powers and upgrades
- Weapon crafting system (not far enough in the game yet to give deeper analysis of it, but it does exist)
- Different game modes and difficulty modifiers (once again, 2 and half hours in, not very far in this game)

CONS:
- Rather than having challenge like the games I stated above, this game might feel grindy for those with experience of Vampire survivors/20MTD/Death Must Die. While it isn't just a walk through simulator, because of the skill tree, every run is easier than the one before it. I'm not saying it's grindy in the most frustrating way, but it doesn't have same challenge as previously stated games, not with my experience at least

A bit of a grind, but it's a fun time. Lots of abilities and mechanical interactions to explore, and it *can* be demanding, or it can be a relaxing, fun time. Once I got over the initial hump of resources, the game has been a fun little escapade that plays a lot like a modern late-game ARPG.

A fun survivors-like game that asks the player for more active engagement, with manual aim (can be changed to auto) and a dash mechanic. The controls are snappy and responsive. Enemy attacks are well telegraphed. The graphics are stylish, and the game runs flawlessly on Steam Deck even during chaotic endless runs.
