This game is absolutely genius. From the differences in each champions abilities, to the intelligence of the abilities and how each one compliments each other, to the way it rewards you for a good build -- this is how a bullet hell game should be played. It doesn't feel early access at all, with progression and leveling being well-thought-out. 

I particularly like the twin stick implementation into the bullet hell formula, it feels so natural! After playing this game and then going back to some other similar games I missed being able to aim my onslaught at the horde. Another awesome aspect are the unlimited and Overlord modes. Being able to hold onto your hard-won abilities for another run is genius, and something I wish more bullet-hell/roguelike games did. 

Hats off to the developers for making a game which is just as addictive as Vampire Survivors, and different enough to breathe fresh air into the genre. Major thumbs up here, check it out -- especially at the price of 7.49 (at time of writing) - it's a steal!

I was looking for auto shooter games with higher fidelity graphics while waiting for DRG:S to come out and this hits the spot very well. I am turned off by retro/pixel graphics so I was excited to see one like this that has a bit more of a modern feel to it.

As you can tell by my play time, I absolutely love this game. 

Cons:
- If you're one of those people that likes to unlock everything, be warned that it's super grindy. 
- The current gameplay style is super repetitive: It's basically a dodging simulator.
- There are tons of different viable builds, but they are so similar in play style that it feels like there are really only two or three different builds.

Pros:
- The biggest pro about this game is the developers. They are very communicative and transparent with the player base, and they actively address issues and make changes that the players want. This is always a mega-win in my book, which is why I continually come back to the game. I will 100% support developers like this.
- Speaking of the devs being super transparent with the player base, they mentioned that they also don't like that the game is a "dodging simulator" right now, and they plan to make huge changes to the gameplay to fix that. Once that update comes along, I'll update my review.
- Tons of skills to play around with.
- All 14 classes are viable, with none of them overpowering the others.

TLDR:
The game is a lot of fun, but it's very grindy and is a "dodging simulator". The developers are the best part of the game. They are very transparent and plan to change the game play so that it isn't a "dodging simulator".

good, up until a point.

Eventually enemy bosses aoe nuke so much that you can't do anything else than to run large circles around them. This however can "trap" the bosses to the center of the map, which depending on the level may have walls for them. 

You can't shoot through the cublcle walls, but the bosses sure can. So, that's "nice".

This also means most thrash mobs are going to get stuck in the same walled box, which in turn means that all the damage you manage to sneak in there, will kill vast majority of the mobs there, so that's also where all the exp drops. And you can't collect that exp due the AOE spam, which would kill player character basically instantly.

The game is fun and varied, but devolves HARD into single gameplay method, which is the running laps around bosses and hoping to not get caught in their AOE spam.

Seems like summon spamming for the player helps quite a bit, but that means all other classes than necromancer (or similar) are fairly useless, but you need to level them up anyway to get bonuses...

I want to give this a recommendation, but can't. Not with the "end game" it currently has.

edit: roughly 40 hours later, player power seems to have risen (or gidgud phase achived). Gettung better, but issues mentioned above are still real for the most part. Pets not strictly a requirement tho. Careful balance of single target and aoe skills are enough. But game is still very repetive, I'm just grinding for the new cosmetics  :P

A Vampire Survivors type game, where you run around and kill monsters, get xp, pick upgrades, and then die and use resources you collected to permanently upgrade your characters.

I heard it called "red circle simulator" (for the damage regions of upcoming attacks that enemies broadcast) and it really is. Run around and avoid the red circles. Enemies produce them constantly in prodigious amounts, and often they are quite large. Sometimes they are only semi circles or "paths" to add variety. But mostly circles. They define where and how you move, which can makes the game quite dull and repetitious, and will necessitate you to get some speed increase power-ups so you can run out of the circles in time.

Also the default magnetic region for xp crystals seems too small, and there is very poor feedback when you take damage (little in terms of video and audio cues). There isn't even a death sound really. The game just suddenly stops with a "you died" summary screen.

I'd recommend you play Vampire Survivors, Halls of Torment, Nordic Ashes, Spirit Hunters: Infinite Horde, or Scarlet Tower.

This is pretty good. If you like (Vampire) Survivors-style games, this one is worth a try. The characters are fun (if not as diverse as they look), the action is good, the power-ups are frequent, and the explosions are everywhere.

Compared to competitor games, the big difference here is that you are most at risk from ranged rather than melee attacks. The more and bigger the opponents, the more and bigger the red circles and arrows on the ground. Get out of the red circle before it fills up while shooting down the enemies. This is often "The Floor is Lava Survivors." The other major gameplay difference is that you can choose to replace weapons along the way, carrying over power-ups to the next weapon. Maybe you didn't like one of your early options and your favorite comes later -- just replace an earlier one.

Once you start having a late game, you will need to turn down the explosion graphics, or else you will not be able to see the red circles. Settings - Graphics - Special Effects Visibility. Turn it down to make the explosions transparent. Set it to 0 to make them invisible, which I how I have it set all the time now. When your powers can cover half the screen and multi-cast, that becomes a slider for how playable you want the game to be.

I cannot say the balance or design are perfect, but I have been having more fun here than with most of the competitors. And of course, anything I said above could change in a later patch, since this is Early Access. For example, I cannot recommend trying for 100% completion right now because that includes grinding to unlock everything on every character; as I type this, I have 2/14 of those and you can see my playtime. I like this game a lot, and that still feels like a lot of grinding to me. On the other hand, if you also really like this game, you will still have character advancement available to you 100 or 200 hours into the game.

Walking backward in circles simulator.

What is nice:
- quick 10..20 minute runs
- dynamic builds every run slightly different
- tons of upgrades

What is not so nice:
Enemies spawn at a near constant rate, and since you are doing not enough normal DPS to clean them up you are relying on some form of AoE DPS, for which you must make your enemies cluster. 
So you spend the last 90% of your run walking backwards so that enemies follow you in a cluster, so that you can hit them with your AoE spells. And since you need to collect the coins the fallen enemies drop, you need to circle back to the coins.

So all runs are essentially completely the same, walk backwards in circles, while avoiding the "red areas" (where the bosses soon will drop an attack).
There is no strategy. You just walk backwards while not step on red.

Last there are tons of upgrades, but the leveling seems a little slow and it quickly feels very grindy.

This game takes everything that made Vampire Survivors so great and turned it up to 11. I can't wait to see where this genre goes from here.

EDIT: It's 12/24/2023, almost a year after I wrote this review, and I must say the genre has gotten out of control!

On higher difficulties/curse levels, mobs are far too bullet-spongey, making the modes feel cheap. Too often you'll end up facing four bosses at the same time who will zone you out simultaneously while hiding behind a hundred constantly-spawning goons that make it impossible to focus the important targets. On one map long-range magic pillars spawn to attack you far before your damage output is even able to dent them. 

Grinding out the skill tree helps, but it's too resource-intensive, requiring many full runs that have already lost their luster. You'll need to take down the same bosses dozens of times on several different stages to make any progress, just to artificially bump up the difficulty/curse level, just to unlock yet another character, just to go back to the skill tree to do it all over again, padding the gameplay loop out to the point where it stops being fun. 

It's in 3D, which sets it apart from other VS-likes, but it's less charming than some others in the sub-genre.

Game Smithing just keeps impressing me with every update. 
This is definitely a game worth it's price for any Rougelite/Swarm Survivor fan.

It's not much of a "story" experience, but the depth of the class system, progression and such is pretty incredible, and unless you are REALLY pushing the most difficult content (max Curse+Overlord endless loop 4+ or so) pretty much every thing CAN be played, and exploiting the most powerful builds and set-ups to start pushing OL9+ in an hour long run is pretty fun and interesting as well, or speedrunning the first loop, which takes a completely different mindset in choosing skills and power-ups!

Perhaps the best part in my experience though is how communicative and interested in community feedback the team at Game Smithing has been since the pre-release beta, it always feels like there is another patch just a few months around the corner that addresses an issue in a really impressively nuanced way or opens up at least another week worth of experimentation and theory-crafting, whether it be a new character, new skills, or a change in the Rune system. There are so many levers going into how you play each Swarm Survivor style run, and even that might be getting updates planned (no promises, but there was tentative mention of dungeons or challenge mode runs and the like being discussed in the most recent dev talk on their youtube, which even just being able to hear from Allan about what they want to do is pretty cool for a small indie studio like this, even if it needs to get scrapped, there's definitely an interest in some pretty interesting and exciting experiments in the genre in the works!)

Seriously though, this game is an absolutely STEAL at it's price for how much care and talent this indie team has put into it!

Got this game pretty much as early as it released in EA, and I've pretty much played a majority of the major updates. Things have become more streamlined and easier to read over time. It's much easier to see what spells are available in each character pool and which ones are locked behind achievements. Old reviews might complain about visibility of screen when there's effect and enemies, but you can toggle opacity on spells all the way up to making them invisible so you can still see enemies. More recent updates reward players for moving around the map to collect bonuses for each class, which I think is pretty neat since it used to be pretty common to just camp corners in this game. Spells and weapons are all pretty fun to grind for, and achievement grinding will get you plenty of hours on its own. There are occasionally things to come back for in terms of updates, although a minor frustration might be coming back between versions might force you to respec when a system is overhauled. However the save system seems to be good at remembering your resource counts and achievement history!

The biggest downfall for this game for me is that once you get near endgame, you have probably experienced the best builds already and there is not much to incentivize trying out lesser builds other than a few funny secret spells. However, considering the general price of this game is about $9.99 as of this review, I think it will take a long time before you hit that feeling, and you get your money's worth. Each character has pretty unique feeling from each other, despite most of them sharing similar spell pools. The early levels of the game let you kinda bumble about choosing all kinds of spells, while also letting you experiment with what modifiers or spell types you like. The overall feeling of this game is a bit of a Diablo-lite with the grinding system of Monster Hunter in a way. You can definitely min-max a specific targeted build and really demolish the game, and the runes and charater mastery systems let you spec both gameplay and character skills. You need to go back to certain maps, and beat certain tiers of bosses to get better weapons which unlock newer spells. These objectives naturally lead to getting achievements, which also unlocks more spells. Then you want to keep trying new spells and new weapons for more spells and high curse levels for more achievements, etc. This gameplay loop has kept me pretty satisfied, and the seasonal events are nice little map challenges. While many will argue there is more depth to the map mechanics of VS and other survivor games, I kinda like secretive but not too complex objectives for the seasonal events. I'd easily recommend this to people who like survivor games or achievement hunting, especially on sale!

Simply the best Survivors game out there. Updated on 18/12/2023 with the Arms of the Ascended (AotA) patch.
 
[list]
[*] Good variety of builds, 
[*] endless mode, 
[*] boss rush, 
[*] accessibility options (custom difficulty selector, transparency for skills, input lock on level up to prevent accidental choices, etc.), 
[*] relatively good looking (you'll mostly forget that it has a blocky look during a run),
[*] now with unlockable skins (no mtx),
[*] hidden levels!
[/list] 

And most importantly satisfaction. You can become OP pretty quick which is a lot of fun. The game is still in early access and there are a couple placeholders ingame but tbh the game is worth the price it's asking for already.

Red circle dodge simulator memes are real though.

[strike]I'm giving this a thumbs down only for visibility reasons, and quite frankly because the controller <> UI issues are really bad.[/strike] [b]Fixed in AotA, this is now an easy recommend and the best roguelike I've played in 2023.[/b]

If you don't care about the following stuff, go for it, I [strike]100%[/strike] completed the game (minus new content in latest patch). This is by far the best Survivors game as of now and the developers are actively fixing bugs.

Needed fixes:

[list]
[*] [strike]Controller support while in a run is fine, especially with hotfix v0.11.038 but there's still stuff that isn't accessible via controller (UI elements) or is really annoying to select. Examples: Everything labeled with a (?) question mark is basically only accessible with a mouse (like all stats). Choosing stages, character skills, character skill tree etc. are a real PITA with controller. It's also impossible to see the description of already picked up skills and power-ups unless you get a dupe or something to replace them with. Worse for character specific stuff like bars and their respective effects / buffs. Make more use of the D-Pad and streamline the usage of bumpers and triggers.[/strike] [b]All of these points have been fixed in AotA[/b]
[*] Still a couple of invisible damage instances, even after v0.11.038.
[*] [strike]With major soulstone conversion active, finishing a level with just a couple soulstones on the floor (like 10) causes heavy frame drops. You can die during those stutters to random damage. IMHO after finishing a level any active damage instance should be cleared immediately.[/strike] [b]Fixed in AotA, no more frame drops[/b]
[/list]

Suggestions:

[list]
[*] More hidden levels / events please! Honestly the most fun I had was trying to figure out the events. They were a welcome distraction from the otherwise monotone achievement grind.
[*] Ingame wiki and overhaul of stats explanation and other UI elements. The tooltips aren't really helpful.
[*] Characters other than the Death Knight +- Sentinel don't feel any different to each other, especially after you unlock their skills for others. Most character specific skill trees / special skills are just pick x up to get buffs y or damage z while damage z is mostly irrelevant and the buffs y don't last long. Picking x up can be really difficult in late game, more so when red circle dodging becomes important. The worst part are any of the "stand still" or "stand in this area" requirements. Not gonna happen.
[*] Given that every character model also (probably) supports every animation, a Challenge mode with randomized stats would be great -- you know, an actual roguelite mode in a roguelite game. Currently there's no reason to even experiment with new skills once you find out what works for you and you can basically brute force your one default loadout. This is fine for accessibility reasons but the game should actively encourage the usage of different builds AND characters IMHO. Otherwise scrap characters and let the player customize his own character.
[/list]

The actual gameplay is a lot of fun (I've spent almost 55 hours playing it), but the overall design is terrible. The Soulstones are only used for the skill tree, which you will max out within the first few hours. I have millions of the basic soulstones and 1000+ of each of the others. The characters are basically all the same, within a couple rounds the power-ups you choose will more than make up for the starting stat differences. The only real difference is the abilities that are available to them, but even that can be overcome through the use of runes, though there isn't much point, just switch to the character that has the abilities you want. And speaking of abilities, there's only a few that are any good (Light Beam), most of them are useless beyond the first round or two.

The game is in early access, maybe they'll fix these issues, but it would require almost a complete redesign.

Edit: For what it's worth, I believe they have fixed these specific issues, except now they've taken it to the other extreme and you need endless soulstones for a complicated progression system that honestly I haven't bothered trying to learn. Maybe one day I'll get the motivation to spend some time with it and change my review.

Please do not get confused by the length of the complaints below on this reply, my positive recommendation stands, it does so much right that I honestly don't have a lot to say about what it does right -- but I do have some complaints and suggestions, and they are as follows.

 [i]Keep in mind that this is from the perspective of someone who has completed every map with max (48) curse, and many of these complaints won't be felt until you're 50+ hours in[/i]:

1. The game needs an actual Endgame. Endless mode sounds neat, but once you've unlocked everything, and figured out good combos, the run inevitably devolves into circling bosses trying not to get 1-shot as you chip away at billions / trillions of HP.

You will feel really powerful ramping up through Bossmode Endless 3-4, it might take you as short as 4-5 minutes to progress through Endless 5, and then it quickly outpaces your damage, and by Endless 7 you are suddenly spending 20+ minutes to get through it while trying to dodge getting 1-shot regardless of how much block/armor you've picked up.

To be clear, you can absolutely still progress past this point, but when you get to this level you will be fighting your own boredom, rather than the bosses. Eventually you will give up because you simply cannot be bothered to spend a half hour+ to whittle away a level when the bosses all have more than 500 trillion hp, and there are 65 of them. I've never bothered to complete Endless 8 -- not because I couldn't do it, but because after a point it ... just stops being entertaining.

This makes for bad streaming, and bad speed running, and those are often the lifeblood of a rogue-lite game like this. Even if the end is just time, seeing how far you can get in 30 minutes or 45 is better/more fun than endlessly circling bosses for an hour+, and it would let the Devs be more free with the damage multipliers they add to the game, and ultimately let you become more powerful.

2. The game needs more viable recovery skills. An endless push simply requires Arcane Shield, or Exorcism. They are the only two skills in the game that provide you with Damage Absorption effects or Healing, respectively. You simply cannot expect to get far in Endless mode in this game without them, and they are restricted to two classes (Arcane Weaver / Paladin), which means you need to spend valuable Runes that unlock these abilities on other characters, or play only these two characters.

3. The game needs a way to, with 0 cost, disable the seasonal skills. As more seasonal events happen, and more seasonal skills get added, you are better off not doing the achievements, because they will pollute the skill pool. Because of the secret achievements, there are now 6 seasonal skills that can appear in all of my runs, and I *never want them*.

I'll say it again, more plainly: Doing the secret achievements makes you less likely to see the skills you actually want.

Also, personally, they ruin the fantasy of the classes that you choose. I do not ever want my Paladin to summon Santa's Elves, yet the option is presented to me in every run, [i]in place of a different skill that I might want[/i], and I can't go back and undo having done the achievement.

4. Bosses are endlessly recycled, and it makes every map / run feel the same. How many times are you going to fight Keythaiz the Prophetess during an Endless boss-mode run? It could literally be 20-30 times over the course of an hour, depending how far you get in Endless. [i]By the end of a run you might have 3+ of the [b]same boss[/b] on the screen at the same time[/i]. The game needs less, but more significant, bosses.

5. The way the game ramps up difficulty is a bit odd. The same enemies, and bosses just move and attack faster and do more damage. The defense skills can't keep up with the speed at which you progress through endless mode, so you're better off not taking them. By endless 7 if you get caught on a tree and stand still for more than what feels like 0.5 seconds, the bosses will catch up to you and 1-shot you, regardless of whatever defense skills you have. The only thing that can save you is Arcane Shield. This causes some whiplash from just 10 minutes prior when you were rocketing through Endless 5. Let me feel powerful/untouchable for a bit longer, eh?

[strike]6. The runes that add skills to your pool need to allow you to select the skills. Right now they "add 6 random skills of the given type, that you otherwise would not have access to". If I take the Arcane skills rune because I want Arcane Shield and Arcane Assault on some class that is not the Arcane Weaver, then when the run starts I spend all of my rerolls, and then restart, and repeat this until I see both the skills I want. Doing that is trivial, but it is a needless annoyance. The rune should pop up a window that allows me to [b]select[/b] 6 of that-type of skill, that I otherwise wouldn't have, and put them into my pool.[/strike] -- THEY DID THIS! YAY!

7. The maps are cycled through, so it doesn't matter what map you choose -- if you do an endless run you are forced to play on all of them, which makes choosing the map pointless. This has not mattered in the past because the maps are basically identical / reskins, but as the maps get more distinct (the last update revamped the enemies on Whispering Grove), the game should keep you on the map that you chose as you progress through endless mode. Perhaps add additional things like per-map uber-bosses to be added every X levels, and otherwise give the maps some personality.

---

Overall, this is a really neat game, I love so much about it, and will continue to play as the future updates happen, it has so much potential, and I hope that it becomes something much greater than it is right now.

[b]Soulstone Survivors[/b] é um [b]"Survivor like"[/b], mais um jogo que aperfeiçoa o estilo acrescentando outros recursos ao gênero, expandindo a jogabilidade e o fator replay.

[h1][b]Personagens[/b][/h1]
Existe uma boa variedade de personagens, e provavelmente ainda vão lançar mais. Atualmente são 14, cada um com uma arma única com habilidades diferentes, é fácil encontar um personagem que condiz com seu estilo de jogo.

[h1][b]Ferreiro[/b][/h1]
No ferreiro, é possível aprimorar a arma do seu personagem até 3 vezes (tem um espaço para o 4 upgrade, porém ainda não foi lançado), utilizando materiais que você consegue farmar durante as runs. O problema é que se torna um processo demorado se você desejar fazer isso para todos os personagens, pois o grind pra alcançar esse feito vai ser pesado.

[h1][b]Habilidades[/b][/h1]
Para mim, esse é o ponto forte do jogo, existem muitas habilidades, possibilitando uma boa variedade de criação de builds: Utilizando magia, melee, build com foco em debuff, long range, summon, etc...
Vale lembrar que alguns personagens não conseguem utilizar algumas habilidades. [spoiler]Porém, é possível resolver isso com uma runa que você desbloqueia facilmente.[/spoiler]

[h1][b]Maldições[/b][/h1]
Você consegue liberar níveis de maldição no mesmo mapa para liberar novos materiais e aumentar a porcentagem de experiência, entre outros recursos que você pode adquirir. Obviamente a dificuldade aumenta, mas é bem irritante jogar nas últimas maldições porque o mapa fica lotado de círculos vermelhos (marcação de ataque dos inimigos) poluindo DEMAIS. Já basta a poluição das próprias habilidades.

[h1][b]Árvore de talentos[/b][/h1]
Na medida que você upa teus personagens, você consegue desbloquear melhorias gerais e individuais. O ponto forte aqui é que cada personagem tem uma habilidade única, uma espécie de "ascensão", que libera uma mecânica nova diferente para cada personagem. [spoiler]Por exemplo, o necromante passa a encontrar partes de um golem na run, e quando todas as partes são encontradas, o golem é invocado para lutar ao seu lado.[/spoiler]

[h1][b]Senhores do Vazio[/b][/h1]
Senhores do Vazio, ou Lords of the Void, são bosses que você encontra durante a run. É necessário matar uma certa quantia para terminar a run, sendo úteis também para adquirir materiais especiais para comprar novos personanges, upar suas armas ou investir na árvore de talentos. E são os maiores responsáveis por poluir seu jogo com círculos vermelhos!

[h1][b]Poluição visual[/b][/h1]
Eu geralmente não coloco um ponto negativo como destaque na análise, mas isso aqui atrapalha muito a gameplay (pelo menos ao meu ver). Isso acontece pelo fato de que alguns inimigos, quando atacam, exibem uma marcação em vermelho no chão com a área de ataque do inimigo. Funciona bem nas primeiras maldições, mas depois fica horrível; você não sabe para que posição andar, pois muita coisa acontece na sua tela ao mesmo tempo. Não sei como poderia ser resolvido esse ponto, mas com certeza é algo bem negativo.

[b]The most mechanically bland survivor game[/b], despite looking flashy and varied.
This is worse than 6 of the 5$ survivor games I tried so far.

[h1]Gameplay(5/10)[/h1]
In a word: bland.
[list]
[*] You run in circles and collect crystals. That is all you do.
[*] Your inputs only matter for evading attacks (until you can't see them due to your own attacks)
[*] All class/skill combinations result in identical gameplay. So far only difference I've seen is needing to aim with some skills (and I use "aim" loosely here).
[*] All upgrades (temporary and permanent) are boring linear damage/defense/mobility boosts. Skills and gameplay doesn't change with upgrades.
[/list]

[b]Upgrades[/b]
I strongly suggest everyone considering this game looks at [url=https://soulstone-survivors.fandom.com/wiki/Attributes] Wiki "Attributes" page[/url] and tries to find at least 1 exciting thing, because these are all the upgrades you can get in game (temporary or permanent).

[b]Skills[/b]
So there's like a hundred skills in game, and maybe like 20 status effects, half of which are damage over time effects. Why am I bringing this up? They all feel the same.

Ignoring different elemental version of skills (which is more than half of the arsenal) the skills that aren't different in any meaningful ways. Great, one skill shoots a bolt, one thrusts a sword and one blasts an AoE around you. 

Damage difference is negligible, range eventually becomes irrelevant as even tiniest attacks hit the entire screen with enough range buffs. 

An example done right would be having a sword that is average damage, speed and range and offering a sniper rifle that has a narrow line for AoE, but hits hard and far.  Rogue genesia does it right, as despite so many weapons being just projectiles they do feel different because gameplay highlights the small differences in punch-through, reach and such.

[b]Terrible visibility[/b]
This game telegraphs most dangerous attacks and you're meant to dodge them. Problem is eventually I blast so many massive overlapping visual effects I can't see the ground (and telegraphs). So far all of my deaths (in decent runs) ended with me dying to an attack I couldn't see due to my own attacks.

[h1]Music[/h1]
I enjoyed the music initially, but after it looped for the 20th time It started to get annoying. Also it seems to have vocals

This didn't influence my opinion of the game, but if any future devs are reading this, the longer the music is playing the less noticeable you want it to be. Music should only grab your attention if you want it to make an impact during a short section of the game OR if you're prepared to have a large variety of tracks.

[h1]Why it's worse than competitors[/h1]
I'll compare it to 20 Minutes Until Dawn(20MUD) and Rogue Genesia (RG), because they are good in different ways, while sharing some of the flaws.
Below are things both of these games have and Soulstone survivor doesn't
[list]
[*][b]Feeling of growth[/b]. The biggest things those 2 games nail is feeling of progression. You go from needing 3-5 hits to kill a basic enemy, to then killing multiple with 2 hits to finally 1 hit killing hordes of elites elites before you even see them. Also both in both of those games progression is not limited to stats. 
[*][b]Tension[/b]. As much as I dislike contact damage it makes those games tick. If you're too slow, or don't have enough damage to clear a path - you lose. This creates stakes. In this game I often start out with terrible movement speed and just casually walk around enemies, because only bosses are a threat.
[*][b]Playstyle variety[/b]. The whole point of classes and weapons is offering different playstyles. For example: 20MUD sniper rifle (slow powerful piercing shot) and a pistol (average at everything) feel very different despite both firing 1 similar projectile at a time. Furthermore, those games have you build for different weapons differently.
[*][b]Engagement[/b] is a result of previous points. 20MUD and RG have you actively engage in combat (at least early-min run) AND building your character. Soulstone survivors offers 14 classes and probably 100 skills, all of which have you you run in circles and offers no nuance in builds.
[/list]

Pretty fun for the type of game it is, //OUTDATED//[strike]however I got to the point where I needed 18 curse intensity on The Frozen Wasteland in order to progress toward unlocking a character. However, the game will only allow 12 curse intensity. There is absolutely no information on why this might be and nothing I could do in game seemed to make any difference at all. Eventually got bored with not being able to progress toward goals.
Basically, super poor design. If the player needs to do something it should be CLEAR, not an unsolvable mystery.[/strike]//OUTDATED// Not much more to say. The progression system appears fairly deep and satisfying.

This is probably the most feature rich Survivorslike game out there now. In fact, I have more hours in this game then I do Vampire Survivors.

Large selection of characters. Large selection of skills. A good selection of maps and a skill tree, this game has really come into its own. The only real downside is that the your screen becomes literally filled with red circles in the deeper difficulties. You end up spending most of your time watch your feet, but the game also lets you get pretty deep into the power fantasy scale. As the game has an endless mode after you clear the first map, and has no cap to the amount of passive skills you can stack.

Without some of the crazy aoe it would become too easy, so its not a big ding against the game.  Cause currently, if you want a 3d Survivorslike game, this is the premier one. I'm hoping they'll keep growing on it with time, as it has a great structure to do so, so much.

They've added a lot of content since I first played so I'm hoping they continue to add maps, bosses, characters and spells. They already have a pretty large upgrade and skill system that will take a long time for anyone who doesn't cheat to unlock, so I would prefer if they leave it at that and focus on new spells and characters that mix up gameplay more than different stat buffs.

This one has a massive skill tree, weapon forging, runes to equip, match history, and a load of both active and passive skills. There´s an incredible amount of possibilities for your build.

This game has a dash ability. You actually need to move, dodge and pay attention for the entire match! Even choosing abilities when you level up is active: you have to choose between three alternatives.

So, compared to Vampire Survivors, Soulstone Survivors is more complex and IMO is more fun. Because you actually play it, unlike VS.
It is a great middle ground between the characters and weapons in Vampire Survivors and the deep core play of a Diablo. Highly Recommended.

High action low input game play. Ridiculous power levels. Lots of unlocks. Great music. Extremely flashy. Dynamic difficulty scaling so anyone can find their comfort zone. 

This game is pretty fun. There is a lot to unlock. Lots of things to try out. It is very over the top with the power scaling. And I think it's sadly now an iconic part of the game the devs are going to have to work with moving forward. There are a wide range of difficulties as the scaling comes from curses and there are like 30 or so to chose from and you can have them all active too. No curses is very chilled and casual where as max curses is more for people who (like my self) enjoy making game breaking builds and dancing out of dmg zones. 

The fact that you can go from slowly tickling bosses to death to instantly destroying them is a very fun dynamic to experience and leaves you in awe at the madness you have created. 

You can even bind the visual intensity of player attacks to some hot keys so you can tone up and down how much you can see your abilities. At very late game you might find your self even turning off the visuals for your abilities completely as you know that as long as it is on the screen you are hitting it and you need to have a clear view of the ground to avoid deadly attacks. 

The art style is fun. It is like somewhere between World of Warcraft and Runescape. You have explosive goblins. Kobolds with candles on their heads. A Deathknight.. but the low poly vibes of runescape. 

The music is the best thing about this game. Very nice psy trance beats but not too heavy on the kick so it doesn't get too much in the way of the other game sounds.

Very interested in seeing where this game leads. I think they could squeeze in a little bit more end game as after reaching level 170 on a character there is nothing left to unlock for it yet you can still level up. 

I would like to imagine there is still one more tier of stuff planned out for basically 200-250 as so far character level tiers seem to match difficulty level tiers in colours and 200-250 would be gold like the highest curse difficulty.

This is the only VS clone that is worth mentioning that I´ve found so far. It is less clever than VS, has fewer levels, and is needlessly grindy. If you enjoy VS and want to grind out some easy achievements over a weekend, this is a nice fix for you. If you want the best ever reverse bullet hell game: this is not it.

never played one of these games before, but now i understand the appeal.  this game is a blast and feels great to scratch that action-rpg/progression itch.  leveling up is quick and every upgrade feels impactful so you can immediately see your choices in action.

The game is a bit boring and repetitive. The core gameplay is pretty fun and exciting, but after approximately 20 hours when you beat all the bosses on all difficulties the game has nothing to offer. 
P.S. I've played longer because steam messed up my cloud save when I booted the game on another rig.

Game is fun, it's nice to have a lot of different things to unlock and customize for each run, and it's enjoyable trying out different skill builds to make it a unique experience each time.
My only real complaints at this time are:
- At some points it feels like your only goal is to dodge the red, which...yeah, but it's not in a fun way necessarily.
- Need bigger variety of bosses, at some points you'll have multiple of the same on the map which is annoying.
- Music could use a little bit of improvement/variety. Some of the tracks get a little grating after more than like, 5 minutes.

Overall, it's worth a buy as it seems like devs have been pretty good so far about updating.
Looking forward to see where it will go in the future.

+Very smooth and addictive gameloop
+A TON of skills, combos and fun synergies
+Very few skills actually feel bad and pretty much each of them can be OP
+Characters have character.. like they play very differently :D
+Metaprogression is super cool,structured like that - skill tree for each character, very distinct from the rest

-The metaprogession actual progress is reversed, meaning its very hard to progress it in the begining and SUPER EASY to finish it. like you can get a chat from 1 to 100+ in single run and its not every too challenging to do that, once familiar enough.
-At a certain point having the proper global metaprogression and runes unlocked is more impactful, then then character you're playing, meaning you can go full necro on a paladin and be just as sucessful, since anything in Overlord/Endless 4+ oneshots you anyway, its give or take the same experience
-The game looks cool, but you always end up turning all effects to 0, cuz otherwise you cant see sh*t
-The "enemies spawn meteors on death"mechanic is cool and all but.. my left hand literally hurts from nonstop dodging those 5000 red circles :D

Overall the game is very fun and a cool concept, but can definitely benefit of some.. adjustments to the difficulty, by which I dont mean its difficult by any means, but its difficult in the wrong places. It quickly becomes from chill bulletheaven to chaotic bullethell as you approach endgame.

I want to like this game, it's very fun... But it's literally unplayable. I get 1-2 FPS on the later stages even though my graphics settings are set to the lowest, enemy health bars and damage numbers are disabled, and I've even downscaled the resolution. While I don't have a NASA supercomputer, I was able to run [i]Baldur's Gate 3[/i] on medium graphics without any lag at ~30 FPS, so my specs are not the issue here. Last few times I died because I had a literal slideshow on my screen, even though my stats could have carried me way further (Curse 7, Overlord 5). Ugh. Until the game gets optimized, don't bother.

My initial review was basically "this is prettier than Vampire Survivors but I really don't feel like playing Pretty Vampire Survivors long enough to see if any of the five zillion things hidden behind unlocks makes it actually an interesting game".

This weekend I decided I was in the state of mind where playing Pretty Vampire Survivors felt like a good way to fill a few hours, and somewhere around 10-15 hours in I had unlocked enough stuff to actually be playing a pretty neat abstract twin-stick shooter with lots of little monsters on top of it, when I feel like turning the visual effects down enough to see them instead of a lurid carpet of shifting color fields with numbers popping up on top of it. I'm a longtime fan of Jeff Minter's work so "playing a game while you can't see more than about 10% of the visual cues" is my idea of a good time, and I really appreciate that there is a visual effects intensity slider in the settings for when I'm not up to a lengthy session of that. Then I started unlocking stuff on one of the character-specific skill trees that you have to unlock the entire base skill tree to get to and it's actually started giving me some real variety in how the different character play.

But before I could get to that, I had to grind for most of a day. And fiddle with the controller configuration so that the dash button auto-repeats, and assign the right touchpad of my Steam Deck to "mouse", which the default layout does not do for some reason - super annoying in a game that has a zillion little info boxes to mouse over as you work out your build!

5/10, it's a decent twin-stick shooter if you're willing to grind for a day or two to start unlocking stuff.

The game is fun and enjoyable but is also way more graphically demanding than others in its genere, it also tends to get boring a bit quicker than the alternatives due to more repetition in bosses and especially the soundtrack. In general: game is not perfect, could be a bit boring or grindy, looks great, plays great, runs great and has tons of potential and unlockable content and I would highly recomend picking it up on sale.

It's fun as a not-too-serious game but I kinda feel like it's missing something. The incremental advancement system is kinda boring: 20% more of this, 3% better chance of that, +10HP, etc. And it doesn't get harder as you progress, the enemies just turn into bullet sponges. There's no new attacks, no new bad guys, no new environmental dangers, just the same thing at level 10 that you had at level 1 but now the enemies have 50,000 HP instead of 500 HP. But you also have +400% dmg...so number go up means good? It needs better boss attacks and a larger variety of bosses. And probably weapon/power-up pairing or dependency. Or weapon evolution. Cause the weapons only do their 1 attack and that gets dull.

I dunno, it's fun for a bit but gets kinda boring after a while cause you are just running around the map waiting for guys to die. Also, there are no mid-run saves, you have to play through the whole run, which can take over an hour. That kinda sucks because sometimes I get interrupted with life and have to forfeit because I gotta take care of a thing.

This is the survivors game for fans of Path of Exile. It's a touch slow to start, and long runs can become a hectic colorful blur of explosions, but that also makes it fun and satisfying in the same way Dynasty Warriors is satisfying in laying down thousands of enemies.

There's a lot of depth to the different characters, powers, runes, and skill trees, especially for a survivors game.

Quite possibly the weirdest survivors game I've ever played.  The heart of the game is great and was possibly one of - if not the outright best survivors game of the bunch.  Here's what's wrong with it currently and why I'll spend exponential less time playing Soulstone Survivors vs. any other survivors game:

[h3]Rock, Paper, Rock? [/h3]
The core game is so good but at the same time, you'll feel like you're chasing your tail. Once you get over the initial hump of starting out new, the rounds go for too long.  Feels like they won't end...until the bosses spam AOE all over the ground.  Basically, the end result is that you'll feel like you aren't accomplishing anything, since there's no way to counter it.  

[h3]Too Much Hamster Wheel[/h3]
Then there's the progression.  For completionists this game has grind on top grind.  There's so much to unlock...too much.  The problem manifests itself when you consider the process of unlocking everything with the aforementioned boss AOE spamming.  That's when you start feeling the insignificance of it all.  You can melt bosses and mobs easily, but there's no way to deal with boss AOE spamming all over the ground and the impact it has on picking up soulstones.   

I love these types of games, but idk if I'll ever even touch this one again.  I feel like I've already experienced everything there is to experience, but haven't unlocked anywhere close to everything there is here.  However, you can tell pretty early on that nothing you unlock is going to change the game in any significant way.  It's sounds weird saying this, but it's like they put way too much content into this game.  It's a complete waste.

[h3]Aesthetically Soulless[/h3]
And then there's the art style, which is completely played out and overused at this point.  But for some mind boggling reason, the devs thought it was good idea to use it again in their new game.   It embodies the feeling of cut and paste and simply lacks originality so much so, that I just can't stand looking at it anymore.   That's just me....I'm sure there are plenty of people who won't mind it as much.  If I never play this game again, this won't be why - but someone has to say something.   Enough is enough with the cutesy clash of clans look from 2 decades ago.
pretty fun and chill. update skill trees made it much better. plenty of progression as well.

Vampire Survivor-like with a ton of depth.  Definitely give it a chance and get past the first few unlocks.  That's when the motivation to come back and play hit for me and now I really enjoy the game.

As much as I want to say I like Soulstone Survivors, the game has some HUGE glaring issues.

For one, you usually have to spam the dodge button. It's not an occasional "Oh sh*t" button, it's a constant and continuous use. Because...

90% of the screen is covered in high damage AoE effects from the bosses, which means you have to keep out of their range, which means you don't damage them, which means you don't complete the stage, so you have to dive into the AoEs, spam dodge, hope for the best, take a ton of damage anyway, then likely die/lose a life in the process. It makes completing stages on higher difficulties (which is downright required for progression) very, very difficult because of the oppressive AoE spam.

It's soooooooo close to being where it could be, but the AoEs/dodge spam makes playing the game tedious and unfun for me. I wish the devs cared enough to reduce the spam but they seem to believe it's for the best of the game. Other reverse bullet hells are not this oppressive and have other methods of difficulty that work fairly well.

This is by far my favorite survivors game out right now. The development team is doing multiple big updates a year and adding lots of content. At this point ive played 90 hours and im sure ill play alot more.

I need to see how it goes if I have several different summons, how it goes if I shower the whole screen with meteors, how it goes with napalm, how many different doom skills are too many (answer: just one more). Simple game, but so addictive.

I can't stop playing. 
A couple of points I find important: this game allows directional aiming, as in you aim where you want. I have bought and played a few of these VS type games and can't stand the locked attack directions that only attack in the direction you move. The second is that this game has progression outside of runs, so your always progressing and want to play a bit more to level up your characters, get more upgrades or unlock other characters. The different characters are fun to play and have different styles, you can also unlock a rune/skill that allows you to use all unlocked skills with amy character you want. There seems to be a lot of freedom in this game.

50 hours update:
I've unlocked the last character, Death Knight, and OMG I'm on a horse!  I haven't really tried to min/max my toons or searched online guides for the most OP builds, just trying out stuff and exploring the various skill combos.  So far this is what I know:

1. I love and will always pick the Chaos Golem, cuz "it's dangerous to go alone!"  Doesn't matter if I'm supposed to be a tank (barb, paladin) or a glass cannon, or even if I already have pets (houndmaster and necro).  I love love love my golems.  They are such good distraction for the bosses and I can run around and concentrate of killing from afar.

2. The necro makes me happy.  It reminds me of Diablo and I love having a massive group of pets doing all my dirty work while I collect stuff and avoid the red zones.

Got Soulstone Survivors on sale and it rekindled the joy.  The music is very hypnotic and a perfect match for being in the flow state and zone out a bit.  I love the skill tree and runes and different characters and experimenting with the various combinations of active skills and modifiers.  So far so good and I'm trying to max out the Barb and use that to farm components to build better weapons for all the other toons.  Highly recommended!

Bullet heaven.

Soulstone Survivors (SS) is a reverse bullet hell in which you create the projectiles.  It's already becoming my favorite survivors-like games.  Obviously, it's similar to Vampire Survivors (VS), but really only premise; kill hordes or enemies, level-up (create build), survive.  One major difference is the twin-stick-like aiming.  Don't get turned off by this as you don't need to be as accurate as a shmup since most attacks end up being AOEs.  SS also deviates with bosses intermingled in each level (5 by my count; which spawn after defeating a number of enemies), these bosses drop giant XP which also sucks in all the maps shards (XP) - which is like VS magnet.  Each class has some unique skills, though you can use your favorites on any build if you want.  Unlike VS, you can dash as well.  The maps really don't differ much beyond aesthetics.  I think adding level specific mobs, hazards or terrain (snow, ice, sand, etc.) might be interesting.   One of the reasons I like SS is you feel like you can actually beat a map.  Some of these survivor-like games just make it impossible to beat, which can feel frustrating.  It's nice that you can add modifiers if YOU want.  

There are a few cons.  One being that since you can pretty much make every class play the same, I'm not sure how deep and varying builds can actually be.  Classes differ by HP, damage, speed, and obviously their class specific basic attack.  You can pump up the starting stats in the skill tree; which is also pretty basic and will apply to all characters.  Another con is some things are explained very well or consistent.  Sometimes completing a map will gather all the XP to level up, but then you go through the portal to end the run.  While, in some maps, you can continue to another level.  After a while, some of the level ups seem a little underpowered for your level as well.  **you can add some rerolls via the skill tree, but they are pretty expensive and I'm not sure how much they actually might help.  So far there doesn't seem to be a large variety of bosses, but I'm only 4 maps in, so maybe there's more...

SS might need to have separate skill trees for each character to add to the longevity.  *edit- I just saw there this does exist!  Still, there's a lot to like and the unlocks and achievements are keeping me engaged so far.  It's a good base right now and I hope to see it continue to improve and progress.

A solid bullet heaven. It has an impressive roguelite system, infinitely scaling difficulty and skill progression (it would appear), and very well balanced in my limited experience. The game ramps up in intensity and fun simultaneously, unlike some in the genre that get brow-beating hard and don't maintain the same joy of the midgame. I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone who enjoys Bullet Hell / Bullet Heaven games, or even just fans of roguelites that are interested in trying the genre out.

Fun game.

Quite a good time early game to build-craft and unlock new characters/upgrades. The game starts to suffer once you get to higher curse levels, as most builds cant keep up with the sheer enemy density/boss hp pool. The runs end up feeling samey and the novelty runs out.

 Essentially, as of the time of writing this, the gameplay loop turns into: Use runes to force into a strong poison/summon build, kite bosses and ads by spamming dodge to keep out of the constant red circles until you win. Choosing to continue the run using an alternate portal doesn't extend the replay ability for me. All it does is plop you in a new area with minor changes. No new strategy or new hazards are introduced, except the bosses have more health, do more damage, and attack faster. This just ends up being a race until you get one shot by a non telegraphed attack.

TLDR: worth a try and provides quite a bit of entertainment, but the endgame is lackluster in its current state.

So I tend to stay away from games that are Early Access, especially ones that are a year in and it doesn't seem like additional updates have happened, but I was sorely mistaken at first instinct. While this game has been out for a year, the Devs have been updating it regularly and keeping up with the community as they continue adding content. Concerning the gameplay, I absolutely love a Roguelike, and I've been getting into some of the mass-enemy games recently (another good one is Goobies). But there's something different about Soulstone Survivors. It is endless right now, but it still has some charm. As I unlock new abilities for my favorite class, it opens up new themes and builds. While yes, I wish there were more maps and bosses to fight, I am sure this will be one of my favorite games to return to once they're put into the game proper.

This will be my 4th review iteration. So i've played the game ever since it was available and started out a lilbit above positive, it was all good and fun and the more you play the more unfun it becomes. Not because it's repetitive, its because its unbalanced as FUCK the higher levels you go, and I get it, obviously more progression made in the game = more difficult, as it should, Atleast.. until that difficulty is beyond what can even comprehend, seriously, you can't stand still for .1 SECONDS without getting fucking one shot, even moving constantly isn't that reliable because of the 12000 attacks coming at you in all shapes, forms, sizes, and speeds.. if you don't wanna play on the higher difficulties (Which you're forced to to unlock new classes and there respective weapons) then I guess that fine if you want 5-10 hours of gameplay and never touch it again, around 3-4th tier levels is where it gets frusterating, I'm on tier 6's (out of 7) and you can imagine thats not better. The game just has severe balance issues. It wants you to enjoy your character and there build but guess what, Wanna go heal Paladin? welcome to tier 6 where 95% of all healing is reduced.. great cool. Wanna make use of your class? Many of the classes need to stand still or in an small area for your special to work.. guess what you stand still, and you're fucking dead. You cannot play the game the way it wants you to without being punished for it. It has probably one of the most fun and synergetic ability systems in any of these survivor like games.. but it just dissapoints soo much in the end by being nearly unplayable. I don't speak as a casual gamer, I play games 12-18 hours a day. This is not fair or balanced. so heed my words when I say everything I have. Devs. Fuck you I've been telling you guys for so long how you can make small changes to make the game playable and you ignore all of them. enjoy your negative review. Go play death must die or 20 minutes till dawn, spirit hunters or even army of ruin

This game is almost a thumbs up, but ultimately I don't think I can recommend it except to big fans of the genre. It's not as smart as some games (like VS), and instead relies on grinding various stats that all end up feeling kind of the same. There's not much strategy since all roads lead to the same place - and this is common in this genre, especially in the less well-designed games. The other major problem is the graphics - the spell effects are nice but they're TOO MUCH. Everything on the screen makes a huge explosion, or a huge shockwave, or draws huge weapon trails, etc. Pretty quickly it's impossible to see what's going on and the game just becomes red circle dodging. Why does my minion skeleton mage's basic attack create a giant purple shockwave every 2 seconds across the screen? Not everything needs to be a massive display. Now multiply that by 15 minions, yourself, and the enemy mobs and the game becomes very hard to play. And while the art is nice, I don't need it assaulting my eyeballs like that. The music is great and full of energy - perfect for a game like this. There are also lots of unlocks to grind your way through if you like that sort of thing. I didn't notice too many secrets, but there are a few. Most of the unlocks are the generic Kill 500 of X or Beat this mode X times.

This game is one of the few survivor games that constantly gets better. From devs implementing features that address issues/improvements to listening to the community, this game has gone through many changes within a year.

To be fair, I started playing a year after it became available on steam so I got to enjoy all the changes already. But I looked into how the game was in the past and especially coming from other survivor games like Vampire Survivors, Holocure, Halls of Torment, etc. this game is refreshing in both content and quality of life. There are so many different builds you can test out across 14 characters (as of today), so many different skills, and runes. Not only that, my favorite feature has to be the opacity filter when the screen gets too clonky w/ all the abilities towards endgame. Makes pushing for harder areas more fun and plausible. 

For a lot of alpha/EA games I have played in the past, the devs either just do their own thing or they stop working on it after several months. This game is quite the opposite in listening to the community as well as consistently fixing existing issues or adding new content.
 
This game is good if you like survivor games and also fun for people who want to kill mobs of monsters with lots of different build variations. 

TLDR:
Game good. Wont regret. Lots of content. New stuff consistent. Good for smooth brained apes. Like me.

Been following this game very early on. It's a great Roguelike game with lots of customization. 

Pros:
-Character builds are pretty wide open
-Skill trees and rune system for further customizing and replay-ability
-Fighting styles for everyone

Cons:
-Only 4 or 5 levels is boring
-Only 1 game mode (Area). Seems like they're releasing a separate game to address this...which is odd but fine I guess given its price.

Well I think at this point I owe this game a review.  It is my favourite 'Vamp Survivors' style game. While it is in that genre, its pretty unfair to call it that basic.  

This game offers awesome depth in it's characters, weapons and abilities.  A real draw for me is that over the course of development the meta progression/leveling has really improved, there are tons of achievements and weapons to unlock. I have owned it through a fair number of patches so far and can safely say the developer changes are awesome and every patch leaves the game feeling more polished. 

One fair complaint from lots of people is that as the game progresses you need to turn down the visuals and have a lot of dodging in your life.  Honestly, I don't find it reduced visuals diminishes the game play enough to effect enjoyment and....well these types of games are always about dodging shit that kills you - it's part of the fun! 

I found the game worth the purchase price and know I will continue to get play out of it.  Last tip - if you struggle at all on higher difficulties (or want something easy to create a build around) Chaos Golems are almost every builds friend :)

The game has a great variety of skills and combos, each class brings its own playstyle with its different weapons, though most skills and builds are kinda useless in higher difficulty and endgame, where the summons are your best bet, since they both get the aggro making you dodge things less, and have high damage output. While the dodge can become very annoying and the grind to unlock skills and gear is also too tedious, you sure won't get bored as long as you know what you do and try to stay alive since there's always something to evade. The fact that there's no timer on the run and it ends only when you kill all bosses or die can make the game longer but if you have a good build it can also make it shorter.

So generally you could say it's a love-hate relationship, the annoying things here make you waste more time without too much reward but the developers keep working on the game and it has great potential, so hopefully they will find the balance and make the game more enjoyable and feel less like a job :)

This is a good start, but I would not recommend it. The balance of the builds feels one-dimensional, designed around attack speed and triggering status effects. Being able to stack as many as you want does not help. Furthermore, the game piles on layers of potential grind. Playtime feels disrespected, but basically everything is designed around a carrot on the stick of the next level of grind and power creep. Solid 11/10.

It's an autofire, bullet hell, hack'n'slash, rogue-like game that will attract the attention of anyone that likes Diablo-style games. But they will be disappointed very quickly. Because this game doesn't feel rewarding like Diablo. There are no item drops while playing (only some out-of-game runes and some craftable weapons for each character). Absolutely no reward while playing. You just aimlessly dash around boring maps, trying to avoid enemy AoEs, choosing randomly dropped skills while leveling up and hoping that your summons will kill the boss enemies so you can advance to the next boring map just to repeat that dash'n'survive cycle. Imagine doing that for 90mins.  Feels exciting. Yay? No. You finish after 90 mins of surviving that insane bullet hell and you don't even get to unlock a lousy rune! You just unlock higher map difficulties, just to repeat more of that pointless grind. Boy, no. This feels so NOT rewarding! When you wander for that long around maps, you expect SOME kind of reward. Well, this game won't give you ANY feeling of reward.

Another game-breaking problem at high-level playing is that the animations of many spells will obstruct your vision of enemy's AoEs. Which, as you might guess, can be fatal at high levels.

That's pretty much it. There are other, similar indie game titles out there that actually feel rewarding for grinding through the maps. Save your money for those games.

This one has a good grind to it that feels worth it as well as what seems to be a good balance so far to the difficulty of things. Easy buy for sure especially while on sale.

[h3]visibility[/h3]

The best I can describe this, is if you port Vampire Survivors into Diablo 3's visual engine without the RPG and looting elements... then add a sprinkle from Path of Exile's skill tree and you have a recipe for success!  Fun spell-builder action roguelike!

Fun, reasonably addictive, it's kept my interest for 37 hours so far and I'm still invested. 

It's a VS-alike, if you've played one you've played most to a degree, but they've carved out a nice little space in the genre for themselves. 

What differentiates this one: 

* _lots_ of different weapons and damage types and effects
* iso rather than 2d
* weird indirect hitbox for damage

The last point is hard to get in a sentence - coming into contact with mobs doesn't damage you until they actually attack - and the areas where attacks are about to land are highlighted; you get hit if you stay in the zone too long. 

This makes sense with an iso perspective, as it's hard to be pixel perfect in avoiding things otherwise, but it does feel a bit luck vs skill, using your skill to _lower the odds_ of getting hit rather than actually avoiding attacks directly. It's unfair to say this but... combined with the low-poly style, it makes it feel slightly mobile-game. The gameplay is plenty fun, but... ehh, there's a slight flavour there. 

The other complaint I have isn't a *bad* thing, it's just missed potential. There's a million and thirty different tags on attack and damage type: swing, burst, missile, nature, magic, holy, arcane etc etc - and there are perks that apply only to certain categories, incentivising you to focus your build around them, which is neat. 

It's just that there's very little complexity and no downside to any of the interactions between weapons and perks. What would really put this game into a category of its own would be deeper interactions, with both synergies _and_ dysergies. Put in some tradeoffs, force the player to make some tough choices. Add a perk that buffs X but nerfs Y, make combining some categories less effective, make ferinstance slowed monsters hit harder or something, so you're actually shaping your build rather than just throwing everything in the bucket as it comes. 

I haven't unlocked many runes yet, so perhaps they fill some of this gap - but it seems like a gimme to bake some of this into the basic mechanics.

The game idea is nice and captivating, but there are few points why I wouldn't recommend this game to anybody else, except for people with masochistic tendencies.

1. Visibility - yeah, the latest update did jack sh#t! Nothing changed, enemy attacks still grow increasingly hard to see over the course of a run. Yes, there is an option to turn down effects, but that completely kills the game. Why the attackmarkers do not get changed into complementary colours when covered by the characters skills, is beyond comprehension.

2. Received damage - Oh yeah this one is a big fun killer and infuriating at times. Additionally to enemy attacks being hidden behind way to intense skill effects, there is also no indication of an attacks threat level beside the size of the circle on the ground, which may or may not be visible. So in higher difficulties one can get struck for 150+ damage out of nowhere (recognisable that is) while franticly trying to evade incoming attacks.

3. Healing - There are a few ways to heal, but the healing power is a bad joke when compared to the damage one can receive.

4. Area of denial - Damaging puddles of negative effects are lasting way to long. Sometimes it is simply not possible to get close to the bosses to fight them or get their loot. Also some elite enemies summon vortecies which do an unholy ammount of damage on the character, this wouldn't be a big problem if their ammount would be reasonable.

5. Defensive abilities - Armor and damage reduction upgrades in the game are almost useless and most of the time you are better off choosing a damage, area, frequency or multi-cast upgrade.

I wanted to like this game, but it's just so damn grindy. 

You might think that's ok, that you enjoy the grind. But I'm here to assure you that in this game it's next level ludicrous. 

Your average victory will take ~10-15 mins, and rewards ~10k blue crystals. That's enough for a couple of the low level tech tree upgrades, or a fraction of a major upgrade. 

There are 96 upgrades in the initial tree. And from here it unlocks even more and gets CRAZY nutty.

Stay clear, check out this game's better bretheren; Vampire Survivors, Death must Die and Hades are far FAR superior.

Is the game bad? No. It's a great spin-off of Vampire Survivors, but, the main issue i have with this game that overwhelmingly ruins the game play is when you get to the later stages of the game you can't see anything making what seemingly is the challenge of the game "Dodge the red circle", virtually impossible. My second issue, is the game really isn't challenging. The game is prioritizes a very droney grind towards the endgame which is kinda pointless because the end game is a bunch of projectiles and sword strikes covering the red circle that's going to one shot you. But overall, it's a decent game worth getting on sale, hopefully the devs can do something to minimize the late game screen clutter and introduce more interactive challenges .

The only reason I recommend this game is that there is no middle option for review. It is not bad. Very polished and looks super promising. But with all curses active game becomes frustratingly annoying with entire floor in red circles to the point I am fighting urge just to slap ALT+F4. It is just constant dance around ground effects with bosses basically unreachable and during that dance even more spawn.

Also grind looks crazy to me. Maybe just first impression but yeah... Lots of crystals and other stuff needs to be picked to unlock everything. Other stages of the passive tree locked behind full unlock of all passives does not make it any better.

Good game probably, just needs some oiling to ride it smooth.

----
Seems like passive tree from each character is connected to the main node and some of the passives works for all characters as it is one single tree branching out to characters. That is more grind but already interesting.
---
After few more character grinds. The higher tier areas I play, the less I enjoy the runs. It is just non stop red circles everywhere. Constant running around and dodging as bosses are unreachable. Usually happens a lot with slightly less lucky skill options. My favourite was when for 20+ level-ups not a single movement speed option showed up. With specific meta builds or full unlock of the tree probably that is not an issue. But I doubt it. In other words - challenging by enforcing annoyances and friction.

Game is addictive for sure.

---

Week later - in the end game fun dissipates super fast proportionally to the red circles filled around the bosses. It is not hard by any means it is just not fun and annoying to circle around constant area denial. Will wait for updates with changes to that before playing more.

TL;DR: As a working adult that wants to sit down and just play a few matches and leave... Not happening. This is a GRINDFEST.

Pros:
1. You can get epic level ups and rare level ups from the get-go.
2. You can specifically boost your area/attack speed/damage. Neat!
3. Matching Spells can feel rewarding with legendary upgrades.

Cons:
1. Super grind!!! Everything in this entire game is a grind! (everything needs materials which you get a tiny amount PER RUN!)
2. This game explains absolutely *NOTHING*. When you finish a run, there are 3 doors. they don't explain wtf they do.
3. When you start this game, expect to have to spam the first stage until you buy powers, because you're going to have a bad time if you try to play the second stage without them.

I'm purposefully leaving out all the other bad things about this game cause everyone has said it already (only 5 bosses/poor music)

Very good game, probably one of the best survivorlikes I've played. The game's got a bright future, and my only real gripe is that there aren't mods for the game... yet. Pick it up whenever you can, it's a wonderful game to play in downtime to unwind.

A year after my previous review, they literally fixed everything. The game is progressively easier as you progress through the passive tree, the upgrades are interesting and each character plays differently. The grinding is a lot more bearable, you get like five times more resources compared to before. You can now look up which skills are in the pool before starting a new game.

It took time but the new features are starting to make this game very fun to play. I can now recommend this game!

Too many game design mistakes.
They want to make the game challenging like a bullet hell but you can't control your character when you get hit and you're forced to keep moving because there's a ghost following you that will one shot you if you stand still.
They want the player to dodge but the zoom/field of view is too small and you can dash into a rock or tree and die.
There are minerals that you can grind when playing on some maps, but for some reason the uncommon minerals are harder to grind than the legendary ones.
Characters have different unlockable skills, but you don't know which one unless you look up the wiki.
Half the runes are boring and useless because they don't add anything to the game, just change the RNG when picking skills

I can't recommend the game today. The game doesn't have soul. It's a bunch of features mixed together quickly trying to replicate the success of Vampire Survivors. The optimization is really bad too, you will have to play with all skills effect off to get more than 20fps, even on a good pc

Soulstone Survivors is a game that does most things really well. Despite being in early access, the experience so far has been almost completely bug free and surprisingly not too heavy on the hardware. Audio is more than decent, music depends on taste - the OST is not intrusive and it keeps a good pace. There are quite a few builds to try out and combine thanks to the recently reworked rune system. The existing 14 characters feel distinct, and I believe at this point another 8 characters have yet to be revealed - there is simply a LOT of content. Challenges are at a medium level for achievement hunters, and won't exclude casual players. The overall flow of the game is good too, even with difficulty modifiers (called Curse intensity) cranked to their maximum.  The community has more than a few players willing to help out newbies or bounce ideas for theoretical builds. The development is communicated quite openly with players - an important plus.

This all being said, there are drawbacks and limitations that need to be disclosed. The current balancing is kept at a reasonable Loop 3/Curse V level. Going beyond this is possible, but the difficulty scaling for enemies is a matter of escalating numbers - this is a major gripe I tend to have with game design in general. It is entirely possible to create a build that can win Loop 7 or even 8+ where enemies have their basic HP multiplied by hundreds of thousands, their attack speed makes a mockery of human reflexes, and the damage from common goblins can wipe your life out many times over. But even if you put together an ungodly tank with a 75% chance of ignoring attacks outright, a 95% damage reduction for attacks that do connect, and healing up to your full life per second, sooner or later you are completely outscaled by numbers alone; when you win another full Loop it feels like a chore.

Replay value is also a hit-or-miss. If you're into the arena survival genre it's already expected. If you are unsure and only getting into this type of game it can get quite monotone and be more of a slog than an exploration of what the game is and does. Quite a few attack type pools [Slam,Chaos,Fire etc.] are shared between characters, which can also contribute to the feeling of having done everything before. The seasonal events are a permanent part of the game, and even when completed you can still do them at any point. Again, for some this may be a welcome side challenge or a reminder of milestones that were crossed before.

Terrain. This is one of the worst enemies in the entire game. Getting stuck on a tree or piece of wall can be a death sentence for an otherwise promising run. It's not the end of the world, but the frustration terrain-related failures bring is real. It can put people off from getting into another run.

While obviously flawed, Soulstone Survivors is a good game. On the whole, I would happily recommend it at a discount for anyone curious, and at full price for enthusiasts.

Soulstone Survivors is a pretty good entry to the genre and feels like a more complete game 1 year into early access. Overall 6/7 bucks is a fair price for the game and worth picking it up if you're a fan of the genre and have exhausted the content in Vampire Survivors, Halls of Torment and Holocure.

One notable innovation is the ability (and necessity) to dodge red circles and squares. This makes movement more engaging and they did a good job making it feel responsive and fluid.

The more interesting twist though is the fact that runs are not a set length of time. Instead, you are required to kill a set number of monsters. Kill them quicker and progress faster. This makes build optimization have meaning. Plus the ability to opt-in to effectively boss rush mode at the end of a successful run is really great.

The place where it falls short though is on thematic and general character. Everything is 3D including visual effects so they're more costly to make but the content isn't as memorable as the assets of say Vampire Survivors or Halls of Torment or Holocure. The characters you play feel like generic assets. The abilities you get are mostly standard lightning/shadow/fireball/etc. I'd love for them to find a way to inject some life and style into the game.

Another disappointment is the level of challenge. The base levels are all pretty easy. It's possible to clear your first run without knowing much about the game mechanics at all and just picking offensive powerups. At the upper end challenge modes and boss rush it can get difficult but I'd love to see a smoother curve to mastery and learning. The balance between defensive/offensive power seems so off I feel as though the game would simply be better if all the defensive talents were removed.

Still despite the shortcomings it's still a well made game I'd recommend fans of the genre pick up. I'm sure the developers will only continue to improve it throughout early access as well and they seem like great folk so support em.
