Soulstone Survivors, when it was initially released, was a game that I rather quickly dismissed for lacking anything unique or memorable about it. The classes were bland, the abilities were similar to stuff in other games, and there wasn't really anything to make it stand out.

That said, it has been supported for over a year now. Hoo boy have things changed.

Sure, the crafting is still as limited as it ever was (which is fine), but the skill tree got expanded [i]dramatically[/i] and now includes things like unique passives for each class that give them significantly altered gameplay, a whole slew of abilities, unlockable runes that let you customise your character each run, and enough difficulty to scratch whatever itch you happen to have at any given time. 

The Developer is currently working on some aspects of the game that are still a little wonky, but honestly given their progress I think it's now certainly worth buying. It's a satisfying 'Vampire Survivors-like" with a bunch of content and combos you can employ. 

At this point I think the only things I'm really longing for is more uniqueness among the classes. I'm still invariably using (mostly) the same abilities for each class so I want to see them all have a couple of passive abilities that really entrench differing gameplay, even if it's only minor overall changes. I crave asymmetry. 

Regardless, it's a solid game and the developer still seems to be working on it, at least for a while longer as there are still several classes to be added to the game.

I would refund this if I hadn't played too much already. But it's not like I feel ripped off either. It's just boring.

If you've played Vampire Survivors, Halls of Torment, and Brotato I doubt this game has much to offer to you, but it is "more" of the same. This game doesn't seem like it understands the slower ramp up of those games, instead offering a massive skill tree and so many characters and progression!11!1!! I was quickly doing a diablo barb whirlwind spin larger than my screen every 0.1 seconds and it feels like nothing. Nothing in this game feels like anything, it's not distinct like it is in the other survivorslikes or whatever you call these.

Ultimately I died because I got bored and lost focus. Other than that it seemed like I could go on forever. And you probably can, with the progression because the skill tree is fucking massive and there are tons on characters. But the two I tried didn't feel super different, and I doubt the rest of them do either judging how porridgey the enemy and level design is. Looking at the videos the characters have differences, BUT, they make no significant difference so why bother with the grind?

I think I'll come back and try it with different characters, but I have my doubts. It just fundamentally doesn't feel interesting. Brotato can do more with an area that's about a quarter of the size, and there's no overbearing +hp +dmg +this and +that etc. progression. I really don't know what the devs could do to improve other than completely remaking it to be much more deliberate and slow.

After several patches I feel that I need to change my review. Previously this was "fun but nothing special" game. Now it is a strong pretender for the best in genre. Developers are very active and constantly add something fun to the game, being more content or UI improvements. Some additional maps and a few more bosses would be great to have, but the game is still in Early Access and considering how much good changes already happened - it is quite possible to get improvements there too.
What is there, anyway? 
* Good amount of characters, with each having their own ascension skill, impactful enough to make a difference. Each character also has whole big passive skill tree with several unlocks that will work for everyone. 
* Enemies on different maps actually become different not just in skin, but also in abilities. They have different patterns of attack and different toughness. And some more were just added a few days ago.
* Thanks to recent changes in how runes work build varieties are over the top now. It was good before, and it just become even better. Technically speaking you could make sameish build for pretty much every character now, but it will perform worse than build catered for specific character strengths.
* Most abilities and elemental statuses get their own quirks now. In the past the game suffer a bit from feeling that various elements and their abilities have a feeling of being simply recolored. Not anymore.
* The soundtrack is still amazing and get another track or two just recently. I admit that with amount of grind it does start to feel too limited. 

But beware: the grind is real in this game. If you want to complete all characters skill trees - you are looking at hundreds of hours of gameplay. Not that you NEED to do that, you can finish max curse on any map with only a fraction of passive skills unlocked for any character. And having more maps and bosses could make grind a bit less repetitive. Still, grind is fun because you are not simply spending hours of play to get yet another +5% of damage for that specific character. Each character has 3 new runes in their skill tree that you can use on any other character to get even bigger builds variety. And some passive skills also applies to everyone, not just character you unlock them for. That makes grind rewards actually exciting.

But the long grind is the long grind. If that is not for you - maybe look for another game there. And that is alright.

I LOVE this game, but please read my full review to understand why I don't recommend it until they fix a single point.
------------------------------
The game has an amazing progression system and synergy between skills and level ups.
You can customize SO MUCH with runes, mixing skills from other characters and leveling them up to add permanent bonus stats to the other chars.

The only HORRIBLE downside is how the difficulty scale works:
You have to set the "curses" by yourself, kinda like Hades, they increase the exp and currency you get, so they are needed to be activated on higher levels. The problem is that there is a point where you can't even stand still for half a sec while all the screen is red with damage indicators.
I've seen bullethells more merciful than that.
To add salt to injury there are a LOT of chars with specific mechanics that need to stand still for one or two seconds to get their buffs, making them USELESS ON HARDER CURSES.

Please devs, Hitting harder>>>>hitting the whole screen. We already have to deal with the stupid curse minion that has a insta death if you let it reach you and bosses that deal OHKO.

This stupid "whole screen covered with enemies and damage zones" only pushes the cheesy summon builds where you can leave some coccoons/turrets and just go to the other corner of the map while they melt the bosses, as some summons are untargetables by enemies.

This is my favorite 'Survivors' style game. The gameplay is fun, the different characters and builds are fun to experiment with, and the progression is satisfying and rewarding. The 12 minute rounds with options to extend are a fantastic way create runs you can end periodically but extend if you're in a groove.

I've been playing for a few months and the devs have put out multiple, substantial updates, including an anniversary patch today that overhauled the rune system (for the better) and addressed one of my biggest complaints by upgrading the UI to make the value of different upgrades clearer. I was originally a little concerned to see they have another game coming soon while this one is still in early access, but it's clear that this game is a priority.

If there's a complaint, it's that the difficulty scaling can be a little rough. You set the difficulty by adding different curses at different tiers. Having all the curses from a tier unlocks new rewards (primarily crafting material or extra upgrade currency) and you can choose different curses a la carte. Unfortunately managing your curses can be frustrating (I would recommend allowing different curse 'profiles') and the highest difficulties can sometimes feel punishing more than challenging with the amount of the screen covered in attacks. In my opinion these aren't deal breakers and I plan to edit this review when (I'm confident) the devs continue to rework systems.

Overall strong recommend, enjoy if you like other games in the Survivor space.

I was quickly hooked on this one, and could easily see the amount of content laid out for me to unlock and play. It hasn't taken me that long to be working on max level curses with all characters unlocked, but at this point in the game I'm starting to see limitations, many of which are being addressed by the developers in future updates so I remain optimistic.

The two main issues for me are:
- Most of the characters feel the same at high level, despite each having individual core mechanics to unlock. This is mainly because of the amount of AOEs the game throws at you, especially when you're up against 5+ bosses at once. You end up just running and dashing around the map non-stop hoping that your build will work. You don't even see the bosses much, because if you get remotely close to do some more direct damage, their other AOE abilities come into play. I played five different characters last night and the gameplay loop was exactly the same.
- Some of the character designs rely on collecting items, being close to something or even standing in a particular spot for a few seconds to gain buffs. For some of them, this conflicts directly with the ridiculous quantity of AOEs, making the characters feel useless. 

The other minor complaint at this stage is the small number of levels - only 5 right now. Aside from that, the UI with a controller could use some work, particularly the runes page as it's hard to navigate. I also hope that they can come up with some more achievements, because without being a completionist I've got 75% of them already. There are some balancing issues and the amount of base currency you earn even at the highest difficulty is a bit low, but I'm sure these are among the many things that will improve by formal release.

Not a lot of content currently, but definitely enough to justify the price.

Recent updates have fixed the core complaints of the community, showing that the developers are genuinely focused on making the game for the players and not themselves.

In the future, this game could be well worth it's asking price, but currently it's just acceptable.

[UPDATE]

They added way more content to the game. It's very good now.

My favorite bullet hell game.  

Progression is amazing.  You have a skill tree, blacksmith weapons and an extended tree past the skill tree plus runes.  

There is enough to customize and build that you feel progression kicking in every single round.  

Characters are unique in their own ways, they have minor stat differences but huge ability differences.  Each character can also be played several ways based on the weapon and runes you pick.  Making build diversity quite extensive.  

There are 5 levels to choose from and in those 5 levels there are multiple difficutly scaling options.  Making the game progressively harder if you so choose.  There is even an endless mode or a boss hunting mode at the end of each map, this makes gameplay extend as far as you would like.  

The music isn't half bad either.  

Cons
I feel like my abilities override enemy abilities which means that you can't dodge anything or even see anything.  This makes the game frustrating, relying less on skill and more on bad design. 

I feel there isn't enough level diversity.  Small arena's without much going on.  There aren't any meaningful things to do.

I feel that characters need to be a bit different than they are when it comes to base stats.  They feel boring and uninspired. 

The game would benefit from more equipment pieces to build even more diversity.  Add armor or trinkets.  It would help with freedom of choice and building options.  

Lack of multiplayer isnt my favorite choice developers make when they create these games.  This game would be twice as fun with multiplayer.  Your characters are small enough to comfortably be able to fit more players on the map.  

Overall the game is a solid 8/10.  It could be a lot better in some areas but as a whole it definitely stands apart from others. 

The experience is really engaging and totally worth the asking price.  Updates are coming quickly and a roadmap is in place.
Absolutely a blast, can sit down and play for however long I want and make some cool account progress.  Tons of exciting things to unlock and each run is whatever I want it to be.

It's fun I guess. Gets repetitive in the long run. Eventually turns into a seizure inducing light show where you can't make sense of what's happening on the screen which is the only way to survive because everything gets really close to killing you in one hit. There's no point where you can just stroll through the game and "have fun." Basically what I'm saying is, if you're looking for a game to come home to after a stressful day at work, this ain't it unless you want to get MORE stressed.

Damn fine survivorslike game, and plays very well on Steam Deck (Minus some slowdown at later stages, when the screen is covered in enemies and explosions). The base difficulty will allow you to feel like an all powerful destructive force after a few rounds, and for the scaling difficulty you have 7 levels of modifiers, all with attention to meta progression variety.

The things that really let this game stand out: NO CONTACT DAMAGE!!! I cannot tell you how much I appreciate the fact that damage is clearly coming from an attack animation, not just from base to base contact.
Variety! Something like 20 or so classes, each with 6-8 unique weapon skills on top of the hundreds of universally accessible skills. On top of that, they are finishing up super meta progressions that feel like a prestige class for each and every class, that will introduce a whole new mechanic to the class.

This game has many hours already from me, and will earn that twice more in the forseeable future.

Amazing addition to the "Survivors" genre, and clearly has a lot of work put into it. It has so many differences from Vampire Survivors you cannot call it a "rip-off", because you would be wrong. Nothing is without issues but those will be addressed over time, adding to the quality of this game. After the recent update, it is clear the developers put a lot of work into this game, having different enemies each level and this huge skill tree with a ton of upgrades, and these platforms on the ice map that I have no idea what they do but I still like them. Honestly, very entertaining to just jump into and have fun.

Easily one of the best bullet hell roguelikes, has a lot of depth with tons of things to unlock/upgrade. The maps look great and all feel different with a nice variety of enemies, the characters are all pretty unique with their own weapons/abilities and the runes are a fun perk system that gives you a lot of options to tweak runs or useful stuff like improved loot drops. There are almost 150 skills with both a lot of unique ones and different variations allowing for all sorts of builds.

One thing that is unique is you can replace skills mid run, and while the characters have different skills you can also use the runes to enable either individual skill types or all of them if you like it random. Upgrades during runs effect either individual skills or different types so being able to swap skills out depending on the upgrades you get keeps things interesting.

It has a pretty good balance between being a tad grindy and having a lot to unlock and improve, if they made it much easier you'd run out of new things too fast and it also forces you to plan out what you focus on. More specific dificulty options could be nice but it gets plenty hard at the highest settings.

Especially considering this game is only around 50% through early access it really is impressive.

This is a Recommended Review with a slight caveat.

Soulstone Survivors keeps to that Survivor-like trait of getting a lot of bang for your buck. For a cheap game, there's a lot of content here to keep you entertained and coming back for a quick game.

The caveat with this is the end-game, which is where I feel it does a good job of drawing you in, but then flounders. As you progress in the game, you add modifiers to levels to make them harder, but give more rewards. The problem is that as you go up these levels, the amount of reward you get for the difficulty of the level sharply drops. At Curse level 5 or higher, the screen is often filled with red damage areas that in some cases can instantly kill you, and by 'filled' I mean 'filled'. If you don't spam the dash button you're almost certainly dead.

It's here where the initial fun of making builds falls apart as there only viable builds narrow dramatically, and the gear you create from the extra crafting materials doesn't offer much of an advantage, but an alternate style of play which might not even be viable for higher Curse levels.

Essentially, there comes a point where progression hits a brick wall. Whereas other Survivor-likes try to keep that progression arc curved, that's not the case here. Furthermore, as far as I can tell a level can effectively last for an infinite amount of time, which is a divergence from the usual formula that I feel should be adopted. One of the great aspects of your typical Survivor-like is that the game ends at a set point, so you always know that when you press play, win or lose you're done in 20 minutes. I would even suggest that the developers strongly consider this, because there's no worse feeling than spending 49 minutes grinding a Curse level only to get OHKO'd from an attack you couldn't see in the midst of all the others.

TL;DR Great Survivor-like with a strong start to the end-game but rapidly hits a brick wall.

This is a hard one to review.  Not because its bad, far from it.  It just hurt my hand so severely trying to play it that I am in danger of serious injury if I try to complete it.

The game is complicated, intense and demanding yet somehow quite addictive.  The music is great, which helps.

After 4 hours I was hating the game for its bewildering array of skills but I went on, played another 4 survivors games and came back to it.  I am glad I did.  I just think I need to potter about a bit in it some more before attempting to unlock the last character - unlocking the second-last nearly broke me.

The basic game is quite entertaining and much what you would expect from a Survivors game, for all its massive skill tree and rune selection.  Then you discover debuffs, "curses" which raise the bar significantly.

For comparison, I have played Nordic Ashes, Yet Another Zombie Survivors, Battle Grid and God of Weapons.  Each was a stroll compared to this, fun though they were.  Not one of them has threatened to reduce me to physical and mental breakdown the way Soulstone Survivors is doing.

But will I keep playing it?  You bet your life.

Edit: 59 hours for all 256 achievements and the game looks like it will promise a lot more in the future so I will keep it installed and hope.

I'm going to literally copy and paste what some dude already said because this is pretty much exactly how I feel about the game, except I'll give it a positive review. I got 30 hours of fun for $5, you can't tell me that doesn't deserve a thumbs up. With that said... there are some issues, as shown in the following review, written by some other person:

"Ehhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh. This is a maybe for sure. There's a ton of fun to be had here - the abilities are fairly varied and flashy and a lot of the builds can feel different, the rune system + weapon system (plus the new character-based skill trees) are a good way to change it up in a lot of ways.

The problems you run in to are twofold: To get the highest tier materials, you HAVE to turn all the curses on to max. This turns the game into one where realistically only a few ways to build work and even then you have standouts where doing anything else is hurting you. The reason it gets so restrictive is the absolutely unending spam of red circles (projectiles, slam attacks, AoE attacks, whatever) coming at you - they happen when you kill enemies, they happen AGGRESSIVELY every minute or so when a bombardment tower spawns (that you then have to dash straight towards and kill to get any breathing room), and the bosses screen-covering attacks which mean you want to be hitting as many things as possible at all times, ideally when they're not even on screen.

You pretty much have to turn the visual transparency to max which takes out a lot of the "feel" of going fire over poison, for example, to be able to see. Also all you do is move and dodge red circles, there's really no more to it than that on max curse, no playing around with things, etc. That would be fine if it were an optional difficulty but it isn't if you want to craft weapons (which you do, they unlock more content!). Turning off the curses for the towers and the after-enemy-death meteors especially helps de-escalate the red circles a ton, but those are mandatory too.

The problem on top of this is the clearly poorly balanced material farming rates. You have to have curse maxed out to even see the high tier ones, but also the lowest 1-2 tier materials are what you need the most of by a landslide. Spending 10-15 minutes per run farming to get 1/6 of the material needed to craft 1 weapon for 1 character is nonsense, and that's WITH the high level rune to increase material rate by 50%. So you're rerunning the same 1 map 6-7 times in a row with the same runes, same curse, same build, because anything else might slow you down, and you get to unlock 1 of dozens of weapons (more of which are coming). I know I've highlighted this (and some others have posted about it as well) to the devs for months and it's one of the things they just have not acknowledged - apparently they must think it's fun this way, but I don't.

Keep in mind, this is when I had 100% unlocks going into a new patch, with abundant materials leftover from playing each of the new weapons, and I still fell short of literally every new weapon released. I have almost 60 hours in from the initial release and It'd take me probably another 10 of dedicated grinding, no actual variety, to unlock the rest of the weapons in the game as of this post.

The REQUIRED highest tier of difficulties need to be reworked to be more interesting and interactive, and the material rates (or costs) need to be overhauled badly. Those two changes would make me put this in the "recommend" but right now it actually feels like a bullet heaven that doesn't respect your time, it almost feels GaaS-like in the grind requirements, and frankly? F that. This genre is great because in 10-30 minutes you can have a whole fun experiment and then do it again, Soulstone Survivors asks "what if you didn't actually get to do that?" and the answer is, it gets boring fast."

This game is super fun and frustratingly boring at the same time. 

Fun, because it got smooth gameplay, a lot of variety, meaningful choices of abilties, tons of powerups. Fun meta-progression, lots of characters. There is a ton of customizability available with different skills and weapons for each character and additional runes to make every run even more unique and try out things.

With all these positives, the bad part becomes even more frustrating: The balance is kinda off. Lower difficulties might be challenging at first, but become a walk in the park quickly, once you understand how things work and which spells are good and synergize. So the natural thing to do is play at higher difficulties, for even more rewards and special rewards. And thats where things... fall off and every run starts feeling the same - no matter how you build your character. You have all the stuff available, but no matter what build you choose, which character you play.. You end up with the same gameplay: Dodging red circles and AoE attacks for as long as it takes for the bosses or yourself to die. You have to turn the effects nearly 100% transparent to be able to see every red circle. So no matter which build, everything looks and plays the same. You end up going for the same 3 builds that just work every time and have no incentive to change it up. And at the same time, going back to lower difficulties feels totally unrewarding, because no matter which build, it gets super easy and no challenge. And you miss out on the better rewards.
You basically want to change things up and try different builds, because there is so much possible variety. But there is no reason to do so, as everything just is the same, except that enemies die at different speeds.

You get to have a ton of fun until you get to that point, though. So the game gets a thumbs up from me. 
Also a tip: Don't look up builds online. Find the OP-Stuff and combos yourself, as thats the biggest factor of fun in this game. After you found them, the boring part sets in, as described above.

This is a great game if you like survivors game ( good place to start if you have not played one) . Huge amount of content  for the price. Pick it up! even at early access it has 100+ hours of game play possible.

There are many good rogue-lite, survivor type of the games out there but this is my favorite so far. The introduction of the dash mechanic makes the game play a lot more intense, so rather than just moving around and aim/auto shoot you will also need to time your dashes to avoid getting hit. It's almost like a shooter. 

While the game has 5 maps which you play over and over again, the character customization possibility is HUGE. At 70+ hours, while I have unlocked all of the characters and got all of them to level 70+ it will still take me a while to unlock all of the skills for all of the characters. So big plus if you like character development, but this will also likely to annoy folks who dislike to grind because you will be doing ALOT of grinding. Fortunately much of the grinding was quite enjoyable at least for me. The game may appear to be difficult at first, but once you get a hang of it (after 5-10 hours) it becomes a blast as your your characters start to build up. While some of the abilities are more powerful than others, all characters have the potential to be overpowered provided that you have a good build strategy. Speaking of build strategies, in addition to abilities which randomly appears as you level up there is also the use of runes which allows you further customize your build. 

All of this plus the music is awesome too, for less than 10 bucks makes recommending this game a no brainer!

One note of caution, while you don't need good graphic card to play this game it does not play all that well on regular MacBook Pros (mine is 2021 model with 16GB RAM and 1TB HD). The performance was great on my PC laptop with a fairly cheap GTX 1650 card, everything ran smoothly at high settings (remember to turn off effects though which makes it impossible to dodge attacks). The game is stable and never crashed once.

This game is very fun with the amount of skills, characters and weapons at your disposal, which lets each run be different than the last (in most games I always end up choosing the same thing lol). The added skill tree also adds a way of progression beyond unlocking characters and achievements, which I find lacking in other games.

[h1]An Exciting Game Marred by Critical Bugs[/h1]

Rating: ★★☆☆☆

Soulstone Survivors had the potential to be an engaging and enjoyable gaming experience, but it's severely hindered by a game-breaking bug that threatens to overshadow any positive aspects.

The concept of the game is intriguing, where you collect soulstones and embark on a journey through beautifully designed maps. However, this excitement is short-lived due to a critical bug that results in the complete loss of map progress and all hard-earned soulstones. This bug is not just an occasional inconvenience; it is a persistent issue that has left players frustrated and disheartened.

Imagine investing hours into meticulously exploring and conquering various maps, only to find all your progress wiped clean in an instant. It's a demoralizing experience that ruins the sense of achievement and progression that a game like Soulstone Survivors should offer.

The lack of responsiveness from the developers in addressing this issue only exacerbates the problem. Players have reported the bug, and while there may have been some promises of a fix, it appears that the problem remains unresolved. This lack of attention to a game-breaking bug is inexcusable and demonstrates a lack of commitment to the player community.

In addition to the critical bug, the game also suffers from some minor issues, such as occasional glitches and subpar graphics. While these may be forgivable in isolation, when combined with the game-ruining bug, they contribute to an overall negative gaming experience.

In summary, Soulstone Survivors could have been an engaging and captivating game, but the persistent bug that causes the loss of map progress and soulstones makes it difficult to recommend. Until this issue is addressed and resolved by the developers, it's best to steer clear of this game to avoid a frustrating and disappointing gaming experience.

Its a semi-afk simulator. All you do is control direction and facing and it auto fires your skills.

Fun game until you really get into the meat and potatoes of unlocks and character building.

Lategame is basically endlessly dodging red circles and only a few skills actually doing enough damage to even kill the bosses ( which are the only way to actually win. ) 

Many, many, many classes can't even use their unique trait because they require standing stationary at a point or remaining in an area for a prolonged time, which is almost always guaranteed to cost you a life.

Skill damage, usefulness and even usability vary wildly, most melee classes become God Run or No Run in the late game. Death Knight in particular is absolutely abysmal on high difficulties, as you entirely depend on constantly dashing through the residual ground effects, which the Death Knight is unable to do. ( Not to mention his base weapon is absolutely awful. ) 

Furthermore, Many classes have weapons that won't even reliably clear entry level waves and you depend on essentially kiting until you tickle down enough mobs to level and get any other skill. Really disappointing to craft a new weapon and immediately feel like you've lost a ton of damage.

Skill trees become a generic game of skipping all of the "flavor" of a class to get generic stat boosts.

By the time you really begin to get deeper into the game, you find yourself being really frustrated by it. A real shame.

Great take & iteration on the survivors genre.

Significantly more challenging than Vampire Survivors. You are a bullet hell, and you have to dodge bullet hell as well. You won't get powerful and become able to AFK in this one. It has scaling difficulty as you unlock more things, level up and get better at the game as well to keep it interesting.

There's a slider for graphical effects that you can move to be able to see what's happening on your screen once you get massive AoEs & cast rates that would normally make a survivors-like into a flashing lights sim.

Many of the abilities feel pretty good and fun to use. I particularly like the whirlwind style abilities, of which there's at least 3. Big variety of skills.

I have played many hours of Soulstone Survivor during the past few days which is more than enough to provide a healthy feedback considering the fact, that I love reverse bullet hell games and I have played almost all of them available to this date. 

Soulstone Survivor is I believe the best game in this genre today on the market when it comes to graphical design, music, character progression, options and customization. I still have to give it a thumbs down, because where it lacks the most is also the most important aspect. The gameplay itself. 

I currently play on Curse level VI across multiple maps trying to unlock the hardest difficulty Curse level VII and I have also crafted my Epic weapon. The gameplay until here was very fun and I enjoyed it a lot. But unfortunately at this point, lategame is a total mess. The game could also be called, Dash, The game ! Because that's all you do, press space to dash nonstop in order to avoid damage. It is not fun. It is also impossible to play lategame without any piercing or high aoe skills , because there are so many monsters that there is no chance to even hit the bosses from distance. Having 6 bosses at once with 30 million hp each. Sure, I can cheese them with dashing in, deploying ballistas, dash away , rinse and repeat until they die  but again its not fun.

Also playing the Pyromancer and going pure Fire skills is unplayable and not because it could not be viable, but If you have the whole screen and ground burning from your fire skills, you will have absolutely no way to tell that you are standing in an enemy danger zone. Only your hp disappears out of the blue and you are asking what happened, as you didn't seen anything. Red on Red is a no go, this needs to be fixed otherwise Fire skills are useless.

This is a very cool and promising game until you reach the endgame. And there is also big potential. I had a lot of fun with it for the time being, but I don't think I am going to spend more time with this game until the issues I have with this game are addressed. It's still in Early access ( how surprising ) , but I will keep an eye on it as I wish so much that this game will become the best in the genre. I have very high hopes.

I want to like this game, but in it's current state I don't believe it holds up. The core game play is simple, pick up some power ups and attacks and go wild. The difference here is that everyone has there own abilities and perks. The style and theme is great and it feels great getting massive power ups and clearing out hordes. The problem is the core loop is stale. At normal difficulty its easy and slow and takes forever. At anything higher, you are just constantly running from explosions and colorful booms. It's tiring on the eyes and exhausting to even play. (Let alone it feels like an hour each run)

As you level up a character it becomes a disgusting grind that, while rewarding to get new abilities, falls flat and feels very underwhelming for the effort. The same bosses over and over again is also just plain lame to look out. I'm sure that after the next 20 hours it may get a little bit more bearable??? but like why put the effort into that if its just the same 5 levels with the same 5 bosses, over and over again. 

If you're looking for a better Survivors-like please do yourself  a favor and play Vampire Survivors. If you came here after beating it like me, probably pass on this. At least until it's less of a bland time sink.

This is a really fun game on the surface with a ton of layers of progression and gameplay... if you can get past the nonsense this game puts you through. The biggest issue the game has is the complete over whelming amount of noise on the screen once you progress through difficulty tiers. The game gets to the point where there is so many damage aoe's on the screen you actually stop understanding what's happening and default to just running around in circles hoping you're avoiding getting hurt. Seriously going through a stage at late game is actually a draining and irritating experience. 

Another problem the game has is some of the skills you have access to blind the screen and take up screen real-estate by hiding the damage aoe markers meant to warn you and if you level them a certain way it can cover the entire screen. Some of the level up mechanics that would be very cool and fun actually hurt you in more ways than they help you making a certain number of skills actually completely useless and not worth having at all, which is a real shame. 

All in all, I can't recommend the game in its current state. There's too much that is just annoying, frustrating or just simply not fun to deal with. It's a fun design but it's a shame it misses the mark by slapping more enemies, more damage projectiles to just overwhelm you into submission. Winning isn't even all that satisfying, you're just happy the hell is over.

The game itself is fine and fun, but there is an extremely game-breaking bug that is very easy to encounter that will, basically, reset your save back to 0. Currently, the only resolution to this known issue that the devs have is to overwrite your save with a different generic save that sets all characters to 70 and gives you a bunch of resources to re-unlock the skill tree.

Issue is that this bug is so easy to encounter that you might as well just be frozen at that level of the game. I had all my characters over level 100, two of the class trees completely maxed out, and now I keep getting set back, over and over.

Until this issue is fixed, I cannot recommend this game.

EDIT FOR CLARIFICATION: The bug that I encounter is that when the game crashes, which has been a frequent occurrence, most all save progress will be reset to 0. All characters will be at level 0, you won't have any of the skill tree unlocked, you won't have any Soul Stones, you won't have any of the perks unlocked.

🌟 Soulstone Survivors Review

Score: 8/10 🌟

Soulstone Survivors is an action-packed roguelite adventure where you confront the Lords of the Void and their relentless minions, striving to collect their Soulstones and ascend to godhood. As an Early Access title, it's already making waves with a "Very Positive" rating on Steam.

🔥 The Best:
🎮 Addictive Gameplay: Engage in exhilarating battles against hordes of foes and titanic bosses, learning powerful skills to enhance your character's abilities.
🛠️ Deep RPG Mechanics: Explore an extensive Skill Tree, unlock multiple characters, and experiment with hundreds of Passive Skills and Runes to tailor your character to your playstyle.
🎶 Soundtrack Variety: While some tunes may not hit the mark for everyone, the game's soundtrack offers a kickass vibe that complements the action-packed gameplay.
📜 Progression and Customization: Discover almost a bunch of unique Active Skills, experiment with curses that add challenge, and craft legendary weapons to become more powerful.
🚧 Early Access: The developers are committed to evolving the game based on community feedback, promising more content and improvements in the future.

🤔 Areas to Improve:
📊 Visual Clarity: Improve visibility, especially during crowded battles on higher difficulties, to enhance the player experience.

Soulstone Survivors, in its Early Access state, shows great promise as a roguelite action game. With a rich Skill Tree, character diversity, and challenging battles, it offers addictive gameplay that keeps players coming back for more. As development continues, addressing bugs and introducing new content will likely make it an even more enticing experience. If you're a fan of bullet hell and roguelike games, Soulstone Survivors is a title worth keeping an eye on as it evolves towards its full release.

The gameplay mechanics are the most interesting and reactive (and you can dash! <3), the progression is much more in-depth with a Path of Exile flair, the graphics are 3D. Fantastic!  They are doing an incredibly good job on this mindless hack and slash style, fantasy themed game.  If you are looking for something you can turn your brain off and play, this may be for you.  If you are looking for a story line, intellectually stimulating puzzles, this isn't it.  Keep looking.

If you like the frantic-paced, action-packed, constantly attacking style games then please look more closely.  This game can be challenging (just stay away from red circles!).
type of game that makes you close down the game and then 10 mins later you want to play it again

It's basically a cringe mobile game, except there's no "energy" that limits the amount of runs you can play and you can't use real-world money to unlock everything. Everything else is exactly as you'd expect from a soulless generic app store "game". And it's executed perfectly, along with terrible controller support.

Not like it matters. You turn off your brain, play an audio book or a podcast or whatever other type of pill you're taking to cure your boredom, and you turn this on, and you enjoy the spectacle while fooling yourself that it's your skill doing the vibrant colorful fireworks. It's just mindless grind, and you know it.

Still the best bullet heaven/ twin-stick shooter / VS style game around. Active movement and necessity for dodging makes gameplay challenging. Scalable difficulties means risk vs reward works well. High difficulties are actually tough, though certain classes are simply a bit more powerful than others due to the nature of their class specials. Huge passive tree constantly provides new rewards and incentives and makes each character just that bit more powerful after every run. 

Some of the complaints about visibility are deserved. You must reduce effects visibility to about 1/3rd to have a playable game on higher difficulties, otherwise you can't see the red 'floor is lava' effects. Higher difficulties also become dodging simulators, especially when bosses are active, but I actually like it as it adds another layer of complexity beyond just 'what build is best'. 

Overall - I highly recommend this game. It's one of the smoothest, nicest looking, well playing styles of this particular genre out there. It's still in early access but has dozens of hours of content available. Combined with scalable difficulties and more unlocks than you can shake a stick at, it seriously sits on the top of the bullet heaven pyramid.

TBH for a game that feels like a mix between Vampire Survivors and Risk of Rain 2, i had pretty low expectations. I then proceeded to put 30 hours into in in maybe a week. So clearly I like it. The abilities are fun, the different characters are cool, and there's a lot of different ways to play if you don't want to play the right way (All doom all the time bby!)

In fact the only complaint I have is the unnecessary clutter with the add ons.

AS AN UPDATE: Since my original Review they have done a big content update which cleaned up a chunk of the clutter and made certain things more clear. TO simplify, passives of the same tier now properly show the stacked numbers! Foe example, if I have Passive ability Lethality (which adds 5% chance to crit), when I mouse over the passive it will now say that i have a 15% increased chance to crit when i have three stacks! 
This was a huge complaint of mine previously, so very nice to see that fixed. It also helps clarify what stacks and what does NOT, for example on Debuff applying passives, the CHANCE to apply the debuff does NOT stack, but the impact of the debuff does.

HOWEVER, they still do not combine the higher tier versions of passives into one card, so green Lethality and regular lethality are tracked separately despite being the same damn thing. but tbh that's my only real complaint at the moment!

All in all, great game that needs some QOL work. Which is to be full expected in early access!

This game saved my life.

I am 36.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

follows is the orig. review unedited
------------------------------
tentatively positive, but if they don't fix the most important issues I have I'll change it to  thumbs down.
the game is quite good, has a lot of really good ideas, but since the things that I can't stand have been here since last year, I don't see them changing it

what I like:

I like colors. a lot of games these days go for extremely muted colors and boring visuals. this game does not.
while I am not a big fan of the art style particularly, I do not hate it. it's pretty ok. a slightly less mobile-game way of designing the models but with the same colors, spell and so on design would be great.
basically, I like the look - mostly

music is certainly different. I muted it after a while. but I like that it's something else, some style I haven't heard in games yet. not for me, but I appreciate that they aren't copying 8bit or some other style
and I really mean that: I'd much rather have innovative music than a worse version of what genres are usually used. maybe at some point I'll grow to like it, maybe not. but at least they're doing something

I like the leveling system, a lot. this is where the game shines.
I like the many many unlocks, 
you get minions as well.

the screen at the end of the round is a good start -- but it lacks a lot of info. and the dps numbers are hidden during the round which sucks.

you can continue with new rounds when you finish without dying. very cool.
-----------------------------------

what I dislike:

no joke, I never die basically unless I get stuck in the terrain. and I get stuck constantly. this sucks. 

it really bothers me that it is completely unclear how and when rare resources spawn. 
I go through the map, and nothing's there. I fight for a while, go a bit farther away, and suddenly there are several rare. but I can't run around like in most survivor games because it seems XP despawns after a while. So I am torn between hugging a spot and looking for rares. it sucks.

you can't see stats for so many things, or only when it does not matter.

how much damage did all the poison do I added? how much the doom? and so on...
game will never tell you. so it feels completely meaningless and demoralizing.
the system they use is GREAT! I love it actually. but you *never* see the damage bonuses and it feels like useless.
the whole point of these games is stats and improvement.

the weapons you can unlock have stats you can't see. who on earth thought it is a good idea to *hide the stats* of things you could potentially unlock? it makes it completely not interesting.
even worse: you can't tell if what you see at each character is the weapon, or the character bonus.
so you can never tell *if the weapon you see is even an improvement*. 
show me a COMPARISON between one weapon and another. so stupidly designed.

the damage circles are not visible through your spells, your minions and enemy mob models. once you're far enough, all you can do is avoid anything and circle the combat area from far away, or you just die from hidden damage circles.
such unbelievably stupid design. 
damage circles need ALWAYS be visible, or forget playing at a certain point.
--
you *can* make effects transparent, on a slider. but that does not solve the issue really. I like how the game looks. check out RPG games or other games how they make things that transparent on the fly so you always see the most important things. do that. 
general transparency is not a solution


they do not show differences when you level up.
e.g. you choose "adds poison to 30% of your hits - does 100 damage" - but that is not true. you already chose it 3 times, so the skill should say "adds poison to 30% of your hits - does 300->400 damage" showing that you increased from 300 to 400
the game feels like it is designed to hide the EFFECTS of the upgrades you got. they show the upgrades, but you have no idea what reacts with what and what adds what after a while. because the game does not show you in an easy manner

worse: since there is interactions like "if a hit poisons, it also dazes" (similar) - but you can't see it on poison skills.

here is what the game SHOULD do, to ENCOURAGE and SHOW you the upgrades you have running, so you can see what you achieved:

in a neutral color:  "adds poison to 30% of your hits - does [in red->] 300-> [in green->] 400 damage. "
under that: "trait/upgrade interaction: [in green] poison procs [in yellow] daze"
then show the DPS all 4 poison upgrades do in a window I can see DURING gameplay AND at the end of the match.
right now the game hides it everywhere

suddenly you can easily build your proc based build and see it work.



if they don't change that, I'll change it to thumbs down. 

"Halls of Torment" is a vastly superior game where it counts, even though it looks much worse. especially because it keeps the Vampire survivors way how you receive damage.

the spacebar dodge is only more fun on paper. it just creates this incentive to make you *have to dodge all the time* - making the game into a dodge simulator, not a vampire-survivor-like game

this game is way too hectic and not chill at all. *but* this can be solved if they make sure the damage circles are <VISIBLE> always though models and skills/spells.

and they really need to fix that you can just get stuck on geometry, or have the game make it look like you can dash through, and then you can't

and show those from the same day on the top always.

Soulstone Survivors is a horde-survival action game with roguelite elements (similar to e.g. Halls of Torment) . It's very well-polished both visually and in gameplay mechanics. There are huge number of playable characters with their own lines of weapon progression, and a large number of enemy types as well.

The visuals are stylized, low-poly graphically (think Minecraft but with better fidelity). Some people will dislike this style intuitively, but I think it looks great (the color palette is really well managed, for one thing). It also means the game will generally run well, even if you don't have a top-of-the line GPU.

Mechanically, the game is very tightly designed. Movement is responsive, which is crucial, because you will spend a lot of time running and dodging enemy attacks. The core of the combat is based on selecting skills as you level up during each run. The attacks trigger automatically, so you can just focus on positioning (at higher difficulties this is more than enough challenge) and you can also aim certain skills. Making smart selections for your active and passive skills, and especially trying to achieve synergies between them, is important. Essentially, the skill system is a deck-building mini game.

As a rogulelike, once you finish a run, your character will return to lvl 1 the next time you play: you will have new randomly-generated options for skills. However, there is also a pretty robust progression and unlock system for characters between runs: you can unlock new weapons as well as a separate set of permanent skills on the skill tree. You unlock both mostly by spending materials you earn from doing runs, with rarer materials coming from harder runs (there is a "curse" system you can use to up the difficulty as you progress.) Importantly, as far as I have seen, there are *NO* microtransactions of any kind: you can only "buy" things with materials earned in-game. This is obviously a very welcome design.

The music is also really great. Techno/dance-inspired, but with some other elements woven in. It definitely matches the frenetic pace of the gameplay.

The game isn't perfect, of course:  I wish there were more levels, and I wish the levels they had felt more different (they are all the same size and dimensions, and there are only a few real environmental elements to interact with mechanically). I think they should also have more bosses ("Lords") as you will quickly get used to seeing the same ones over and over. There are also a few very minor quality-of-life things (controller support is good but is a bit lacking in menus. This won't affect combat or movement, though.)

These negatives though are *far* outweighed by the positives. If you like this genre of game, it is definitely worth your time.

So, here's the thing about soulstone survivors - well on the positive side its certainly very colourful to look at and....umm well thats about it for the positives really.

The major PROBLEMS with the game are its numerous bugs chief among these being the inability to quit out of the game without stalling/locking the steam deck. Then theres the fact of its competition in the form of the VASTLY superior Vampire Survivors. Soulstone Survivors just feels massively clunky in comparison.
The in game menus and skill tree upgrades come across as needlessly cluttered and confusing and constantly having to swap out abilities/buffs during in game combat is extremely irritating/annoying.

combines the overcomplications and longevity-required playstyle of an RPG with an auto shooter / quick in-out survivor game. it's astonishingly grindy to get unlocks and they actually only do 'so much' to change up the gameplay. 

you basically progressively up the difficulty to keep up with the [horrifyingly?] gigantic meta-progress tree so the difficulty stay pretty linear but the visibility and slowdown goes insane [unless you turn off the effects in which case it just looks weird and empty] i kept playing for a lot of hours hoping to get some unlocks or more levels that felt like a real change but ultimately it's just not that fun to play and waaaay to grindy for a game devoid of story or meaningful unlocks to make playing the same runs over and over and over feel rewarding.

TLDR - i understand combining genres is the new secret sauce but minimal survivor game X slow progression RPG is a fail

The game is incredibly fun. It's like if you took the Torchlight 2 experience and hyper-condensed into a roguelite session instead of a persistent character, but also greatly expanded the build diversity/depth potential. I love the colorful and simple animations, but you will eventually reach a point where there's too much stuff on screen and you'll want to lower the spell effect opacity to around 25% just to be able to see the attacks you want to dodge.

Music is on point. Very pleasant and fun.

The rune system gives you quite a bit of flexibility to try different build ideas, even on the same class.

The only real downside is that there's a bit of initial grind to completely unlock the central hub of the skill tree before you can access the class trees, but if you focus on clearing each map with all curses on, you'll get through it pretty quickly. Don't farm lower difficulty settings until you have unlocked the highest ones. It's just not time efficient and will make that early grind feel worse than it is.

Loads of things to unlock and earn, tons of achievements, and the characters you unlock have awesome and unique abilities. This game is totally worth the money. I really hope the creators stick with what they're doing because this game just took my #1 fav spot!

After getting a few good hours into this game i'm finding myself getting burnt out on it. There seems to be a point that you will arrive at where if you don't go with "meta" builds, you're not going to live to get to the last of the run. There will get to be sooo many ads that you can't even breathe. Red circles EVERYWHERE constantly to where you'll soon find yourself getting annoyed and frustrated. The game could use some balancing for the abilities as well as the characters. There are a good chunk of the abilities in the game that are pretty much useless at the higher tiers of the game and there's only a small pool of the characters that can handle the higher level difficulties. The game is fun, up until you get to curse level 3. Then it turns into a grindy sweat fest. Lots of scenarios where it seemed like certain surfaces had a layer of gorilla glue and caused you to be stuck in place for a second. This may seem minor, but just wait until you're being tailed by a graphics card destroying crowd of mobs or several of the boss lords at once. It sucks to be at the tail end of a run and get killed and lose all your rewards. 

game is okay, but needs some re working and balancing done.

I bought about 5 rogue like survivor games the past couple months and this is my favorite so far.
Easy to get into, quick or long games, balanced progression, and instant gratification ( very rewarding feeling gameplay even as a new player who hasn't unlocked anything)  Only $10, this game is awesome!

i cant recommend the game in the state its in, crashes are abundant, and for a game like this its absolutely awful. For a game in early access, there is A LOT to do. each stage has up to 5 difficulty each with progressively more difficult modifiers. game starts out easy and then gets to a point where it gets challenging in a good way. levels are seemingly endless per run and can allow for a lot of different builds. from aoe to group to single target damage. along with damage over time builds. each character also has 4 different weapons you can unlock that each have their own skills and different play styles. on top of that, there is a rune system that has a bunch of different options. each different rune has a different way of unlocking it. whether it is a timed challenge or getting to a certain prestige level with each character. there is also a skill tree, which each character has their own tree once you finish the main tree and when you get each character to level 20. if you want a game with plenty of content for a long while this is easily hands down an easy recommendation.
Fun Vampire Survivors clone with a lot of unlockables and loadout customization. AoE can get a bit hectic in higher difficulties though

[h1] This game is FANTASTIC [/h1]
From character variety to skill variety. Soulstone Survivors will keep you engaged for hours as you unlock its secrets.
The flow of each "run" is its biggest strength, along with is daunting difficulty scale if you decide to delve deeper. all though some builds are completely shadowed by others, they are still satisfying to get firing on all cylinders. 
The game itself is the final boss, can you crash it? you definitely have the tools to try.
If you are familiar with this type of game, level up, pick a choice from skills or passives, and enjoy them, you cannot go wrong purchasing this game.

All though I do recommend this game, it does have a small issue with identity.
where it tries to be complex, it becomes a bit tedious.

[spoiler][h2] Things I would want changed in the game [/h2]
[b] GET. RID. OF. THE. CRAFTING. SYSTEM! [/b]
I see where they wanted to go with their crafting system, its great in theory.
For this game though? it just doesn't work, it isn't fun, its a chore to get you new unlock. I already work towards unlocking the weapon, and now I have to get resources to unlock it? nope, not fun.

[h3]Introduce more feats of skill to unlock new content.[/h3]
  don't get hit for X amount of time. this could also encourage using block.
  survive X amount of time with increasing health, armour or movement speed ect.
  complete a run using only common and uncommon upgrades.
The options are limitless, this can obviously replace the crafting system. Rather then having the weapon unlock at a certain level it could unlock after achieving a feat of skill

[h3]Change some of the character special ability[/h3] to fit the games archetype more. this game requires movement, a lot of movement. so playing a class that needs to stop, or focus of their ability, feels, hmmm bad.
the two best characters to explain this are The Spellblade and The Sentinal. Their abilties require to much attention, and in end game content just arn't viable, and quiet frustrating.[/spoiler]

[h2]In conclusion.[/h2]
This game has potential to be top tier, the dev team has produced a great product that deserves the play time. just play it.

After spending more time with Soulstone Survivor, my perspective on the game has evolved. Initially, the overwhelming graphics hindered my enjoyment, but tweaking the settings made it much more accessible. Now, with a comfortable visual experience, I've found the game to be surprisingly addictive.

The inclusion of pet and zombie builds adds a strategic depth that enhances the challenge and enjoyment. While there's room for improvement in enemy variety and additional content, Soulstone Survivor offers a satisfying and enjoyable experience. If you're an action RPG enthusiast who appreciates pet and zombie builds, it's definitely worth a try.
Super in depth progression system, dozens of skills, passives and such. Can't wait for more to be added to this game!

Fun.

Ehhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh. This is a maybe for sure. There's a ton of fun to be had here - the abilities are fairly varied and flashy and a lot of the builds can feel different, the rune system + weapon system (plus the new character-based skill trees) are a good way to change it up in a lot of ways.

The problems you run in to are twofold: To get the highest tier materials, you HAVE to turn all the curses on to max. This turns the game into one where realistically only a few ways to build work and even then you have standouts where doing anything else is hurting you. The reason it gets so restrictive is the absolutely unending spam of red circles (projectiles, slam attacks, AoE attacks, whatever) coming at you - they happen when you kill enemies, they happen AGGRESSIVELY every minute or so when a bombardment tower spawns (that you then have to dash straight towards and kill to get any breathing room), and the bosses screen-covering attacks which mean you want to be hitting as many things as possible at all times, ideally when they're not even on screen.

You pretty much have to turn the visual transparency to max which takes out a lot of the "feel" of going fire over poison, for example, to be able to see. Also all you do is move and dodge red circles, there's really no more to it than that on max curse, no playing around with things, etc. That would be fine if it were an optional difficulty but it isn't if you want to craft weapons (which you do, they unlock more content!). Turning off the curses for the towers and the after-enemy-death meteors especially helps de-escalate the red circles a ton, but those are mandatory too.

The problem on top of this is the clearly poorly balanced material farming rates. You have to have curse maxed out to even see the high tier ones, but also the lowest 1-2 tier materials are what you need the most of by a landslide. Spending 10-15 minutes per run farming to get 1/6 of the material needed to craft 1 weapon for 1 character is nonsense, and that's WITH the high level rune to increase material rate by 50%. So you're rerunning the same 1 map 6-7 times in a row with the same runes, same curse, same build, because anything else might slow you down, and you get to unlock 1 of dozens of weapons (more of which are coming). I know I've highlighted this (and some others have posted about it as well) to the devs for months and it's one of the things they just have not acknowledged - apparently they must think it's fun this way, but I don't.

Keep in mind, this is when I had 100% unlocks going into a new patch, with abundant materials leftover from playing each of the new weapons, and I still fell short of literally every new weapon released. I have almost 60 hours in from the initial release and It'd take me probably another 10 of dedicated grinding, no actual variety, to unlock the rest of the weapons in the game as of this post. 

The REQUIRED highest tier of difficulties need to be reworked to be more interesting and interactive, and the material rates (or costs) need to be overhauled badly. Those two changes would make me put this in the "recommend" but right now it actually feels like a bullet heaven that doesn't respect your time, it almost feels GaaS-like in the grind requirements, and frankly? F that. This genre is great because in 10-30 minutes you can have a whole fun experiment and then do it again, Soulstone Survivors asks "what if you didn't actually get to do that?" and the answer is, it gets boring fast.

There is a lot of things to unlock, the game is big and getting bigger.

Soulstone Survivors is a great addition to the garlic-like genre. It ticks all the right boxes with massive amounts of enemies, unlockables, and flashy graphics. There is, to an extent, build diversity, given the fact that some classes can't unlock magic skills and vice versa. A couple minutes into the match, the screen becomes very crowded and if you're planning to play endless or overlord mode, better prepare for slight seizures. The soundtrack can be very hit or miss. I like the kickass attitude but there are a couple of tunes that tend to get on my nerves pretty quickly.

A huge skill tree and loads of achievements keep the game interesting and a (basic) crafting option unlocks new weapons with new skills for each class. Still, if you're going for 100%, be prepared to grind. It is a fun game that lacks a bit of personality but that doesn't stop me from playing round after round.

Cute, well executed combat. But the game is soulless. It has the tropes, you level up, you progress, but eventually you realise that all characters are the same, and there's little variety in monsters/bosses.

It took me hours to realise it, but once I did - it was a huge disappointment. 

Huge talent tree? - yeah, +1% damage, +1% cast speed etc. That's all it is.
Craftable weapons? - yeah, different icons, but same stuff, out of some 80 weapons, there are only 4-5 actually different ones.
Different levels? - tiny arenas with little set dressing, a couple of trees and walls. That's it.

My main gripe with the gameplay is that it's not balanced beyond 15 minutes of gameplay or so. After that you can litterally not tell what's going on on screen, it's just white flashes. You can't see monsters, you can't see where you are or if your character is moving even.

I feel like this game was developed by a competent team, but designed by marketing team trying to tick as  many boxes as they could.

I love this genre. I have nearly 100 hours in Vampire Survivors and 360+ in Brotato. I played Soulstone Survivors in Oct 2022 during NextFest and thought this game had real potential, so I bought it and promptly forgot about it in a Brotato-induced fog. I picked it back up a month or 2 ago, and tonight achieved ultimate glory in getting 100% achievements. 

Was it worth it? I don't know. I haven't clocked in at work, showered, shaved, seen my family, or eaten in 3 weeks. But I have digital godhood and my little blue ribbon to prove it! (I'm also down about 20 lbs from the not eating thing... don't recommend that part.)

Is SS worth it? 100% yes. The beginning will suck. Getting past Tier 5 maps sucks. Grinding for resources can either suck or be tons of fun. I made it fun by playing with weird character combos and stumbled across some really OP stuff. (Chaos Paladin anyone? Arachnid Master? Hallo?) In the end, I love every change that's been made, all of the additions, the gameplay, even the "dodge'em simulator" the game becomes at high levels. 

Now what do I do until the next update? Anyone wanna be friends?

The game is good until you start doing around curse 5 where it just becomes impossible. The game is just hoping you don't get hit by the hundreds of red dmg projections on your screen. What makes this even better is the fact that some of these are lingering effects! And you'd think these types of effects would do a pretty meager amount of dmg if you dashed through them of touched them for a fraction of a second, right? Nope. 20% of your hp gone. And this scales into taking direct damage as well. Bosses will just straight up one shot you for being on screen with them. Which makes it impossible to close the distance and actually do damage. And with this new update there's some enemies that will just bring your framerate to a near halt when they attack, making dodging even more impossible.

Overall, the difficulty scaling makes no sense at all. The difference between curse 4 and 5 is insane and it only gets more insane from there.
There is a ton to do honestly cant wait to dive more into all the content this game has to offer. With every build being viable it makes it easy to want to try out everything.

Pro 
-Fun combat with many weapons and abilities 
-5 levels more to come total 10 levels
-Skill tree is big still work in progress
-Many Runes to pick from 

Cons
-Grind is to much for new weapons. Their is 42+ weapons to unlock each one cost a ton of resources. 63 more to be added so much grind to get.(Reduce the resource cost)
-Enemy health gets into millions,billions, trillions, and etc.
-Curse levels should unlock for multiple levels if you choose to hit continue to other levels and beat that level also. Reduce the grind a little.
-Some abilities get to big so you can't see when to dodge.
-100% the game a pain

ah man holy shit do i like this game. takes the best parts of vs (gameplay loop, upgrades, builds etc) and changes the few things I didn't quite like about vs (30 min timer, lack of character development aside from random golden eggs and initial base upgrade list) for the better. the skill trees for each char give a hell of a lot of customization into how you want to play and spec, which is a gamechanger for these style of games. i also really commend the visual style of the game as it is one of the few survivor type games that i can visually keep track of what is occuring on screen at least until very very late game runs where it doesn't matter much anyways. i could go on for so long about what makes this game great to me but i will conclude this review with a wholehearted recommendation to try this game out if you are a fan of the genre.

A lot of improvements were made over the last few months. Updates are kinda slow, but there's plenty of grind already here if you're up for it. Death Knight isn't really viable still since dash is pretty mandatory at higher levels. Other than that, it's a good reverse bullet-hell. Looking forward to future updates.

I would recommend it if you like games where you try to survive for as long as you can. I don't want to say Vampire Survivor like because there is so much more going on in this than Vampire Survivor. I don't really care for the unlocking of different characters though. Some of them unlock from achievements, I guess, and others you unlock from gems? I'm not 100% on how they all get unlocked, but one way or the other would be a lot better than having to do both. 

I will say getting the achievements feels rewarding. I just did an infinite run with the Paladin and got a BUNCH of achievements when I finished and it felt good. So this game will give you that dopamine hit you are looking for. I will say, if you have epilepsy, or suffer from seizures, this game is probably NOT for you lol. On the infinite style runs the weapons get wild in how they activate. I couldn't even keep track of what was going on lol. I had so many things flying out of me, into me, onto them, most of them just laid on the ground lol. I think I actually knocked them onto the ground, anyway, it was a fun time, but lots of flashes, and things flying around. 

So I definitely recommend it, but just know there are a lot of flashes and things flying around the screen.

If you are a fan of this new "reverse bullet hell" genre, this is the A+ game to have.  I've tried them all, and it doesnt get better than this.  This game offers many ways to play, and yet everything is pretty well balanced.  And even as things are well balanced, the characters feel different enough that your choices matter.  This must have been a nightmare for the poor soul in charge of balancing but a top notch job was done.  So many skills are available, most of them good in their own way.  So many characters available, all of them unique in their own way.  Nearly endless progression is availible, yet you dont need to be maxed out to do the maps and play the game.  I just cant imagine the work that the folks assigned to game balance would have had to do to pull this off.  Updates take a while, but they are always big meaty updates with loads of good content.  This team obviously values quality, it shows.  You arent going to find anything else like this game in the same league.  Grab it, enjoy it.  When you wear out on it, just set it aside for a little while and wait, before long another high quality, crazy big update will surely drop and you can resume "Surviving!"

Soulstone Survivors has been an enjoyable game to play. The amount of customisation has been surprisingly good, and the variety of skills, characters and mechanics implemented, along with the runes, additional weapons, and curses has given me plenty of replayability. The action is fast paced, but not overly punishing (although it can get a bit annoying at higher curse levels), and the levels are targeted at a 10-15 minute completion time (typically), which makes it easy to pick up, play, and then move on when you haven't got a huge amount of time to spend.

The additional content being added has been a delightful surprise and very enjoyable, and while the experience isn't 100% bug free, I think that in  my ~80 hours /played, I've maybe run into a couple bugs that were in any way noticeable? If there were more, I'm drawing a blank on them.

My one biggest complaint with the game is that of visual overload due to spell animations, which you can address using a slider under graphics settings to make special effects more transparent. The biggest problem there, I find, is that with high multicast and AoE levels, you basically have to make spell effects entirely transparent if you want to be able to see what's going on. Ideally, I would love to see a dynamic transparency option added (making effects more transparent according to how many there are) because I feel like having all of my spells being invisible to me for the sake of playability really makes them feel less impactful (but I do appreciate having the control to do so-- definitely not sorry that it's an option).
Great game, many different ways to play and constantly being updated

30 hours in update:
