It's a fun game but visually there's just too much happening. Go to Settings and under Graphics turn down "Special effects visibility", it's needed to see where the danger is.

Another thing is get ready to fly across the map and die, it's one of the more frustrating things for me in this game. Sometimes there's just so much AoE that if you get hit once you'll get knocked back into other danger and get knocked back again, rinse repeat and die.

I also wonder what the point of health and armor is, it's not worth investing into those and other defensive stats at this point. It's better to just go on full offense and clear the field imo.
Brazilian Phonk + Soulstone Survivor = Better than Sex (Not really, but you get me)

I liked it at first, the higher curses quickly makes it unfun though. It reaches a point where there's too much stuff going on screen and you can't tell what's what anymore (I've already played around with the settings to reduce effects). I have died several times to exploding goblins (that I couldn't see) that push me into a boss' aoe attack, and since attack and movement speeds of enemies keep increasing it reaches a point where you just can't do anything about it. The grind for minor soulstones (main currency) is real too, my characters are leveling far faster than the currency I get after completing a round. This wouldn't be a big deal if there were a lot of stages to play on but there's only a handful, making things rather repetitive. The skill tree is also pretty boring, it consists of stuff like "increase critical damage by x%" or "increase cast frequency by x%". The lack of rune loadouts is rather confusing, runes can be a pretty powerful mechanic and each character has access to different weapons with different pros and cons so it would make sense some runes go better with certain weapons than others.

Game definitely needs some more polish, I'll keep playing a bit since I can't refund it anymore but I do think it's best to wait for a few more months as of writing this review to buy it.

EDIT (after frostborn wrath release)

They've somewhat improved visuals by allowing folks to tweak certain things, all of my other complaints are still valid though. I tried out the new update but after a match I got bored. I feel like there are other similar games that do this genre better. Still don't recommend this game.

I have had this game ever since the few first updates, and i am in awe of how the devs keep adding amazing things to the game, the constant expansion to the basic systems that were there in the beggining are just mind boggling to me! 

With that out of the way, I can safely say, that the game is just a joy to play, i will have to try it from the start again, as currently i have the oversight of a person who's had their progress at near constant 100% so i can't say nothing about the grind of the game, but the gameplay loop is incredibly satisfying, the game flows great, the skills and synergies are a delight to collect, the characters and their builds can feel very different from each other, and it's very suprising that a single weapon unlock is able to make the least enjoyable character, a wholly new experience!

It's safe to say that this game is slowly starting to take shape as an incredible experience, but i will now stop myself from playing, and come back to see a fuller picture. But given how the game already has as much content as it has, is definitelly giving me a lot of hope!

I really want to recommend this game because it's an absolute gem. The reason I can't, is because there is no way to know how many skills are in this game. I want to know what skill belongs to what types before I go on a run so I can theory craft and create builds or try new things out that I haven't before. Only way to do that? Either take about 500 screenshots of every single skill and flip through that insanely large album of photos or memorize every single skill and typing. This information is all in the game already because it's there on the skill select screen.

Great game, similar to Vampire Survivors, but has twin stick targeting and dodging. Plays great with KBM or controller. Excellent Steam Deck game. The graphics can get a little busy to the point of obscuring your vision, but the options allow you to customize colors and opacity, as well as turning off effects. This is great when you're on a slower machine and playing a super enemy-heavy run.

The devs have a roadmap full of new unlocks, enemies, and QOL improvements. Winter and Spring updates have been fun and brought new toys to play with. I'm happy I bought this game in early access and I'm looking forward to the full release. Definitely worth the price if you like these kind of games.

Best and most complete roguelike survival game I've played to date.  Smooth gameplay, fun leveling and unique skills tied with an engrossing upgrading system with blacksmithing weapons and a huge passive tree that make this game a must-play for people that enjoy this genre.

Game is extremely addictive and good, but unpolished. I got all the achievs, so I feel obliged to give The feedback:

- Please Add Spells catalogue/Pokedex with option to filter by types and search by name. Probably No.1 QoL change for me. - ADDED ON ALPHA, THANK YOU!
- Beastiary would be cool, to see stats/abilities/weaknesses of enemies, as we discover them.
- Characters need more weapons. Most resources are being completely unused at the moment. Maybe some sort of upgrading system here? Seems too basic in current form, could go many directions. - ADDED
- Runes system. It seems to be the "end-game" features, as is locked behind a bit of a grind. However, it feels not impactful. There's literally few cool runes, where vast majority is boring copy-paste with barely any impact on the game. Honestly, re-design the whole runes system. But if you have to keep it in the similar format, please make runes more interesting. Maybe make each take 1 slot, where you have max 3-5 slots. Balance the runes out, get rid of boring ones. Add some potential synergies for builds into runes. Something like that.
- Skill Tree. Uh oh... I'm a huge Ability/Skill/Talent Tree enjoyer, but not the one in this game. It does not give any flexibility, it's literally "grind, unlock and forget". Make real trees, with points limit, so you cant have everything. Also, make some checkpoints within each tree, so mixing could be an option. Overall, the tree in its current form is rather a grind-it-out bar, than a Skill Tree. Feels unnecessary, a bit confusing too. CORRECTED NICELY
- Achievements, so the real progressing in this game. Spells/runes slots and characters unlocking via the Achievement system is ok. 

Summarizing, the gameplay, modes, curses and difficulty is on point. Game is fluid, responsive, addictive, it's good. Progression and personalisation systems however, seems a bit out of place. I feel like there's no room for theorycrafting, outside of abilities combo (which is pretty much random ingame). Gamers love theorycrafting.With impactful Runes, flexible Talent Tree, more weapons and customisation, game would be insanely good. (Spells catalogue is top priority tho).

Much from my feedback list has already been added/corrected. I can't say a bad word about the game nor the dev/s.

Great take on VS, 3D graphics, aiming, loads of upgrades to unlock. 

I have just scratched the surface at 11 hours, and that's good.

Despite looking good its a game without DEPTH - it has no specific classes builds, everything is kinda universal, no real synergies, no trade-offs. It is like a pretty looking girl which ruins things the moment she speaks.

You find out (but just at the end of your run - oh great design choice there) that one ability deals -way- more damage than others. One example is golem. Is the reason your particular build? NO (there is no particular build in this game) - golem will simply always do a lot of damage. Will also keep many mobs and bosses busy - so is a no brainer - you pick golem u are in for the long run.

Very easily (and I mean very easily) you will find yourself just running around with pumped stats (huge aoes, extreme fast spamming, applying poison, fire, frail, frost, doom, and many many other effects which do not really matter). Can you say it feels good? Can you say you feel that choosing frost over poison made a difference? Not really - you haven't really contributed to this steroid build, except maybe you avoided choosing bad when leveling up (where often, not always but too often, have a choice between really strong buffs with minor ones)

And then you might die in just one boss hit :)) And what I mean by that is I was choosing repeat at the end of the level and did that 3 times. I was on my 4th repeat. My barbarian had his first attack bigger than my screen and was spinning faster than ice skaters are doing air pirouettes. Fast as a Formula 1 car. Spells were huge, I was bombarding mobs way better than russians bombed Mariopol, if you know what I mean. A boss hit and I was dead - :))

Design is far from being thorough, where careful choice matter. Another cheap design choice is the 'invitation' to grind hours long  to upgrade your characters and stats (no joke here, it seems it will take literally take a huge amount of hours to upgrade your characters). Characters which always end up playing the same - a frantic move around and do nothing else except maybe trying to see between your spells you cast 20 times per second.

Go Vampire Survivors or Halls of Torment if you like this stuff. Way better

Short Version - Pretty Great Game

Long Version - First things first, I gotta say that the soundtrack really slaps in this game, particularly on the whispering grove. It's got a very unique sound to it and I am here for it. 

The game is pretty simple, you auto attack while mainly focusing on movement control and sometimes directional attacks, but there is an option to auto-aim at the nearest enemy to allow you to just focus on movement which is a pretty nice accessibility feature, although I still prefer manual aim myself.

The different skills from the different schools are very interesting and the fact you can use runes and the level up system and different weapon choices allow for a wide variety and mish mash of playstyles with all the different heroes! You want to be a necromancer houndmaster? Go right ahead! You wanna be a wizard barbarian? Ponder your Orb and Master the arcane you wonderful savage, you! Want to be a mage that beats people with your stick? Well.. do I have news for you! There are all sorts of wonderful builds you can make work, and its up to you to find the playstyle that suits you.

There is quite a bit of content and well worth the $10 investment and the game is still in early access stages. I can't wait to see more!

The only complaint I really had was the screen would get cluttered with visual effects from all the abilities constantly going off and making it where I couldn't see the markers on the ground to dodge, but unlike some other games this one has a handy dandy setting that lets you shift the transparency of abilities to make it easier to see the ground markers. You can even practically make the abilities invisible if you so choose, but I've found a happy medium at around 70-75% of the slider where I still see the spectacular visuals, but can also see the ground markers.

Highly recommend giving this game a shot!

What sort of kills it for me it's the lack of class coherence. 
Why am i a Pyromancer who's best build is lightning.. a frostbolt spamming archer, a golem summoning assassin (funny enough this one is absolutely necessary if you want to play the assassin at all).
Why have classes at all if you are not forced or at least incentivised towards class specific themes. How does a bit more damage, crit and area of effect designate me as a "pyromancer".

Bringing the classes more in line with their theme would in my opinion both reduce RNG/ skill pool bloat, And visual strain on the eyes (by at least having mostly the same colors on the screen.

Everyone being a "rainbow" is not my thing.

Anyway.. since complaint is majorly subjective.. the game is recommended.

Updated review: Developer has added in much more meta progression since my original review. Tons of new skills to unlock as well as passive stats to unlock for about 8 characters at the moment, with all characters to receive them eventually through updates. I would say at this point the price is fair due to these additions which allow much more progression to work towards.

Overall the game is fun - maybe a bit over priced at the moment. There is lots of characters and achievements, and the runes are OK but I feel the meta progression overall is a bit lacking.

You'll have almost all the meta skills maxed in ~10-15 hours and from there it's just down to achievement grinding to unlock the remaining runes and characters/weapons.
The unlocks are great but the power increase seems to stop too soon since you can max out the skill levels fairly quickly. Adding more meta skills to work towards would be very welcomed, especially since there's a lot of grinding character ranks to unlock the remaining things, which feels too repetitive knowing you're as powerful as you're going to get from then on apart from some good RNG skill rolls during a match.

Yes it's early access and more will be added, I just think $5-$6 is a fairer price for where the game is currently at. It's still fun though and I enjoy it overall so I will recommend it.

Alot of the negative reviews I see are actually why I really enjoy this game over other rougelikes. The scaling of your own power can go crazy high to the point where your abilities have full uptime and span across your entire screen, almost every run on max chaos will devolve into this, but I view that as a major upside, it actually feels like you are getting stronger and evolving as a run goes on, and obviously to combat this the enemies have to scale just as hard. Keeping in mind, the game only becomes a bullet hell on the hardest of difficulties, so if people dont like that, they should probably not play on the hardest difficulty. Speaking of which I have even seen people say that you can only play a select number of builds as on the higher difficulty its not possible to use other stuff, but that is a flat out lie lol. To get every characters weapons and levels in the hundreds Ive played every different ability and build possible MULTIPLE times, and never once did I feel like I had to play anything specific on the maximum difficulty.

In conclusion, I eagerly await future updates and think not only the scaling feels rewarding and fair for both player and enemies, but also really enjoy not feeling like I ever have to play one specific build and had plenty of content to unlock before I ever ran out of stuff to do.

It is hard to get a truly good run off of the ground due to the excessive amount of abilities that are in the game. For the price, one of the better entries in the genre. It is very grindy, and gets old (at least to me, YMMV) long before reaching the end of the content, but I feel I got my entertainment buck out of it. The early stages and unlocks are pretty fun, a twist in this game is that, even though you have plenty of auto-aim and AoE weapons to choose from, you can also manually aim directional weapons making it a twin-stick shooter hybrid. 
You also have the ability to dodge for a couple i-frames which seems like a fun addition. More advanced enemies have telegraphed attacks indicated by danger markers, and you need to use your dodges to escape these danger zones quickly. Also the game is well-optimized, so slow-down/frame drops are less common in this game than many others like it, despite being 3D instead of sprite-based. So that's all good. 

There are class skills to unlock which make each character more powerful and more distinctive in playstyle. As you start to level up your classes, you will need materials you can only obtain by turning up the "curse" level (difficulty modifiers).
Past a certain point, the difficulty became less of a challenge and more of a tedium, sessions stretches from the cozy ~10 minutes of the earlier game into half hour slogs. The ground becomes basically lava from all the area attacks and without the right builds, you can barely even approach the bosses to land hits. 

Some other complaints might be the menu system is kinda messy and hard to navigate, the music while not terrible is almost hypnotically repetitive and boring which is not a good fit, some of the class abilities are basically worthless at higher levels. Despite all the enemies on screen, the game feels slow-paced.

At this point it's a game I'll pick up every day or two still to kill some time, but the novelty has worn off. That should be expected of most any game though, I'd say 50+ hours of cheap, mindless entertainment is more than reasonable for the price. If you really like this type of game though, there's a lot more content than that, probably at least twice as much so far, with more updates coming, at the time of this review.

Game starts off strong and quickly falls flat on its face. Late game has a small handful of actually viable strategies. The devs pride themselves on how many abilities there are in the game, but the vast majority of them aren't playable at higher difficulties. 

What's more, difficulty is scaled by just increasing the number of attacks that are being thrown at you, so lategame consists of spamming the dodge button as much as you can and increasing your range to try to damage enemies that you can't actually afford to approach. 

This rules out about half the characters from being competitive. The actual endgame meta strat for a lot of characters is to use a rune that gives them abilities of other characters to make them playable.

Editing this later to say that the devs are releasing another, different game while this one is still in early access. HIGHLY recommend that you avoid, it's obvious they have no intention of fixing this game's issues. You'll get a few hours out of it and then realize it's a shallow cash grab that they've moved on from.

The game was fun for a few hours, assembling a build and dishing out massive damage like a god. Then the game beings a massive grind to continue unlocking features, and it never really gains any depth.
You earn tons of skill upgrades each run. The only choice that seems to matter is the 6 "active skills" you take, but you can pretty easily get the exact build you want eventually. Then the rest of the upgrades just involve taking the option with the biggest number for the biggest damage.

Another fun take on the vampire survivors formula with more control over build and characters. Admittedly less unique unlock requirements compared to vs, but still fun to grind regardless. Runs loop between stages and get exponentially harder, so you get to savour a build longer than the 20 minute cycle of vs. 

You can choose up to 5 perks (once you build up to them) for each run and then get 6 autocasting abilities during the run, which you can swap out as others are presented to you, or upgraded. Each ability has a number of types associated with it which allow for big gains by matching these (getting lots of abilities with the AOE type, for instance), which can be upgraded as a group (+ AOE range or damage). Highly recommend for the smaller pricetag, with content being added and reworked constantly.

So, I saw the success of Vampire Survivors, and I wanted to try out This genre of game, but the graphics of that game are so bad that I had to look around for alternatives.  I recently tried out 5 games in the same style, Army of Ruin, Brotato, Soulstone Survivors, Spirit Hunters & Yet Another Zombie Survivors.  These games are all $10 or less, and I got them all on sale. (Brotato is on sale for $3.99 at the time of this review).

All of these games provided enough fun to justify their purchase, but the two that stuck out to me were SoulStone Survivors & Yet Another Zombie Survivors.  Both of these games were easier to jump right into and start having fun with.  SoulStone felt like the most polished of the bunch, while YAZS felt like the rawest of the bunch for now, but maybe the most fun and with the best future potential.

Hey, wait for the Steam Fall or Christmas sale, and you could probably pick up all five for $20 or less. (and maybe one or two more).

But if you want to dip your toe in the water just to try your first one out, I would recommend Soulstone Survivors as my top pick, with YAZS being my second choice.

SoulStone Survivors in its current build is a game that is pretty fun for the first hour or so. SSS takes the mechanics from Vampire Survivor and removes the weapon enhancements for a synergy system. Active and Passive Actions have or are associated with characteristic. AA come with different traits such as 'Bomb, Frontal, Magical', then you can associate a bunch of PA to those traits, specifically or through a character trait i.e Bomb, Frontal, Magical. 

The whole system becomes convoluted as you attempt to weave in Core stats, Attack, Speed, MultiCast, Cast Speed, Armor, Crit rate, Crit Multiplier....., into your build. Game play plateaus when you hit level 40 at which point you are just kiting things as you get caught on the poor level design.

There are 4 levels right now, each classically skinned to be desert, snow, forest and mines. None of these levels really stand out and the only real reason to chose a level is for when you need to farm materials to upgrade a character's weapon. There are something like 13 different classes, each one with their own unique set of abilities that get added to the core ability pool. For the most part they all play the same, they only real difference are the the starting buffs and debuffs.  Which become easily compensated through leveling. 

Games like these are more of a time waster than anything, but  SSS is fun for the first hour. Unfortunately that fun levels off quickly. If your not into currency grinding you probably want to pass on this game. If you are in to currency grinding and unlocking you may want to pass on this game as well. There is no reliable way to do an endless run. Most times you beat a level and are told to 'Return', but which they mean the main menu. 

My summary, The game starts off promising but offers no reliable way for the game to evolve with the player. Do to the game's experiencing capping out rather early I can only hope they address the game in a way they simplifies things while making the overall more intuitive and challenging, something that will make want to be invested in it. SSS in its current stage is a glorified Idle game; and becomes something to look at when you need to kill some time. If they took the time to remove the convoluted skill tree/rune system with more a deck building/centered mechanic the game would be more sustainable in my opinion.

Soulstone Survivors, a satisfactory game for its price point.

+ Every achievement in the game has been completed for me bar a few weapon unlocks within 70 hours of gameplay, that is more than acceptable considering its price of $13 CAD.
+ Content felt interesting and challenging up until I finished every map on Curse VII.
+ Rune unlocks were unique and fun to strive towards.

- Upon beating Curse VII on each map, game became very repetitive / redundant material farming spree, even with the 50% bonus material rune on each character
- Specific talent point trees for characters is fun, but an expanded generic talent tree would be more compelling and allow for more build specific investment
- Chaos Golem / Moose minions, pulling aggro from bosses makes the game a cake walk and I was frequently able to complete Curse VII runs on level 1 prestige characters while trying to unlock all achievements.

The game is under currently development and is new, but fundamentally it is a pleasant experience which becomes a dodge-em / bullet hell under higher difficulties. Further development towards the end game and alternate modes would make this game even more enjoyable. Finding a solution towards the material grind to make it less tedious and more in line with the completion of other aspects (runes. characters, map completions) would encourage me to put more hours in.
Waiting for the next update so I can fully use my other characters' Awakening skills!

After testing a lot of games like "Vampire Survivor" and buying some of them, I must say, this is by far my favourite one.
A run can end as soon as you want, since the goal is'nt time-based, it's kill-based.
The skilltree is really interesting, especially after unlocking further options.

And my absolute favourite part is, that each run "tells a story".
Dependend on which char you play, you get different active skills to choose from, and with runes and what not, you can create a very specific skillset.
And every single run I did so far was completely unique and got stuck in my head.

It ranged from running super fast while slashing enormous swords around to a char who applied with every skill a huge chunk of debuffs.
Or the bomb-flinging archer.
Or the pyromancer, who did a mix of fire and poison.

You can create so many "roleplay chars", which maybe don't deal the optimal amount of damage, but they are still good enough to carry you far and are extremely fun to play.
I can't stress enough hoch much I love the uniqueness of each char and run.

Another big plus is, that there is basically no contact damage.
Only one enemy, which is a suicide bomber, explodes on contant.
If you play well enough and have the dodging skill (your own, not in-game), you can get really far without getting harmed.

Highly recommended!

Surprising amount of depth, pretty forgiving. Great game with a lot of variety. Fights have good damage indications, even though it can get cluttered really fast, but the movement is fluid and helps a lot.

Big downside: The fun really begins after you had one or two god-runs, before that it is a slog. This can be improved greatly, and easily. The first few runs need to feel fun, not like "okay i need 5 more like this to unlock the first thing".

Other personal gripe, the first level in each run should come much faster. It takes almost a minute to reach level2-3, and even then, getting another ability is not guaranteed so it doesn't help the beginning feel good.

But besides those points, the game is great, and really has a lot of depth. I am just sad that it tends to act as a filter to most people given how boring the beginning is (of both runs, and savefile). In the (now flooded) market of vampire-survivors-like, the first runs are decisive as to wether or not people will stay, this has to be improved here. The rest is already there.

- You can aim your attacks (this is huge for me because it feels less like an idle game and more like you have actual control over your attacks.)
- A LOT of variety in builds (They are not all viable but it makes for some really interesting and fun build combos. Can access more abilities/skills as you level for each class to have access to.)
- A decent amount of characters to unlock (I think 14 at the moment and each has a different starting ability, 2-3 weapons each to unlock which change their starting ability, and have access to different pool of level up abilities that can be unlocked for the rest of your classes as you play.)
- A skill tree and runes (Skill tree affects ALL of your characters but the runes allow you to fine tune each class  and even allows them access to other classes level up ability pools.)

Things I did not like:
- Screen can get TOO busy (Some of your abilities are so big they hide enemy red circles and even enemies not killed by said abilities. There can be a LOT of your own abilities ALL going off at the same time and so it hides things in front and/or around your character.)
- Enemies spawning under and next to you (There is no player character zone that enemies cannot spawn into. I've had enemies spawn behind me and block me from moving. Would be a real QoL to have a player character zone that enemies can't spawn into.)
- Bosses with insanely long range attacks (The boss won't even be visible on your screen but you'll see their red attack box up to 2 screens away.)

Soulstone Survivors is a survivor-like / reverse bullet hell with a lot to offer and some interesting depth for the price point. The game is currently in Early Access, however, it feels extremely solid. No major UI or graphical issues and it supports 21:9 out of the box. The game features a "Class Ascension" system which allows some of the classes in the game to have a "pseudo" subclass during normal gameplay. It features an extensive skill tree & perk system (runes), and much more. I have only made it to roughly the halfway point, however, the game features a lot of replay-ability and it seems that achievement hunting in this title will not be an absolute chore. 

In terms of gameplay it diverges in the way the main gameplay loop functions. Instead of it being time based (e.g: Vampire Survivors, Halls of Torment, etc) it goes based on kills. Once "X" amount of kills has been achieved a boss will be summoned. Progressing in this manner will eventually give the player the option to end the round, continue on infinitely with mobs scaling higher and higher, or enter overlord mode where the bosses get even stronger and more spawn at once. Overall a very solid and rewarding gameplay loop. In addition, the game also features a "curse" system. This allows the player the opportunity to earn unique crafting materials, additional exp, and more at the cost of increased difficulty. 

Moving on, the character identity and progression system is extremely well done. The "general" skill tree is easy enough to follow and fill out while offering the player generic upgrades such as: more damage, crit chance, health, etc. Where the game truly shines, however, is in the "Class Ascension" portion of the skill tree for select characters. This allows these characters to have a whole ability that occurs during regular gameplay and essentially "unlocks" a new subclass for them. The perks are well thought and you can feel your characters power grow between matches. Furthermore, the Rune system (which is this games perk system) is rather creative and can allow for some unique gameplay differences across matches. I thoroughly enjoy the fact the game rewards players for ranking up and unlocking the different characters and their weapons. This directly unlocks new abilities for all characters in matches & new runes to select. 

In terms of the playable characters each are unique in both their identity, weapon choices, and overall skills. You can further refine this with rune selections to make some off the wall builds. Each character has a nice selection of "generic" abilities and "skill" abilities. Some are reskins of others, however, this does not bother me too much. I also like that each character has different stat allocations. E.g: More health, less movement speed, etc. Overall, I really enjoy the variety and none of the classes so far have felt too "samey".

In terms of overall content you will be hard pressed to find a better deal for the amount you receive. I have been playing over 40+ hours and I am still making my way through the multiple levels of curses, character weapons, and so on. So far the game feels incredibly feature complete which is shocking in today's gaming environment. I briefly mentioned earlier, that achievement hunting in this game feels natural and doesn't involve the player completely going out of their way or bashing their head. 

Now moving on to things I dislike:

The music in my opinion is awful. I know this is purely subjective but it just feels extremely repetitive and out of place for a game like this. I found myself turning the music completely off and playing something more exciting and thrilling in its place. Would love to see more music options down the road. 

The gameplay is fantastic and graphically it looks incredible, however, the game requires a machine at times to run. In the later levels or with your graphics maxed out you will realize how CPU / GPU intensive this game is as it tries to load all the mobs, their effects, your effects, and so on. I found that at times I had to bump the visible spell setting slider down just to finish more intensive matches which is a shame. The spell effects are put of the fun of this genre and I hope the developers can figure out a system to allow multiple spell effects to exist without chunking FPS.

Due to the infinite scaling nature of the game you will eventually reach a point where the bosses or mobs will straight up one shot you. I do not have a problem with this normally, however, in the higher difficulties there is so much ground clutter / boss ability spam that the whole level is covered in red and you are constantly spamming the space bar just to survive. Hopefully the mob / boss ability spam will be toned down in the future and just made to hit harder as a compensation. This would not only improve the overall gameplay experience but allow the game to run smoother also. 

To conclude, I absolutely believe that Soulstone Survivors is worth the price they are asking for. The game seems to have active and knowledgeable developers who care for the game and want to see it get better (this much is apparent from the most recent update). The main gameplay loop is extremely fun and fluid with unique characters for whatever play style you are looking for.  The game features an indepth perk system and skill tree system adds even more replayability to the title. Where the game suffers in my opinion is the music being repetitive and out of place, the higher level curses / levels where the ground is littered in enemy abilities, and finally being CPU and GPU intensive during higher levels of gameplay. If the developers improve the last two issues -- I would have no hesitation giving this game a 9.5/10.

TL;DR: Worth the price, however, it is a solid 7.5/10 due to certain issues found in higher levels coupled with the fact it is so graphically demanding that it requires the user to make on the fly spell effect / graphic adjustments just to complete a level.

Updated 2023-08-01:
The game is fairly fun. There are a lot of skills and the addition of character-specific passive trees is nice. The grind for new weapons is kind of awful. Many of them require loads of common resources that aren't as abundant as you'd like. Which means that it can take 5-10 runs on the same map just for a new weapon. Additionally, some of the characters have a custom ability that requires you to stand or move into specific areas. That would be great, but at higher curse levels, it's not viable. Gameplay is still built around high mobility, so anything that strips that from you turns into high risk, mediocre reward.

Don't get me wrong, the game is getting a lot better, but I'd give it a mixed review if possible. It's fun, but has some core issues.

Old: 
The game is very... okay. There are a lot of skills and characters that give you options for builds, but so many builds aren't exactly viable, especially at higher curse levels. The game is clearly built around high mobility, which is fine, but the biggest problem is that as you increase your curse level, enemies have massive AoE attacks that feel borderline impossible to dodge. As someone who has nearly every achievement, I can tell you that it's not impossible to do, but it stops being fun when you almost feel punished for doing the objective (e.g. Killing towers that launch attacks requires you to stay in a small area that will be bombarded enough that it will kill you. Do you choose to take damage, or ignore the tower knowing that more towers are on their way?).

The game has a lot of potential, but there's something about it that just isn't as fun as other competitors on the market.

The POE of survivorlikes, Soulstone offers a significant amount of control over your runs. Massive skill tree of permanent upgrades, runes to amp up certain abilities, weapon crafting, unique material farming, several dozen characters, the content here is extremely impressive given the price and competition. That being said, it might be too much for some, given the genre itself is about one handed controls and mindless gameplay. My only real critique is the sheer amount of shit happening at once. Its very common to have runs that have 20-50 explosions happening at once, both from you and the bosses. Chaos is the only way i can describe it, and it makes bullet hell aspect turn from strategic dodging and kiting, to running around like a chicken without a head.

I don't usually go this indepth for these kinds of games, but Soulstone is seemingly trying to be as deep as possible in the growing genre. The fact this is still in EA is shocking given the sheer size of the game already. $10 is extremely fair, but be prepared, you aren't stepping into a puddle, you're diving into a lake that's still being dug deeper.

I make my new metric of game goodness measurement "fun per gigabyte". This game sits at 2.37GB on my disk and my fun rating is 8 (out of 10) so the fun per GB is 3.38 rounded up. In comparison, if I got the same fun from a 100GB game, I would be at 0.08. That indicates a high disk space requirement to fun ratio for this game making it highly efficient fun and efficiency is what I strive for in my fun. Good job devs. Don't bloat it.

A solid experience all around, with few, if any, bugs. The game has several meta-progression systems that'll keep you occupied for a respectable amount of time. 

That said, the game has class balance issues(beyond even the advanced class system, which at this point in time benefits only half the available characters) that become very apparent in the late game. Some struggle to kill boss waves faster than the new ones appear and are heavily reliant on either summons or good RNG to do well, while others let you almost sleepwalk through the game even if you get bad rolls. While further class updates are likely to address this, at the moment this is the situation.

The last noteworthy thing to point out is that once you are late into a match and the whole screen is drowning in spells and enemies, the game has a tendency to bring your FPS to its knees. The commonly suggested solution of hiding damage numbers and health bars has, at least in my case, very minimal impact.

In closing, the game offers a lot of entertainment and has only a few truly noteworthy issues. For 10 euros/dollars, and considering it isn't finished yet, it is well worth checking out if you are into this type of game.

I like the game but devs should fix one fundemantal problem. 
Yeap, you guessed it correct. 
I'm talking about what every other person gave a thumbs down for; game simply forces you to play a dodge simulator... No matter how strong your build has become.

You can clear an entire screen? 
No problem; I throw you some red dots from offscreen enemies which you cannot see.

You can clear two screens? 
No problem; I've already sent you an undamageble reaper from the very start so move your lazy arse and work!

Also, shortly after some progress you **HAVE TO** turn of your animations and this is a big one because it takes all the satisfaction of your ZoomZoom build. I mean seriously, who thought people would enjoy that?

Edit: Game also has one of biggest design flaws I expect from the genre... *I'll punish you for getting stronger*. If you get movement speed to escape from red dots, they become increasingly harder to dodge, casting faster and punishes you for getting movement speed. You won't get the feeling of getting stronger and stomping around but you will feel the game tries really hard to keep you in check.

In its current state, at higher curse levels, it becomes a [i]'the floor is lava'[/i] game. It's essentially a dodging simulator. There are so many AoE markers going off from enemy attacks that you're constantly on the back foot running for your life. It was fun for a while, but now it's just monotonous.

It's the same with your own skills, which is made substantially worse with how the game scales. During a long run you'll get to a point where you've accumulated so much cast frequency/area(AoE) & multi cast chance modifiers that your spells will eventually cover your entire screen, essentially becoming a photosensitive epilepsy inducing headache. This brings me to my next point:

There's a setting in-game which allows you to lower the transparency of all skills. For me, this was lowered as far it would go as soon as I got to a point where the game became a seizure simulator, which wasn't long at all. Maybe an hour or two. I haven't turned it back up as higher curse levels pretty much require you to have this lowered as far as it will go if you want to see anything at all. 

I assume it's the same for most players. This means I, & I'm assuming a lot of other players, probably don't even know what the majority of skills look like? I know I don't. What's the point of going through the process of designing all of these cool looking skills if most players won't even be able to experience & appreciate them? Seems kind of pointless.

So, Game Smithing Limited. If you read this, tone down all the bullshit by about ~75%. It does not scale well in higher curse levels.

Update after 20h :
Most of my arguments are still valid and I still don't see a real point to go up un curses if not to farm/craft weapons that are almost always underwhelming, add passive skills (that are too long to farm and underwhelming too) or getting the unlocks or discovering new characters (that are all kinda the same with different skillset that you can use but not enough distinction between the way you play them imo).

However I must admit that the game is a huge blast in higher difficulties, incredibly hectic and fun. The amazing and on point soundtrack helps too. Though very very punishing when above 35 or something curses. And very demanding for the computer.
I also feel like there lacks a bit of balancing and I always tend to do pretty much the same builds and avoid a good third or more of the skills. Still feel like the build possibilities anddepth are too few and shallow but I concead it is not the easiest thing to do.

My main complaint is that the game is wayyy to farmy and there is nothing pushing me hard enough to play and farm (gets repetitive and I think once I'll have done all the maps in top difficulty I'll just stop and never farm for runes or passive skills or weapons, I just don't care).

Overall, it's still a lot of fun and I will get a good 30h out of this EA and surely at least 10 more out of the complete release. While I do have problems with the core mechanics of the game, if I cen enjoy it for a good 40/50h and then play it every so often, I'd say it was a good deal.
I do very much recommend it and recommend to quickly go and up the curses, the game will be more fun then. It's actually maybe the VS I had the most fun on. Not as polished as Brotato or even HoT but a lot of fun and more dynamic than any VS I've ever played when lots od curses.

Old review:
First off, it's definitely the most visually impressive VS like out there in my opinion. But it does require a much better configuration than most to run properly, especially when lots of mobs start to spawn and in endgame when everything is exploding everywhere. Little problem being that there does not seem to be a very wide gap in performance between low and high settings. So if you don't have a decent config forget it.

Now for the game itself. The simple fact that it can go so far in terms of build and make you feel like the god of death like no other VS makes it worth trying. The first few runs are super fun. Now, there are quite a few problems.

First off, the game might be too easy. My very first run was like 45 minutes long (I finished and looped once and died in loop 2 in overlord mode I believe). My second longer and my third too long (like 70/75 minutes and 5 or 6 loops (not in overlord) or something). And each loop only seems to scale the ennemies up in terms of damage/health. Does not add anything. So my third run and it's several loops was tideaous to say the least. There are ways to make the game more difficult (curses) but the bonus those give seems not that interesting and the difficulty is mostly just changes in stats (bonuses for ennemies and downgrades for you), not a lot of fun/creativity imo.

Then there is prestige/leveling and crafting system (very basic, to make better weapons for each character), and also a rune system. Those are the elements supposed to make you want to play more but honestly they're not enough. There is also the argument of the many characters, and while it's great there is such diversity they kind off feel the same, even tought they don't all have access to the same kind of skills, there are still always a few very similar characters. You probably won't have that feel of a dramatically different gameplay between the different classes like you could have on brotato.

The leveling system is also a bit strange. You can choose between three distinct traits that can have different levels of rarity (common, uncommon, rare, epic and legendary). But honestly, I feel like the rarest option is the best in 95% of the cases, making this good on paper concept pretty shallow. The trait and build system lacks depth and synergies imo tbh. But I'm pretty harsh because it does have quite a lot of diversity from what I've seen. But like the big number of characters and skills, I'm afraid they've gone for quantity over quality and game feel.

In conclusion, it's good and I'll probably play some more, especially when the full release is out, but I'm scared of the tideous aspect of the game. A shame because everything is quite good on surface level (graphics and art direction are great, musics are great too but far too few, base gameplay and build possibilities are amazing...).

Would still recommend to give it a try if you enjoy the genre and have the money. For the others, I would wait for full release and observe what the reviews say then (concerning the repetitive and shallow feel of the game)

Ah yes, haha, very nice

i would give this a 10/11 for a vampire survivors alike. 

- there is an option in the menue to reduce you skill effects visibility. so many games need this, pravo to the developer for having this QOL feature. also damage numbers etc. its a simple menue that has all you want / need. you dont need to save either, just pick and go on. 

- you have quick fun and long term motivation. more: characters, runes, skilltree abilities, weapons for cahracters and curse levels to progress and access. some are quick, some are grindy. all feel kinda worth. 

- a couple areas with some mini easter eggs (kill certain stuff in certain areas etc.)

- the upgrades you get in each run have nice sync and are thought through. for example crit over 100% has an additional chance to crit (aka 120% crit chance has 100 chance to crit and 20% chance to crit twice). "chance to apply an effect" (like burn, poison, slow, etc.) also stacks endlessly because the chance to apply it stays the same but the AMOUNT of stacks you apply increases. BTW dots (like poison) unlike in POE for example, CAN crit. 

- the graphics arent a pixel mess or depressing grey-style. love it. 

- bosses , elites and even trash mobs :D have some decent ability sets /targeted abilities that you can and NEED to dodge. its very fair but still requires skill and prevents you from standing still and wondering why you shouldnt afk anyway. there are heal and tank skills though if you wanna force that haha. havend achieved it yet but i think its possible. 
- that said: armor, block chance and multicast chance do have deminishing returns. look up some wiki table if you dont know what i mean. first 100(%) of it gives the most everything above still gives boni but the more you stack, the less you get. you will never reach 100% block or 100% quadriple cast but at the same time it isnt hard capped at 75% or smth like that as in other games. i like the system (not the first time i see it but there are worse options so i praise it). 

conclusion: you wont linger 500 hours in this but its quick fun and lets you come back a couple times if you like the game-type i assume. progressing all perma upgrades takes quite a while if you dont look up turials and stuffs and experiment yourself. (im 21 hours in and have almost all skilltree but i still lack about 95% of the runes / half the characters and ANY weapon upgrades of any characters but the fire guy i "main" atm. so there is still a lot of stuff to do. also curse levels im only at 4 out of whatever it was (in some maps only as well). 
also its dirt cheap, just buy if you like the genre (better than the other 5 i played so far. "bio prototype" might be better maybe or they are same tier i guess.)

Edit: i finished what i thought was the entire skilltree. little did i know :D there is SO MUCH MORE.

Edit 2: 50 hours in and i feel like its getting a bit boring by now / and or frustrating. why is that? (still a good game, just wanna state whats to improve if that was to avoid)

- if you want to progress you kind of have to stick to one character because playing the others would take very long till you get on the same power-level with their weapons being locked behind resource grind and level caps of the individual characters, runes locked behind achievements, skill tree (besides the core of it) locked behind level (and im talking about lvl 20+ to get at least one point of the prestige skill tree.) as well. this is a bit sad because i kinda wanna try some other characters for some of their individual skills or runes, but i also dont wanna grind them to the same level i have the main char right now and just playing them in low curse feels very disappointing as the rewards are about 200-300% less with rare materials NOT appearing at all. 

- the higher curses spawn more elite monsters AND more bosses. that means you get like 10 elites and 4 bosses simultaniously + some random towers that also spam abilities, resulting in your entire screen (starts on curse 4+ i would say, when the bosses spawn) being painted red with the targeted spells. if you dont have enough movement speed stacked and dashes (sometimes you dont get them as reward) it is literally impossible to dodge stuff (not just hard, im saying impossible). now there are multiple problems in this context:

1. bad run with no extreme upgrades (in either OS damage or getting golems before bosses or getting enough MS or dashes) may result in the run being not hard but impossible. its nice when it gets harder but no matter the RNG you should always be able to do it (if your skill is "perfect"). upgrades should just make it easier.

2. the golems you can get (some other chars have skeletons for example, that works the same) feel MANDATORY as they take aggro from the mobs around them, letting you actually shoot between dodging, sometimes you can even chill near boss. they dont just cc a lot, they also most often have highest damage of all of my skills. needs balancing. not getting them before the bosses spawn on high curses feels like a "RIP" for the run because you either cant dodge now (to much aggro, to little MV / dashes) or cant get enough DPS on them (trashmobs block, you have to dodge so much you cant aim at the bosses, most abilities are either short ranged (even if they penetrate mobs) or have random targeting AND if you dodge to much, kill other enemies (Which you cant prevent) while you do so, the NEXT bosses spawn in as well so if you survived so far thats the furthest you will come with that :D. 

3. i think bosses getting higher cast frequency on higher curse level is not the way to go. its fine if they oneshot me now, or get some new attack patterns or the time window for dodging the abilities (faster cast) gets smaller, but having multiple bosses with insane high cast frequency doesent feel harder, it feels random. somtimes aoe skills dont get shown on the map because its uneven and only half gets colored. sometimes i chainsaw or msth that no longer gets shown on ground is still shot into your direction or is on its way back to the boss who casted it but you have no clue-indication it will. if these are single things in lower curse levels you can look out for them but with multiple bosses AND rares AND high cast freuqency AND towers shooting stuff at you AND ground effects like ice spikes and poison lingering on the ground AND little things blocking your pathing (like palm trees), it gets to clustered to still be related to "skill". (IMO)

4. the golems are in one way OP but in the other way also suck. if there are many bosses and they target your many golems, you have no way of knowing where the abilities go to. while you are no longer targeted you get hit by random stray projectiles that may come from any direction at any time and no longer show the red colored indication area beneath them. 

solutions: 
- more different cc abilities that also work on bosses (black hole that clumbs things together for example) 
- nerv golem dps
- fix some of the target indications on the ground that get bugged by terrain level (aoe circles mostly)
- dont increase cast freuency with curse level or reduce the amount of rares/ bosses that spawn. make abilities less often but have more impact, so you have windows of attack and windows of dodge. 
- increase range of piercing projectiles so you can try to not get minions and other cc stuff but stack up on dps spells and dodge yourself, circling FAR around the bosses, piercing everything in your direction, eventually also downing the bosses. 
- give prestige points in general, not char specific. or make the grind feel a bit more woth it /fresher. example: dont let high curses drop low level resources. this gives incentive to grab an unleveld char and play low level to get these specific resources. or make character specific maps with specific mini-features (like different bosses, some ability-related event where you have to do smth specific), etc. 
so it feels "newer".

Coming back after unlocking all characters. I still find the game to be lots of fun overall. However there are some issues. 

1. Visibility. When you're on overlord mode 3+ (4+ bosses) or with curse 4+ there will be shit tons of enemies and projectiles. You can reduce *your* effect visibility but not the enemies. That makes sense, since I need to see them to dodge them. Still, they make visibility issues. Then there's the big enemies and swarm of small enemies mixed in. It's hard to tell which and where to dodge.

2. Enemy attack warning clarity. 
2a. All enemy attack has the same warning style. Common enemy, elite enemy, bosses. Obviously, you'd want to prioritize dodging boss attacks, then elite, then common enemy. However amidst the chaos, the red warning marks are all you can see. Boss attacks are generally larger, but some elite enemies also have large attack aoe. Then there are boss attacks that throws lots of small projectiles. 
2b. The attack timing sign may be misleading. The attack timing sign does not tell when the attack will reach you. It tells when the enemy will begin the attack. Some attacks like beams will immediately reach the end of the range. Some attacks like spikes and discs travel slowly. Again, among the chaos, the red warning marks are all you can see.
2c. The attack timing sign is unclear when there are a lot of them. The warning stack on top of eachother. The timing is shown by the warning area being redder, usually from the center or the caster end. But when warning stacks on top of each other, it's really hard to tell. They're all just very red circles.

3. Obstacles are sticky. They seem to have very high friction coefficient. When you walk towards bottom left and hit a wall facing right, you'll move downwards very slowly even with high movement speed stat. But okay, that's a wall. But it doesn't happen to just walls. It happens to small obstacles and even enemies. When that happens among the chaos, you'll have to dash because otherwise the attacks you've been dodging my walking would finally hit you. This happens so often because visibility of obstacles are really low among the chaos.

4. FPS drop or stuttering. When it gets too chaotic I'm getting FPS drop or stutter every 15s or so. When that happens I'll have to pause or I'll definitely die. The pause is often late too so sometimes I'm already cornered or just about to take a hit. And I can't see the game state before resuming because pausing darkens the game screen. I wish there were a countdown before the game actually resumes. Sometimes FPS will still drop after resuming (after paused 5 secs or so).

This is the perfect game to just load up, pick some cool skills and mindlessly zoom around slaying thousands of enemies. There's enough variety in the skills that you don't feel the need to just pick the same build over and over, and the different classes add a bit of flavor. The difficulty ramps up nicely, although higher levels seem to be a game of constantly dodging red "attack incoming" circles while trying to point your skills in the direction with the most enemies. There's lots to unlock between playthroughs as well.
You'll get your money's worth with this one and more, since the developers are regularly updating it and fleshing it out. If you're not sure, try the demo version, which will either get you addicted or not.

A polarizing game. The premise is fantastic. A fast moving, nuke the screen survivors like. Very different from a sea of clones in the genre. However, the execution comes down to some of the worst scaling mechanics I have seen in any game. 

Specifically, you can't see anything on the screen without turning off your own damage effects. This turns it into a Jedi mind tricks trainer where you wave your hands around and things die. Funny at first, but once that wears off it looks ridiculous. Even worse than this simple annoyance is the floor is lava simulator. Having ~15 red circles on the screen at all times is not difficulty. It removes the ability to identify priority attacks, enemy types, and to some degree strategy, as the game-play becomes spamming dodges while your Jedi dance moves hopefully thin the herd.

Because of the above every run feels mostly the same. With effects off and your skills scaling to hit off screen, combined with dodge spam from targets you rarely see/notice, it feels bland after you quit chasing unlocks.

Just to point out a few things that need work:
[b]1. This was the most annoying thing in the game. Either this is a bad game design, or it just hasn't been thought out.[/b]
[b]Problem[/b]: Getting stuck behind trees and walls (even seemingly invisible object edges) is why i died 95% of times. 
[b]Solution 1[/b]: if NOT standing right next to the object and using a dash in the direction of the object and dash projected end-point would be over the half of the objects middle point - dash would go though. But if not - dash would hit the object, as it is now. However, the 2nd dash would then go though the object, regardless of how long the dash is. 
[b]Solution 2[/b]: If calculating objects middle point and dashes length seems too complex, when not standing next to the said object and dashing, then at least make it so that dash goes though an object when standing right next to it. if i dash and hit an object, the next dash then goes through the object, regardless of how long the dash is. 

[b]2. Performance needs heavy calculation optimizations.[/b] I read that developers are aware of this, but still - when doing endless, the fps gets real low even on rtx 3090. 
Regardless, you will still die 95% times not because of this, but due to problem number 1 above.

[b]3. Arcane Weaver special skill-tree crystal mechanic is not a good game design[/b] in my opinion. 
[b]Problem[/b]: you have to stand still for a moment to pick up the crystals. Running over the crystals does not pick them up 99% of the times, so i gave up even trying to pick them up eventually. When playing on 48 curse intensity, it's not possible to stand still to pick them up.
[b]Solution[/b]: increase crystal pick up radius, so they can be easily picked up while RUNNING over them, without a need to stop and die senselessly.

[b]4. Need an option to see the outlines (without animation) for player skills, when they are triggered[/b] This would greatly improve visibility, when runs get longer and skill area % greatly increases. When turning off animation visibility to 0% due to visual clutter, it's real hard to tell, how far/wide character skills are, and also hard to guess when they will trigger. 
While on the topic of transparency - there is a bug, when skill transparency is set to 0% - also skill sounds are not played, so you can't tell when the skill would trigger. 

[b]5. Need an option to have red ground hazard elements to show above everything else.[/b] This would greatly improve visibility, when runs get longer.

[b]6. Need skill transparency settings section[/b] where players can set and save a skill transparency slider for every single skill. 

[b]7. Skills need multiple animations depending of how long the skill total area % is.[/b] 
[b]Problem[/b]: when getting further in the runs, skills get so stretched out, they look real bad and you can't see anything.
[b]Solution[/b]: when reaching certain skill area percentage, switch to next skill animation implementation. This means, that each skill needs multiple animations, depending on area%. This could also be used as a solution for not seeing anything when all skill area increases too much, by, for example, making it so that the animations for higher skill area levels are more transparent or by making them less stretched out.

[b]Game is good[/b], don't get me wrong. 
Some things need to be improved still.

I`ll tell you about the legacy of Essence. 
Once there had been a silver disc. On its top it got colored in deepest black and gotihc Letters were written on it. A demonic hand longing from it, aiming upon your soul.
The disc was filled with the essence of Action and Stats. It consumed the Lifetime of ingenuous people  with no mercy. 
Millions of hours of lifetime pulled down to hell. 
This essence of all time consuming addiction, that had been ever thought about at that time, was called Diablo. 
After beaten, and three reinkarnations in different shapes, it came to be, that there was a new war rising.  A war so flawless and fluid as pure Water dripping into a thirsty mouth. 
Leaving behind the slow downs, like walking to get to a Place of action, it took the essence of the essence to claim the throne of addictive efficiency. 
Never again should there be a moment to think about interrupting the consuming of lifetime. Where there has been small chances to get out of the whirlwind of addictive action, in a such short time of relaxing peace and boredom, now there is only addiction left. No compromise no useless time wastes. It keeps people playing and pleeding for more without forcing them only with rewards for boring tasks. 
The purity of non stop action, efficiency and  satisfaction, was born. And it was called Soulstorm Survivors!

I was recommended this game by a friend while I was playing Vampire Survivors. They're both amazing games, and very similar. Vampire Survivors in its 'arcadey' feel and simplicity. Soulstone Survivors has more customization and a more modern feel. 

If you've never played either game, they look simple and boring but I promise they're fun and addicting. You might not get endless hours out of the game, but 30+ of fun for this cheap is a steal in todays market if you ask me. 

Both games get a 9/10 from me, they're great for what they are and don't pretend to be any different.

Bought this in early access, and I was surprised how complete it feels. For what is available, and not being bombarded by microtranactions, it makes it very easy to pickup and play for long periods. Its a nice take on the survivors-like style, being familiar but very much so an original and unique take on the systems that will make you play it along side the game that inspired it.

All in all I'd say this game is VIRTUALLY a solid 10/10 and has become my favorite vampire survivors clone.... HOWEVER The music is absolutely abysmal. The OST for this game needs a complete overhaul. 

Personally just play madness combat nexus OST in the background instead, it fits much better.

I was having to dodge blindly just hoping I didn't get hit, all because my spell effects were filling the screen (especially shockwave? or earthquake? IDK...huge rocks everywhere in a cone in front of me). 

There's also next-to-no explanation on many systems, so if you finish a level it'll tell you to pick a portal with no description of what each portals is/does. 

The skill tree is super deep, but WILL take a LOT of play to advance it. Unsure how varied it gets. Rune seem cool also, but the method to get them either involve skipping out on buying skills, or rarely through limited achievements. Given how many runes and skills there are, this feels balanced a little heavily towards grind in a game genre I don't intend to play hundreds of hours of a single title.

Something in-between Gunfire Reborn and Risk of Rain 2, but in the style of Vampire Survivors. Starts slow and clunky, but picks up to feel [i][b]great[/b][/i] over time. The progression systems are addicting: different classes have overlapping in-game skill/character building progression, allowing for a sort of class-mixing experience. There's also a large out-of-game (lobby) character progression system - nice to have, but the progression is a little slow, and many parts of it are locked for a long time. Overall, fun game, addicting progression, funky vibes!

Fun and high-octane excitement are skillfully balanced in Soul Stone Survivors, making for a thrilling experience from start to finish. The game's superb character development system and wide variety of interesting spells are yours to explore as you progress through its many challenging encounters.

The magic of development is the key to winning the game. Beautiful and engaging character growth is paired with deep and strategic spell customisation to deliver an experience that goes above and beyond.

It's true that the game's intricacy can make it difficult to know which path to choose at the outset due to navigational confusion. This, however, also attests to the complexity of its setting and story. The subsequent elation of exploration and victory more than makes up for this minor setback.

Soul Stone Survivors offers a substantial and satisfying sense of fulfillment and success upon completion of its challenging courses. It's an adventure that puts the emphasis on the fun of the trip rather than the final goal. This game does more than simply make it, it flourishes, providing a journey through gaming that is both fascinating and hypnotic.

[h2]Damn if I Could Give a Mixed Recommendation, I Would[/h2]

Soulstone Survivors is the epitome of an early access game. If you're not all about that beta-testing-the-game-for-free-and-half-the-features-missing, then [b]don't get this game.[/b]

Gameplay-wise, it's a very nice loop and you do hit that serotonin high as you mow down everyone in your way.

This game is big on its legacy element and your character does get a lot stronger the more you play it.

However,
[list]
  [*] Half the features are missing.
  [*] No in game encyclopedia of what does what or what skills you're allowed to have on your character or even what all the skills are. Leaves you guessing most of the time.
  [*] Suffering from too much visual clutter. There's lots of red circles to dodge, but all your skills are very beautifully animated and take away enemy visibility. So you turn down the visuals. Now the game looks super bland, but at least you won't die to something unexpected anymore.
  [*] Stats are unbalanced. There's no reason to take defensive stats because at higher levels, you're going to die in one shot anyway, and ironically, offense is the better defense.
[/list]

My recommendation: [b]check back when this game hits 1.0.[/b]

A good survivors game with an honestly huge amount of meta-progression to unlock and grind through. Dozens of characters with multiple weapons that give them unique starting skills. Lots of categories of skills that each character has in different combinations

Rounds do start to feel a bit samey after a while, compared to some other survivors games, but it's still good for many hours
great game

THIS HAS BEEN ONE OF THE BEST PURCHASES IVE MADE IN A LONG TIME! 

Not much to this game so far, but here is a simple breakdown of what I think makes the base foundation of a great game:

- VERY EASILY ACCESSIBLE, but challenging to master. THIS IS GOOD! 

- CLASS VARIETY and differentiation is fantastic, though I do wish to see more class selection, OR class customization options in the future. 
(im currently messing around with hybrid builds, more on that later)

- REPLAY-ABILITY  is outstanding and the progression through ranks and scenarios is very rewarding. 
(this is one of the few games in my recent experience, that ive felt accomplishment in leveling up)

- SKILLS and ABILITIES are visually amazing, and the design choices behind what skills and powers in the game are well thought out! 

- OST is pretty damn good for a small studio, 

- SOUND EFFECTS are one of the weaker points of the game tbh. Its not the most dynamic when it comes to sound design, so after a while it becomes kind of hard to listen to, but nothing an update or patch cant fix. Also, i put on my own music when going for long sessions anyway, so not a huge deal. 

SO basically, this game is pretty damn cool, and thats not even mentioning the newly released update, which brought in SO many more features and progression system, its pretty cool! Im very happy with my purchase, which I believe was on a steam sale, but honestly I wouldve bought this game at full price, maybe even double, because of how much time ive spent playing already. Its really fun and you wont regret it! 

TO THE DEVS: 

Now this is just a wish list of sorts, just some ideas I thought of while playing that would make this game a classic. Nothing too hard to implement, just some REALLY nice additions IMO. 

1) WE NEED multiplayer! Now I know gamers arent known for having friends, but damn, this would be such a fun game to play with your closest discord mods, or roomates. If you were to implement a MP mode, I would suggest no more than 6 people. The maps get a little crowded even with one person.

Which brings me to my next WISH! 

2) MAP MODIFICATION // WORLD BUILDER TOOL would be f****** awesome and a wonderful complement to a MP mode. Something along the lines of simple "sectioned drop-in" map building mechanics would go crazy fr. 

3) We need a storyline / main quest line / story mode / more map selections for this game to have some real depth and replay-ability. This could be tied into, or overhauled / substituted for a map building tool, but we need more maps. 

4) I believe more character customization options, when it comes to character cosmetics, coloring, spell colors, weapon designs, etc etc, all the cosmetic customization in other games, would be a really welcomed addition here. (even if there is a STORE, idgaf, just something to add some user personality to our experience) 

LASTLY, 

5) Hybrid class mechanics need to be a thing. I think after the update to the rune system its pretty good. Everything for the most part feels balanced, however, I think if we could dial in more specificity on certain spells or abilities, or removal of certain abilities within a certain spell pool, etc etc the game would benefit greatly. Its cool for now, but I can see overtime it might get a little boring using the same setup over and over again. 



But these are my opinions, thank you for reading. Thank you to the devs for such an awesome experience, and I cant wait for the next update! PEACE! -
