Recently had a friend ask me "If a person was to only have one Survivor-like, what should it be?" and I think that answer isn't really easy as different people value different mechanics or gameplay loops, but I figured I owe it to Soulstone to at least put my thought out into the ether for others to see.

[h1]TLDR[/h1] 

I currently feel like Soulstone is the most complete package for the price point and the game is still making it's way through Early Access. The recently added "Class Ascension" mechanics (which currently less than half the cast has) gave a much needed jump into class identity and the vast amount of customization options available means that you can truly play the game the way you want to play. Infinite scaling makes this feel more like Risk of Rain sometimes, including the part where when you scale loops in higher tiered content you will eventually just get one-shot, but most content can be played very comfortably.

[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]

Typical Survivor-like gameplay. Only stipulation is that the run is ran by kills, not time. You kill normal enemies on the map and gain experience and at certain denominations a Lord (Boss) will spawn and defeating them will give you a Soulstone. Soulstones are both your meta progression and your "Magnets" in this game, so they vacuum all XP on the map.

Upon finishing the fifth Tier of Lords, the game ends immediately. If you completed the run fast enough, you can choose to loop your run into another random map infinitely in either Endless (enemies scale across the board) or Overlord (+1 Lord per Tier, less kills to spawn Lords, Lords scale more) modes and each has different meta progression benefits and feel different enough to merit each other.

A large majority of the normal mobs do not have projectile attacks and even all of the Lords' attacks have skill shot displays and timers. You have access to a Dash with a moderate amount of invulnerability frames, but at the higher tier of content eventually your whole screen is going to be full of asynchronous danger zones and so it gets considerably harder. Very few classes have access to healing, but there is an amount of randomly spawned Health Crystals on map; otherwise, it's HP on level and Health Regen for your recovery.

[h1]CHARACTER IDENTITY[/h1]

Every character is more or less a collection of various stats, with very few of them having meaningful differences there, besides classes with an extra dash or Death Knight not being able to Dash. They can also only select a handful of the game's 200+ Skills depending on their associated Element/Type tags. Paladin can only equip Electric, Holy, etc skills, but due to the secondary Types you end up with a large handful of generic skills.

I mention generic skills because each class DOES come with a handful of skills that only they are allowed to draft which you unlock as you advance that class in level. Now Paladin has another four skills that are only going to be offered to them. That's before considering that each class also has multiple "weapons"  that each have a primary unique skill and various further stat bonuses.

Every character easily has multiple high end win conditions and it seems that the developers are also adding more "build options" weapons to each class. Probably by release every class is going to have a minion-build and/or scaling build IN KIT with the weapon system as well as using the rune and generic element skills systems.

The Ascension update adds skill trees to less than half the classes (unlocked after completing the initial global skill tree) and in those trees are MMO-style resources and mechanics specific to each character. Most of these are honestly just do a thing and gain temporary huge amounts of stats, but the interaction is still pretty unique, even if some mechanics are clearly more equal than others. Namely, mechanics that force you to stay in an area for an extended period of time don't work well with high-level content.

[h1]BUILD/RUN IDENTITY[/h1]

While I really don't subscribe to the idea of running Roguelikes or the like with the idea of "builds" in mind, Soulstone is set up to where you can almost reliably play the build that you want.

The game boasts a "Rune" system, where you can choose up to five different perks (the capacity of which is dependent on meta progression) that can range from guaranteeing your first offered skill is a specific class, adding skills your character normally doesn't have access to into the skill pool (including unique skills from other classes), scaling options, min-maxing stats, etc. etc.

Every level, you alternate between drafting skills and choosing a stat enhancements. Whenever you are offered a Skill and your Skillbar is full, you can elect to replace one; this will lose all Skill-specific levels invested into that skill, but the new skill might fight your build better.

Unfortunately, whenever you have this much player agency run identity usually suffers, but I suppose when rounds only last like ten to twelve minutes, that's okay. I still feel like it's the only place where Soulstone Survivors is lacking. I personally wish that the Elemental Synergies weren't solely in the skills and boiled down to "you have three Electric Skills, so sometimes you get offered Electrical Area of Effect".

[h1]CONTENT[/h1]

I think the only game that has this amount of content (that I am aware of) in the genre is Army of Ruin, which I am playing through right now. Maybe Brotato? For costing 50~100% more than other Survivor-likes and having the low-poly graphics that most others don't, it's honestly a lot. 

Granted, some of that content in the Skills department is same-y. "What if we had the cleave attack, but this time it was PURPLE!?!" "How about another laser, but this one is cold?" but at least there are characters that are focused around 'purple' and cold, so at least it's filling a niche. Probably the most heinous example is Heartrending Strike (a Seasonal Event skill) and Ravaging Strike, where Heartrending is literally the exact same except it has a Seasonal Tag and does slightly less damage, but that's literally the only case so far.

[h1]WORDS OF WARNING[/h1]

Just figured I would also put a place for all the things that you might want to be aware of before purchasing the game.

More than most other Survivor-likes, the Low-Poly graphics plus infinite scaling of attack speed and area of effect can cause "skill blindness". There is a slider in Options to downscale all your skill effects so that you can see enemy attacks on the ground and avoid them; I highly recommend reducing it down to around ~30% almost immediately.

More than most other Survivor-likes, due to the infinite scaling of attack speed and area of effect, the game has a lot of CPU load to register all the hits, effects, and debuffs that you will be placing at any particular time. There is an option in the menus for "ramping damage numbers" or something like that helps a lot with your system "chugging", but won't solve the entire issue.

More than most other Survivor-likes, due to the infinite scaling of enemy attack speed and damage, you WILL eventually die. You should be fine for your first initial loop, but eventually enemy stats get so high that no matter how much armour or block you stack you will not reduce it all and there will be so many dangerzones on the ground that you cannot feasibly dodge them all. Eventually the life expectancy for everyone reaches zero and you will not be an exception.

The Grind for this game isn't entirely egregious compared to others as I had all the current 250+ achievements and characters leveled for their Ascensions/when their Ascensions drop within ~60 hrs. There will be times where you have to run specific maps for crafting resources, but if you Ascend/Level Arcane Weaver first to about ~60 when you finish the core Skill Tree, they have a Rune that doubles all Crafting Resources found for only 2 Rune Points.

addictive and fun to explore the upgrade systems

This game is fun and it uses the roguelike aspect well, with short and long-term things to keep working towards. The different classes play different enough to promote experimentation and coming up with different builds is fun.

The downside to this game comes in the later levels. I'm currently on Curse level 5 on all the current maps and its very chaotic at this level. There are so many enemies and visual effects on screen that it is hard to make out where you should and should not step. 

There's also so much visual stimulation going on in these levels that I have to pace my gaming out more. Instead of playing for hours on end, I'll play an hour or so and then need a break.

The core gameplay loop is fun though. It is not a bad game, but it gets to a point where keeping up with what is happening on screen is more than I like to have to deal with.

This has been my go-to game for months now. every time I think i'm about to tire of it, I think of another approach.  It's game of mechanics - all these different tweaks and choices you can make in your ultimate goal to turn your humble little guy into a human power washer, just wasting everything within seconds of it materializing.  It's a really fun challenge.  it's nowhere near perfect, with lots of strange balancing issues, especially around skills that seem amazing on paper but are feeble in-game.  But it's just a matter of devs identifying it and tweaking their little "spreadsheet" that' underneath everything.

The other quirks are that they still haven't figured out a way to have all the effects on the screen and have the game be playable (too many effects block neccessary information).  Thankfully there's a slider to turn transparencies up (or make effects go completely invisable. Also some effects are way too heavy on the GPU - your build will determine your framerate, which is a bit strange.

Anyhow, I adore this game.

Great light fun survivor-type game. Huge fan, my favorite out of the numerous survivor and survivor-like clones I've played. Tons of customization options, different weapons that actually change up the game play for the characters in meaningful ways, 14 characters to pick from. All that leads to a pretty decent depth and tons of replay-ability. This is the PERFECT game if you just wanna pick up and have some quick fun, do a run or two, etc. (just be careful, because the "one more run. Okay, just one more. okay okay one more" feeling is real. The gameplay is super fun and there's always new things you want to try next time) I've been using it as an"in between" game for when I finish a massive plot-heavy game and don't want to jump straight in to Mass Effect: Legendary Edition after beating Elden Ring (as an example). I've also found myself playing this as my primary game for weeks straight because the loop is so satisfying. Great casual game, with enough depth and difficulty options that you can dive in to this head first if you want.

Other things I like: 
- A subset of the skills can be aimed if you want (you can have them all auto aimed if you prefer). Some of the survivor-likes I've played have all skills fully auto aimed with no control other than character direction. I really don't like this and appreciate being able to have a bit of agency (clear a path vs cover retreat).
- Graphics are some of the best out there. Vampire Survivor and Halls of Torment are fun, but there's something to be said for a game with full iso-3d graphics. Gameplay is the most important factor, which is why I've spent so much of my review on that, but the graphics are worth noting.

Take it or leave it:
- All the weapons/characters/runes that you could want for your favorite characters are unlockable within the first 20-30 hours (if not much sooner). This assumes you play all classes up to level 20 (about 10 hours total), and then pick and stick with your favorites for the rest. However, some people in the community want to unlock everything: every skill, every rune, every weapon. This can result in pretty major grind for materials (obviously). I don't think this is an issue personally because I don't have a huge drive to unlock every single weapon/rune. There are 3-4 characters/classes that I like the most, and I have those fully unlocked and didn't need to do any extra grind for materials. I have absolutely zero desire to keep unlocking some of the other characters (looking at you, Sentinel, Paladin, and Pyromancer) and don't have any plans for crafting their stuff. If you're the type of person who likes to fully complete everything and needs every single weapon and rune unlocked: The developers are aware of this, and said they have some changes planned in the future to address the end game grind. So hopefully everyone can be happy!

Early Access Stuff:
The game's still early access, but I'm not taking points off for that. Everything here is fun and playable. No major bugs or issues that I've seen in my hours of gameplay. But they're still developing the advanced skill trees for about half of the newer characters (Necromancer/Chaos Walker can't specialize like some of the others, YET), still adding extra weapons for newer classes, etc. The developers communicate all of that very well, and the game as it is today is worth the price imo.

Developers are re-skinning the game and reselling it as a roguelike.

It's the same engine, graphics, moves, ect, but it's a different camera angle. Expect Soulstone racers, Soulstone FPS, Soulstone RTS, Soulstone fighters, Soulstone romance visual novels and Soulstone 3D Eroge Simulator coming soon.

They complain that they're only a 2 man team, but they're splitting their attention between two separate game developments. Updates are already bringing as many bugs as they are features. Most runs end in instant death from invisible attacks or stuff clipping through walls, or even just outright being lied to by the AOE warning markers.

I said it to the developer, and I'll say it here.

I'm sorry I supported this, and I'm sorry they think it's something to be proud of to screw your customers over and deliver a lackluster product while promising to fix it, while you're ALREADY jumping ship to another project.

Edit: Was permanently banned for speaking out about the developers shady practices with this review. Another instance of abuse from developers who can't take constructive criticism or being called out when they're doing something dishonest.

It's simultaneously too easy and too stressful to play. It's a totally brainless game up until a point where you add enough curse modifiers that the ground is filled with so much red circles of "shit that is about to hit" that you can't possibly stand still for a moment. The game has no clock like Vampire Survivors, so it only pressures you in the sense that if you summon a boss and dont kill it fast enough, you will start progressing towards summoning the next boss before it dies, which can snowball into a loss if you don't have enough DPS.

The bad decision of including a dash move for the player character also stands out, making it trivial to kite every single enemy and making the game full of enemy AoE telegraphs that try to run you out of your dash cooldown. The only way enemies can threaten you is by literally filling the screen with so much crap that you can't possibly get out of the way fast enough, but it doesn't happen in the gradual "zombie horde" manner of other Vampire Survivors clones and thus feels more like the worst aspects of Diablo or hell, an MMO raid encounter. Dashing into terrain by accident is a bigger threat than any of the enemies.

There are 50000 abilities to pick from that are all meaningless variations on the same thing and eventually they stack so many modifiers that they turn into the same screen-covering bullshit that you actually have a VFX slider in the game you can turn down so you can actually see the fucking gameplay. So even though there is a lot of choice, it doesn't matter because the mechanics of each attack eventually converge into the same screen-covering spam so the base design of how the attack works is surprisingly unimportant.

It's a shame because the game is confidently designed and has a lot of content but the core gameplay ends up being unfulfilling, even plain old Vampire Survivors makes me feel more like I'm "in" the game. It will milk some dopamine out of your shrivelled brain but eventually you will come out feeling empty inside.

Plus for the soundtrack which is actually unique and has a distinct psytrance/goa flavor.

Good game with lots of content but this game suffers a lot from SO MUCH CLUTTER.

On higher difficulties it's just impossible to see what's going on, even with reduced spell visibility, because bosses and spires just red circle the entire map.

If you're a melee char, then it's over. You wont go far the longer the run goes on, especially with 4 bosses and if you can't kill them fast enough.

But game is good and fun.

A really fun game with lots of progression and things to unlock!

Biggest downside is build variety is essentially non-existent, you can choose any combination of abilities and they all end up feeling exactly the same, which does hurt it's replay-ability a lot for me.

Worth your time overall if you enjoy survivor games!

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Passover in 2022 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Played under 3 hours and wasn't impressed by anything.

Game's top priority is character progression. General character skill trees, individual skill trees and some weapons. For latter you have to grind a lot. Changes stats +/- and give new skills.
Most important thing at start is to get a second dash.

There is very small variety of enemies, bosses and maps. Each map has different upgrade resources. 
Visually Elites and Bosses may be different but all are doing the same. Worst here are bosses. Basically all patterns: a lot of red circles aoe, one big red circle, frontal cleave/half circle, directional frontal charged attack that can be either cast or channel. There's 6 or 7 (?) bosses in base game (heard events had more) and 5 of them you must finish to complete the map. I mean none of them have their own biome or something unique. Just a cannon fodder.

Skills and level progressing are disappointing to my humble taste. Often, choosing higher rarity upgrade on level up is the way to go. You can choose to upgrade dmg for one particular skill or general damage but in lower quantity for example.
Didn't enjoy skills at all. At start I wanted to try and play around some control build but it's meaningless. Just go all damage build, because hp and defensive upgrades seemed worthless very fast. I've tried (what do they call it..)..uhm..Overlord mode ?...the red portal. Everything was fine until second pair of bosses spawned and I died instantly without anything under my feet. That's okay, nothing to be upset about, it's just dumb.
So yeah, just look at good Dmg:Cldwn skills, pick and upgrade them. Purple, yellow general dmg, multistrike upgrades are no brainer.
Also, you can't modify skill's effect in any way, except it's stats. At least I couldn't yet.
First 2-5 minutes, while you still see smth on your screen, you still distinguish skills animations. After that "boom, splash, kaboom".

Game doesn't feel rewarding. You just pick those skills, have access to the best upgrades on the first run and then just slap slap slap. Let's see: that skill kills shit, oh and that one too, and this one ! Abilities doesn't look interesting, all you can think is "oh, okay", when you see it. Because of this it's hard to care about characters or their skills. Okay, one of several heroes that I unlocked had a dog. Wow O_o. Okay that's cute, but it was late and maybe because of that I had no idea what can it do. 

There's some Curse system which I didn't try and idk how to access it. IIUC it's the main time sink. If devs just increase enemy amount (4 bosses very fun, har har har) and stats and decreasing players stats/exp gain - it's most dumb and cliche concept in video games. If bosses also have new moves and maybe maps have some mechanic - it's already something.

On top of everything mentioned above, only one thing can further worsen boring and repetitive experience. And it's narcotic and repetitive music. Omg...the first map's theme. Just shoot me in the head. Same monotonous beat and repeating one or two words over and over again. Arghh....and also that word I couldn't recognize sounded like "pirozhki" :D Had a couple laughs, but yeah..awful and annoying music.

IF in future, I will revisit this and my experience will be different, I'll change my review. For now this is how I feel.
PS: better go and try [spoiler] Nordic Ashes [/spoiler]. One of my favorite in genre.

Well, I said that I'd change the rating if it got 'better'. To me, it did. The overall feeling of the game is somehow smoother. These folks obviously keep working on the game and it's early access. Knockbacks are still not enjoyable but they're definitely more manageable. Thank you for your work, devs. Peace.

[h1]It's just 3D Vampire Survivor but with faceless dudes, a hell lot more polished everything and made for kids.[/h1]

Although I am to refund this right now, I plainly recognize that Soulstone Survivors makes the genre a lot more accessible to people who would like to play VS but want a more balanced (?) game overall.

+ Dash
+ Simple yet very polished and well designed UI
+ Dash has low cd
+ Even though a lot of things are going on at the same time you can turn what you like off and even customize abilites opacity
+ You can dash through enemies
+ EVERY enemy has an attack animation so there's no retro touch damage bullsh1t (the only letdown on retro games for me), a HUGE improvement
+ Dash iframes
+ Boss mechanics are basically a sum of a variety of WoW and Runescape bosses
+ Quite good starting variety of skills and combos
+ Graphics can be simple but are visually comfortable whilst in the middle of chaos and warfare
+ Dash graphics are also nice

- You are forced to swap skills every damn time, at least at the beginning
- Cast and run can be quite boring after a little while for those who prefer a VS approach on ingame progression as your character is either abominably overpowered or easily overwhelmed by bulky hordes
- Reminds me of Adventure Quest 3D and League of Legends
- While bosses are indeed very cool, some skill hitboxes are off, which makes them sometimes land a hit without being capable of doing so (e.g channeling a skill forward and yet hitting through their back)
- Made for kids

Soulstone Survivors is an action roguelite with a lot to offer. The game has a variety of characters, skills, and items to choose from, which gives you a lot of freedom to experiment and find a build that works for you. The challenge is also well-balanced, with enough difficulty to keep you engaged but not so much that it becomes frustrating.

One of the things I really like about Soulstone Survivors is the sense of progression. As you play, you'll earn Soulstones, which can be used to unlock new characters, skills, and items. This gives you a sense of accomplishment as you make progress, and it also helps to keep the game fresh.

Another thing I like about Soulstone Survivors is the challenge. The game can be quite difficult, but it's also very rewarding when you finally beat a tough boss or reach a new high score. This makes the game very addictive, and it's always fun to try to improve your skills and get better at the game.

The visual effects in Soulstone Survivors are also very impressive. The game is full of bright colors and flashy animations, which really helps to bring the action to life. The sound design is also top-notch, with a great soundtrack that really sets the mood.

Overall, I highly recommend Soulstone Survivors to fans of action roguelites. The game is a lot of fun to play, and it has a lot of depth and replayability. If you're looking for a challenging and rewarding game, then Soulstone Survivors is definitely worth checking out.

Here are some of the things I like about Soulstone Survivors:

The variety of characters, skills, and items.
The sense of progression.
The challenge.
The addictive gameplay.
The visual effects.
The sound design.

Here are some of the things that could be improved:

The game could use a bit more polish in some areas.
The difficulty can be a bit uneven at times.
The weapons you craft can be underwhelming. 

Overall, I think Soulstone Survivors is a great game, and I highly recommend it to fans of action roguelites. I'm excited to see how the game develops in the future, and I'm sure it will only get better with time.

Here are some tips for playing Soulstone Survivors:

Experiment with different characters and builds to find one that suits your playstyle.
Don't be afraid to die. Death is a part of the game, and it's often the best way to learn and improve.
Pay attention to the environment and use it to your advantage.
Don't be afraid to use your skills and items. They're there to help you, so use them!
Have fun! Soulstone Survivors is a great game, so relax and enjoy the ride.

[h1][b]Soulstone Survivors[/b][/h1]

[b]... an epileptic shock simulator[/b]


[h1][b]The game in a nutshell[/b][/h1]

Soulstone Survivors is an action-roguelike arena shooter and stands, as the name suggests, in the tradition of the Vampire Survivors phenomenon. Kill hordes of increasingly stronger and more numerous enemies, level up your character, learn spells, powers, AoE effects, find synergies to maximize damage and defeat the baddies. Finally upgrade permanent bonuses after each run - rinse and repeat...


[h1][b]+/-[/b][/h1]

+ great art style and sound
+ motivating game loop and progression system
+ 14 characters
+ as typical for the genre you collect currancy with each run to permanetly unlock perks - Soulstone Survivors adds different variants of the primary weapon for each character - more build variety, high replayability- and experimentation value
+ a big plus for me is, that you don´t need a meta build to succeed. Although there are the "better" and stronger synergies, I managed to finish runs with experimental builds I never thought I´d win at first
+ instant dopamine release
+ worth even at full price

+/- playing with default settings is comparable to a movie that only consists of CGI. I think I´ve never played anything that close to overinformation or an epileptic shock. Depending on your build you might end up with a mix of a Michael Bay movie and Timothy Leary´s psychedelic adventures. What sounds funny might really be a thing if you are seriously susceptible to epileptic shocks! The good news is, you can change that in your settings and I highly recommend doing so, because above a certain level and strength of your powers and AoE effects (as beautiful and flashy as they are), you can barely see anything on the screen. In addition, there are obstacles in every arena that you can get stuck on and you don´t find them anymore in this madness

- at harder difficulties you probably always end up running in circles around several bosses, dashing ninja style and hoping for the best that they die earlier than you because of neverending additional enemy spawns. 


[h1][b]Conclusion[/b][/h1]

Soulstone Survivors is a worthy descendant of Vampire Survivors and leads the genre in the right direction. The progression system is motivating and the game is simply fun to play. However, it is visually often "too much" and on harder difficulties it should be more balanced. All in all, a great game with high replay value and enough variety to lead different characters and builds to victory.
I enjoyed Vampire Survivors, but for now this feels like a successor to me. I'm having loads of fun, buy this game!

This game has huge potential. It has an addictive game play loop that will keep you entertained if you are interested in this genre of game. It kind of reminds me of POE without gear. You are weak the first few rounds and then later you are clearing screens of mobs.

Pros:
Progression in game and skill tree
potential with crafting system
addictive gameplay

Cons:
Build diversity 
boss skills/frequency

"build diversity" is a bit of an illusion. You cant just go in and choose skills and hope to complete the hardest difficulty. Some skills are miles ahead of others and some classes just dominate the rest. Melee builds are usually punished the hardest with how the bosses work.  This could always be fixed with balancing so its not that big of a deal.

Now here is the biggest issue. Bosses. When you are melee and there are 7 bosses on the screen throwing out AOE that is the size of the screen and also shoot out "fire/lightning beams" that seem to be constant, it just becomes a chore. It isnt fun. The boss AOE's need to be reduced drastically and the cast frequency of the beams that move faster than you can dash need to be tuned. 

If these 2 things are fixed i can see this game being the best in the genre.

It falls short. The gameplay ideas are promising (like dashing, enemy move predictions, and boss fights), but the game smothers them with excessive restrictions such as currency, crafting, and skill trees. Perhaps some players enjoy endlessly grinding one level for in-game currency to craft an upgrade they unlocked by defeating a boss, but that's not my cup of tea. When I beat a boss, I want to be able to obtain the upgrade in the next round.

Additionally, the pace of level progression is quite slow within each run, and the upgrades offered are relatively minor. This lack of substantial progression can make the early game less engaging, especially without the introduction of new characters or weapons.

Finally, and this is very important, the UI needs to be traversable with just the keyboard. It becomes quite bothersome to have to switch to the mouse every time I need to select cards during level-ups. Please ensure that all UI elements can be easily accessed and operated using keyboard inputs alone.
There's a lot more to this game than I previously expected... very fun.

Frame rate drops are so bad, make the game basically unplayable. I have a system that can run games 10x this same on Ultra so I don't know why I'm seeing frame drops on this. Shame because the game play was somewhat enjoyable.

This is a bit of a tentative recommendation. This is a game that has a lot that it wants you to do (character unlocks, weapon crafting, skill trees, difficulty level unlocks, runes, etc), but not a lot of ways for you to do it. You'll be fighting the same 5 or so bosses over and over again while fighting waves of enemies that all feel basically the same to each other even if they have different designs based on what map your on. The maps all also feel very samey, probably because the enemies don't feel different enough from map to map and the bosses are the same regardless of what map you select. The skill selection system is interesting, but feels self-defeating. 99% of the time, it's correct to just take the rarest skill being offered, so it never really feels like you are making a choice. Also, because combat is so reliant on dashing, the skill that gives you an extra dash is by far the best in the game, and should be picked every time you see it, which feels a little boring.

All of that being said, there is a lot of good here too. All of the characters feel varied enough from each other, and you can get some really insane builds going if you pick enough synergies with your active skills. It never quite hits the insanity point that Vampire Survivors does, though. You'll never be able to just fully afk this game, and that's probably a good thing. I really like the art style, even if the visual noise can become overwhelming at times, and the soundtrack is pretty solid.

This is a game you'll probably be done with way before the game runs out of things it wants you to do, but I'm hoping the developers take a break from adding things to grind for to add more variety to the grind itself. As it is, I think this game is worth getting if you really like Survivors style games, and are willing to wait a bit for more content to be added.

Hi!

If you're not into a reading marathon, i'll spare you the trouble and give you my thoughts about Soulstone Survivors in this short version: yes, this is a pretty solid game, definitely enjoyable, with a feel of adrenaline, progression, you'll struggle until you get your builds right, lot of options and skill variety, it does honor to the genre. I 9000% recommand it. Bullet hell games are awesome if you're into them, this one is awesome.

Now the long one:

A bit of context: 
My first ever 'bullet hell' game was Realm of the Mad God and I was not into that kind of game at the time. I did not understand the concept and wasn't interested, and RoMG is kinda different from all the others. While most bullet hell are all about 'choosing a character -> fight -> get stronger -> keep going until you die', it feels like RoMG is a HnS with permanent HC mode and coop mode but without the campaign. I launched the game, made a character, got into a game with 3 high level guys, hit lvl 50 in 5 mins, died from a wandering projectile, lost my character... and pretty much left it at that. I can't say it's bad, but that just stopped me right there.

Then much later on in my discovery list I got one of those and decided to give it another chance. I think I shouldn't have (I ended up spending HOURS and DAYS in there). So I was offered to play Fray fight? I liked this game, it was hard enough but also I could understand the mechanics of it, it had that full screen aspect typical of the genre, but some stuff in there was also disappointing. So I looked for more of those and I found tons of free to play crap clones of vampire survivors, which is, if not the most, one of the most popular bullet hell games around. Then I found Soulstone Survivor! And off we go spending hours and days on it.

About bullet hell games:
Bullet hell games are games where you play a character (usually a class as any RPG / HnS...), you find yourself on a map, you slay waves of monsters starting with a bunch and growing up filling the screen, using a variety of skills that may or may not synergize with each other but also growing to filling the screen. If you die, you have to start all over.

Well not exactly all over because some of those games have features such as talent trees and some sort of upgrade systems so it gets easier at the start and so you can go further. Some of those features can be unlocked through 'quests' or 'achievements'. So you really have that feeling of growing stronger to a point you're an almighty godly being. 

What I like about Soulstone Survivor:
*While the maps are not infinite (like in Vampire Survivors) they're not tiny either (like in Fray Fight)
*The game has its unique design, most games really all look like Vampire Survivors)
*Also has its unique skills, (unlike all other Vampire Survivors crap clones)
*Not only the skills are unique but they have a huge variety even within the same class
* The 'curse' systems: give yourself a harder time by checking some options and have to think a bit more about choices and strategy for better reward
*The talent tree (classic HnS feature)
*You can spend A LOT of time to try and reach endgame (if it even has an end, not there yet)
*I understood that there were events in the game. On a map I found a chained heart and when I broke the chains a Cupid like monster popped and attacked me, also spawning pylons with a heart on its top (valentine event I guess)

What I don't like about Soulstone Survivor:
*Obviously the whole game isn't realesed yet, for instance all classes don't have their own talent tree yet
*The thing that bothers me the most is that there is so much going on on screen you have to make the particle effect transparents so you can see the monsters aoe so you don't get hit and die... yeah
*There might be more but I enjoyed the game so much it's very possible I missed some of negative points about it

I was on the fence about buying this game. But damn, this is a great game. There goes my weekend for less than cheap.

I really like this game and would highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys this genre. However, my main issue arises with the endgame, particularly with rank 6 and 7 maps that include all curses.

You know those red swirlies you have to dodge, right? Well, they are literally everywhere. It feels like everyone is casting spells that require you to dodge them - bosses, elite mobs, pillars, you name it. The entire map becomes a chaotic mess of red swirlies. On top of that, there are knockbacks from boss spells, constantly trying to throw you across the map. It's just not fun.

The number of swirlies needs to be reduced. Perhaps consider removing the pillar curse or reworking it somehow. Additionally, losing control of your character is one of the most frustrating things in any video game. It would be great if the developers could make it less annoying.

Lastly, I believe this game would greatly benefit from having Life per Hit and Life per Second stats. Although I haven't tried every hero, it seems that the only hero with some kind of damage nullification is the Arcanist with Arcane Barrier. Having more options in this regard would be a nice addition

The game is good fun while you unlock characters, beat stages and unlock the various curses. 

Pros:
- Art style.
- Visual effects.*
- Skill variety.**
- Characters do feel distinct.

Cons:
- Although there are a significant number of skills, in reality, there are about 1/3rd of the total volume, but with different flavours. This allows build flexibility across various negative effects (weakness, bleed, haemorrhage, poison, rot, exposed, slow, doom, etc) and different elements (holy, fire, frost, poison etc) but bloats the skill selection somewhat.
- Visual effects are nice but overpowering. You will often need to turn them down or off otherwise you cannot see incoming damage markers and will die as a result.
- The game ends up at harder difficulties being a repeat of "aim towards spawning enemies while dashing in a circle avoiding ground indicators until you die or the bosses do" and with visual effects turned down enough it becomes very repetitive. 

Overall its a very solid entry in the genre, one of my favourites, but before you reach the kill 500,000 enemies achievement it should already have gotten to the stage of grinding materials just to unlock all the weapons and skill trees but the skills and gameplay loop by that point is likely to have already become too familiar and monotonous.

Summoner characters can be strong however due to abilities auto casting, increasing cast speed results in you constantly re-summoning your summons, preventing them from meaningfully staying on enemies to attack as they spawn at you. This means the later in a run you go with summons, the more you'll find yourself having melee summons run to mobs only to reach them and get re-summoned at you, not dealing damage.

Dodging damage is just a case of dashing out of the marker indicating when and where damage zones will be, but the further you go this just increases the frequency of these markers meaning you just need to keep dashing in circles. There's no meaningful tanking mechanics and although those skills exist it is only to lower the damage you take when inevitably you dash into damage or get stuck on terrain. As your run scales, enemies will also as you get through cycles, which increases their cast speed. With a strong build eventually your death will be due to an instant cast oneshot and unavoidable, so an infinite run is not possible.

A lot of the above may sound negative but these are my observations after 42 hours playing the game, For the price its been fun overall and I'm glad i purchased it. A lot of the above is also a hallmark of the genre, and this does give good variety when compared to the genre average.

So I started with Halls of Torment, then tried Vampire Survivors, and they're decent games.  When I tried this game, it's like it's on a whole other level.  There's options for all the big issues you normally run into in this genre.  Option to turn off advanced graphics if the effects are taking up the whole screen (happens late in a build) so you can avoid hazards.  There's an option to disable auto-level up so you can hit Q and level when you choose so your level up doesn't pop up when you're in a sea of red.  Auto-aim option with an over ride key you can set (default right mouse) to temporarily manually aim.  There's an option to change the crosshair size and color so you can see it easier.  Option to auto-pause if the game loses focus.  Those are the good QoL things that I like.

Soundtrack is great, graphics are too.  There's skill trees with advanced skill trees I've yet to unlock.  There's character unlocks.  Blacksmith to change weaps that have different base skills on them and change character stats like move speed, armor, dash, etc.  There's a rune system to further build your toons (you'll need to set runes for each of your toons, its not a global setting.

Easily the best game of the 3 I've played of the genre.

Of the 6-7 I've played, this is my favorite entry so far in the Survivors genre, particularly with the new skill tree upgrade system (partially) rolled out in the most recent patch.

The skills are fun, the bosses are fun, the scaling difficulty is mostly quite good. 

I will note my complaints/concerns, even though this is still a 9/10 game for me.  Not gamebreaking but hopefully issues to fix:
1) The tank-type NPS (paladin) don't seem to be quite tanky enough particularly for modes that have 3, 5, 8 bosses up at a time, but in some ways not even tanky enough for a lot of normal mobs unless I'm missing something. They should get more scaling from armor/block/dmg reduction rather than just a base increase, since the base quickly gets outscaled. Ironically pet/golem builds allow for less reliance on speed.
2) Another boss or two wouldn't hurt, albeit despite the lack of boss types (4-5?) the game's real boss challenge comes from the various combinations of many you'll run into on higher challenge modes.
3) I'll add it if I remember which one, but there's a blue skill in one of the mage builds that, when amped up with area/frequency/multi-cast becomes almost literally blinding.  More prominently, a few other builds block out damaging ground effects and terrain features and with certain buildouts I end up dying because my own spells make seeing what I should be avoiding impossible to see.  While the graphics are truly fantastic, I hope the devs work on either transparency or filtering in things you need to avoid over your own damage effects.

Those few issues aside, I think this is a fantastic game already (10/10) for anyone who can stand a bit of circular kiting in their gaming life and I look forward to seeing what the devs do with this as it proceeds.

I think this game should be re-named [b]"Crack: the game"[/b] or [b]"Addiction Simulator"[/b]

Soulstone Survivors is flat-out ADDICTIVE
When you beat 4 bosses at a time, get so many power-ups, not a SINGLE enemy can touch you, or kill a boss in less than a second (before it fully spawns in, even), it makes you feel like an absolute god. 

The simple control-scheme is great, too. As someone with a neurological condition, I struggle to use my keyboard properly anymore. I don't often possess the speed or accuracy to do a fair few of the games i used to be able to play. But with Soulstone Survivors, you're only required to press the space bar at the right time (along with moving the mouse). 
I'm able to get the sense of being a GOOD gamer again, slaying the map with my insane magic combos. 
It's [i]w o n d e r f u l[/i]

A few other reasons to buy Soulstone Survivors:

- killer soundtrack (great percussion, awesome bass, epic violin)

- absolutely AMAZINGLY OP magic combinations. Seriously, I think I've managed to stack around 10-12 debuffs on my enemies at a time (it's hard to count in the heat of the moment)

- ENDLESS combinations of skills. I genuinely think this game has the most variety of skill combos in ANY game of this genre so far (think Vampire Survivors, 20 Minutes Until Dawn, Magic Survival, etc). This game takes those and buffs them up with ALL the steroids, lol 

- TONS of classes to play with, all with unique skill trees

- Early Access, so it's only going to get better from here. From what I can tell, updates are often and the devs are active... Even if the devs fell off the face of the Earth today, there's still hundreds of hours of different class/spell combos in here. 

- Steal of a price! for $12, you're getting an insane amount of content. Seriously, nab it while you can! I'd say this game is easily worth double that, lol

**PRO TIP**: Go to the graphics settings and change the special effects down to about 50% opacity.

[h1]"Vampire Survivors is that you?"[/h1]
After the huge success of shoot'em up roguelike games, more companies are trying their hand at creating the perfect competition. In this case, we get better graphics, a class system and a forge, significantly changing even basic character skills. All this makes the possibility of combinations almost limitless, and different types of gameplay such as endless mode or overlord mode or the presence of curses only add depth. The game is surprisingly difficult, especially for a new player, who, quickly advancing to higher levels of curses, may bump into a wall. Nevertheless, the initially challenging difficulty level and the multitude of things to do make it money well spent. 

Unfortunately, it was not without downsides. I see the most serious one as repetitiveness. The maps, despite the different graphics, have the same bosses, the next levels of the curse, instead of making it more difficult to fight the existing ones, simply spawn several of them at once. Despite having a class system you are able to choose the same skills on several of them, making the once chosen build used to go through the game with all classes. In addition, despite having gameplay modes, they only boil down to changing the number of bosses and their HP. All available achievements are done on the basis of killing a certain number of bosses/monsters or hitting a certain level, which ultimately gets boring. 

Nonetheless, it should be noted that the game is constantly evolving, as evidenced by the recent huge update to the class system, and with future updates it could reach a whole new level. I look forward to it.

[h1]Tips:[/h1]
- Don't hate the class after the first encounter, because one good build can change your whole attitude (I myself hated Death Knight, but after discovering one build I ended up with the highest level on this character).
- Use the overlord cycle to farm raw materials. It shortens the gaps between bosses = more resources.
- The summoned creatures are OP. You can take a necromancer, all the skils for summoning and make Curse 7 without any problem.
- Turn off the visibility of your skils in the menu. This will ease the burden on your computer and allow you to dodge opponents better.

Decent casual arcade rouge-like. This game does not try too hard to be something its not. It's a good "its been a long day at work, I just want to relax" kind of title. I would give this more of a neutral-positive if I could.

Its a pretty standard gameplay loop where you pick a character and some starting buffs and then get dropped in with wave after wave of baddies. There are lot of characters and initial buffs to pick from. The game is fast-paced and character builds quickly become chaotic in a fun/crazy way. You collect resources along the way through a run to unlock permanent, character-agnostic buffs in a modest tech-tree. Visuals and audio are overall pretty good I felt. 

That being said, the gameplay loop is arguably a bit bland. The game overall has an overarching feeling of being very easy. While in a run you gain levels which in turn allow for a choice of powerups. The powerups are always positive powerups, without forcing you to make any hard choices for your character and the health of the run. There is no mechanic to weaken one of your abilities while strengthening another, for example, they are all positive outcomes. 

As a side note: the scaling in this game quickly becomes asymmetric and it does not seem possible to extend a run through 4-5+ rounds of bosses regardless of how overpowered your character gets in the first few rounds - the scaling quickly becomes asymmetric past a couple rounds in.

This one is still in early access so it would be nice to see some balance changes to add a little more of a challenge and maybe some more features in the near future. That being said, its a decent casual game for reasonable price right now.

If you really enjoyed the feeling of building passive power in Vampire Survivors, but want a bit more character building and active play, you can't go wrong here. This hit that itch perfectly, and more. Really excited to see future updates!

Great Vampire Survivors-like game that hits the difficulty curve just right. Ran wonderfully, no crashes, just a bit of hiccuping when it had a lot of effects on screen. Levels are tight and small, but still enough room to dodge around, and if played well enough, allow for an Endless mode (loop through levels until you die) or Overload (slowly building boss rush!). Runes to collect and unlock that allow you to tweak your builds before you even get into a match. There's even a few holiday secrets to hunt down, available even outside of the season, that unlock more skills, which was a great surprise!

As of writing, a few classes have advanced skill trees and specializations, and I'm really interested to see more when future updates arrive. Weapon crafting that tweaks passive stats to start and unlock more skills, though not everyone has their epic yet. And one currency that doesn't seem to do anything just yet... Not that you're at a lack of materials to collect and money to earn, of course!

[b]Кролики - это не только сезонный скилл, но и 3-4 миллиона ахренительного, легкоприменяемого дипса![/b]

А если серьёзно, то в патче на момент написания отзыва критовые саммоны выносят боссов на высоких значениях проклятий по щелчку пальцев. А если ещё руны на дамаг добавить к этому - вах!

Вышеописанное так же является примером главной проблемы игры на текущий момент - отсутствие вообще хоть какого-то понятия баланса в эффективности навыков. Даже в данном конкретном случае среди саммонов есть явный фаворит, оставляющий позади остальные возможные варианты.

Так же абсолютно мимо кассы всё, что заставляет игрока останавливаться для подбора. В стартовых условиях это ещё как-то работает, но чем выше уровень проклятия - тем меньше времени на передышку в маневрировании между парой сотней красных кругов на земле, иллюстрирующих области поражения врагов. Так что, да - это одна из игры, где остановка почти всегда равна смерти.

Ещё у меня персонально есть проблема с коллизией объектов на карте - персонаж постоянно цепляется за угол коряги или стены, хотя визуально там ещё есть место для прохода. В условиях абзаца выше это может легко отправить в таверну, т.к. с дамагом на высоких курсах враги вообще не шутят.

А, ну и да - сразу выкрутите в настройках видимость эффектов в минимум, иначе потом на экране ничего не будет видно, и можно там же сразу включить автоприцел на ближайшего врага, как в Vampire Survivors. Автоприцел - фу? Не льстите себе: выцеливать конкретного врага вручную в той мешанине и одновременно уворачиваться от сотни атак - это надо иметь очень хорошую реакцию. К тому же большая часть эффективности всё равно сводится к разгону АоЕ в половину экрана и выше.

Так а почему отзыв-то положительный с такими тезисами? Да как бы...

If I could give a neutral review I would since I have very mixed feelings here, first of all the gameplay is great and I like they added the dash button, it gives and extra something on top of the Vampire Survivors formula, the effects are awesome weapons are cool and the options to increase the visual effects transparency and modify a few things such as how leveling up works are amazing options and auto-aiming lets you play however you prefer instead of locking you up to a specific way, overall gameplay is very fun.

Now the BAD:
The grind here to progress your characters is stupid, like for real is too slow I guess is just a cheap way from developers to keep you playing for long BUT it is ridiculous the amount of minor soulstones dropped in late game is so low and your characters levels up so slow you will barely see any progress in their skill tree, so get ready to make hundreds of runs with a single char to reach max level. The special abilities of some characters is very weird and not organic to the gameplay since you need to stand still in a specific point to charge your ability while being bombarded from everywhere, is a bad design. Also there are too many power ups while playing especially the passive abilities and you are only offered 3 at the time so your options are pretty limited some times and you are forced to choose something useless. The enemies will overpower you out of nowhere most of the times not because your build is bad but because the enemies scale faster than you when playing infinite mode.

Overall this game has great potential but feels more like a job than a game when farming levels in the skill tree.
3 options when leveling up are not enough, 4 would be better also considering here passives have rarities.
Rarity chance should increase with your levels while playing so we don't get a normal passive at level 100
Add more banish and rerolls.
Allow to banish skills before the run, the same way Vampire Survivors allows this.
And finally improve how the abilities charge for some characters, just let them charge with kills and let it be, standing still in a point is not fun.
This is THE Vampire Survivor's style game that EVERYONE should start with to get into the new subgenre. It's way more polished visually and easier to get into than VS

Good fast-paced action roguelite game where you fight your way through hordes of enemies to collect Soulstones and level up a huge skill tree that makes you stronger each run. There is a lot of replay value thanks to the variety of characters and weapons to choose from.

If you are a fan of games in this genres, then you should definitely give this one a try. It is a great game that is sure to keep you entertained for hours on end.

The game is constantly updated by active devs so expect new contents once in a while.

WHY THE HELL IS HEALTH SO HARD TO GODDAMN FIND

probably my favorite game in the genre (kinda autobattler, kinda bullet hell, but also a lot of hack'n slay arpg)
unlike most other bullet hell/auto battlers you actualy don't battle auto (yes, attacking is automated), but instead you are quite involved and active. you are constantly dodging, moving, targeting or making split decicions about what to do: collect exp to level, collect mats for the extensive skill and crafting system, grind mobs, kill bosses or use the countless character/class specific advanced mechanics. 
while the core appearance reminds one of autobattlers ala Halls of Torment or Vampire Survivors, it's honestly way more involved (in all the right ways).

the presentation ain't CP2077, but it's definitly not an ugly game, it has quite a Torchlight vibe (the good ones) and the brilliant OST does the rest of bringing this game to live. it's just pleasant to watch and listen to.

all this would already be "good", but their whole approach to meta-progression is probably the best in the genre currently.
different run-locations offer different materials (again coming in different rarities), which are all needed for weapon crafting (permanent choices/improvements to individual classes, that sometimes change their core-gameplay quite a lot), or unlocking boni via a pretty decently sized skill-tree (offering both class specific upgrades and boni for all classes).
so there's a skill-system, there's a crafting system, but there's also a "rune system". 
via unlocks you can net a pool of rune-slots, which in turn can be used to equip specific runes (unlocked by various means, like the skill-tree, or specific dungeon challenges). these runs again are a pretty massive progression and customization system allowing even another layer of permanent build crafting.
and still it doesn't end there; during individual runs you earn prestige-exp for the class you are currently playing, which nets you skill-points for the skill tree, aswell as opening up level requirements for weapon-crafting, but also lets you improve each class (currently there about half? implemented) with unique class-mechnics; like unlocking the ability to find food for your dogs on kill with the Hound/Hunter-class, which opens up a whole new layer of inrun choice (imagine something like a warrior-rage mechanics in a mmo).

most of the popular auto-battlers/action roguelike offer pretty solid core-gameplay mechanics, but you will be hard pressed to find a game coming even close to the brilliant perma-progression systems Soulstone Survivors offers.
Frenetic and fun, albeit sometimes with a little too much going on on screen all at once. Dev keeps improving it and adding nice features. Definitely one to stick around for!

The verdict is the game is worth the price tag, and if you like Vampire Survivor, you'll like this.

The good:
The unlocks seem consistent. Currently every run feels like a progress toward something new or a boost to my character. The music is good. The graphics are cartoony, in a good way. In the late game, you get that god-like feeling if you've built your character well. At 19 bours in, there's still a lot of things that keep me hopping back on to do a run. For $10? That's a damn steal.

The bad:
Currently there's only 5 bosses (?). Maybe there's more, but I've only encountered 5 after my 20-ish hours of play. Hopefully there'll be more in the future. Secondly, once you get further and further into a run, the thing that will likely kill you will be your own skills. Some of the abilities' animations are TOO much that you literally cannot see any telegraphs on the floor causing you to get hit needlessly. Yes I want to see my character get stronger and the abilities looking cooler, but making a giant pillar of earth cover my whole screen ain't it. Maybe allow an option to make the abilities of choice invisible, or allow the enemies' abilities and your character visible through yours.

Update: So I stand corrected. There is a way to reduce the visibility of the abilities. However, by do that, it removes the visual of ALL of your abilities which then makes the game look bland. Hopefully in the future, they'll implement something to balance things out.

This game is being quite actively added to, but I've ultimately come to the conclusion that this game just isn't really for me. I love survivors-style bullet heaven games, but the reason I like them is because I can kind of just half-play them and once I get really built can just kind of leave my character there farming.

This game is not like that at all. It gets more and more stressful over time and eventually you have to be constantly spamming dodge because there are so many projectiles flying absolutely everywhere. It doesn't matter how much clear you have, how built out you are, you will always have to be constantly dodging once you hit the endgame. There's also no life regen or lifesteal so you have to wander the map for life crystals.

It's a very farming-heavy game, which I like because yay progression, but that farming feels like such a chore when I have to be constantly dodging for 25-30 minutes.

In short: A bullet heaven with surprising amount of depth and customization, albeit somewhat dependent on roll of a dice. Great OST, decent meta-progression options, gigantic selection of skills once you unlock most of them, somewhat spotty difficulty scaling.

In long: Soulstone survivors was something I kept my eye on pretty much ever since it had a steam page and while still in relative state of infancy it already offers a rather impressive slate of characters, skills, options and various ways to tailor the horde slaying to your taste while sprinkling that experience with just a tiny bit of the good ol' ARPG style. So how do we slay the literal thousands of mobs and what are our respective tools of various levels of violence?

First layer is your character choice, every character has several skill tags which define what pools the level system will pull from once you level during a wave, these tags are further defined by a weapon, all characters have 3 weapons, some have 4. Important thing to note, these weapons are not distinct upgrades from one and another, mostly sidegrades and they are your founding blocks for a build you plan to go for. I.e. Want to go set the world on fire? We pick a pyromancer with a fire oriented staff. Want to become a literal lightning tornado, pick a berserker and give him his electric axes. 

Second layer is your skill tree, in other words, the meta-progression, simple stuff, inner ring is shared among all characters, outer ring is character specific improvements along with specific class abilities, which is a rather genius way of preventing all of the characters from becoming just a blob of "skins" by making them have unique abilities and specific preferences and biases.

Now we are set and ready to go, we pick a map and go horde slaying, right? Wrong. Well, almost wrong. Currently there are 5 maps and each map (after you beat it once) has a curse rating, which as the name suggest is a way for you to gain more goodies from every wave at the cost of the game becoming harder. I'm pleased to tell you these are not distinctly just making mobs tougher, there are things like making elite opponents more numerous and spawn more often, have suicidal goblins that run into you and cause massive knockback, potentially pinballing you straight into a group of mobs, straight up more bosses, curse towers that shoot at you from wherever they spawn on the map because f*** you and your HP, meteors that fall from the sky in your general area when you kill ANY ENEMY AT ALL! You get the point, you can make the game pretty damn hard if you choose to.

Once we are through that, we go into a map and from there it's your familiar bullet heaven experience, start at level one, enemies drop exp for you to pick up and level in that run, kill roughly 3000 enemies and 5 bosses and win. 10-15 minutes a run, simple, easy to pick up and fairly nice to play in short bursts... or you can choose to go endless and fight till you drop dead, good news here is, once you finish the first wave, the run is considered won and even if you later on die in endless there are no penalties on the amount of meta goodies you've acquired during it. So if you feel like pushing yourself, the game is happy to reward your effort.

So on the whole it's a pretty damn good game, the arstyle is simple but colorful and gets the job done, the music is bumping, the numbers are big, the skills are nice and diverse, the potential of crazy builds is basically unlimited if you want to push into endless. Even right now, I'd say the game is well worth the price and often ends up in sale.

Little gripes/Wishes for future content:
Early on basically anything is viable as long as you know what you are doing, in higher difficulties, viability of a lot of builds basically falls off a cliff and only a very focused set ups have a fighting chance to get anywhere.
Some skills are not created equal and some status effects are drastically worse than others. Summoning builds can push drastically further than most others.
I hope for there to be some sort of prestige/paragon system for characters that would reward you for playing them with improved stats, say every level of prestige above 100 you have on any character will grant them 1% improved in a stat randomly chosen from a pool of all stats in the game(Think golden eggs from Vampire survivors, small but permanent upgrades). That way you would have a reason to focus on a character you enjoy even after you max out their skill tree.

Knowing this is in Alpha, I only have 3 issues with this game.

1: Collision
For the love of God, please fix this or do something with it.
Getting stuck/glued into the walls gets me killed 90% of the time, this also applies to getting stuck into enemies as well, this also completely stops your dashing as well if you are so much as one pixel colliding with something...

2: Enemies bunching up/concentrating in one spot.
I have noticed this problem where the enemies tend to bunch up in one spot, especially the bosses like to do this. 
This only gets worse if you have Chaos Golems as your active skill.
All the enemies/bosses bunches up into one spot and as soon as your approach them, they all start casting their spells, causing you to be unable or barely able to approach the enemies to get some damage in. Borderline causing a softlock.
(The game isn't softlocked but you get what I mean, unless you wanna get clapped, by all means...)


3: Certain enemies causes WAY too much lag.
In later stages, or when you go deeper into the void, certain enemies when casting spells starts lagging the game badly. 
I have seen dips in the FPS hitting in the teens, and causes heavy input lag, so not only am I fighting massive hordes of enemies, I am also fighting against input lag.
I know this isn't my PC skill issuing (Ryzen 7 3800X and GTX 1080ti) since this issue is very similar to Risk of Rain 2 when you loop the game enough.

All and all, knowing this game is still being developed. I really do enjoy this game and would recommend others :)

Just out of interest, I have pulled the most recent 3 negative review from this game at the time of my viewing.  They are as follows -
"Lacks soul." - yfz
"getting repetitive fast with almost no deference between runs" - No_Regert
"Enemies NPCs have to much AOE attacks it becomes impossible to finish a single run after a certain level because of onehitkill AOEs." - Nidux

Here is why I am giving a thumbs down even though I have enjoyed the game to a certain degree (if only Steam would allow nuanced reviews).  I agree with all three.  All the various characters and their skills are not balanced well against end-game scenarios.  Why even have them?  Summons are King.  Literally, Chaos Golem for the win?  Why?  Because you can forget even getting close to the action as a normal player character without getting wiped possibly before your first run ending without Golems cleaning things up for you.  This game has a TON of potential.  I just don't see the balancing happening.  If it does, I'll change my review.

A solid 9/10 game with the potential to become a 10 imo.

I'm expecting to see more whack in upcoming patches: faster start of runs, more curse variants, an even bigger skill tree, new lords, artifacts/relics (like in Risk of Rain 2) to change the game even further, maybe even skill fusions, more runes, ... and the list goes on!

Fun take on the bullet heaven genre with a lot of depth and build diversity. Really enjoyable, I have a lot of small issues with the game, but I believe it's because the rest of the game is so enjoyable that annoyances stick out more.

For my list of small issues:
1) Build diversity is great at low curse levels, but certain builds start to REALLY stand out above others at higher curse levels (summons and ice vortex especially at the time of this review) but that can and has been previously balanced.
2) Weapons take too long to gather the materials to craft, similar issue with the extended skill trees but much less of an issue there.
3) Overlord mode (red portals) has weird scaling on it, boss attacks start to cast faster, so at high overlord levels the game is literally just about spamming dodge and hoping you don't get hit by all the one shots that bosses are spraying out.
4) By default, the game is absolutely blinding once you get a build off the ground. Your spells will block out your entire screen. There is a slider in the graphic section that helps this, however spells scale very differently so a helpful spell to see might be nearly invisible while other spells that still block a massive portion of your screen still show even with the slider turned way down.

All that being said, probably my favorite game I've played of the bullet heaven/survivors type of game.

This game has come a long way.  Enough that I had to change my review.

1.  Characters now actually feels unique and not carbon copy of one another in different skin.  Many different skills and combinations are possible and viable for majority of the content.

2.  Dodge actually feels like dodge, unlike in olden days when you can dodge and still get hit in mid animation, now you can dodge at last second to negate big boss damage.    Instead of having to stack armor to take hits, you can build an evasion tank.

3.  Each map has their own unique encounters.  maps are no longer just background difference and feels and plays differently.    

Overall the game has addressed majority of my gripes and complaints.  Now it is a game that I can recommend to others unlike in the past.  *not sure if this is implemented or not but if green healing crystal heals percentage of health instead of set amount, it'd add another dynamic to builds.

It's a good game. Solid foundation so far. No bugs that I've run into, but I also haven't been trying to break the game.

Good music, Solid Gameplay, Minimal Bugs, sound effects aren't super annoying (and can be toggled off/on).DPS numbers can be toggled on or off, as well as set to show different numbers from source damage type (magic, DoT, physical, etc). 

Abilities are varied enough to make each build feel different, but not so much that you can't see synergies in the abilities.

[strike]However, the game doesn't really feel like a roguelike/lite. No much in the way of progression in between runs. No big stat boosts, no semi-permanent modification or upgrade to the abilities. There's just not enough to spend the base Soulstones on, to be honest. There's very little in the way of upgrading and permanency after each run, even if you prestige 30+ times in one run.Skill Tree nodes rapidly require the Void Lord Crystals past 2 or so levels, and that seems to be the only place to spend the Soulstones. I've just started and I have an excess of some 500k+ Soul Stones after getting almost everything on the Skill Tree upgraded. I have one thing left to get to max level, and that requires Void Lord Crystals, not Soul Stones. I'm hoping once I max those, that the skill tree will "reset" or "upgrade" to a second level with those added to base stats, but not expecting that.I'd ask for more levels / increased stats / more expansive stats (ie, ailment chance, xp multiplier, etc) in the Skill Tree. [/strike] No Longer application to the current version of the game. All of this has been greatly expanded in the latest patch (Path of Ascension).

All in all, it's a fun game, but it can use some work, which is expected in Early Access. I'm definitely going to be playing this more in the future, especially if the roadmap is accurate on the number of things they have planned to release (345 skills, 21 characters, 105 weapons, etc). As is? Recommended. Hopefully that won't change in the future.

EDIT: [strike]One thing I would heavily recommend is that Summon skills not go off if they're at max capacity and nothing needs to be summoned. Summon skills + Cast frequency for buff or other damage skills often results in summoning minions before they can even get to an enemy and attack more than once or twice. It's annoying.[/strike] -- A Patch removed this concern. Summons are now healed if the spell is cast with them alive and fully summoned.

EDIT 2: I have discovered that the Status Effects make me want to flip a table. Not enough to change the recommended status of the game, but enough to make me frustrated. Weakness, for instance, increases damage taken by enemies by a %. It varies wildly. Some skills apply it for 24%. Some apply it for 3%. Which one is applied first? Do they stack or override each other? I'll sometimes have hundreds of stacks of a status effect on an enemy, but I have no idea which one's are doing what amount of damage. Burn deals different damage per 8 seconds for almost every skill. How do I know if it's doing the 800 damage from the highest skill or the 100 from the lowest for 5 seconds? Do all the different DoTs from Burn deal damage at the same time? Do they go in order?

I have 100 hours on Vampire Survivors. This game is a whole other beast.

[b]Pros:[/b]
-Characters feel unique and balanced.
-Absurd amount of skills means an absurd amount of flavor to your builds on top of a big build variety.
-Enemies have a LOT of different attacks.
-Game can still be difficult even after maxing out a character.
-The Rune system adds a whole bunch of different sidegrades for added replayability.
-There's almost always something to perma upgrade before the next run, Ascensions, Runes, Weapons, the main Skill tree, there's a whole lot of upgrades and sidegrades to grind for.

[b]Cons:[/b]
-Unlike Vampire Survirvors, this game is just mindless gameplay. There's not a hint of a story or a meaningful boss fight. No gimmicky secret levels or special encounters. They could at least make a different, way more powerful boss for the VI difficulty, but instead you get to fight 4 bosses at the same time.
-The linear weapon upgrade system makes me feel like I have less choices than I actually have. It's perfectly viable to make an Arcane build for the last Spellblade weapon (the only Epic one so far), but it gives you a Fire skill and it's visually made of fire.
-I might be wrong about this, but it feels like summons are a bit broken. The main difficulty of the game comes from having to dodge all of the crazy telegraphed attacks, but just one Chaos Golem skill is enough to disperse the attacks so much that most attacks don't ever come near me. Still, you can become really broken without them, but there's something here.
Hopefully my computer passes the next round.
This is a high quality game of the genre, well worth the price even if not on sale.

The Dev seems to only know one trick: knock-up. Every attack is a knock-up. It's boring.

It also stops the player from playing. While you're flying through the air, you're not doing what you want to do. Removing agency from the player constantly is just not a good game design choice. 

The game does look nice, but all of the effects are enormous. The only options for making the playing field more visible is to increase the transparency of every effect. This might reduce the number of seizures you're going to have, but it does not actually improve the information you're receiving. 

There is no indicator of any effect applied to the player. You have no idea what DOTs are on you or how long they will last. 

Varying the attacks (fewer knock-ups, for one) and improving communication (smaller visual effects, icons indicating current DOTs and the time remaining, etc), and generally providing more specific details would flip this to a thumbs up.

As to the last item, player attacks and effects have very little actual information. Two immediate improvements would be 1) hovering over an ability would show an outline of the attack pattern on the screen and 2) actual numbers, such as the 'area' of an ability showing '1' for the base area and then larger numbers as the area increases, would make it possible to understand what the percentage increases would be working with. The 'area' number could just be a relative number, not a number of pixels, but just about anything would be an improvement over nothing. Apply the same ideas to damage numbers.
