I really enjoyed this game. The start feels super easy and getting my first clear took me 2 tries, so I was wandering if there is any way to keep me entertained. The game introduces a system of curses which makes the game harder by spawning more enemies, making your heals less effective, etc. which makes next runs more challenging.

Pros:
- Decent replayability with big variety of spells and curses
- Big character pool (characters need to be unlocked through achievements, although most of them are easy)
- Every character has 3/4 weapons to choose from making spell building even more variable (must be crafted and characters need some lvls to unlock them for crafting)
- Skill tree is a really nice way to feel like you are progressing even though you have basically cleared the entire game
- I really like the graphics. They are simple but nice

Cons:
- Extremely low drops of materials (even with the rune I get ~250 base mats per run and you need up to 1,2k to craft a single weapon), so getting more weapons is tedious and doesn't feel good
- Extreme amounts of AoE DoTs. Only bosses, "invaders" and few monsters have these. The monster ones are fairly weak and disappear after a little while. From the invaders, the only bad one is Death Knight and bosses with DoTs are all bad. I am not against the idea of reducing the space where I can move. But at full curse it is basically impossible to walk around, because the DoTs stay on the ground for like a minute or so and they can put them down like 3 - 4 times a minute. [spoiler] At full curse intensity you get to fight 4 bosses and if you get unlucky you can get 3 with DoTs making your life a hell (especially if you play a DoT build) [/spoiler]
- Terrain... I am playing on a keyboard thus I can only move in 8 directions. If you just slightly dash into the wall, you get stuck. I hope this gets updated, it's very minor thing, but if it happens to you, you will most likely die or lose a lot of HP. Just make me slide along the wall or something. Stopping a dash because it goes slightly into the wall is just stupid.
- On full curse intensity, it is almost impossible to dodge some boss AoE attacks without the upgraded dash (rune).
- I also feel like the hitboxes drawn in the game aren't always showing the real hitboxes. I sometimes stand inside the Aelfraed's spinning attack and it does not damage me and sometimes I am pretty far away from it and it starts hitting me (I assume it is because the hitboxes are drawn above your character, but it's still not very user friendly), Tiaggro's laser doesn't have nearly as much range as is shown, Gammuth throws his rocks like 4/3 the distance shown, Keythaiz's laser is wider than it looks (initial indicator of hitboxes is correct, but if you get near it later, it is wider than it looks)
- Inconsistency in attacks, Aelfraed's shield bash is basically Tiaggro's saw attack but comes out [b]way[/b] faster, which wouldn't be a problem, but the tracking on those attack is just too insane.
- Hunters mount ability needs rework, it is by far the worst one and getting to mount the panther is never worth it, making the ability unusable.

Although I listed a lot of cons, they are mostly just problems at high curse intensity runs (41 - 48, anything below feels very nice most of the time). Earlier runs feel super balanced and basically anthing works there. I feel like the game needs a little polishing and will be a really nice way to spend 15 - 60 hours of your time.

[h1] Not yet. [/h1]
Soulstone Survivors has a solid base for the devs to expand on and refine. A fair number of characters with plenty of meta-progression to unlock, decent performance, acceptable graphics, some levels, some enemies. I'm primarily not recommending it because every run seems to reach the point where you smear the entire screen with constant, massive, colorful attacks that hide enemies (and their attacks). The main skills I was enjoying, Chaos, cause random debuffs— fun, in a way, but the debuff icons on every enemy started taking up several times the screen space that their 3D models and attacks did.

Suggestions to the devs:
More types of level-up bonuses, to dilute the pool instead of every run covering the entire screen in low-cooldown, huge AoE visual effects. Ex: change block to have a %chance of a flat damage reduction per hit taken; reuse current complete damage avoidance mechanic as "dodge"; partial homing/"lock-on" mechanic for projectile-based attacks
More enemy variety (basic goons look like recolors)
Higher base difficulty/better enemy attacks. (I haven't unlocked many Curses yet, but it felt too easy to get through multiple stages without being hit a single time) Goblin bombers felt like the only non-boss enemy to really warrant attention. Giving enemies a little more speed could help for both speeding up the early game and making it more difficult.
More gradual scaling for boss attacks vs player defenses? Seems like the only time the game gets difficult is when bosses are nearly one-shotting the player, because they have the hardest attacks to avoid.
More methods of player interaction-- stage mechanics (ex: traps that affect both enemies and the player), consumable items, manually-triggered long-cooldown skills, maybe different dodge-replacing movement skills

Sometimes a fun survivor game, but it has serious issues that need to be bailed out:

Pros:
-) Loads of different characters
-) Clear progression system via skill trees and rune system
-) Fun to play only for 10 minute or so

Cons:
-) Effect visibility is really, really poor, effect layering is completely off.... Hostile effects should always be layered above your own
-) There is no way to enter Overlord or endless modes in a stage you have completed previously ... go back to the start and play for 30 min if you really want to get to the next juicy lvl of the mode

Will revise my review once the issue with the effect layering is fixed, then it's really much more fun

I really enjoyed this game to begin with, and I don't hate it now but I am no longer a fan.  I wish there was a neutral rating for reviews.  I found the game to be fun during the early stages as you unlock skills, weapons and characters.  But once I got to the higher curse levels the difficulty gets artificially increased with the addition of towers that can snipe you from the other side of the map.  At that point it feels more like a rhythm game, timing your dodges to balance avoiding attacks while making sure one is always charged.  If you get caught by an attack you can get flung across the map, which either sets off a chain reaction of you getting hit or interrupts your dodge rhythm.  The decision to add in multiple bosses at once is great as they have a variety of attacks which can make things challenging in a fun way.  I also enjoy how crazy some builds can be, but there certainly seems to be some meta builds which isn't how I like to play.

The updates are regular and the devs are listening to the player base so I may revisit this review in the future.

I have enjoyed this and I am liking where the recent updates are pointing the future of this game towards. For the price point I was satisfied with what I got. 

Some Notes/complaints however:
1. Summons are way too OP just having one summon skill can carry you through the hardest curse setting.
2. Some abilities scale with area badly. They start to obscure too much of the screen. it becomes impossible to dodge incoming damage because I cant see anything. 
3. I think their needs to be more interesting mechanics to the curses. I liked the reaper that follows you. More stuff liked that rather than simply throwing more enemies and buffs endlessly. I like the idea of forced positioning. For instance a deadly mist rolls in and you have to find a safe spot to defend for a certain period. Stuff like that. 
4. Another thing about summons. I feel like summons should either take aggro really well or not take aggro and do a lot of damage. With the current state of the game. They do both monstrously well. My character feels weak because they do sooo much damage and also enemies start ignoring me for them. Its like why even get other abilities when they cant compare to summons other than for aesthetic reasons.

At first Soulstone Survivors felt like it was pushing a little too hard. I was used to the frictionless ease of Vampire Survivors, I wasn't used to my fights having texture. I admit I got mad at the game and started "pushing a little too hard" back at it. This was, in fact, very fun to do. And now, darn it, I get it: a little too hard is the perfect amount of push.

GRADE:  A (maybe not quite A+, but subject to change as the title continues to grow and improve) -- Breaks builds with the best of them, and has a more dynamic combat challenge than most (all?) of its competitors

This game is an incredibly well done Vampire Survivors-like experience with unique classes and good progression system to keep you playing. It also looks great and runs smooth even when you unleash total mayhem on the screen.
Worth trying!

At first I maybe wouldn't have recommended the game in its current state, but the new update to the game has added enough content to really bring some more bang for your buck. I was starting to run out of things to spend my currency on about 15 hours into the game, which I found incredibly strange. There was a feeling of, "surely there is more to this". But just my like a couple of days ago a new update dropped and now I have a massive skill tree to fill out that feels awesome. 

This game is like Vampire Survivors in many ways, but I think each game has it's own strengths. This game has better boss fights, a dodge ability for all characters and a better power fantasy where you will barely be able to see anything happening on the screen but it will still somehow feel pretty cool. Also the music in this game is an absolute bop.

However what Vampire Survivors does better is making each option feel strategic. Because Vampire Survivors core gameplay has limitations in the number of items you can carry, the game ends up having a little more strategy to it. It's not just about what you do pick, it's about what you refuse to pick. Banishing options also delays your power spike to remove some unwanted clutter from the long list of potential upgrades. Some things won't synergize with your build at all, and if you choose something that has less synergy, then you may forever be locked out of the best combination of items. This push and pull is a nice level of strategy. In Soulstone survivors you just endlessly power up. There are no bad options that won't synergize with your build. All upgrades are applicable and no matter what the screen will always be a blurry mess of nonsense that you will struggle to navigate through. For better or worse. 

I have had plenty of fun with this game so far, and plan on spending plenty of time experimenting with the horde of upgrades available in the game. Seems really grindy, but in a good way. 7.5/10

Edit3: Jun 4, 2023, after Path of Ascension major update. I seriously doubt the devs playtest their own game, because the balance is laughably bad. Here are two examples:  
[olist]
  [*] The Paladin has this light power up you can get. You need to "catch" the light when it fills up within a small area... and it's stupid. Why? Because the light area is random, and you basically won't stop moving on higher difficulty. Which means you'd rarely if ever be able to catch the light because the moment you stop is the moment you die. Which dev thought of this, and how did this got through playtesting is beyond me. It's a great power up... when you don't need them, because that's the time you can actually catch the light without being overwhelmed. In other words, the power up is a death trap!
  [*] Hunter and panther... just why? So you need to stay with range of the panther which runs randomly around once you try to link with it. The random run itself is a death trap because it can run into bosses or hit areas. But this is not the worst - the worst is that you don't know where the panther is! There's no indicator of where the panther is in the stage, so you are just running around blindly hoping to link to the panther. Sure, an icon kinda shows different sprites if you are near the panther... but you're not going to be looking for the icon change when you are running for your life. Like seriously, who designed this mechanic and why did they think randomly finding your panther is a good idea?
[/olist]  
Another thing that puzzles me is the devs does a live strea mof their runs. But they basically said "banish all defense upgrades" even on their own streams... if the defense upgrades are so bad, then why do you have them in the game? Make defense viable, or take them out! 
The devs works hard and push out new contents... except I think they somehow keep working on adding more shiny toys then caring to fix the gameplay. All the complaints I have below is still valid, especially with the boss spamming, fast tracking, and the need to focus fire. The game is hilariously out of balanced at higher difficulty, which the game wants you to get to because everything requires grinding... 
This is the last straw for me. I'll not be playing anymore of this game. And neither should you. Please put your time and money elsewhere, this is not worth it. It might look cool and fun in the beginning, but trust me, the more you play, the worse it gets.

Edit2: Apr 19, 2023 - yup, all the problems I listed still exist. Major update my ass.

Edit: updated Feb 24th 2023. 

[hr][/hr]

This game is frustrating.   
It's frustrating because it has good potential, but the balancing is off at the higher difficulty, by A LOT.  
This is STILL the case since I last updated this review, kinda tells you how the devs work.  
To be fair, there has been improvements, but overall I believe a closer look at WHAT and WHY something needs a rework would be better.

Let me explain:  

[olist]
1. Questionable balancing. Did the devs even play test this? At Curse level 30+, the difficulty is getting close to stupid, which exposes the many weaknesses of the game. For starter, the bosses tracks us way too much AND their hit area is too big, AND they hit too hard. Also, seriously, once we kill the boss/mob, any lingering effect from them on the field should be gone. I'm looking at their dead bodies but their ice crystal is preventing me from going near their crystal to pick it up... just why? And not to mention since the enemas get more health, they take longer to kill. So it's not uncommon to face 4+ bosses at the same time. The problem is... THE ENTIRE FLOOR IS MARKED WITH RED! And this highlights two design issues:  

[list]
  [*]  Stacking status effects requires focus firing, but the game refuses to let us to do at higher difficulty. Since the effects (poison, doom, etc) have a timer, like 6 secs, you'd want to stack as many of the same effect onto the same target as possible. Not too hard when you only need to pay attention to one target... things get silly when you are being chased by 6 bosses and you have to keep moving and dashing since the floor is covered with all kinda of dmg zones and effects. If you can just have the time to focus on one boss, maybe 10-20 sec you can burst it down. But because you have to keep running around and thus resetting the timers, it takes like 10 times longer instead.  

  [*] Bosses can synergize with each other and makes approaching even more difficulty than just facing the copies of the boss. When bosses come in pairs, they are still manageable but you already start to see the problem: you dashed through a boss attack to get a hit window., only to find the other boss is starting new attack, so you are force to get away. This gets a lot more frequent with 3+ bosses on the screen, to the point you are just running in circles and hope that you can find one window to get in without dying. THROWING MORE THINGS ON SCREENS IS THE BAD KIND OF DIFFICULTY. I hate to use the words artificial difficulty but this is it. The bosses are already faster than us and tracks us faster than we can run/turn unless we have like +80% in movement, but if we pump movement then our dmg output would be worse. Either make the red hit zones on the ground smaller, or reduce their dmg on player, or reduce attack frequency, do *something* to balance the game at higher level, please.
[/list]


  [*] [strike]The base soulstone currency is still useless.[/strike]

  [*] We need more runeslots, seriously. 6 runeslots limits the build we can make, and some runes is so good that they shouldn't be  a rune but rather part of the upgrade. Like getting the 2nd weapon for free - sure it takes only one slot, but why not just have it as a unlockable upgrade? Same with the dash upgrade - our dash feel incomplete without it, and makes sense with it, so this means that the dash upgrade should just be our normal dash. Don't nerf a power so you can turn it into an upgrade. That's bad design for a PvE game. Becaue the game is designed with dashing in mind, why not make dashing good by default.

  [*] The combat itself is annoying. Firstly, too many things to stop us from moving. It's nice that unlike other VS clones, we don't immediately take dmg when we run into enemies. But we do get stuck and need to use a dash. Random trees on the map, trash mobs, some those damn suicide bombers,   

  [*] Those towers are way too tanky at higher difficulty. It's almost not worth the time to kill them, but we should because they add more attacks on screen (yay!). Like seriously, what is this? If I want to play League and push towers I'll go play that. I'm playing this because I don't want to play League.

  [*] Powers/Skill balancing. Some skills are just too weak you wonder what's the point. Many of the starting skills of the weapon is too weak that it's better to replace them if you can. Which brings me to another point...  

  [*] Let us see what skills are accessible for each weapon! And similarly, we should see which additional runes we'd get when we equip the X mastery runes, like fire mastery. It says we get 6 fire skills to choose from - which 6? Just show us, why hide it?  

  [*] Why the 6 skill slots limit? Who decided that all VS clones should just have 6 powers? No, screw this, give us more power slots because the game balance is trash anyway.
[/olist]

TLDR: Game is not bad, kinda fun at lower difficulties. But once you get pass a certain level then things break down and exposes a lot of design issues with the core mechanics. I believe they could be fixed, but it's up to the devs. As for you who are interested in the game, just know that what others said is true - the more you play, the less enjoyable it gets.

Pros:
-Addicting
-Fun
-Fast Paced
-Great Music
-Replay-ability
-Class System (NEW) 
-Multiple Weapons (New weapons in recent update)
-No paywall or pay to win at all (No actual dlc shop :) )

Cons:
-Character balance (Some characters are FAR SUPERIOR to others (For example I was stoked to see a spartan and planned to happily main it but it's one of the less efficient classes in the game and is basically useless at higher difficulties)
-You'll lose track of time (5 hours felt like 1)
-Limited class advancement (A work in progress!)
-No multiplayer (would be fun but the game is fine without it)
-No in game store (Could be a pro as well but some skins and weapon skins to support the creators would be dope)
-Grinding for mats can be annoying since some only drop at the highest difficulties (It's really fine though, git gud nubs)
-Terrain Collision (Literally more dangerous than any boss xD)
-Just too much effects: For example if you run a chaos build, you will literally see NOTHING but your own skills, making harder to dodge. Would be nice to be able to see (You can do this by changing the opacity of your skills in the settings but even still :x)
-
That's about it! Enjoy.

The game is fun, i'll give it that much. But it has a long way to go. You will earn a ton of currency you can't spend because there simply is almost nothing to spend it on. Also a few skill categories are massively overpowered, while others are simply not viable for anything but the basic difficulties due to lacking in damage and/or survivability. Also there are only five bosses in the game as of now and quite a limited assortment of enemies you will cycle through quite fast. After that its just more of the same. More enemies, more bosses simultaneously, oftentimes you will face multiple copies of the same boss. Combined with the fact, that you will unlock most of the game defining stuff quite easily its not good for long time motivation. For now i would recommend trying out something like Vampire survivors and give the developers some time to implement some more things to do and balance things a bit more.
EDIT: Well as i wrote this review, a new patch came out with lots of new content. So we will see what that brings :)

It's just ok. There are some bad design choices like the special effects. Late game is pretty much instakill if you get hit so you have to turn them down to even be able to see anything and then it looks bad with not even being able to see your skills doing anything. The aoes also don't always render so deaths feel cheap. I've also had late runs where everything just dies offscreen and it's like every 30+ seconds I have to move to avoid an aoe.  

There is quite a bit of missing in game information, the rune system is really annoying in that it shows how to unlock the rune but not what it does, during runs you can't see what damage the different skills are doing so you don't know what to prioritize, and there are a lot of interactions that aren't detailed like what skills do summons get, when buffs get to longer than cast time can you get multiple copies.

Damn, i didnt expect this game to be so fun!

I have quite alot of those wave survivals or "vampire clones" so i wasnt expecting too much, but damn this is on a completely different level.

You can have active skills like any other game of this type, you cant level them up by upgarding them themselves, but by increasing their passive skills, there is NO upper limit on how high those passives go or how many you can have, so you end up with area modifiers of over 400% making you basically see nothing, especially if you pair it with multicast, its a bit bothersome but also super fun and epic. 

The game has an endless loop i guess, once you finish a stage you can go right to the next one with all upgrades, additionally the mobs will increase in difficulty aswell with each "cycle" i only played 2 hours so far, but it was a blast!

It's similar to other survior games, but thats about it, the game plays rather differently. If there was anything i could complain about its the variety of mobs and bosses, but that shouldnt be too hard to fix. Also, performance drops pretty hard when you achieve a certain level of attack rate/multicast/area modifiers, so i had to set it to low to not drop below 40fps. My pc can handle it easily, the game just seems to hit its limits.
But im absolutely loving this game

The variety of build strategies this game brings is huge. 
I played quite a few different styles:
-- Archer (?the one that has +1 dash) with Doom stacking and Shadow+Poison area type active skills that were doing damage for ~50% of the map.
-- Paladin with Holy light front and stacking of DoT skills + runes (unique rune to pick the same active skill multiple times).

When you start playing a game, even an office laptop easily handles graphics with 60FPS on high/ultra graphics. Well, it's only for the early game.

I am a bit disappointed that I could not reach a limit of the character build strategies, as the limit of my hardware power was reached way earlier :) When I started dealing tons of damage, like tens billions per second, and stacking thousands of debuffs in a second, I had an experience of playing with 2-5 FPS. I even downgraded FULL HD resolution to the minimum possible (800x600), picked very low graphics, and disabled visibility of my effects. It, unfortunately, did not help. Hence, my office laptop (HP 15-sqXXXXX, AMD Ryzen 5 4500U, 16GB RAM) could not handle the game.

The sickness of how far you can go with your builds is amazing. I tried only a few, and I enjoyed them a lot. However, I cannot continue playing the game due to limited hardware that cannot handle meta builds.

First the physics are wonky, the collision with hitboxes for both enemies and decarotive is awful and will get you stuck. Knockback makes no sense, it turns the game into a bouncycastle and bumps you either across the map or into all the enemies. The game without curses is too easy and with all curses the enemies are so poweredful, that you barely get to do anything.

If those things were changed, then yes, it would be a great game, but right now they are introducing new monsters to each map (which is cool and unique) making the game harder. They are also adding new weapon rareties (which is awesome), some of which are worse than the supposely more common ones (mainly because DOT damage and debuffs are make it or break it in this game, NEEDS TWEAKS).

If you want any chance, cheese the game with debuffs, because they are brokenly overpowered, compared to anything else in the game, which hits like wet nuddles.

Because the game imposes literally 0 limits on the number of passives you can get and how juiced you can make them literally every run ends up devolving into massive screen covering effects that all do ludicrous damage and makes every run feel the same, which should never happen in a roguelike, the whole point of the genre is to give a fresh experience every time you play. This is yet another game that looked at the success of Vampire Survivors and thought "why not try the same thing, but with better graphics and (slightly) more engaging gameplay?" So far, it's the best of the lot, easily outclassing Vampire Survivors, 20 Minutes to Dawn, etc. There is more moment-to-moment decision-making by the player than in VS, since some skills fire in the direction your mouse is facing, and you need to pay close attention to damage zones and telegraphed monster attacks to say alive, especially since there is minimal healing, meaning that every hit brings you closer to the end of the run.

The visuals are great for the most part, again outclassing other games in this subgenre. They remind me of Diablo 2/3 in many ways. My only real complaint is that by the late game, the visual field gets quite cluttered, but that was probably inevitable in a game like this. That said, there are some powers that completely overwhelm the screen once you have several area of effect upgrades, like the shockwave spell. Instead of creating a row of stalagmites along the ground, it raises what looks like an entire mountain range, temporarily blocking your view of the entire screen.

Why, then, the negative review? The answer is that even with some additional player input and more creative monster design, the VS subgenre remains cursed by shallow gameplay, and Soulstone Survivors does not manage to innovate out of that problem. The core gameplay loop still revolves around shallow character positioning decisions and a bit of mouse-look, and not much more. Additionally, there is an excessive amount of content gating, which is clearly intended to force the player into extended grinding sessions to pad out gameplay time.

Looking at how much basic grinding was required to achieve even minimal progress, I realized I just didn't care enough about the core gameplay loop to go through the motions in yet another VS clone, no matter how polished. So if you're tired of the VS subgenre, this game probably won't get you interested again. But if you've never tried this kind of game before

I guess I should have known what I was getting into with "survivors" in the title but I didn't look closely enough. 

This game plays itself as you walk in a circle for the entire gameplay loop, and there is close to zero input on the battlefield other than movement and the dodge button. Essentially all attacks happen themselves with zero or almost zero input on their effective function. 

The upgrade system is a farce/grind. Like in basically all games these days, upgrade prices increase insanely per point essentially giving you no choice at all about a build. You are pigeonholed into equally leveling everything up or you're just wasting money. Why is this so common in games now? Skill/talent trees used to mean something and require thought. And they also gave you a chance to express yourself by planning your character with thought and commitment. People just need a grind to become addicted I think, which sells well. **Edit to clarify: my comments about skill/talent trees is regarding permanent upgrades. Upgrades during each run are different and while they provide some choice, basically any choice feels the same as the rest - get skill, enemies explode.

Call me weird but it's troubling that this mindless gameplay is becoming so popular, when in reality the concept of this type of game has so much potential. But they are all almost entirely mindless and seem to thrive off people wanting to see bad guys exploding regardless of how braindead the actual play is. Every single one of these games has too many enemies and explosions for there to be any intricate deeper strategy to the combat. No enemy could actually do something interesting because the whole battle field is just diarrhea splatter and meaningful mechanics wouldn't fit well at the same time.

I hope someone figures this genre out, because it could really be something. But if this is what passes as an incredible job I don't see why anyone would try.

Nothing will ever beat the -experience- of Vampire Survivors, but Soulstone Survivors DOES win out when it comes to gameplay. You are able to move, aim attacks, and DODGE, and you better get real good at dodging real fast. There's never a point in SS where you can afk gold farm or just kill everything without thought; you're gonna be scrappin till you die every time. It differs from VS in that you choose your 6 main attacks (which you can change out at any point) but the passives are endless as long as you survive. This is definitely not just a lazy VS rip-off; it's a well thought-out, very fun addition to the genre. Oh, and bosses, lots of bosses!

Pros:
+ Lots of variety of skills.
+ Promising for being EA.

Meh:
* Many possible builds. Though only a strict few are viable on higher curse levels.

Cons:
- On higher curse levels you end up circling around your enemies as there's not many other viable strats.
- Too much aoe (everything is an aoe).
- On higher curse levels all enemies end up being bullet sponges.
- Resource gathering for items can take several days or weeks depending on how much time you have on your hands.

TLDR:
Looks promising for being in early access but could do with some balance changes towards higher curse levels.

Also: 
The video they're streaming at the very top of the store page is not representative of higher curse levels, if you'd like to get an idea of what higher curse is like I've linked a short video below.

https://youtu.be/7AuFmszEqEQ

Don't get me wrong, I love this game and I understand what they are going for. This game is in early access, BUT they really need to add long term "grinds" to the game. The rune system is very cool and interesting idea but feels like a failed concept. I would love the idea of grinding a LONG time for the ability to unlock 10, 15, or even 20 power for these. The idea that i can only equip 1 or 2 high level ones just feels boring and weak. There are 58 (if i counted correctly) runes, I understand they are powerful, but that's the idea of games like this. Start weak and be godlike towards the end after the grind. To be able to customize our characters how we want but still having to chose between very good options sounds great. I would also really like to see VERY hard to get achievements. Like have a run last multiple hours, or kill 1000 bosses in one run, etc with the rewards for completing these being worth while. That could just be stuff they plan to have for full release, i just wanted to make sure they have some constructive criticism. Other than those, I'm very pleased with the game. I would like to see more weapons, characters, etc in the future but as of right now there's a lot to go for and plenty of hours of gameplay.

Highly recommend. Why?

In short - graphics, soundtrack, unbelievable amount of variety and replayability. And lastly - clusterfuck. And that might I add is IN ALPHA.

Long version:

If you are like me, scrolling through games, trying to pick something with an oomph only to fail badly every day - you are in the right place. This game provides hours of fun. Gunfire Reborn was the last game that entertained me this much, and you have to agree, that game is God-tier.

Do you like a challenge? I do, Do you learn fast and can dodge everything like you were born for bullet hell games? Add some curses (difficulty changers) and you'll be lucky to find a spot for dodging. You finish a run under 10 minutes? Lucky you, Now go ahead, challenge yourself and finish 5 runs in a row, with each run getting harder and harder.

Do you hate being limited by skill level caps and just wish you could upgrade your skills until your NASA PC bursts into flames? Here you go. Increase your skills into such lengths, that they'll cover up half of your screen and you'll get an epileptic seizure, even if you never had epilepsy.

Do you love a good banger? This damn soundtrack makes you steal those studio speakers from your job you always wanted, just so you can MacGyver them to your 20 year old amplifier and head-bop while you kill bosses (in-game bosses, don't kill your actual bosses or you won't be able to play this game in prison).

Have you ever wondered what it would be like, to stack 200 stacks of poison in a game on an enemy just to be cucked by more limitations? No worries here mate, there's so many enemy debuffs in this game that stack forever and ever, that they'll go off your screen if you try hard enough.

Do I recommend this game? Yes. Will I finish it soon? I'll let you know in 200 hours of playtime.

___Conclusion___
It's quite an entertaining game. Since it's not that expensive either, I can recommend it, it's fun, I will definitely continue to play it. However, farming is a bit boring for me in the long run and the game loses its appeal relatively quickly. I've tried many different vampire survivor like games and in my opinion there are much more "exciting" ones. But overall it's a cool game with unique mechanics and graphics. If you like the game principle, you will definitely have fun with the game, so I can recommend the game, but you should be aware that especially in the late game the grind for upgrades to progress is relatively high and takes a long time, which is a bit boring.

Holy crap is this game addicting. Lots of characters and skills to unlock and the speed at which you can unlock things is very fast, at least at first. It looks like it will take a long time to unlock all the runes. The gameplay itself is very smooth, and it's severely fun toward the end of the run, when you're pumping out so much magic that the whole screen is nuclear. (Turning off your spell graphics is not only possible, but becomes necessary, as there are more and more hazards that you need to dodge, and you can't see anything when the screen is filled with your huge, constant spells.) But no matter how powerful you can get, you're never overpowered. Harder enemies are always sent in. The runs themselves are kinda bite-sized, which I love. You can complete a whole run in 10 minutes, and head back to the title screen with tons of progress. Perfect as a palate cleanser if you're also playing games that have a bigger time investment. Also really nice if you have a bit of time to kill on a lunch break. I imagine this game would be rad on the Steam deck. As far as the negatives, I could use a little more variety in the bosses and the stages. It looks like there are only 5 of each. Be prepared to fight the same boss multiple times per run. I could be wrong, but that's what it looks like so far. And although it looks like there are a lot of classes, they're not really all that different. They each get stat modifiers that only matter in the early part of a run, before you start buffing the hell out of everything. Their starting ability is always different, but they all use 6 out of the bank of 12(??) types of damage in the game.

EDIT: I still wish there was more variety in stages and bosses. But after playing awhile longer and unlocking the later classes, there's more variety there than I thought. The main difference between classes, other than stats, is your starting ability (or abilities, each weapon has up to 2), which is unique to that class and that weapon. I still play this game even after getting every achievement and unlocking everything. Developers, please give me more reasons to grind this masterpiece.

EDIT 2: I'm not sure why I'm about to ask this, since it would lengthen my play time even more, but here goes. Could we do something about getting hung up on trees? 75% of my runs end not because I get overrun by the infinite army, but because I get hung up on tree geometry. In a game where you have similar destructible objects like crate piles and stalagmites, you're telling me I can't chop down a little tree? And said trees will almost always lead to my demise? I don't believe you. This game is about fighting a huge army that never ends, and yet that army is powerless to stop me unless the pine tree holds me down. The pine tree, which doesn't attack at all and does zero damage, and smells nice to boot. Come to think of it, maybe you could just let us zoom out a bit. After 3 rounds of boss rush, not being able to see more of the stage (and the deadly pine trees) is really what kills us. And please, take what I'm saying with a grain of salt. This is a great game and it almost never annoys me, and after mowing down a few thousand enemies over 45 minutes, I'm kindof hoping to get stuck on a pine tree and die, so I can stop playing. It just hurts my brain, not being able to chop those sons of birches.
Great game to pass the time, to actually "turn off" your brain from tedious and stressful stuff, and just enjoy the ride.
Definitely one of the best games in the genre!

[i] Obligatory intro [/i] "I am a Vampire survivors fan". Played and beat it on PC and Mobile, so another game that apeared about same time with the same surname piqued interest but I decided to buy it only recently and I would say that the game is good, for the first 15-20 hours. After you unlock most of the content i.e. characters, runes, talents and weapons, you shall notice that the game is not that diverse as you want it to. The lvl up perks are closely tied to numerous passives like aoe, dmg, frequency etc of all attacks and you just buff your character with stats over and over again which at some point become tedious. It is not like other games of the same genre are different but for some reason VA feels different and fresh.

Cons: 
- The main currency, which is minor soulstones becomes obsolete after you buy all of the skill tree. You will be swamped with millions of them shortly with no place to spend them
- The character specific runes are sad and pointless
- All of the characters have almost similiar stats and you will find yourself using between 3-4 builds after some time.
- OSTs are there just because
- Last char is difficult to use when you play on higher curse levels and which is excatly when you shall unlock him
- Some weapons are useless and have no place in any of the build

Pros:
- Little to no lags on average PC
- Sexy visuals
- The game becomes quite difficult at some point and you will be pressed to actually think about your build
- Great time killer

As mentioned before it become a bit more challenging to play at this moment, which is the main reason I am still invested in playing and beating the game. It also mostly matter of actual skill rather than grind which feels nice.

This games soundtrack is horrid, and the gameplays meh as well.

The game even though it has a "repetitive" loop around each run, manages to keep itself relatively fresh through the sheer amount and variety of skills, characters, and upgrades. 

You can build your characters however you want, skills interact well with each other and pretty much everything will work if you actually put some thought into it. 
[Melee] Characters benefit from "Area" upgrades, while [Casters] benefit from damage over time and etc... Just don't forget to pick some health upgrades here and there (wait for the +30/+45 ones) because in Endless Mode or with high enough Curses you are going to get hit often and for quite a lot of damage. 

Weapons and Skills don't require that much grind, play it like you would play a looter-shooter, keep farming the materials passively while progressing with other characters and doing challenges and you will have the resources in no time. 

BTW running this on Linux and it's way  smoother than expected.

10/10 for Casual  1/2 ~ 1 Hour Sessions, lights and effects might give you some headaches if played for longer than that, so beware.

Fun game, it's like diablo 3 where vampire survivors is diablo 2.
The graphics are nice, the skills and abilities have an identity, each character has some cool stuff going on, the sound track is an absolute banger but each stage only has the single song so it gets pretty repetitive.

Some gripes I have:
-You can't see shit, because of the game perspective being angled instead of straight top down it makes it impossible to see anything when abilities have an infinite/tall y-axis visual, there's just too many things on screen for you to be able to dodge anything, there's some skills that just completely cover your vision such as Smite (AoE ability that casts down beams of light) that block your vision entirely.
When you can see what's going on it looks amazing but the second you pick an ability that destroys your ability to see and in turn dodge attacks it breaks the experience.

-It feels super grindy but lacks the variety to make grinding fun, you've got several characters which admittedly do spice things up and each character you can level up by playing them but it'll be on the same 5 stages, the stages do have unique enemies per stage but they all play the same (enemy puts red under your feet, you move out of the circle), the bosses are static regardless of what stage you pick and they all feel relatively similar where it's just a big dude that casts a giant AOE at you

-The passive skill tree (the one you can level up for like +1% stats) is pretty tiny and fast to max out, leaving you with nothing to spend your money on apart from unlocking characters, so grinding for money/exp becomes relatively pointless and you're left with grinding character levels which seem to only unlock runes (weird passives) or alternate weapons.

-The end game boils down to a system similar to the system in Hades, but instead of "Heat" you have "Curse" and instead of gradually increasing your "Heat" you have to max out to unlock the next tier of "Curse" and then max that out to reach the next tier which begs the question why have the "Heat" system if it's just difficulty tiers? It's like Diablo 3's Torment all over again but instead of just being a global difficulty you have to do every tier on each map separately, meaning you have to complete a run with curse tier 1, then tier 2, then tier 3 etc for EACH map.

Pretty good, and has already quite a lot of content for early access.

A bit of shame that you ABSOLUTELY NEED to disable visual FX just to be able to see the ennemies attacks tho. 
Sure you can keep a bit of opacity for FX, but it kinda looks ugly and glitchy, so better turn it off completely.
It's a decent little timekiller.

There are few games that can truly be called masterpieces, but this one undoubtedly deserves that title. It takes the classic 'Survivors' formula and elevates it to a level that is truly beyond what a normal human brain can understand and process. The attention to detail, the depth of gameplay, and the overall experience that this game provides is truly unparalleled.

From the moment you start playing, you'll be drawn into a world that is both beautiful and terrifying, filled with thousands of monsters coming to get you. The game's visuals are low poly but stunning, with richly detailed environments that are both awe-inspiring and haunting. The sound design is equally impressive, with a nice pumped up score and sound effects that will send chills down your spine while you mow down billions of monsters and bosses on screen.

After one hour, you will feel euphoria never before experienced in your mere existence, it's like TAKING a punch to your BRAIN, as one of my friends Veraxx said.

But it's not just the aesthetics of the game that make it so impressive. The gameplay itself is a masterpiece of design. It takes the classic 'Survivors' formula and expands upon it in ways that are truly remarkable. You'll find yourself facing challenges that you never thought possible, and you'll need to use every skill and tool at your disposal to overcome them.

The game's mechanics are incredibly deep and complex, yet they are also incredibly intuitive. You'll never feel overwhelmed by the sheer amount of information that you need to keep track of, yet you'll always be challenged to think creatively and strategically. The game's difficulty curve is perfect, gradually ramping up the challenges as you progress, without ever feeling unfair or frustrating. Having over 6 bosses on screen at one time in higher difficulty levels will feel intense and amazing!

A great step forwards for the genre. Though it does not have the visual or audio appeal of Vampire Survivors, or the perfectly balanced challenging-but-fair difficulty of 20 Minutes, Soulstone Survivors carves out an excellent in between-niche that fills my personal craving for crazy effects, big numbers, and creative weapons.

While there are tons of upgrades and abilities to choose from, the devs made an intelligent decision to limit what specific categories could be pulled from for each character, though this can be altered with the currently basic but interesting Rune system. This allows them to craft abilities which retread already covered ground, with a slight twist, while reducing bloat and maintaining what makes each character unique. On top of the wide variety of abilities you can select in a run, each character currently has three weapons to craft and choose from before a run begins, shaking up their gameplay with adjusted stats, or creating a focal point to form themed builds around thanks to their two built-in unique abilities.

On the character front, some have been given more care than others. Pyromancer, Arcane Weaver, Elementalist, and Chaoswalker share the heaviest overlap of skill sets, and all four of them have Arcane available to them - currently what I believe to be the most powerful skill set, alongside Holy. This ends up routing their builds down similar paths, though this is to be expected, as the three "pure magic" classes of the game. But from what we've recently seen in the Death Knight, an incredibly unique character who cannot dodge, but rides around on his steed at high speed and cannot be knocked back, future characters will likely avoid this problem with more complex design. I would love to see this level of complexity reflect back onto the older characters with balance changes in the future. Perhaps Pyromancer could deal Fire damage faster than other characters, or enemies in contact with one another spread the effect.

On the enemy front, Soulstone Survivors has the most involved elites and bosses I've seen of any game in the genre. Elites each have two attacks (Other than the very basic large goblin elites, who deserve a little love.), and bosses have four. This FAR exceeds 20 Minutes one or two attack roster, and with the large variety of elites you can find on each stage, their appearance can shake up a situation immediately. I cannot entirely say the same for bosses, due to how few there are currently. Most of their attacks are actually quite homogeneous, and just create clutter on the screen. Beams are quite popular among Lords of the Void. I do still enjoy them, and each additional boss will only increase my enjoyment. Can't wait for that one with the anchor! Alongside all of this, the devs are crafting a unique set of enemies for each available stage. Currently only one has a set of exclusive enemies, but I'm excited to see what else they put out.

Music and audio can be a bit bland. I do enjoy the strange brand of electronic synth jungle the devs have gone with, and its relaxed tone pairs well with normal gameplay. Bosses share a single track, appropriately amped up for their appearance. I'm no musical expert, but I can say with confidence that I do not personally find these track memorable, outside of their suitability for their given context. (I do remember the "ahh ehh ohh" part from that one track, but I believe that's the fault of a certain "jerm" in my brain.)

Earlier I mentioned crafting, and it's by far the worst part of this otherwise great game. Materials are obtained in game by destroying ore nodes. At the lowest difficulty of each stage, only common metals and uncommon jewels are available to find, but a new ore spawns as you increase the difficulty, up to tier 6, when bosses drop their essence. Currently, you only need up to rare materials to craft every weapon. But... you'll need a lot. Far too much to get in a single run. In a game with such an intentionally designed short, sweet, and simple gameplay loop, farming materials becomes a boring chore that currently cannot be alleviated by the game's available content. Crafting weapons is the endgame (outside of speedrunning), and it goes on a fair bit longer than I enjoyed. Hopefully the material requirements are lowered in the future.

Other than my weapon crafting complaint, I think of Soulstone Survivors as an excellent and unique addition to the expanding Bullet Heaven genre, with entertaining, fresh ideas, and a clear roadmap which has me excited for everything this game will have to offer in the future. Not super excited for the weapon grind though.

As a final note, please make sure you check the options for "effect opacity" before you post a review about how you can't see anything.

TLDR: Soulstone Survivors is an enjoyable and engaging game that combines survival and RPG elements to create a unique and immersive experience. While the game has some flaws, including a lack of variety in enemy types and repetitive gameplay, its strengths, including its deep customization options and challenging gameplay, make it a worthwhile play for fans of the genre.

Pros:

Deep customization options: Soulstone Survivors offers a wide range of customization options for your character, including weapons, armor, and abilities. This allows you to tailor your playstyle to your preferences and experiment with different builds.

Challenging gameplay: The game is challenging and requires strategy, quick thinking, and skill to survive. You'll need to manage your resources carefully and make tough decisions to stay alive in the harsh and unforgiving world.

Immersive world: The game's world is rich and detailed, immersing you in its dark and mysterious atmosphere. From the eerie ruins to the haunting forests, every detail has been carefully crafted to create a sense of dread and tension.

RPG elements: Soulstone Survivors features RPG elements, including character customization and skill trees. This allows you to develop your character and grow stronger over time.

Replayability: The game has a high level of replayability, with multiple endings and branching paths based on your choices. The game also features randomized events and encounters that keep each playthrough fresh and exciting.

Cons:

Lack of variety in enemy types: While the game features a variety of enemies to fight, they can start to feel repetitive over time. More enemy types or variations could have added more diversity to the game.

Repetitive gameplay: While the game has a lot of variety in its environments, the gameplay can become repetitive over time. The missions and objectives can feel similar, and the game's level design is not particularly varied.

Steep learning curve: Soulstone Survivors can be overwhelming for new players, with a steep learning curve and complex systems to master. This can be discouraging for some, but the game's depth and customization options make it worth the effort.

Technical issues: The game has been known to have occasional technical issues, including crashes and performance problems. While these issues are not constant, they can be frustrating when they do occur.

Limited character movement: The movement system in Soulstone Survivors is somewhat limited, with characters unable to jump or climb. This can make the game feel restrictive at times and can be frustrating when trying to navigate around obstacles.

Overall, Soulstone Survivors is an enjoyable and engaging game that successfully combines survival and RPG elements to create a unique and immersive experience. While the game has its flaws, including a lack of variety in enemy types and repetitive gameplay, its strengths, including its deep customization options and challenging gameplay, make it a worthwhile play for fans of the genre. The game's immersive world and high replayability ensure that there's always something new to experience, and the game's sense of challenge and tension make it a thrilling adventure. So grab your weapons and prepare to survive in the dark and dangerous world of Soulstone Survivors.

TL;DR - Yes, it is a 'Vampire Survivors'/'Twenty Minutes Till Dawn' clone. Yes, it adds enough new gameplay twists to warrant it being a separate game. Yes, it is enjoyable and distinct enough to be a separate addition to any game library. Yes, it is worth the price tag and more.

----

'Vampire Survivors' genre of game where your skills are automatically used combined with the '20 Minutes Till Dawn'-style of aiming your abilities. Has a healthy amount of meta progression outside of a run similar to games like 'Heroes of Hammerwatch' that increase your character's effectiveness, strength, defense, ability usage, etc. during a run. Unlike other games with meta progression (a la 'Vampire Survivors'), it is not strictly necessary to have a successful run.

The game is much easier than other games within its genre/style and that is in thanks part due to the fact you can create a build fairly easily and are not pigeon-holed into a specific style of build or ability archetypes. You can make almost any build work and that's awesome for feeling powerful.

The game is $10 and has an amount of content that puts other more expensive AAA and Indie titles to shame in terms of characters, weapons, and archetypes. While the "Runic Powers" or "Meta Game Progression" is fairly basic and easy to understand, there are dozens of characters and each one has multiple weapons to choose from. There are several ways to play each character and several ways more to build within any singular skill. One downside to this is of course is the fact that it does seem to diminish the "uniqueness" of each character because they are versatile enough to be used in similar builds; however, each character still does have a slight feel of uniqueness enough to warrant being separate from one another. Just don't expect a drastic gameplay-shifting style between them.

Want to go crit? Go for it.
Want to go ability spam? Go for it.
Want to go Damage over Time? Go for it.

All three of those archetypes (not all encompassing) can nearly be used effectively on any skill you choose to build around. Hell, you can even choose to completely ignore or dump the starting weapon/character skill and replace it if you want.

Graphics are good for the game. Visual clarity gets a bit burdensome at times due to the art style, the sheer amount of damage you'll be doing, and the number of enemies on the screen. Thankfully, there are a few key graphics/de-clutter options you can enable in the settings to alleviate this problem. Overall, it's not an issue I've experienced so far. The graphics will not blow you away by any means but they serve their purpose.

Music is pretty good. Some songs are better than others but I have not yet muted the in-game music which is a usual sign of it be a pleasure to listen to. So far I have not heard anything that is "annoying" that would change this stance.

Overall: If you are looking for a rougelike game with action similar to '20 Minutes Till Dawn', 'Vampire Survivors', and meta progression of 'Heroes of Hammerwatch' this is without a doubt worthy of its $10 price tag.

Soulstone Survivors is an exciting game that offers fast-paced action that will keep you engaged for hours. One of the things that I really enjoy about this game is the controller support - it's very responsive and intuitive, which makes it easy to dive right into the game without any frustration.

Another great feature of the game is the ability to turn down the spell effects. This makes it easier to see what's happening during intense battles, which adds to the overall experience of the game. The upgrade system is also a lot of fun - it's a satisfying grind that keeps you coming back for more.

One of the things that really sets Soulstone Survivors apart from other games is the variety of classes available. Each class feels unique and offers a different playstyle, so you can find the one that suits you best. The build variety is also fantastic, giving you lots of options to customize your character and tailor your strategy to your playstyle.

Overall, I highly recommend Soulstone Survivors to anyone looking for a fun and engaging action roguelike that offers lots of replayability. The fast-paced action, controller support, upgrade system, and variety of classes and builds make this game a must-play for fans of the genre.

While this game is still somewhat in it's infancy, it fails to provide a satisfying survivor concept with a lot of replayability.

First of all, the balance of this game is completely wack, even for early development. The variety of builds that actually are fun are extremely limited, with only a handful of strategies being able to access the endless content where you can go for personal bests. This is due to a time constraint where you have to win in under 12 minutes, which is virtually impossible on the highest difficulty (Curse VII), without a broken ass build. As a consequence, the meta strategies are 2easy 2cheesy and anything else is mega ultra hard mode.

Second, this game looks bad. And even if it did look good, nobody would know it because you have to completely nuke the graphics the higher you climb for visibility and so the game will run like it's supposed to. The enemy designs are mostly uniform but even the unique ones are very distasteful. This is in conjunction with the UI being so bloated with completely useless information that you cannot get rid of. A third of your screen will eventually just be health bars, objectives, and upgrades.

Lastly, this game is unrewarding. Without runes, which are achievement-based rewards that make your character stronger, you have basically no shot at beating any serious difficulty or infinite mode. This basically means the first 100 runs are an unlock-a-thon, which creates a completely unnecessary grind that once at the end, you're left with nothing to do. The general unlocks of the game feel weirdly paced and have almost no satisfaction once achieved. I've played almost all the way through the game, and only like a handful a characters and only go for a handful of abilities because the rest simply don't work or make the game trivial. Not to mention that after 54 hours, I can't even say I've been able to upgrade everything completely. That is an insane amount of grind that I simply can't bother to do anymore.

Overall, this game has many, many flaws. Most people who take it seriously are confined in a restrictive, dominant meta that makes the game severely neutered. Higher difficulties feel like a punishment when playing for completion, or personal achievement. What's the point of a survivor game that gets less rewarding the more you play it?

This is one of those games where you really need a "meh" rating. 
The combat loop is okay. It adds a directional control gimmick over something like Vampire Survivors. While this adds a bit of depth it also removes some of the 'chillness' of Vampire Survivors. 
Where the game really falls short is with the scaling, to the point where I am not confident that the developers understand how the mechanics interact. Choosing defensive upgrades is essentially never worth it as the enemy damage scales so much faster than your defense could even if you only chose defensive upgrades. Bosses always OHKO you even if you have close to 400 health. Comically, some of the 'Rare' upgrades will reduce the damage taken by 1 - 2. Ironically, the permanent upgrades for defense are some of the most expensive which really calls the developers judgement into question.
 This is further compounded by the health scaling of the enemies, which easily gets into the millions after a few rounds in endless. Because of this, all of the games really feel the same.

Made me binge play on a weekend and I really enjoyed this fast pased game.

If you're looking for a survivors-esque game like Vampire Survivors, but want more meta progression, more build variety, and more engrossing player input than the set-and-forget progression of mid-late Vampire Survivors egg farming runs, then Soulstone Survivors would be for you. 

For where it currently is in Early access, there's plenty of content to keep you occupied with mindless/endless monster killing, character and weapon unlocks, a skill tree (rather small currently), and runes and achievements that both diversify and unlock more content for you to try out. While it's expected that each type of character has their own unique stat variety, the weapons and active skills you can choose have "elemental tags" that allow you to play a single character in potentially many different ways!

There are however some FPS/optimization issues when all your skills recursively proc damage over time effects--to then recursively proc the skills you just cast, repeating the fun all over again... though I'd still stack the multicast stat over and over again, heh. 10/10, would definitely get killed by a frame lag death by a monster attack I physically couldn't see on curse 40+, many times more 😅

Looking forward to how they flesh out more of the progression and build variety in the future!

This is an EARLY ACCESS review from a previous version of the game:

+ Good value for an Early Access "Bullet Heaven" title, starting off quite mild in difficulty but ramping up in the higher "curse" modes. Still actively being developed with new content added & existing content reworked just prior to this review.

+ The graphics are bright, colourful, clean and mostly quite readable; enemy attacks and spells are indicated by red circles, power ups are nice shiny "soulstones", with huge ones dropping from boss kills. Graphical Effects opacity can be lowered to avoid the dreaded flare outs where players would otherwise be unable to see anything.

+ There are numerous characters, weapons, runes and bits of seasonal content to unlock and explore. Certain combinations will prove extremely lucrative (while others, not so much).

+ The lack of hard caps on player passive stats (damage, crit chance, crit damage, cooldown reduction, move speed, etc) allows for some crazy possibilities in Overlord and Endless modes. It's fun to run wild with this and your favourite characters/skills/runes.

- Player death will usually occur because of knockback (from exploding barrel goblins spawning on the player) combined with giant boss Area of Effect attacks (global lasers, boomerang saw blades, overlaid expanding cone attacks) or several of the other one-hit-kill Elite attacks with less than a third of a second's warning from the red indicators.

- All the armor, life and damage reduction in the world cannot prevent one-hit-kills in higher curse modes - only player dodging and constant awareness.

- There are ways to exploit certain character, skill and rune combinations to crush the hardest difficulties very quickly and kill every boss long before they can appear on your screen; there's a lot of room for better balancing here.

This is an Early Access product still under active development with the potential for sweeping changes in the future. At present, it is a conditional recommendation for fans of the genre, with the aforementioned negative factors disclaimed.

One of my favorite reverse bullet hell/bullet heaven game. It is repetitive and grindy, as with any roguelike/vampire survivors-like, so if you don't like to sit there and play for 30+ minutes killing things just to get slightly stronger, then this won't be for you.

It's in Early Access but still has tons to do. You can unlock new and fun classes (14 of them so far) each with their own unique skills (3 per class) and 3 weapons per class each with their own unique stats and skills. As well as a skill tree and a rune system which changes how you can play certain classes or even amplify certain builds. Tons of achievements too if you're an achievement hunter then you'll be in heaven. On top of that achievements also unlock skills, runes and runic power (how many runes you can equip as each rune costs X amount of power to equip), they're not purely just for show, so you get a lot of bang for your buck here.

Not to mention the devs do events for holidays and make them permanent, so if you miss an event you can still and always will have the option to unlock special "seasonal" skills. There's a lot of love here and it really shows. 

If you like Vampire Survivors, or any of the other myriad of so called "reverse bullet hell" or "bulletheaven" games, then this game is absolutely 10,000% worth your time. For $10 you get hundreds and hundreds of hours of fun. Best buy it now before the price goes up on full release!

Don't get me wrong. This is a Fun game. Kinda addicting. I'm still going to play it. But is still has a long way to go for balancing. A lot of spells are under-tuned (melee and fire spells for sure) especially for higher difficulty levels and the bosses can utterly zone you out with the AOE spam, which is a severe issue if you are applying runes for 3+ bosses. Melee spells are often an auto-pass as you are relying on rng for area modifiers so you can hit them at the edge of the screen, but then they hit like wet noodles... There also seems to be RNG on the RNG. I have basically built the same characters on different runs and couldn't tell why one run I was melting every thing and the next I couldn't even kill an elite. Some characters are inherently melting machines, while others are a hard pass. This may not be the place to give feedback to the devs, but I can't give a thumbs up to a game that has a tendency to frustrate me consistently. If there were a neutral, I would give that instead.

Soulstone Survivors is cut straight from the Rogue-lite cloth, and I like it! It's super fun and visually appealing, with good class variety which has already garnered multiple tens of hours of play from me, and more come! It has a wide variety of Achievements which make it intuitive to farm new skills, weapons, and runes in-game, and traditional but-well placed stat tree to improve your characters as you do. There's an easy-to-understand crafting system which tells exactly what you need and where to find it. And lastly, the soundtrack in this game freaking ROCKS. I had 3 of my friends pick up this game as well, we've all been having a blast and this is a nice edition to any collection, if you like mass monster slaying, customizing character builds, or just something you can play that's non-committal. However SSS isn't without it's flaws. The gameplay loop is exactly what you would expect from other games that share this genre. You'll have hordes of monsters chucked at you (which is great!), until they inevitably out scale you can you can't win anymore and at the highest difficulty of the game, you're just running from a literal non-stop barrage of telegraphed attacks that if you stop, you'll die immediately. They recently released a dev note saying they want to make each level feel unique and different, but the core gameplay mechanic is actually too fast for have meaningful individual interactions with specific monsters. These devs are probably working really hard on these monsters types and level/boss design according to their vision, but I'm just noting that part of that is lost due to the tempo of a game. It's like taking a road trip, but instead of appreciating the sights and enjoying local food, you just do 120 mph and stop at gas stations only because it's mandatory. Overall, this is a great product and and I look forward to the new changes they've discussed as they expanded their team a bit, as of the time of writing. New modes and player suggestions are being taken into consideration and maybe I will also go to their community to offer some feedback I think could improve the experience, but I absolutely recommend picking this one up!

Overall a well done survival styled game and anyone who liked vampire survivors will enjoy it. My only major qualm is that the game goes from feeling like a skill based system with getting a good handle on things like speed boosts, dodge timing, kiting, etc which rewards you for your timing and understanding of boss abilities to around Tier 4+ feeling like most matches are decided by Tedious RNG. It's fun to have area of effect indicators from mobs so you can skillfully weave or dodge through them but it is in no way fun to have half your screen completely covered in overlapping red circles with zero chance at outplay and then being juggled to death.So if you like the the roguelite survival games you'll definitely enjoy the game for a while but I'm willing to bet you'll straight up hit a wall at higher tiers where it doesn't feel rewarding and the only chance of willing is whether you get the right abilities randomly offered which allow you to snowball faster than the stage can pressure you.

Firstly, I need to make it clear that I am rooting for this game and hope for nothing but the best for it and its team. However...After seeing a couple of updates, I decided to reinstall. I am now uninstalling, again, and fighting the urge to remove from account completely. The player is essentially a super-bounce ball when hit; this has/will continue to end a run with a single hit, as player loses most movement control. Having come back after a significant break, it feels as if the player has been completely nerfed:  Curse I now feels like old Curse IV in regards to difficulty... Not. Fun.I played in the demo, pointing some of this out to devs through Discord. This may or may not be on the task board, but I recommend giving this a pass until the above is addressed. Furthermore, this is not something to play anywhere near someone with seizure, light sensitivity, or other visually triggered neurological issues, even with visual effects turned all the way down.I have been. and am still willing to give this title a chance. What this game brought to the table in this genre is wonderful, and greatly needed. However, some of the mechanics are too much, rendering the game unplayable in higher difficulty (via curses) levels. These issues are fixable, so I remain attentive to development.

This is not a bullet heaven. This is a bullet hell. You will spend all of your time at the higher difficulty levels dodging increasingly faster and more numerous red circles. Bosses are bullet sponges. Enemies have collision, which means trapping you into damage circles and cock blocking you from getting to bosses. Skill tree is a joke. Banish only removes one rarity level of a skill. Rune progression locked behind absurd levels of bullet sponge, aoe spam and reduced healing. Weapon unlocks are not upgrades, they are sidegrades at best and usually objectively worse than starting weapons.But the game is colorful and got/purchased good reviews on youtube. Hopefully people see this before they make the mistake of buying it.

first of all I would like to say this game is great as a time sink on the cheap. It has lots to unlock and do and has some really unique skills that stand out. However it has its fair share of problems right now. while it has something like 100 skills the majority of them are simply cut and paste jobs like a bolt thats either, ice, fire, poison, arcane etc..  this makes things worse as you unlock them as it waters down the pool of good unique skills where it gets to the point of getting frustrated as you used all your re-rerolls and cannot get that 1 skill that links the others up and your builds fall apart. Because of this despite the millions of combinations of skills though all games kinda feel the same. There is no OP build or weak build despite the mechanics in the game. You only win if you move about enough and dont make mistakes. This is a twitch(not the streaming platform) movement game disguised as a rogue-lite.

However, saying that if you just want to sink tons of hours into a game and unlock stuff its great. It just lacks the variety you would think it does when you see the sheer amount of skills. This is early access though so I fully expect things to change and the game be even better over time. Therefore I am not too bothered about the lack of variety in skills. 

My main issue with this game is the random crashes. I would be in the middle of a 2 hour run and it just close. The crash dumps say its a unity error and nothing more. I along with many others have reported this to the dev who simply blame me and others. Saying graphics drivers are either out of date or corrupt or we have overclocked our systems. This is the ONLY game in my massive library that crashes consistantly with my setup, other unity games like Valheim I have played for 10+ hours with zero crashes. I have removed XMP off my RAM, re-installed my GPU drivers using DDU in safe mode and run as admin and still crashes. Its clearly an issue with the game and the devs are simply burying their head in the sand with this. I have near 30 hours in the game but most of that is redoing content i have already done. I have also played too long for a refund too now. 

So be aware while this game is fun at times the devs are not the best and I even sent them a crash dump for them to ignore and blame my pc instead.

Yes, it's another twinstick arena (and this one has a lot of Hades DNA in it).

As is customary in recent months:
[list]
[*]All of your weapons auto-fire. Some (but not all) have auto aim.
[*]Defeated enemies will drop little gems which serve as your XP. They must be collected to gain the benefit.
[*]When you level up, RNG deals you multiple upgrades or additional weapons to choose between.
[*]In-game achievements are the mechanism to unlock new characters, skills, and upgrades.
[/list]
Unlike many other recent twinsticks, success is not specific to surviving a set duration. Instead, defeating a quota of regular enemies will cause a boss to spawn, and clearing 5 boss events unlocks the exit.

Each playable character has a different starting weapon. The numerous other weapons and skills all belong to a big shared pool, but certain types are weighted in likelihood depending on which character you're playing in a given run (mage characters seem to be dealt physical skills less often).

In addition to the expected stat upgrades (do more damage, move faster, raise your maxHP, etc), you will also be offered upgrades that are specific to a skill (eg "fireball does more damage") or specific to a [i]category[/i] of skills (eg "all of your Poison skills cover a larger area") as well as upgrades that give a chance to piggyback negative status conditions onto any enemy struck by your attacks. 

A lot of the recent twinsticks have been lowish-rez pixel sprite affairs with enough abstraction that you can have almost a bird's-eye view of the map but still see your character & the enemies from what is effectively a side-view. This doesn't really translate well in 3D presentations, so you end up with a 45ish-degree tilt camera, which [i]for the most part[/i] gets the job done. Unfortunately, adding any tall features to the map (trees, for example) will result in situations where scenery obstructs your view of part of the arena.

The up-side is that polygons allow for very clean scaling (many of these games allow you to gradually increase the actual size of your attacks, which ends up looking very chunky in games that use pixel sprites).

As of this writing there are 5 maps, all of which take roughly the same gameplay approach in that they are large squarish arenas with indestructible set dressing scattered around. Some maps have more clumsy scenery that will find you getting stuck and unable to avoid incoming attacks.
Each map also has multiple types of mineral resources which you can collect if you spot them while dodging swarms. Most of these resources currently go unused, but some of them are used to purchase alternate starting weapons for your characters. The minerals vary from map to map, giving you a meaningful reason to replay maps that aren't your favorite.

Players can replay stages with additional difficulty features which will improve rewards, and replaying an already-beaten difficulty will allow the player to continue on to a harder stage instead of ending the run. Extending a run can be dangerous, not just because the enemies will be stronger, but because highly-upgraded attack size & attack frequency can make it impossible to see anything that's happening on screen.
