As this is an early access game, and as I'm still willing to give it more of a shot, I'll do something I usually don't: 
Write a review and expand upon it when I've gotten a couple more hours in.

So, we're starting with around 2 1/2 hours played. I am personally very familiar with this  "genre" of games - I've racked up easily more than a 100 hours in VS and others like it. And yet, I can only describe starting the game for the first time as bizarre. There's no tutorial, no tooltips, no nothing guiding you to what to do. The only thing that eventually makes you hit the "Fight" button (which starts your run), is the fact that you can't do anything else in all the other menus for lack of currency. Even in-game, the only thing you get is an annoying tool-tip that pops up every minute or so, telling you to "slay monsters to summon the lord", as if I can literally do anything else. This tool-tip doesn't help, and it's still there after you've already played for an hour, so what gives? 
I am not new to any of the concepts in Soulstone Survivors, yet it expects this in such a way I can only label as feeling "unfriendly". It's like going to a supermarket and having the cashier just silently stare at you. You know you're going to have to pay up whatever amount is on the register, that's how it always goes. But not being prompted to do so would still feel like that cashier is exceedingly unfriendly.

Weird metaphore aside, gameplay so far simply doesn't make me want to play more. The only upgrades you collect are literal stat-stick upgrades for your weapons (active skills, as they're called here), 10% more damage here, 10% more size there, some casting speed (cooldown reduction), multicast chance (% to cast multiple times) and that's it. You're just linearily collecting stat upgrades as you go, there's no power spikes, no changed animations (a % size doesn't count), nothing to give you a marker for player strength progress during a run. It makes me not know what to work towards and it bores me to no end. I do like however that you can swap actives as you wish - even though you lose upgrades when you do, so it's not particularly incentivised.

All in all, Soulstone Survivors has the right idea, but execution just isn't there for me (yet?). I'll continue to play a bit more and who knows, maybe there's mechanics I've missed or haven't unlocked yet that make everything click in place - I'll update this review as I go, but for now, I wouldn't recommend this to my friends to play with me.

Played the Demo prior to this being released as Prologue or Early Access, it has come so far since and it's probably my new favorite in terms of Survival Action Roguelikes out there. Previously you had 3 character, each with 2 weapons to choose between. Some powers to purchase that gave minor help to your characters.

Now:
- A larger roster of ca. 15 characters.
- Option of 2-3 weapons per character, obtained by crafting.
- Prestige levels to show progress.
- 5 unique maps, each with different enemies and resources.
- Curse intensity to challenge yourself.
- Option to Quit, go Endless or enter Boss Rush after finishing a stage.
- Proper end screen with statistics.
- TONS of runes to help boost your future runs.
- Achievements with in-game unlocks attached to them.

It's gone from mediocre game with generic features similar to it's genre, to a game that absolutely has eaten my time the last couple days. Can't wait to see what else they will bring to the table.
Keep it up Devs, you're doing fantastic! <3

This game is enjoyable until you're done unlocking characters, i.e. just enough time for your right for a refund to expire.

Past that, the game shows what it truly is: a shallow, tedious and poorly designed grindfest for shiny rocks with a game loop less fun than a visit to the dentist.

Most skills suck and are copy-pasted all over the place with different colors, and unlocking new ones just worsens your chances of finding good stuff. All characters play and feel the same apart from a couple ones with unique failed gimmicks (e.g. a character who can't dodge and another one with pets who die within seconds).

There are no weapon synergies or fun modifiers, all you do is increase numerical values like damage, area of effect and cooldown reduction until numbers don't mean anything anymore. Having your screen filled with giant hammers is hilarious at first until you realise said giant hammers barely tickle the damage sponges that serve as enemies and bosses, thanks to their grossly inflated health pool.

And you better tone VFX down to the minimum if you want to get out of the bazillion red circles the game constantly throws at you while you spam dodges and hope you don't hit a tree in the process because it would slow you for half a second, which is more than enough time to get one shot.

The developers -I mean the people doing the code since game design is apparently covered by some random clueless people on Discord- have the audacity to ask for 10€ for this game (I guess adding a 3rd dimension is expensive), but you can buy at least two much better roguelites with that cash.

TL;DR Bad ideas poorly executed, save your money.

I think Soulstone Survivors executes on it's goals well enough, but the reason for a negative review is relatively simple:  I think it's goals kinda suck.

This game has a huge amount of meta progression, and while it's not uncommon for this genre to feature meta progression, it is so much that the game really is just about filling bars for hours and hours before all the systems are actually opened up.  Now, if that is a thing you want to do, then feel free to disregard my thoughts - this might be a game for you!

If you can get over the dozens of hours of nothing but grinding the meta progression mountain, this game has another problem:  The presentation gets in the way of play-ability.  Your own spell effects become so noisy that they cover the entire screen rendering the enemies, their spell effects, and their pre-vises invisible.  Now, this could be an interesting element to think about: "How do I make choices such that the screen is still readable by limiting the visual noise of my spell effects", but if that is indeed the intent, then I point to the sign at the top of this review:  The goals of the game suck.

Besides that, there really isn't enough depth here to make the game that interesting.  You can light the screen up with a bunch of stuff, but it's not really in service of interesting gameplay.

If you just want to turn your brain off and watch the light show, this is a fine enough game for that I suppose, but wouldn't recommend it otherwise.

-I'm a stats freak.  What are the baseline numbers?  E.g. what is the base chance to block, etc.  Upgrades are 48% of what, exactly?  5%?  10%?  Or does the 48% percent upgrade mean I now have a 48% chance to block?

I played a decent amount of this game and I quite like it, I'll most likely play more BUT of all the roguelites I've played this is my least favourite one.
 I think it has mostly to do with the skill system, like it feels like your choices have barely any impact at all, all the skills feel like they work in the same way, and in all rounds you get to a point where you are just mindlessly clicking on the same upgrades over and over again no matter what build you are going for. 
The upgrades are boring, seeing your skill increase in area and cast speed are the most changes you will see.
There is an insane amount of DoT and Status Effect type upgrades available to you regardless what build you are going for that it becomes redundant choosing between them, they will all eventually complement each other as well.
 I don't like that you have access to so many skills every time with no drawbacks and the fact that you are forced to pick skills until you fill up your hotbar, it just makes the game more monotonous. 

Another con are the enemies, everything is just AoE galore, in higher difficulties it just gets tedious, dodge one red circle and you fall on another red circle, maybe you manage to dodge that one too but it doesn't matter because there's no safe place to dodge to, bomber goblins spawn way too frequently and curse tower are tedious to deal with too, not to mention how difficult it is to see enemy attacks due to all the absurd effects (I don't mind if they make enemies deal more damage as long as they reduce the amount of AoE attacks and make them more visible), sure you can make your skills transparent but then your effects just look horrible.

Superfluous is the best word to describe many of this game's systems.

Before starting the review, something you need to know if you are buying this game: 

1 - Set the music volume low. There are audio queues in the game that are not heard because the loud music and this will make your life easier.
2 - Reduce the visibility of effects as well. The visual effects can become VERY big and shiny and you need to see the area attacks of the enemies and your character. This will make the game playable (something the devs should put by default)

With those mandatory changes, the game becomes very enjoyable. Another game on the "Vampire Survivors" genre, but with nice visuals, progression and a fantasy theme with a lot of different characters. You need to take skills and try to match their types to empower them and be able to kill hordes of enemies with a lot of different attacks and patterns.

The only thing that is still missing, probably because it is an early access game and they are working on bigger topics, is that progression is too easy and everything is easily achievable with not so much runs. It looks like this is done on purpose so people can test changes, but it is something to warn if you want to play it as a full release.

What a fuckin' blast.

Pro's: Great combat feel, the main game play loop is addicting, and the progression system keeps you coming back. There's a wide variety of characters, builds, and combinations of builds you can do that also inspire you to keep progressing. There's a shit load of things to unlock, every character has new weapons you can craft and each weapon comes with 2 new abilities. It's a pure dopamine hit when it's unlocked and even more fun to then just hop in and try it out. Additionally, the music is great, and the graphics have a look and feel that's distinguished and enjoyable to look at.

Con's: Later stages become repetitive, it's the same content with bigger numbers and a higher volume of mobs. Which is my biggest problem with these types of games. It would be cool to see them add a variety of other game play elements added to those higher difficulties that spice up the rinse repeat nature of this game. Also, it's early access, we only have 5 levels, and they look and feel great in most cases, but it would be cool to see them add more to these maps in time, or even develop procedural generation  with interchanging tile sets to keep things interesting.

Overall, this game slaps, I highly recommend it, and if you got enough money for a Taco Bell meal, you buy this instead and eat some broccoli that day.

Really fun time killer and the higher difficulties offer real challenges, though the increase in difficulty is more arbitrary than a skill improvement/test of practice. Most builds are useless in higher tiers and if you get unlucky or don't have enough movement speed, the majority of the run will be spent spamming dodges and sneaking in bits of damage on bosses. A more appropriate challenge increase is an evolving AI, not just faster/stronger/healthier/higher quantity - these methods just add arbitrary time to the fights and force players into a more defensive role with no option of skillful aggression. If you can only get close enough to hit a boss once every 20 seconds or so because of the constant ability spam of enemies, the fun of the challenge starts to dwindle quickly.

Hitboxes also need to be adjusted, both on terrain and enemy attacks. Additionally, some attacks are missing warning indicators that result in runs being ended simply because the screen is too cluttered to notice an explosive mob or an attack that doesn't render a warning indicator after it has been used, such as the sawblade throw from one of the bosses.

Overall, a great game for anyone who enjoyed VS-style games, just needs a bit more refinement.

Like most game of this genre, it is a bit slow at first and you will never really get swarmed by a screen full of enemies like similar title but the rush is still there and the game is really fun.
The spells effects and are nice, the gameplay is responsive. The characters, mixed with the runes, weapons and different spells and affinities are good enough to keep you going for a couple of hours of fun.

I would say that the only downsides for me are:
1. Sometimes, you can easily loose your mouse in the chaos and that makes you mouse over your skills and the popups are huge with no way to reduce them to my knowledge. I know, you can change the size and color which helps a lot. If you go for an Arcane build (the spells are mainly blue), you can change the mouse color to red for example.

2. I would completely remove (or add the possibility to do so) the mouse over skills with the popup description during gameplay. Eventually, things happens too fast and it's too chaotic to have time to look at them. They are more annoying than helpful. You can easily hit escape to look at them or during level up, which is enough.

3. At one point, when you have lots of upgrades and lvl ups, your spells are soooo big and so many effects happens on screen with multicast that I couldn't see where I was going. I was getting stuck on small trees, unable to move because of my own abilities, which is frustrating because that made me lose really good runs. I was melting down bosses (like 5-6 spawning at the sametimes) but the downside was I would get one hit by their spells so I had to be really reactive, which I really like and is really fun. But dying because your screen is a cluster f*** and your spells are so huge that they overlap with the terrain and prevent you for properly navigating the obstacles... Nah...

Even with these 3 points I mentioned, I highly recommend the game if you like this genre. Lots of fun to be have.

44 Hour Update Below

It's a REALLY GOOD game. For about 20 hours.

At roughly 20 hours in, I started trying to unlock the last character.
To do this, you have to beat a certain level (the snow level) on tier 5
difficulty with every single difficulty modifier enabled. Everything before
tier 5 is fantastic. But here's why it falls apart in my opinion.

First of all, they have so much health that you end up kiting in a circle
for 30-40 minutes. I mean that literally. Backpedal in a circle for 30-40
minutes. And after all that time of kiting, you'll die from getting stuck
on a tree or rock while trying to dodge. You feel cheated every time.

Dodge is your only defense. But it's on a cool down. Which is fine.
But you get stuck on EVERYTHING. So then you burn all of your
dodges trying to get off of whatever you're stuck on. And it's game
over then. You're still stuck on whatever tree or rock with no dodge.

I get that you want to keep dodge from being OP but you can't make
my only defense so UNRELIABLE while also giving them so much health
and simultaneously filling the whole screen with 100 enemies and
100 meteors and 100 whatever the red things are all at the same time.

You'll zone out for a split second and instantly get bounced all
over the screen because backpedaling in a circle for 30+ minutes is
so mind numbing that you can't even hold your mouth closed anymore.
Let alone stay hyper focused non-stop for such a long time.

All of the boss health bars are in the millions. And that's only Tier 5!
I can't even imagine Tier 6 or Tier 7. I have no problem with a game
being difficult. But I went from REALLY loving this game and playing
it over every other game I have (Hogwarts ect) to sucking my teeth
and throwing my hands up in the air. It was like falling off a cliff. lol

I have failed to unlock this character for 6 straight hours.
That's enough to suck the fun out of just about anything.
*Git GuD sCruB*

P.S. The character needs an outline around them. They regularly
disappear completely when the **** hits the fan. An outline 
would surely fix this. And the crosshair is terrible too. 

But I still highly recommend this game. Because even if you buy
it and play it for 20 hours, then permanently remove it from your
library, it's a VERY fun 20 hours and well worth the asking price.
Who knows, maybe they'll fix it one day. It is early access after all.

44 HOUR UPDATE:

Okay I'm currently 44 hours into the game and beating T5 is much
easier now. It sort of WAS a case of "GiT GuD". It's probably
better described as get your character good. Find one character you
like and stick with them for a while to level them up. Then it seems
like they either get better skills or better RNG. Maybe both.

I don't get stuck on stuff as much because I've learned through trial
and error to stay away from everything. And don't stress getting the
last character unlocked like I did. He's fast because he rides a horse
but in turn he has no dodge. That's a terrible trade in my opinion.

I really want to recommend this on a midling note. This game is not good the harder you make the difficulty. It genuinely ruins the game to try and continue going "harder" as it just comes to an cluttered arena as tons and tons of projectiles and beams cross around. This game is heavily projectile based, and it starts to become unfun when it feels like you genuinely cannot dodge everything, and building things such as health and armor do not matter.

For reference, this is "Curse Level 4 and 5" and I believe it goes up to about 6 or 7. I genuinely do not see how it could become worse in difficulty. The skills you can unlock also do not actually help your progression. You do not get "stronger" in a long term sense, you can also gain boons that can accentuate your gameplay, but they will not alter your chance of getting farther in higher difficulties.

Otherwise the game is fun, but I think I've gotten the most of my enjoyment out of it, because it does not feel good trying to go further into the game

Never before has a Vampire Survivors knockoff been so frustrating to play. If you play survivor likes to unwind and relax and trash a billion enemies don't play this game. The harder difficulties are an effort in frustration. 

The game is so RNG dependent that if you aren't having a good run early in you are better off restarting. 

The game is so poorly optimized that randomly even high end PC's will start to chug, drop frames, freeze, and suddenly you'll be hit and dead. 

The game is so visually cluttered the devs had to include a slider to turn down effects. Problem is this includes any indication of where some of your abilities are leaving you little to no feed back depending on the ability. The slider seems to work on some abilities and not others as well.

Even with the effects slider turned to zero you still can't see what's going on because every enemy has abilities with red danger indicators on the ground that overlap with the enemies themselves it just becomes a giant cluster.

The devs are very nerf happy. Any skills that provide any form of fun effective gameplay get gutted quick. They seem to think a RNG dependent slaughter fest about is about skill, dedication, and practice. It's not. This isn't Hades Clone. It's Vampire Survivors clone. There is no skill in hoping you got the RNG needed to be able to survive. The dodge only works half the time. You still get punted across the map or into terrain and get pummeled to death because you're now stuck on a tree and the wonderful physics think you are airborne still so 1000 mobs dog pile you from full to dead in 5 seconds.

What really makes me distrust the devs is early on in development there were even more optimization issues and the game would chug hard as you progressed through endless mode. It was a lot of fun back then, but chugy. All it needed was optimization. Well the Dev team came in the steam forums, say optimization is impossible, so to combat slowdown they nerfed skills and abilities and buffed enemy scaling. Can't run into the performance issues if you can't get there!



There are cool ideas here and these types of games are more than capable of being awesome AND hard as nails, but that only works if they are fair. A death should feel like my fault. This game has everything it should to make me love it. I love pushing the hard modes in these games. I love testing what feels like unlimited power against ever increasing difficulty. But not here. Here I'm just pissed off when I'm usually happy when I turn off one of these games. Poor performance and poor choices by the devs hold this game back, but it has potential.

Leveling up is SO very rewarding in this game, and when you finally complete and Arena map.. even MORE rewarding. Also I do really like how they implemented the way you have to unlock the other Classes. You dont need to use Real world money ( Mobile games are absolutely TERRIBLE about that!! ) and being able to blacksmith a new weapon and get new unique abilities from them.. theres just so much I like about this game, and I look forward to what the Devs do with it in the future!!

For something that's early access, this game was extremely hard for me to put down.

Things I liked:
- Simple mechanics and easy to learn
- Great selection of characters to choose/unlock
- Enough content for me to want to keep playing to try out different ability combos
- Achievements actually give you useful things

Things I didn't like:
- Screen gets super crowded towards the end and you can't really see anything unless you turn the opacity down
- Got stuck on terrain sometimes
- Sometimes late-run isn't balanced/scaled well

The cons, while a bit annoying, weren't bad enough for me to stop playing since I could just work around them. Overall, very good game for the price.

The game is alright, a fantastic take on the "Reverse" Bullet-Hell genre, but where the enemies actually start firing back at you.
There's an option to adjust the opacity of all projectiles (both yours and enemy projectiles) while still leaving the attack outlines on the ground so you can have great visibility on where to move.

If there's a few critiques that I have, it would be the following:
Show the current duration of active buffs like Bloodlust and Might.
Tell us how much damage a summon does.
Give us a short in-game list of information like debuffs and ability rundowns, it would be really helpful in comparing abilities without having to do so in a run, and would also allow planning out a loadout before a run (including abilities that aren't normally available).

Positive review because responsive dev, constant updates/community communication, awesome team and stuff you just don't see anymore, and a generally fun (but not quite there) game. Harsh criticism ahead that I really hope they consider going forward:

The classes in this game have an identity crisis which really hurts my heart. Unfortunately, you can do basically the exact same builds and get the same spells regardless of which character you choose to play as, leaving the classes as basically a cosmetic decision rather than a gameplay decision. Unfortunately this is a product of the vampire survivors inspiration as you can do the same on VS as well, but for a developer to be sinking so much extra work into providing so many available skills in their road map, I truly hope they start to scrutinize and lock down the spell choices for each character going forward as this game could be on par with the likes of Risk of Rain and truly be a contender for the best of the best in Action Roguelikes if the characters were more defined.

As it stands, you can play as a Pyromancer, and run an all ice or arcane build, completely killing off the "Fire Mage" fantasy that selecting that character should bring with it. The same can be said with any class, but as an additional example that's a bit more out there, you get access to the lightning abilities with basically every character, and it makes no sense to me when picking the houndmaster that I could also chain lightning and thunderclap. This unfortunately really trivializes the point in progressing anything other than one character unless you simply wanted to unlock the runes that would give you access to 1-2 more spells from that class archetype.

The only other complaints I have in regards to the game are a lack of diversity in enemies/boss fights that it seems like they will expand on, but not enough, as their current goal is 10 bosses, which just won't breed enough diversity or long term replayability, especially with the identity crisis the classes have.

The current state of the game is:
I can pick any character, and unless I deliberately TRY to not select the same spells, I'll end up doing the same build and fighting the same 5 bosses on repeat, leading to quick burnout and boredom.

I will say that this game is by far the better of the two if you compare it with VS, but unfortunately, this is just that, VS with an aiming mechanic instead of being 8 bit and top down. They have the potential to make this a contender for Best Action Roguelike and I truly hope they take this game farther than their roadmap says they will as the roadmap makes it seem like they might fall just short of a masterpiece if they stop there.

Overall in it's current state, 7.75/10, if they fix the class identity issues and expand on the end game enemy variations to create more long term replayability, an easy 11/10.

I really enjoy this genre of game, and I really wanted to like this one, but I can't stand it. A few specifics:

The dodges getting stopped by random obstacles. This is so insanely frustrating, getting ready to dodge only to go no where because of branch on a tree. The range of the base dodge is also so short it is almost required to take the rune, which feels bad.

The balance of the game is miserable, it starts okay but by the time you get to higher curses it almost requires getting the perfect run. With rng elements getting a "good" run and smart plays should get you through most things. But a little past half way and if you don't have all the right pieces you won't get anywhere. The difficult rate with curses out paces the very few and minor upgrades you get to make permanently. Getting enough levels to stay on the damage curve feels impossible, unless you are getting the perfect run.

The runes that are supposed to help are locked behind ridiculous achievement counts. Some of the kill counts are so high it feels like they are trying to artificially increase game hours played. At nearly 60 hours and I still am not half way to some of them. The rouge-like elements imply a certain amount of failing and re-running until you reach certain milestones. This game way surpasses that amount and doesn't feel like it has those milestones.

If 100+ hours of failing before making forward progress is fine with you then this game might be a good fit for you. For me at 60 hours stonewall with no progress possible other than prestige, which feels useless, I can't recommend the game.

I am loving the recent popularity of Bullet Hell Roguelite's and Soulstone Survivors is yet another welcome addition.

With that said, there are a number of flaws that lessen the overall experience a bit in my opinion. Constantly getting stuck on the terrain, obnoxious visual effects obscuring the screen, repetitive sound and audio, and rather poor event design just to name a few. Most of these, with the exception of sound and audio, are rather irksome considering Soulstone Survivors has a large focus on movement and positioning. I do want to give credit to the fact this is early access so things may be subject to change going forward.

What Soulstone Survivors does have going for it right now is a rather simplistic but competent upgrade/progression system, a decent-ish selection of characters and a plethora of abilities to mix and match from. All of which make the gameplay loop rather solid and interesting from run to run. I do hope to see it fleshed out more as development continues though. Controller support is phenomenal too, which is a big plus for this type of game in my book at least! On another side note, I did manage to 100% the current content in a bit under 50 hours so I believe there's a decent bang for your buck here as well.

Currently it's not quite near the level of Vampire Survivors in terms of fun, content, updates, or value but with some further TLC it could be just as good in the future. I'm going to recommend it at least, with the caveat that you may have already played VS and are looking for something similar that is somewhat faithful to the current state of the genre.

I'm loving the re-emergence of demos - it strikes me as a developer being confident enough in their game to say 'sure - come along and see a bit of what we have'. I thoroughly enjoyed the demo, but no more than a lot of these Bullet Heaven games. (I also enjoyed my demo progress automatically flowing through into the main game once I bought it.)

However, now they have added a lovely quantity of content in the main game. And not just skills, characters, levels, difficulty scaling (curse), runes, weapons etc. Also Quality of Life additions such as rerolls, locks, banishes, and probably my favourite - the graphic scaling bar. 

That last one means I can enjoy the early game in all it's ridiculous glory and lovely carnage, and then in the late game I can tone it down so I can still see the danger circles whilst melting everything around me.

Main thing missing for me is a menu option to browse through all the skills - what tags they have, what they do, which characters have access to them etc. Folks have made spreadsheets, so it can be looked up but I think it'd be nice to have that in game. Oh and a rune for summon spells... rather than having to bloat selection with nature/shadow etc trying to get access to more.

At time of writing we've just had the Valentine's Day update releasing the third tier of weapons for half the champions. I can't wait for X-time in the future when we start to see what they have planned for the legendary tier weapons.

Twin-stick roguelite bullet-hell.  Game play consists of moving around a map collecting xp, materials of different types used for permanent craftables, health.  Leveling up in a map (which happens frequently) allows the choice of active skills or passive effects, with lots of synergies to be explored.  Your attacks (some of which are aimed) happen automatically, with only a dash available for mostly defensive purposes.  Regular mobs are accompanied by elites and fairly frequent bosses, of which each map requires you to vanquish 3 to 5 (as far as I've seen in my 3+ hours of game play).

I'm not sure if anyone else has experienced this, but over the last year, I've found tons of new games like this: movement/collection, with the only strategy being an understanding of which items to pick up.  When I bought Soulstone Survivors, I didn't think it was one of this type of game; in the first few minutes of playing it, I disappointed to realize I was wrong.

HOWEVER...

The game is pretty awesome, and towers over the myriad of its peers (Vampire Survivors, Army of Ruin [which I like for various reasons], Brotato [which is also pretty good], and several others I cant think of at the moment).  It's fast and furious, and requires a more-than-casual understanding of how to create a build.  There's lot of permanent progression to explore, too, though crafting and skill choices - with TONS of unlocks (characters, aps, weapons, skills, etc).

This game is a solid thumbs-up for me...

This game is a great time waster and generally really fun. There are of course some negatives about anything in early access but as an overall package this game currently is amazing. 

The positives: 
1. There classes all do feel unique and there are many abilities and skills that I would not have thought much of if not forced to use them with the associated classes. For those who say some characters and builds are worthless, I really think you aren't giving the others a chance. All characters have the same system of unlocking runes, and any character can have any runes equipped as long as you have enough slots. I do agree there is a clear strong build archetype, which I will detail later. 
2. There are tons of collectibles that all serve some function towards your progression. Sure at a certain point you no longer need the low tier minerals but as you get better at the game and unlock more difficulties you continue to find more valuable resources. The different maps also contain different kinds of resources so there is some times you may find yourself needing to grind, but not for long. 
3. I adore the chain effects. There are passives that will apply a negative debuff if you apply a certain debuff, and there are many kinds of them. Watching the ridiculous stacks of negative effects is honestly just fun to watch as you have abilities hitting so fast, multi-casting and massive area effects that apply 15 negative debuffs in half a second. This game does what good rougelikes need to do: let me feel powerful and break the game if I got the dice roll in my favor. 

The unfortunate negatives:
1. Visibility is a major concern at times. Your abilities and spells can sometimes clutter the screen, and that isn't even accounting for the higher difficulties where the enemies attack every actual possible square inch of your screen at times. There is however a setting to lower how much visual noise you can see, and while it does help in terms of performance on your framerate and being able to actively see, this game when ran to high endless loops become near impossible to actually see anything. Is it really that bad? Personally not anymore. In the beginning I was frustrated and now that I understand how I want to attempt my builds, I am mentally prepared for what I expect my screen to look like. 
2. Curses are this game's scaling difficulty. Curses 1-3 are walks in the park. They barely make a difference other than getting you comfortable with many elites fighting you. Curse 4 and above you start dealing with Curse Towers and multiple bosses spawning at once. Curse 4 and 5 are a bit challenging but manageable. Curse 6 and 7 are nightmares. At Curse 6 and 7 you can now collect Void Essence, which are essentially boss drops (and currently serve no function as of yet) but the enemies have such ridiculous spawn rates and attack rates that you WILL need a good build and lucky rolls to survive. If you do not get enough movement speed you will simply become overrun. 
3. Lightning/Holy is incredibly overpowered. It is 100% the best build from the lowest difficulties to the highest. You can manage on most builds, however should you beat a run you will generally see that Lightning/Holy runs are the fastest to completion because of their effect and how well they stack on enemies. Doom is simply not a viable build on Curse 6 and 7 because the HP the bosses have is too much to reliably deal with. 
4. The terrain will become your worst enemy. As stated above, the maps don't have anything different other than how they appear and what resources drop. All of the enemies you fight will always be the same (at least as of now). Some maps are okay, while others will have rocks and trees that somehow you seem to clip on and get stuck. It's agonizing when it happens.
5. Similar to the terrain concern, on higher difficulties you will be knocked back quite a bit. Should you be dashing or hit by certain attacks while also getting launched or knocked will have your character soar across the map. While initially funny it is a headache and half. You are not immune to damage while airborne and will constantly find yourself either throw clear across the other side of the map to safety or pushed into a crevice or terrain that you must wait to leave until you land as you cannot see your surroundings. As already stated, you also are not immune which means you can also simply be launched into pools of poison, fire or ice and just die because you are on the right space, just above it. This either needs to be removed or make you immune to damage while being launched, because you have next to no control of it happening to you. 
6. The Incarnation of Fire boss has a flamethrower attack and its hurtbox is simply too big. Either the visuals need to be adjusted or the hurtbox needs to be adjusted to be appropriate. Too many of my runs have lost because I took damage to a flamethrower that wasn't actually touching me on my screen and now I am stuck circling the drain on low HP. 

Though I have listed more negatives than positives in my review, that doesn't mean at all that I think this game is more bad than good. I adore this game and am starving for more content already. I love the rune system to build diversity as well as I am super excited to see what new weapons can be crafted with all the materials I am stockpiling. While I'm at it, I'm ready for the expanded Skill Tree as well. Also I really hope the Devs see this and add some kind of catalog of abilities/skills/spells and a way to sort by type. It's great to see upgrades such as "All Slash moves 40% damage," but you really don't know every slash ability in the game and without looking at multiple different menus in separate tabs you really can't figure out all of your options ahead of time. 

Not every run needs to be endless and not every run needs to be success. I have played many rougelikes and learned this all too well long ago. This game does offer you a choice of how to continue your run when you finish a set loop. Blue portal will always end the run, which will be the only option if you take over 15 minutes to complete the loop. Purple portals will scale difficulty by one stage and have you complete another loop. This is essentially the endless mode where you push the game to its limits. The red portal is essentially Boss Rush. Your next loop will reduce the amount of enemies needed to summon the bosses as well as add one extra boss spawn per loop. The red portal will only spawn if your run is fast enough, at under 12 minutes. Which is fine because you need every character to beat a run that quickly to unlock a rune for each class. There is no need to continue to loop on the higher Curses. On Curse 3 I have red portal looped to the third loop (another unlock) and received enough experience to level up about 15-20 levels. On Curse 5/6/7 should you win, you will gain experience equivalent to 30+ levels easily. There is currently no reason to level up past 60 but when has that ever stopped anyone. 

This game has some excellent bones and groundwork laid out for it. For $10 you can absolutely spend it on worse games. This game is great to play. All of my friends that love horde battlers are into this game and we have been dumping a stupid amount of hours into this game because it is so much fun. I am 100% committed to this game and the Devs, as well as curious where the sister title Rogue Soulstone will be heading. I waited some time to pick up this game and now I can't stop thinking about it every time I sit at my computer. This game is worth every penny and if you're on the fence about it, I promise you, you will find at least one character that you enjoy playing. 

I also own a Steam Deck 512GB and the game runs flawlessly on it. I cannot put this game down: buy it now!

Edit 2/13/23 
So I just left this review the other day and as of now a handful of my desires and concerns have been addressed with the newest update. BUY THIS GAME
This is better than Vampire Survivors!

At this point in Early Access, this game has provided enough entertainment for me to rack up 15 hours and feel 'finished' - I unlocked every available character and played a few runs with each of them.  Despite my list of cons below, I do recommend the game and I think it's fun enough for a $10 price point, especially with the promise of more content to come.

Pros:
* The graphics clearly have a leg up on most Survivors-genre games.
* Attacks have clearly marked ground indicators showing where enemy attacks will land - vs many other Survivors-genre games where enemies just do damage when they touch you.

Cons:
* The variety of play LOOKS great at first: different characters with different available starting skills, a few dozen skills to choose from on each character, hundreds of skills in total, a bunch of different levels, and curses that add extra challenge.  But having played at least a few runs as each character, a lot of skills are not meaningfully different from each other, and the skills you have rarely make a difference in what options you choose as you level up.  There are skills that scale with unusual stats (like armor, health, and run speed), but not enough to make a full build out of it.  Few of the passive level-up options actually change how you play.  The curses just "tune up" difficulty by adding more elite monsters, more bosses, more damage, etc - no unique challenges.  Finally, there is no difference of play in the levels - only in the resources you get from them.  Altogether, EVERY RUN FEELS THE SAME.
* At higher tiers of play, the amount of particle effects on the screen are your biggest enemy, as you will no longer be able to see the ground indicators for enemy attacks.  And most of the time, the particle effects are from your own skills.  This is actually where most of my run deaths came from, which feels unfair.

As of now, the game is a very valid vampire survivor clone, with many things to do and try out, the difficulty scales nicely by adding curses. However, the player's power is capped a bit too roughly, since (for now) weapons only have one upgrade and the skill tree is rather barebones.
Gameplay is all about kiting the enemies and dodging their attacks, which can sound repetitive, but each hero and build has a different way to do it.

Overall 7/10, if more content comes as stated in the roadmap this game can easily get to 9/10 for its genre.

If you're someone who just wants to come home and punch some dumb idiots in the face with magic spells, this is the game for you! Similar in nature to Vampire Survivors, but with a fair bit more depth in character customization. The developers clearly love games that are fun, replayable and not rife with predatory microtransactions. For $10, this game is absolutely worth the money. There's a lot here to keep you occupied if you enjoy playing different classes and unlocking lots of upgrades. At the time of this review (in early access, February 2023), there's a wealth of goals that will easily keep you occupied for 40+ hours, and more on the horizon.

For less money than a sandwich and coffee in 2023, this is a real labor of love. Try it out!

Excellent title in the genre.

Plenty of classes with just enough unique values like base stats, signature weapons, and tag selections to offer up some distinct playstyles.

Plenty of content to push your luck against the increasing difficulty of curses in five different maps. Along with plenty of unlockables to reward you for pushing those limits.

A wide variety of weapons and weapon families to synergize and scale.

Seven bosses that each provide a measure of unique threat to the player. You'll become quite familiar with them over the course of the game, but once you have to start taking on two or more, they'll always provide some measure of challenge.

A relic system that allows you to further customize your characters in unique ways for your next run.

Combat with an emphasis on dodgeable attacks - that can get extremely hectic toward lategame, but still manages to stay mostly legible. I can't say that for every game that's tried this.

Overall, really solid title. One of the greats in the Survivors genre.

I originally bought this game because I started playing Vampire Survivors (which I also highly recommend) & thought it played very similar. Well, it does, but this one actually plays a little bit better. Where Vampire Survivors is a tribute to the 8-bit Castlevania titles, this one doesn't feel like a tribute to anything. Yes, there are various characters to unlock, yes there several abilities, skills, & weapons, but what sets this one apart are the attacks, runic powers that you can unlock, & the crafting of newer weapons. At the time of writing this review, I've got almost 35 hours in & still haven't completely unlocked everything. If you keep going in endless mode & continue collecting gems, your character will eventually get stupidly powerful. One of the characters I had, used a spin attack. After applying several expansion power-ups, attack speed power-ups, & multi-casting power-ups, my character's spin attack was so big that it took up the entire screen & completely destroyed enemies like crazy.

One of its drawbacks is the game only seems to offer 5 stages. However, I'm sure that with extra DLC or maybe future updates, they can add to this to give it some extra depth, that's just a minor gripe. Its still fun & I keep coming back to it over & over again.

On a scale of 1 to 5 I give it a 4.5. Its definitely worth a buy, especially if your're into bullet hell or rogue-like games. It also plays perfectly on the Steam Deck.

Overall I'm quite satisfied

Pros:
- I like this low-poly 3d style a lot more than purely 2d
- Unlocking stuff is fun
- Overall the playing process is very satisfying

Cons:
- Skills and balance. Some skills are just weak and I couldn't find any way to make them work (for example rot-based). I would welcome more variety in builds, e.g. increase damage of certain skills against certain effects (cold dmg vs frozen, only physical vs weak, etc)
- performance is not ideal, especially for some builds. I noticed the sooner you kill, the better. So, sturdy or dot based builds do not really play well
- overloaded with mechanics. I could assume that some people might enjoy it, but I would welcome either an option to reduce the number of mobs but increase their power, or prevent most of the mobs doing AoE damage. Currently anywhere past first 3 minutes you are continuously in "red=bad, run from red" mode, having to run and dash ALL the time. This could be fun as a phase, but not the 95% of gameplay. I enjoyed assassin gameplay the most, which rewards "being in the right place at the right time" kind of gameplay. So, I'd enjoy a bigger variety of mechanics, but lesser total amount of them at the given time.
- character and item choices often have small impact on the gameply
- lack of content: but this is an early access so I get it

I've played a bunch of Vampire Survivors clones (bullet heavens, or arena survivors), probably close to 10 at this point. Soulstone Survivors was the most enjoyable out of all of them, and I put way more time into it than any other similar game.

It is a simple concept, easy to pick up but interesting to crack and find out all of the broken combos. Nice and chill, almost no mechanical skill required, which is just great for me at the ripe old age of 37. I enjoyed the grinding and challenges that need to be done to unlock all the runes and heroes. Some might find that tedious, but to me it was just the right amount. I felt the difficulty was well-balanced and scaled just so, making the game feel decently challenging at all stages, just enough for a casual experience. You will need a well-optimized build to beat the highest difficulty, but still there is enough leeway to find different solutions.

A word of advice: the screen clutter in lategame becomes ridiculous, I strongly recommend lowering the skill opacity through the video settings. It makes a differrence.

Game plays similar to smash hits like "Vampire Survivors" only this title expands on the genre adding an intuitive Rune system which allows players to modify certain elements of the match such as Crit chance, Damage, Ability pools and more. Furthermore Soulstone Survivors has a crafting system which at this point of my review looks to be something great still in the works. additionally, every character has a craft-able weapon which modifies both their stats and their starting ability.

First off, extremely polished for an early access game. Never any bugs, crashes, glitches, significant missing features, no major issues whatsoever. Plus the devs are pretty responsive on discord about suggestions and roadmaps and stuff.

As to the gameplay, this is a great take on the Vampire Survivors subgenre. Compared to Vampire Survivors, this game has much more appealing graphics and a really interesting take on meta-progression. There's a blacksmith that upgrades the weapons of every character using resources you find around the maps. You also unlock "runes" (of which there are dozens and dozens) which you can equip in all sorts of interesting combinations before a run. There's also a skill tree which gets maxed out pretty quick.

All in all, if you like Vampire Survivors, you'll also have a blast with this game.

If you like Vampire Survivor, chances are you will like this too.

There is a ton of customization you can do each round (and a lot of RNG). Each of the "classes" feel fairly unique as they are limited to what types of attacks they can pull on levelling up, and they all have 2 unique skills (some are good and some you want to trade or avoid using).

The first round felt super easy and I thought this game was going to be boring, but there is a cursed mode where you can increase the difficulty (exponentially harder with max curses) and there are also separate portals you can take once a map is cleared to continue with your build on increasing difficulty. 

There is a lot of things going on on the screen later into a round, I found it helped (my survival) substantially by turning down the effects in graphics settings.

I have played this game exclusively on my Steam Deck, and aside from a few small issues it is almost like it was made for the Deck. Definitely a fun game to sit down with for half an hour or so when I am relaxing on the couch.

This game is vibrant, polished, and disgustingly addictive. Lots of Early Access games are just a step above bad demos, but this does not feel EA at all. I will get many more hours out of it, and knowing there are more content updates coming, I just feel spoiled. I can't wait to see what else they add.

Balance and abilities already feel really good. Thanks to randomized abilities every game is different, you are deciding and creating your build on the fly based on what you're presented with and that can lead to surprising choices and interesting synergies. I've already played some very exciting and wildly different builds -- from an incredible Arcane fireworks build, to a blinding, wrecking Fire Blast build (literally had to turn special effects down to 0 because the entire screen would flash and I was a tiny bit concerned about seizures), to a Shadow/Doom build where everything just face-melted, to a dash-and-backstab Assassin build that worked surprisingly well and destroyed lords in mere seconds. And I've only played two classes so far out of 16(?). Games can be quick (10-15 minutes) or there's two different endless modes to see how long you can survive. Currently nearly 200 Steam achievements, if you like to achievement hunt like I do.

Rarely I find myself thinking, "I wish that worked a little different" about small things; you get very detailed summary screens but I feel like there is some vagueness in game (like Prestige levels, what exactly do they do for my character?); but I have encountered nothing game-breaking or deal-breaking. If there is anything lacking, it's that what seems to be the main currency (the blue crystals) are stupid common and easy to build up, and there's not nearly enough to spend them on. I want more skill trees, more runes, more weapons and shop-type stuff. Give me some kind of gambling to blow through my wallet. But I'm sure there's stuff coming. 

Overall, really enjoy it. I load it up and several hours will slip away. Great value at the price.

Holy shit this game is fun. Really meaty and in-depth unlocks, satisfying runs, tons of synergies, short but impactful runs that let you proceed further if you're decimating, etc. Really rewards you for good decisions and lucky rolls. Lots of characters with added  equipment crafting/unlock system to work towards. Agree with many of the comments and reviews saying it's reminiscent of diablo's rift farming but quickly fleshing out a build from scratch in rough-type genre form. If you enjoy build crafting, you'll most likely love this game. Not much to the gameplay other than dashing and aiming/moving so it really relies on decisions and skill/buff selections so really amazing game to just chill to while destroying enemies. Only issue for me personally I'd say is the game isn't 100% controller friendly. Sometimes I have to mouse-over UI stuff to get more info or get buttons to take focus to use controller again but no biggie, full controller use is like 90%. Can't compare much to other games in the "horde-killing" genre, haven't really played much besides this and "Her Name Was Fire", but as someone stumbling into the genre, I'd highly recommend if you love math, stat-boosting, synergies, etc.

Excellent Vampire Survivors clone. The weapons are cool, and the graphics and sound effects are high quality. Nice difficulty. I wish the music were better and the curses were better explained.

TLDR: This game already competes with Vampire Survivors through its diversity in abilities and combat. I love the amount of chaos, graphics, and tweaks to combat available. This game has a ways to go before it grows into it's promise and outline of a well polished Diablo-like bullet-hell.

[spoiler]I love: The amount of abilities, passive skills, character perks, character special skills, build possibilities, all of the chaos/ bullet hell, overlord mode (faster mode and more bosses), curse mode & bonuses (difficulty upscale), the first map and the snow map, main screen music; character and skill diversities; boss diversity; game graphics.

I don't like/ wish for updates on: The amount of levels; more detailed levels with breakables, changing environments within levels, side events or side quests within levels (this is hugely needed, some maps are bland or empty with not much thought put in);  more abilities especially summons, nature tree skills, ice skills, or different skill branches/ types; more ways to avoid insta-kill by endless AOE's late game; further late game rewards; 2 player (please); different types or shapes of levels and bosses; option to change music to a different level or main screen one; better controller support in main menu, and navigating owned abilities in game; ways to alter gameplay similar to artifacts or cards in Risk of Rain 2 and Vampire Survivors, respectively; character rotation in main menu; more unique character skills or skins; and refining character menu poses like the assassin and others lol.[/spoiler]

As of right now this game is in early access... And I am absolutely hooked.

There are a number of characters all with their own themes, flavour, and play styles. Differences are largely due to modifiers and abilities, but they fit the given character and their differing abilities all give them a truly unique feel.

Not to mention that progression unlocks more abilities, and playing a character long enough can unlock the ability to offer their more unique abilities to other characters. There's a lot of depth!

I'm a sucker for debuffs, so I'm enjoying The Death Knight right now, freshly unlocked from a great grind with Paladin. Characters feel rewarding, as does progression. This is a beautiful work in development and I'm so eager to see what comes in the future.

While rather fun the lack on content is honestly a bit too lacking at its current state witch in itself is fine however having another game on "Coming soon" by the developer though looking very similar it does make me skeptical at how their resources are being allocated. Till more advancement content is made it feels very bare bones and id much more recommend vampire survivors though it might change as this game gets more content. There is potential but the updates seem rather slow and hence the other in development game makes me really uncertain as to whether this will be another abandoned game in the end or not.

You're way more active here than in Vampire Survivors, with a dodge button and the need to actively aim most of your skills. In the end it's kinda closer to an arena Diablo-like ARPG where your active skills are just automatically cast. I love it and I can't wait to see where it goes.

While clearly derivative of Vampire Survivors, which was itself derivative of games like Robotron and Crimsonland, Soulstone Survivors actually has better graphics, good upgrade selection, and a nice range of abilities to choose from and I found it to be the more enjoyable game. 

It is not overly hard (there's one fiddly seasonal battle achievement but otherwise you shouldn't struggle once you get the hang of it), with a fairly simple permanent upgrade system that you will max quite early on. Beyond that, you'll pick a selection of runes for minor customization, but most variety comes from your selection of class/skills during each run. Each run is enjoyable with a nice progression, and can be difficulty scaled to match your current goals.

My only real complaint would be that after enough multi-cast and size upgrades applied to your skills the screen can be overwhelmed with particle effects to the point where you can't actually see where to dodge. You'll learn the patterns and largely be able to predict / buffer past with dash immunity, but I suspect they could have solved this with better layering to leave threats visible.

Despite this, it is definitely worth a play through. Have fun!

Easy to play, hard to master. Pure Chaos unfolds so quickly! My only complaints here would be the maps should be less cluttered with indestructible obstacles. Too many runs have ended stuck up against a tree lol. Melee survivors like Berserker should also have more HP given how close to death they have to constantly be in. Otherwise, FANTASTIC GAME!

Do you like Diablo / Path of Exile type games?
Is your favorite part tinkering with the different skills and trying out new builds?
Do you hate having to grind for gear for builds to work?

If so, this game is likely a solid buy for you: 
* Lots of different character classes which provide you unique starting stats and skill groups
* Progression unlocks runes and rune slots allowing you a great deal of versatility for your runs
* Very easy to adjust difficulty with the Curses feature, allowing you to 'get in, get ugly' or have a more relaxed run
* Skills are all cooldown autofire, so you're not constantly mashing keys
* Effect Transparency settings means you can actually see what is going on around you

Yeah, if you read through guides you'll find there are a lot of ways to cheese builds to crush the endgame. And if that is your thing, more power to you. But personally, I love trying out the different skills in different combinations. 

It's not a perfect. The autofire skills aren't everyone's cup of tea, and for some can make gameplay a bit boring. Telling you right now, the only button you need to hit is the Dash. Healing and defense stats are still a bit wonky as of this review, so most of the time you're ignoring them in favor of raw damage. And my personal peeve, a lot of time you can get snagged on a wall or some other element of the background. Nothing is more disappointing than dashing away only to get stuck on a minor outcropping of a wall and one shot. 

If the devs read this (yeah, I know there are better ways of contacting them, but I'm lazy):
* Have dash allow you to move through minor background elements, or at least "slide" along them. Being able to dash through a wall for safety would be great, or at least not dashing into that little corner of the element and getting stuck.
* Please move to percentage based healing. Increasing your max HP seems sort of defeating as it is very difficult to recover health to get to that max.
* Have Health upgrade include a minor percentage heal (Increase Max HP by X, then heal Y%), or include a "increase other sources of healing by Z%." I don't feel as if the game needs a lot more sources of healing, just some in-run way of boosting the amount you heal. 
* Please offer rare upgrades that combine Armor and Block chance buffs. Maybe I'm doing it wrong, but I've never found these upgrades to be priorities, and having a few rare ones that boost them both (much in the same way as "improve all arcane skills") would make them more palatable. 
* Thank you, I love this game

Early game Soulstone Survivors is a good and fun game. Really well polished and well paced. However, at the end-game where everything is pushed to its limits, everything falls apart at the seams and is nothing but a jank, hair pulling induced mess.

Balance is all over the place. AI for minions is absolute dog water. Terrain has collision issues where you come to dead stops if an arm hair so much as looks at that tree you're trying to dash by. Some bosses have near instant attacks that's extremely hard to dodge with massive hitboxes that are bigger than what's telegraphed.

Hard pass on this game if not on sale.

If only Steam allowed a"maybe" recommended review. At launch I was very excited to play this game. It was a bit disappointing to learn that none of the progress made during the demo period transferred over to the full game. Now looking back on the reddit comment that mentioned this should have been possible, it was noted that there was an exception for the Steam Deck, which is where I played both the demo and full game. Regardless, the early part of the game was very fun. Unlocking new characters with different playstyles and weapons is the core progress loop for many games and it hooks you immediately. The reason I would say maybe recommend is that the late game difficulties seem unfair. Rouge-lite/likes always need to balance RNG with player skill. In late game, relying on RNG in order to get the exact upgrades necessary to wittle down the multiple bosses health down is not exactly fun. The player movement speed feels like is slows as time goes on, but looking back it may just be that the distance between safe places to stand are further apart. Without at least one summon in a run to alleviate some of the boss aggro, late game bosses attacks will overlap, so you're constantly forced to dash, not allowing much time for attacks to go off near bosses. The frame rate plummets if you get too close to large clusters of enemies, and suddenly the health/armor buffs you've collected are wiped away in an instant. Having to deal with 6 bosses with over 1 million health each, and only being able to output a few thousand points of damage means I'm dashing around the map, aiming at bosses off the edge of the screen hoping to stack debuffs. It was fun in the beginning when the difficulty seems more balanced. As of now, I think this is a good addition to the bullet hell/heaven genre. Since it seems like there are plenty of updates planned, some tweaking to player movement, RNG, and damage output I can see myself feeling less frustrated when a run is lost. I will definitely pick up again in a few months to see if anything has changed.

Very good game. highly addictive. Only issue is the frame rate goes down easily, even on very low graphic settings (tested only on Steam Deck). Graphic optimization is highly suggested to devs.

One of the few "Survivors-likes" that actually add the formula. There is a solid progression system but it lacks depth. The game is fun to play, and worth the price if you played vampire survivors and want more, but the game has some flaws.

1. lack of content. The game is in early access and if the devs stick with it I think it will be great, but right now it gets boring pretty fast, around ~15 hrs or so.

2. lag. The game suffers late into runs, I have a mid end machine and my fps falls below 10 at around the 30 minute mark

3. visibility. Your skills will take up the entire screen. You will be forced to turn down their opacity in the settings so the game remains playable. This sucks because skills look cool.

Will edit this in the future when devs release more content.

The game constantly teases you with new upgrades and systems and characters to unlock, if only you would play a little bit more, but then you unlock them and the game doesn't change.  There's no moment when an upgrade or new mechanic radically recontextualizes a weak ability, or forces you to play in a more strategic/aggressive/complex manner.  Every single new feature that you will spend hours grinding the identical maps for simply gives you a smidgen of incremental power, which you then turn around and use to fight enemies with a smidgen more incremental health.

And who knows? Maybe I'm wrong, I only have six hours in the game, maybe it really opens up after 20 hours put in.  But I'm just not willing to put that kind of time into something so repetitive in order to make it slightly less repetitive.

This is a review of Early Access version 0.9.029e3

This is a good game with potential to be a great game. The early game is simple enough and intriguing enough to make me want to know more. After a few runs, the mid-game shows tidy mechanics and a power curve that makes me feel like I am smashing monsters powerfully; I like that. The late game, currently, is a bit grindy and frankly not fair: The deep bosses and levels are fire fire everywhere and no safe place to stand, you can be killed in one or two hits with little opportunity to recover, and it takes quite long time to dance in the fire and beat down the bosses (plural); this is not fun in large doses.

Some things I would like to have added to the final game:
* There should be a systematic reward for leveling up a character. Right now there are 3 runes and one weapon as rewards, but there should be more incremental rewards per level.
* The power curves should be tweaked. The bosses have millions of HP and the player just a few hundred; giving thousands of hits to kill the boss and the boss can kill me in one or two hits is too lopsided. If I want that kind of experience I will go play Punch Out.
* The current levels are just arenas. Some level diversity which allowed me to work across a battlefield, up a mountain, through a valley, etc. as a means to find and slay the boss(es) would be neat. It would also add some lore or story to the game where presently there is none.

Obviously inspired by Vampire Survivors, I really have to compare this game to both VS and other rogue-whatevers.

Graphics and music are nice. The artstyle is somewhat simplistic but you won't be looking at small details anyway.

You pick your character, their passive runes, other passive bonuses, starting weapon (provide different skills and further stat changes), pick a map, pick curse intensity (additional difficulty for more rewards) and start. 

You will be harassed by an increasing number of incresingly difficult enemies and bosses until you win the round. Then you either end your run or continue further in one of two modes. This makes game harder and harder until you either quit or die. This is the loop, love it or hate it.

Every achievement unlocks new skills, runes, characters, weapons etc. making the game quite rewarding.

The amount of enemies and AoE and visual effects will make it increasingly difficult to survive and see anything. I am not joking - the insane amount of visual clutter is basically a selling point. It's a joke that gets old fast and you will seek to find a balance between seeing what is happening and seeing at least outlines of your attacks. So you will either turn off the pretty visual effects or turn them down. A LOT.

Harder difficulties honestly get so ludicrous they kind of stop being fun for me. Being one shot by a boss from outside the screen isn't fun. Everyone gets faster, tougher, and deadlier. Fast.

Potential problems. Might be actually good depending on your preferences.

- Game gets repetitive very fast. There is basically no lore, no story, nothing. It's a shame because even a little bit of characterisation would give this game more soul (heh).
- Best defense is a good offense. You want to hit hard rather than being able to take the punches most of the time. Being deadly lowers the time enemies are alive and can harm you. Being tanky does not.
- Mobility over defense. That 5 % damage reduction is a nice upgrade but later when bosses hit for 100+ damage you will take movement speed instead. 
- Single target over AoE. I like to have at least one AoE skill but success comes with the ability to take down high-priority targets fast.
- Ranged over melee. The ground can get mostly red with incoming attacks. And if enemies form a deathball you might not be able to even get close if you have insufficient range.
- Knockback. Many enemies do miniscule damage. But oh boy they will push you into something that does.
- Rubber. You get stuck on terrain pretty often. That leads to your death pretty often. Think about it. You have slain thousands only to be felled by a strategically placed palm tree.

One thing I have to praise that unlike many similar games where progression only unlocks new stuff and increases the randomness this one actually unlocks options for you to mitigate this. You can influence what skills you get or add skills otherwise inaccessible for that character. Incredible. Beautiful.  

Overall the game was fun and I will certainly come back with further updates.

i wanted to wait, and play long for the review content, but i would rather you know that if you loved Vampire Survivors for what it is, this is going to rock your socks off. You can give monster gangrene ROFL ; the curses make the waves far more intense, walk around and enjoy being the best bullet hell you can make for any race, orc, goblins, snakes, medieval F's , giants, you'd even kill Ares, Hercules, Poseidon, Hades, etc but you'd lose to Zagreus :D 
Hectic side note: Keyboard < Controller

Experiments should be for the entire session. The spells and abilities are so good that once any upgrade is for the specific spell, it helps push waves back. The engine then also realizes you're kicking it in the shorter space of time that is usual, and tries equally hard to dominate you. The system is so good, I'd say it's 50-50 , and some builds you know from the start you WILL demolish everything. The luck and chance is equal as well, some games are EPIC< LEGENDARY all the time, some are casual, and then the legendaries that pop up hidden in the quick picks of 3, catches you off, and you casually still pick the wrong one. It's a great mental game as well. You neeed to be more present than VS< Less AFK< you can learn your patterns. 
The core ways are establishing your build, and optimizing the spells you start with, You should try to pick cleverly from the begining so you should never ever should you replace an upgraded spell/ability, if you have furthered it, because it can change your synergy negatively if you pick the wrong thing. However, some classes have class-specific spells, and abilities that can only mix into your request for them, by a Rune you have earned, from the starting menu// after many runs.
It's deeper, VS has gold for after-death upgrades. This game has 6 different currencies, in the form of crystals, which can be farmed level-specific to the ores you need.

The enemies are by the swarms. You need them, as much as they need you.

You get 6 major-spells,/ abilities, 
And then passives, which are the upgrades to the said abilities.
Best to get them organized by type- in the beginning, so that you can just keep strengthening the roots of your build.

The passive upgrades you get are plentiful, from the cast % tick, to Area of effect, Multicast %, Crit chance %, Crit extra %, 
You usually get choices of 3 , with some careful reading required to help you differentiate between two different upgrades for the same spell,
It's really incredible,

I want you to have fun! If you loved VS, you will enjoy getting wrecked by this.

You also get Dashes. 2 Max via the after-death upgrades, and then sometimes, you get the chance of getting an epic upgrade dash in-game. 

Levels, are chaotic. for best setting, just turn the spell visibility down by one notch, and game is clear. There's a LOT of screen noise.
I'm surprised they don't warn people with epilepsy, 

The performance of the game is still under construction, and usually after minute 8 you're knee-deep in many things so you are dashing for your life.

The playstyles can vary so much because with each of the different characters, come UNIQUE spells that only certain characters can access :) it's not like VS- where each char starts with something unique to them, but every other person can also get it, etc. There are 3 major spells per character-class, and the ugprades that support them are each wonderful.

This game will keep you entertained for many moons to come.

It's good, play it. If you like this kind of stuff and you appreciate passionate developers.

Cheers.

Was in a 2 hour long run and the game randomly crashed when selecting an upgrade. 

Otherwise game is great.

Edit1: 

If You're going to give me 5 slots for Runes, and make Runes costs a different amount of points, make it so that I can fill all 5 slots with 5, 5 costing Runes points. Why would I use a bunch of low tier junk skills when I worked so hard to get high tier skills to only use 1? 

The highest tier Runes cost 4 points, meaning I can use one low tier one high tier. Why? The amount of replayability to use a ton of different Runes, low-mid-high tier would make this game much better. If I have 5 slots, and want to use 5 high tier Runes at 4 point cost, the max point availability should be 20. 

As well, if you're going to spam large area attack enemies, give us a passive heal. As there are no Actives or passives that give us life steal and the healing crystals do not spawn nearly often enough to be effective. Particularly since they're healing amount is capped. 

I really like this game, but there's some major flaws. I will continue to edit this as I play.

Edit 2: 

Hopefully the Devs won't delete this, this time.

Increase Rune cap to 20. Don't give me varying cost runes if I have to use an assortment of low-cost runes to fill slots with. It's not fun winning a run because I got lucky once out of 100 tries. Runes tie in to your build, why would you limit the creativity and effectiveness of a build? 

Tier5 Curse is unbearably boring. I can't see what I'm doing, I can't and not a single character with any combination of abilities can realistically survive a first round, because kiting doesn't work either since you kill trash mobs fast. 

The Banish/Reroll system is a 50/50. Banish works to keep junk you don't want for a particular build away, but the reroll most times just rerolls the same stuff I wanted to get rid of, back into my option pool. At the very least, show me other junk I don't want so I know it's worth clicking the button.

Characters have too many affinities that are entirely unrelated to them. Runes can help reduce this, And while using all of them, it works for the first 3 levels that you receive Active choices. Then it stops entirely. You would think that this is an okay solution, but now I'm wasting rune slots to ensure I get Active choices that actually synergies with the character I'm playing. Why would I want stuff that doesn't synergies with my character? I'd have played the character that does. 

More health options are mandatory. passive regen, Actives ( or passives ) that provider health regen or life steal effects on hit and/or kill. Almost every single enemy in the game spams AoE attacks, particularly bosses who cover the entire screen or half of it. You can reliably dodge every single red mark on the screen. And between things having more health and dealing more damage and showing up in high frequency, you have to give your players some kind of way to keep them selves alive besides ( Don't get hit ) 

The entire screen turns into a targeted area 2 minutes into a Curce V run, you're forever going to get it. Please make these changes are your game will function much.

Great Vampire Survivors-like Bullet Heaven game until you get into the higher difficulties.
The difficulty scaling is very much forced on you, you get 5-6 options to make the game harder but the only way to unlock the next level is to beat the current one with all the difficulty options turned on, so you might as well combine them all into an on-off switch, and you are going to be having them always on.

There isn't much variety between skills, the game brags about having over 100 but really its just line aoe, cone aoe, circle aoe and then fire, poison, ice, physical, chaos. Then combinations of those. So pretty much every build feels exactly the same.
The neat thing is, there are some really cool tanky skills and stuff that heals you. The bad news is, because the difficulty scaling is forced on you and the mob HP and damage keeps scaling higher and higher, and bosses won't wait for you to kill the last boss before stacking on you, choosing any tanky abilities instead of 100% damage is going to cause you to lose constantly at higher difficulties.

The visual clutter and noise is way too much. Once you get far enough into a run, you will either die or your aoes are so large that you can no longer see the enemies or the crap on the ground that will hurt you if you touch it, causing you to die. I wish I could see the red "Dont stand in this" circles through the effects, and my character. Most of the time the game is just a giant flashing screen of insanity and you can't tell what is your effects or the enemy effects.

A highly satisfying and a promising "You are the bullet hell" game with surprising difficulty in the later levels. Right now there is not that much meta-modifiers to your skill picks, but getting that Legendary +50% dmg boost that hits all your 6 active skills is something else. I also believe that the game is quite scalable, meaning that there are multiple development options for the future. Active skills do feel different but some damage over time effects can be lackluster. A run can be as quick as ~12 minutes, or you can test how well your build scales by going into "Endless" or "Overlord". As of writing this review, a considerable amount (24%) have unlocked all classes, including going "Curse V" on a certain map. I certainly had difficulty doing so. Pick this up if you want an affordable and a fun, coffee break action time bullet hell with promising depth!

When it comes to this style of game, I played Vampire Survivors first and became crack addicted to it. This was a seamless transition from that game to this one. Soulstone Survivors mechanics are a bit different, but still fun and very addicting. Highly recommend!
