If you enjoyed Vampire Survivors this is a must pick, as it does all that VS does but better, though it's a little easier than VS it has some interesting scaling difficulty in the form of Curses, which unlocks higher difficulty curses when you beat them. 

The devs are ambitious and updates seem to be rolling out at a decent pace, about once a month if not more often and they seem to be listening to feedback thus far. 

Overall it's a great game and in a really good place already, I genuinely believe it will only get better.

Another solid evolution on the survivors format with plenty of characters, weapons, upgrades, combos and more makes this a fun time that is easy to sink many hours into. The downsides is that the achievements are not as crisp and fun as other survivor-genre games, and as this is a genre where achievements play a bigger role than most other it impacts the experience. Another downside is that it is extremely hard to see enemy effects in the late-game where particle effects and animations just take up the entire screen, but its quite easy to look past and only annoying when doing the high curse runs.
The Best bullet hell game i've played, so far in my experience in bullet hell type games.

I downloaded this and played it literally for 4 hours straight. THIS is how you do a top down roguelike. Each choice makes you feel just a tad better/beefier/more powerful than the last, whether that's your first level up or your 50th. Killing dudes to summon the boss is AWESOME! Once you get used to it, each level becomes a speed run of sorts. The farming materials in each level is cool and different as well. The progression is great too, as you don't want to rush to the end because you want to see what skills you are given. So far, you DEFINITELY get your moneys worth. Also, the graphics feel perfect for the game!

Seems like most of the important decisions are locked pretty far behind achievements

Under a tenner for 60+ hours of fun, mindless slaughter of 1000s of enemies, feels like decent value to me. Game is another Vampire Survivors "bullet heaven" deals. Less deep than VS, main problem being that at higher difficulties/longer runs all classes end up playing the same, with only a handful of skills being viable at Curse 5+. Graphics are prettier than VS, but if you want to be able to see anything in late-game you'll find yourself turning all the fancy effects off anyway.
The game seems to be under active development, which is good, hopefully it can grow into something more substantial in the long run. However, for now, it's a fun distraction and an easy, cheap source of dopamine hits.

Do you like destroying hordes of enemies? Do you like stacking upgrades? Destroying hordes of enemies? Watching mind-boggling amounts of chaos and damage numbers go up?

This game offers all of that and expands on the "survivor" twin-stick isometric trend a bit with a lot of unlockable goodies. A dozen characters, tons of persistent bonuses that will apply to each character, an optional second weapon for each character, and there's a way to unlock specific attack types for all characters.

Really easy way to evaporate a couple hours (and your framerate if you stack cast frequency too high, roflamao).

I've enjoyed this game, it's more relaxed than other similar games. You can turn up the "Heat" level and make it harder, as you progress, for better rewards. I'd recommend this game to a friend who was interested.

Great game to invest in on those rainy days or when you have nothing else better to really do. The massive skill tree and rune tree add new interesting mechanics to the game to pick up and add to your arsenal.

Looking forward for the full release.  The game as is is really fun, and addictive.  I actually prefer this to vampire survivors due to the more control you have over the powers.  It's fun to find synergies, though they're definitely not as deep (AFAICT) as vampire where items can combine to become a synergized weapon.  I do wish that was here, but there are different starting weapons for each class, and a lot of attacks.  Each run is relatively fast (can be under 10m, though I'm currently taking 11m or so) and there is enough variety.

The game is actually pretty decent for the genre. It stands out with a massive list of unlockable abilities and runes. Classes get unique abilities added to their pool as you level up and unlock weapons for them. 
Curse System is decent too and very much needed for a game like this. Basically get to adjust the difficulty to your liking and get better rewards for higher Curse levels. However. The games one big flaw is that it lacks Resources Sinks. Once you max out the skill tree and buy your weapons, you've got nothing left to spend the resources you've gathered. And they have you able to get high end rare materials that have no use yet if your Curse Level is high enough. So im sitting with 1 million of the Soulstones and some 25-30 of the Boss Soulstone resources. 

The game has a slider for spell FX to be more transparent so you can actually see whats going on when your character is shitting out AoE's nonstop.  
The Rune system is nice too. It lets you get a bit more freedom in your build or capitalize on your build, even some utility.

Dungeons are the only other gripe for now. They lack theme. You'll fight the same goblin mooks in each map, same snakes and ogres, etc. All maps change are which materials can be found and the amount of random shit you might end up getting snagged on. (you kinda stick to walls and it slows your movement, causes potential death)

It's kinda pog for the dopamine seeking, bigger number better person seeing monke brain of ours

edit: works pretty well on Steam Deck as well, so you can fall asleep during Endless runs and cry upon realizing you got hit.
better than VS

This game has genuinely been a surprise treat, and my favorite entry in the subgenre since VS. Characters all have extremely distinct flavors and playstyles, with a wide pool of weapons (already!) that require making real build decisions. Stats grow in a satisfying manner that ends up with some truly absurdist runs, whether that be screen-wide Spellblade swings or LMG fire coming out of a Sentinel's shortbow.

The only thing it's currently missing is a character with access to a dedicated Summon tag for their skill picks, and the appropriate Rune unlocks: It'd be great to have a posse on more characters.

I'm really excited to see where updates take this game! :D

By that I mean, it has that "We need them to invest quarters so kill them at certain points" that pizza place arcade machines had. It is difficult to see, hard to avoid...and honestly not fun.

This game definitely has that arcade game feel to it. No mystery, no charm, no real purpose. Just a game for games sake that tries to capture the feel of games like Vampire Survivors. Anyways, ignore this until they figure that out and go play Vampire Survivors instead.

Probably the most high budget-looking bullet heaven games currently on the market, Soulstone Survivors combines Torchlight-esque graphics and a generally more ARPG approach to the titular progression system from Poncle's genre-creating masterpiece, Vampire Survivors. Gorgeous graphics aside, the main elements that stick out are a surprisingly deep RPG skilltree, the addition of dodges which are essential with most big enemies attacks being area-based, and even some crafting. Lastly, the game puts no limits on the amount of perks and upgrades the player can have, making it so that eventually the entire screen can be covered up by attacks that were barely bigger than the playable character at first. But don't worry, the opacity of these attacks can be lowered.

This last feature contributes to the game's main shortcoming, and it's how the power creep makes the endgame a bit trivial. Eventually, the player can stunlock and freeze every enemy that spawns, though their healthbar becomes larger and larger, making them lengthy bullet sponges to take down while not really offering much of a challenge anymore. This makes the endless runs rather repetitive. But with already plenty of classes, many different weapons, tons of things to unlock and even cool timed events, Soulstone Survivors is easily one of the best bullet heaven titles out there, one I keep going back to from time to time.

Bullet Heaven Fandom review #2. If you're looking for extensive coverage of the games in this genre, consider checking out my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/43402758-Bullet-Heaven-Fandom/]Bullet Heaven Fandom[/url] curator page.

TL:DR If you've finished Vampire Survivors and are looking for something similar yet different, I highly recommend this game. It's early access, so there are some rough edges, but this game is very good. 

The most obvious comparison is to Vampire Survivors, and while I think these two have a lot in common, I think they're also pretty different. I would classify this as a twin stick shooter, as you're doing a lot more active movement than VS and you have a target and need to aim some abilities. I play this with a PS5 controller and it plays very well, but navigating through menus inbetween games is cumbersome unless you use a mouse.

I really enjoy this game, I have about 80% of the current unlocks, so still a bit more to go, but I'm very much enjoying this game and can't wait for the next content patch.

The Pros:
Good graphics and charming art style
Good soundtrack
Tons of abilities
Lots of classes
Lots of ways to customize your run with runes
Really interesting combining different abilities each run to see what works and what doesn't.
Tooltips for abilities update, meaning if your skill does 100 damage and you take a 30% damage upgrade, you'll see it listed as 130 damage.

The Cons:
Game is still EA and I've had several crashes, including losing a 50 minute run, and there's no checkpoints so I wasted the entire run. Almost uninstalled right there, but glad I didn't.
Lots of different negative effects can be applied, but most of them become ineffective after wave 3.
Could use some more monster variety
Would like to see a couple more biomes
Tutorial would be good, to explain things like resources, etc.
Gamepad support in menus is cumbersome, though it's fine when playing the actual game.

What I'd like to see:
A automatic checkpoint or something at the end of each wave. It really sucks to have the game crash and lose 4 waves of progress. It would be really nice if all the resources you collected were saved at the end of each run, so if I crashed on wave 4, I'd at least have all the stuff from the last three waves.

More progression options. This is still EA and the framework for more stuff is there, but it's not in the game yet. I think this will come with time. These games live and die by how many progression paths there are.

More skills that consume DOTs and other negative effects. There are a couple but most DOT builds really fall off after wave two. Having ways to consume DOTs would open up more builds.

Interactions between negative effects. I would love to see combinations of negative effects create new ones. 

There needs to be more currency sinks. I think this is already on the roadmap.

I'd like to see the difficulty curve smoothed out a bit. Some curses are super harsh, others are almost helpful. I'm fine with the overall difficult so far (currently on T5 of curses, one more to go), but I think it's very drastic when difficulty jumps and think it could be smoothed out a bit.

Soulstone Survivors is a blast to play. Have not spent too long with this one just but so far I have been thoroughly enjoying everything that I have seen so far. The active skills are fun to watch and the synergies between 2 or more skills is always very cool. This aspect helps a lot with replayability as you can challenge yourself to aim for specific builds and combinations. The amount of different characters and option to toggle different curses help too. This game offers a charming experience that appears simplistic but is anything but once the waves start coming. Highly recommend for anyone looking for a low-effort, high enjoyment type of game.
Yes

For when you've finished Vampire Survivors and want more of the Survivors genre this is the next step.

110% Recommended!
A 3D Vampire Survivors that doesn't suck and isn't a quick cash grab like so many others. I enjoyed it as a "Prologue" and enjoy it as an EA release.

Unlock Progression is challenging, fun and expansive (Key word here is EXPANSIVE). 
Level up characters to unlock Unique Skills for them. (2-3 Per Character)
Craft new weapons that each unlock a new Skill.
Unlock Runes via achievements to help boost your runs.
Spend excess points in the Skill Tree to make life easier.

The skills and Runes really make the game fun. And seeing how you can level up endlessly, you can make some seriously broken builds.

Keep in mind that it's Early Access so not all Characters, Skills and Weapons are available. And obviously everything is subject to change.

If I had to say some key negatives, it would be how lackluster the Skill Tree really is. Sure, it's useful because it's better to have the bonuses than not but, it hardly feels like a tree. More like a Shrub. Even maxed out, it still doesn't feel like it does enough to really be game changing. 

Naturally performance is often fairly bad with all the 3D effects being used every 2 milliseconds. Even on the best of PC's, your Frames end up tanking.

Currently at the time of writing, there is only about 2 Weapons per character and 14 Characters to Unlock.

I'd like to see some unlockable Dashes or more Dash related skills for different build goals.
But so far the Devs have been doing a great job of adding cool things.
Fun distraction and very colorful

Con:

- Too many icons on the bottom left when you play to a point you can't see your cursor when you play in higher level of difficulty, could use some clean up
- Enemies and boss scale difficulty need some balance for the curse levels
- Not enough weapons for your characters

Like I said, the game is beautiful but it is a big mess as of right now and clearly need more time to work on it. Most game of the same genre are 3-5$, this one is not worth 13$CAN.

On the good side, it's a decent spin on the Vampire Survivors formula, it's like taking an ARPG skill set and tuning it for the genre. The spell effects are impressively flashy (though this also falls into the negatives later), and the game is fully 3d, if low poly, giving it a more standout look compared to others of the genre. It is also just as fun as some of the better VS-likes, due in part to the rather expansive list of skills and runes you can unlock to make a build. All in all a fun little time sink, initially, until you start getting into the later curse levels, at which point the games flaws can become glaringly apparent.

So in Soulstone Survivors, aside from your usual fodder enemies, you have elites and other minor units that have AoE attacks or debuffs to force you to move or take damage. I can understand this as a design decision, often times in Vampire Survivors and others, you can reach a point where you can effectively AFK a run because your damage output and AoE are so disgustingly high you can mostly stop paying attention, however, while initially this mechanic isn't terribly overbearing, as curse levels go up more elites spawn, and their AoE's cast faster and more frequently, followed by 2 or even 3 bosses spawning per wave, which means both more and massive AoE's to avoid. In curse 4 and 5, you practically have to never stop moving or you're dead, which is a strong point against the game as it fails to understand that there needs to be an ebb and flow to waves and fighting, whereas at Curse levels 4 and up, you're basically forced into overdrive by the game and never allowed a moments reprieve. This isn't even getting into the fact that enemy damage scales hard and their AoE's can effectively cover entire swaths of the map leaving you extremely limited space to avoid anything.

The increased difficulty also has no real gameplay merit outside of extra minor soulstones, prestige, or new types of resources from maps, again, also failing to understand what I would consider another core design point of the genre: with increased challenge also comes increased power, both you, and your enemies. there are no extra fodder spawns, or increased experience to go with the enhanced difficulty, which makes higher curse levels even harder and more restrictive as you are heavily dependent on good RNG to have even a slight hope of overpowering the enemies scaling before you die.

As it stands the best strategy for high curse levels is good AoE, movement speed, and damage stats. Armor, block and anything defensive related is all but useless because you can die very swiftly to stacked AoEs, so the only real strategy is to keep moving, which again, despite the rather wide list of abilities to choose from, you're forced to take a specific set of stats to survive, as opposed to others of the genre where a reasonably constructed build can see a run to completion.

I tentatively will give this game a thumbs up in hopes the later curse levels see a rebalance, but only because I somewhat expect a rebalance to happen somewhere in the future.

Early access review, so I acknowledge the devs will add more to this game. 

In its present state, this game is already very fun and allows for a lot of build complexity and quick progression. Your character will quickly surge through the levels required to get your 6 auto-casting active abilities and you'll start buffing or replacing them right after that. You can buff the skills individually or as groups based on their traits, or you can add global buffs to your character's movement speed, armor rating, etc. The abilities are *extremely* diverse, as are the characters; characters have access to specific groups of skills (although you can broaden this using "runes" unlocked via achievements). 

In the future, the game will hopefully diversify the maps further and balance some of the abilities. Their recent (massive, free) update shows their commitment to that end. 

Finally, make sure you have sound on - the soundtrack is wonderful.

This is Vampire Survivors on crack. That's the pitch. If you like the idea of vampire survivors productionalized into a "positioning matters" bullet hell power fantasy, I would buy this immediately.

The gameplay is super varied and fun, while also giving their huge class selection (20?!) the ability to feel unique but also have distinct overlaps. Tons of classes can spec one or two fire skills, but you can't really miss what the Pyromancer is trying to do. Weapons and runes add unique modifiers to later runs, and a skill or two that can completely change how the early game is played.

Difficulty is more similar to Hades than Vampire Survivor, with a Pact of Punishment style upgrade system that ratchets up risk and reward and gives the enemies powers to match your vertiable roguelite fantasy you've crafted over your 20+ hours of play.

Fantastic 'Survivors' style game, easily one of the best.

First off, its a really fun and expansive entry in the "survivors" genre, with interesting skills and build possibilities. It feels the most sandboxy of all the games I've played in this genre (Vamps, 20 mins, Brotato, Spellbook, etc) in how your gameplay style is very open-ended regardless of which character/map/skills you pick. Unfortunately this does lead to a situation where your build path can feel pretty samey. Yes, you may pick one or 2 stats to lean into more from run to run, but when it comes down to it you're essentially looking to buff every stat by as much you can where ever possible. Thankfully, there is enough skill variety to offset this to some degree, however. Finally, the game is a bit grindy, which can get to be somewhat of a drag considering there's no supplementary story or worldbuilding elements.

Every character has the potential to clear Vii(Hightest Curse Tier) you just need way too much luck on some of the underwhelming characters. Curse Tier V, VI and VII require you to get good grade powers prior to being Lvl 20 or you will just lose regardless of skill. Different tier of power ups, namely...Common, Uncommon, Rare, Epic and Legendary. You need a decent amount of Rare to have a chance and it's a roll each time you level up. Enemy density is poorly balanced. You will have 200 enemies clumped within 10 tiles and when you get within 20tiles of them the entire screen(Yeah I mean it) will be covering in Red Circle AoEs(Enemy damage indication delay). You only have 150-250 HP most runs cause HP is pointless same with Armor and the reason is because you need to deal enough damage to things to prevent them from clumping up. They clump up you just lose. So...the game is only playable for Glass Cannon builds. I have Cleared VII because I am an achievement hunter. One of the worst games I have played in thi genre because of the "balancing". If I could give a mixed review I would. The game is early access and I can see potential once they fix enemy density issues.

Soulstone Survivors is deserving of the title Bullet Heaven. At the time of posting, I have just cleared every achievement of the game from the original list, with only the seasonal event ones to go, and the way they incentivise you to do this is by attaching unlockable features behind each of those achievements. There is a plethora of various skills to meet numerous playstyles, as well as a solid roster of characters, all of whom now have two different weapon sets that, in turn, play differently. Abilities activate automatically, which was the initial appeal to me as a veteran of Battleships Pro from back in the day. The roguelike elements also effect the play distinctly, as the skill tree gives you permanent boosts across every playthrough, and the runes page allows you to bring unique ability combinations to the table, to such an extent that you can deeply personalize every run you play in the game. One of the best games I've played in a long time.
It's like Vampire Survivors but with better visuals and more mechanics.

The game is fun, but there's plenty ooprtunity for improvement. At this price though, I would recommend it regardless of my following comment:

At the very base, the game is fine. It's a mostly braindead hack-n-slash where the only real difficulty is making the right choices for upgrades when you level up. It's fun to see what's available, but after you have seen all the possible upgrades it becomes glaringly obvious it really just boils down to getting lucky with rewards.

That would be fine if that was it, but the rewards are tuned horribly.

There's a ridiculous over-emphasis on using abilities [i]often[/i], rather than hitting hard. Every end-game play looks exactly the same: you've chosen your skills and they are being spammed on your screen, beyond the point of even being able to tell what is actually doing damage. I've found myself replacing skills that did good damage and had good area-of-effect just because the sheer spam of the over-the-top skill effects made it that I couldn't see a damn thing.

A lot of the later difficulty of the game comes from just overtuning mobs and bringing out more of them. The enemies aren't diverse [i]at all[/i] and require essentially [i]no[/i] strategy to kill. Even the bosses aren't really an exception, but the game finds a way around that by simply dropping in 4 bosses at the same time so you can't approach any of them without dieing. It's also glaringly obvious that the melee bosses are super easy to deal with, where bosses that mostly idle in place while dropping tons of AoE are literal hell. If you get unlucky with the 4 bosses spawning, it just becomes a boring slogfest while you whittle the bosses down.

Overal I'd rate the game 4/10 right now. It really needs to address the following points:
[list]
 [*]Reduce skill spam and massively increase skill damage. Hitting less often but doing way more damage will help reduce the ridiculous skill spam;
[*]Visual clarity: the spam of abilities and screen clutter makes seeing if you're standing in a bad spot almost impossible, even when dodging that spot would be easy otherwise;
[*]Reduce wall stick (or smooth out dashes). So often I found myself trying to dash past obstacles, only to get stuck on the tiniest branch or corner. Either make sure the edged are clearly visible, or make it easier to dash past;
[/list]

Vampire survivors meets Risk of Rain. 

Addictive as sin, highly recommend.

The good:
Soundtrack!
Animations are VERY smooth
You can dash dodge
Controller or mouse are both viable options
Tons of varied skills with synergies
Rune system to interchange skill and buff behaviors before each run
Active updates from the dev team
Seamless game mode selection
 
The bad, and early release:
The knock back mechanic removes user control (a lot) taking you out of "playing"
Controller navigation in menus locks you out of achievement review, active skills while on a run and has frustrating navigation on rune selection due to 8-way rather than 4
The skill tree unlocks can be completed in about 5 hours game time leaving resource collection very empty
There are currently no level items, shrines, or relics of any kind leaving each run varied only by skill selection
There are no strengths or weaknesses to any mob .ie. no resistance to ice or weakness to fire
There is only one debuff for the player, move speed
The maps are one note aside from the placement of permanent large obstacles and types of breakables (on the list for the next update)
As with most of these games, you can stack things to melt your computer (i got down to about 2 frames a second), but it is a bit difficult to do.
Due to a recent gameplay change, damage dealing is not in sync with hp scaling of monsters as you progress but doesn't really become an issue until stage 5-7 depending on your build

Overall opinion:
Taking in active development, price tag and how much entertainment to be had before things fall off, if you like this type of game there's plenty to enjoy with more on the way.  If you go in with a specific gamestyle in mind you might be disappointed. The versatility of the game is only opened up after getting an unlock to pick the same skills twice.  This is the turning point.  Before this, you might feel a little handcuffed.  Overall I enjoyed this game, but I'll be taking a break until a big update.  You can see my hours; decide for yourself if the price fits.
For such a cheap cost this is a very engaging game.  I like the release/beta and look forward to updates.  Definitely would recommend.

This is the new king of the reverse-bullet hell genre.  My first game, I started with a whirlwind every few seconds, and 10 minutes later my screen was full of all manner of explosions and complete chaos.  10/10 would force my GPU into indentured servitude again.

There are a ton of classes with access to different skills, a skill tree, a rune system, and a tag-based build system so you can actually create real builds unlike most other games in the genre where all buffs apply universally.  Do you want to focus on lasting AOE?  Frontal electric magic?  Physical bombs?  Do whatever sounds fun, and you'll get buffs for whatever you pick.

100% worth the very reasonable price and feels like a solid game even for EA, never mind the fact that it will keep improving.

Decided to pick this up after 100%ing Vampire Survivors like many other people.  I've ran into a few things that I'm not really a big fan of.

1) Stages don't seem to matter.  All stages have the same enemies, the only difference is what upgrade materials you can get on the stage.  Same mobs, elites, and bosses.
2) Later on in a stage I frequently end up dying without really knowing why.  I'm guessing there are just AOEs that are so covered by enemies and my own abilities that I can't see them.  Beam attacks are also infinite range despite their box not showing that.
3) There seems to be serious balance issues with weapons.  Some are just so garbage, while others are absurdly great.  There are also not any cool weapon upgrades like in Vampire Survivors, there are just Bigger Number upgrades you can get.
4) There is never a point where you feel the godlike power you get later on in a VS run.  You always have to keep dodging constantly to avoid the aoes(that you frequently don't even see) and enemies just keep getting so much health that you will always have to keep dodging and aiming.

This new genre created by Vampire Survivors is one of my favorites of late.  While it is hard to choose my favorite between the two, I'll try to comment in comparison.

It took me about 70 hours to unlock everything and get every in game achievement including the holiday event.

The graphical style and skill design is reminiscent of WoW for better or worse (I happen to like this).

Strengths in comparison to VS: Better build diversity, far greater skill choices, each "class" feels much more unique to each other compared to VS.  More active gameplay involving aiming as well as dashing.  Skill tree and the rune system is more developed that VS's arcana.

Weaknesses in comparison to VS: Map diversity is non-existent.  There are no differences between maps other than the look and atmosphere.  Only 5 maps.  Few if any secrets.  There is a joy of discovery in VS that doesn't exist here.

Conclusion: For $10 and 70+ hours of entertainment, this is a no-brainer if you enjoy this genre.  All of my listed weaknesses are in the dev's roadmap to address as this is EA.  So buy it now, have fun, and look forward to the excellent support and additions in the future.  There is so much variety now, which will be more that doubled in the future (according to roadmap).

This is a [b]very strong[/b] (and my personal favorite) entry into the "Survivors" genre. The overall look and feel are pretty simplistic but the loop is so satisfying. 

[h1] Pros [/h1]
1. The upgrades [i]feel[/i] really good to obtain. You level up like crazy at the higher curse levels and almost every single upgrade feels immediately impactful to your run (I'm looking at you [b]Powerful Strikes[/b]). Once you get a good feel for the game and run through Endless and Overlord modes, you are heaping upgrades on yourself and becoming a ridiculously strong monster on the battlefield. It definitely fulfills a power fantasy.

2. There are tons of achievements to work towards so you never have an "empty" run for dozens of hours. I was constantly getting new prestige levels and climbing the curse ladder to gain runic power and more abilities. Once you have it all you are left with a really fun playground to test different builds and rune combos

3. The devs are pushing out really cool updates. One of my cons was going to be that a lot of the characters didn't have alternate weapons and better abilities but that changed literally yesterday. They seem really active in getting quality updates in our hands when they are ready. 

[h1] Cons [/h1]
1. Once you get far enough in a run, there is [b]so much stuff[/b] going on onscreen. Once your area of effect is large enough, you can't see enemy hitboxes anymore (even at max visibility). This isn't always a huge problem since you will be moving a lot but it hurts a few characters in the late game.

2. Some of the characters don't seem viable just yet. Maybe I haven't tried the right builds but certain characters seem to click immediately while others struggle. 

I really like this game and will continue to complete all the content published as time goes on. Once you get comfortable it is even a great game to play while multi-tasking (like listening to podcasts or streams) if that's your thing

If you're into auto-attack games this is right up your alley. especially if you like combining multiple skill to make a broken build or synergies.
The only minor cons here is the overall audio. The BGM is bad the sfx is almost non exixstance.
Solid game

Soulstone Survivors is a pretty good addition to the reverse bullet hell genre. Like any other game, it's got its pros and cons, but overall I think it's an enjoyable experience and, for the price, definitely worth a buy.

There are 14 playable characters at the time of writing this review. Every single one of them has access to unique abilities, and the ones that are available to you depend on the character you are playing. This means that every character ends up having their own unique ways of being played by default (although you can change that with passive power-ups). There's a lot of unique kinds of runs you can make, which is fantastic for replayability!

The meta progression feels pretty good - You get passive unlocks that apply to every character in the game, runes that are basically powerups you can mix and match on any character and change at any time, and every character now has a main and a secondary weapon. Each weapon comes with its own unique skill and stat bonuses, which impacts playstyle even further.

Balance feels very off in some cases - Things like chaos spells feel really weak compared to a build like bleed stacking barbarian. Once you get into infinite portal 5 or 6, the scaling tends to get out of hand and it's not really feasible to keep up. Enemies have tons of health, they will one shot you if you make a mistake, but you are leveling more and more slowly so you can't keep up with their stat increases. Some builds definitely perform much, much better than others later in the game.

There are also curses that you can apply to a level before starting it - These are basically modifiers that make your runs more difficult. Some of them are simply not fun, in my opinion - it feels like added difficulty for the sake of it, which I'm sure a lot of people do enjoy, but I feel particularly negative about having invincible enemies following me around, or that have cast times so quick you can't even react.

Another thing that is frustrating currently is collisions and the AoE indicators for enemies - It is very easy to dash into a tree or corner and get stuck there, like the momentum gets you glued to the hitbox and it's really hard to get back out. I really wish you'd just slide along it instead, because a misplaced dash can easily end your run once it's been going for a while.
Also, AoE indicators can be completely incorrect - Attacks regularly go further/are wider than the indicators show once you get further into runs. I'm not sure what the deal is here, but things get hectic really quickly on higher curse levels and it makes it really difficult to tell where you can and can't stand. Enemies also cast their abilities faster and faster as your run keeps going, and at some point there's basically no time to react at all on some of them. Doesn't feel very good when you get hit for your entire life pool an hour into a run because the boss decided to smack you instantly.

At the end of the day, it's a good game. It's got some minor issues that are definitely inconvenient, but I think it's still worth getting in its current state. There's room for improvement and I do hope that the developers rework some skills and make longer runs feel more fair, as it's a really fun gameplay loop and there is tons of replayability. At the time this review was written, 100%ing should take 40-50 hours - Pretty fun grind if you're into the genre.

Despite the fact that the game is in early access, it can already provide content for several dozen hours before everything that is available at the moment is open. This is already a good result for the requested amount of money. But besides this, the devs are actively updating the game, releasing +/- large expansions once a month.
In the last update before the New Year 2023, a lot of skills and new weapons were added for a number of heroes, new boss and boss arena, which expanded the replay value and made it possible to return to the destruction of crowds of opponents who were not lucky enough to be on the same field as our protagonist.
The game has a fairly wide range of skills available to choose from. most of it is not available initially and opens gradually, with the unlock of new heroes, achievements and the crafting of new weapons for heroes. Yes, in the game, achievements are not just a way to satisfy a sense of completion, but also a means of accessing new game content.
Unfortunately, there are also a number of disadvantages.
As I mentioned above, crafting is present in the game. Unfortunately, this system is currently rather poorly implemented, but the devs are gradually expanding the list of objects available for crafting, and in the future this system should become quite diverse.
Also in the game there is a elveling-up system for runes earned during battles. Unfortunately, at the moment this system is also extremely non-variable and tiny. So far, the developers have not made any attempts to expand it, but due to the active work on many game systems, I am sure that this system will become a much more interesting element of the game.

In summary: I would like to recommend this product for purchase even though it is in the early access stage, there is already enough content to recoup the cost of the product in terms of price/quality/content amount, while game development has not stalled, unlike many other products that have entered early access.

I enjoyed this game for quite a while, it's actually a really good game and sets it apart from other survival games. 

However, I can't recommend it simply because of what the game becomes when you get to the chaos modes. I know these details might seem minor on the surface but it does have a major impact on the games fun and is a fundamentally flawed design that really begins to stick out.

The core issue with the design philosophy seems to be the way they handle the dodge mechanic. The frequency you can dodge means they eventually have to spam a lot of AoEs to keep it challenging...and this is exactly what happened. The end result undermines any playstyles or build diversity by around chaos 3. 

It's a shame because the game itself could be great, but unless they rework the dodging and totally change the enemy design (and those really annoying towers) then I don't see any way to make all of the diverse build options they give you to really matter or be balanced in a fun way.
Becomes easy and monotonous very fast. I guess I'm over the VS-like fad.

Its an alright game. Hoping to see it improve with future updates. 

It's a skeleton of a game right now. Abilities are not balanced very well.

Late game is just increased difficulty with more AoEs to avoid, and no real incentive to do it. 

Classes are definitely not all created equal, with only one class having natural access to self healing (arguably making it far superior to all other classes).

Level ups happen so frequently that it breaks the pace of the game. If you already have the active skills you want, theres no way to automatically ignore new active abilities and instead you must click "replace with passive abilities", further breaking the pacing of the game. 

Currency is 99% useless, after playing for 3 hours you will have gotten enough of every resource to buy all champions, weapons, and skill tree nodes. I have like millions of minor runestones and hundreds of major runestone, gems, and other resources just sitting around. 

Runes are very meh, and mostly just unlock the ability to get active skills on classes that normally would not have access to them. 

Bomb goblins are annoying, can instantly explode if they spawn next to you and send you hurtling across the map. It's almost a requirement to get a fast aoe to defend against them. This is like a "build tax" that is forced on you just to play the game. 

Developers just dropped an update, that didn't address any of the current problems that most players agree the game has, and instead just added 19 new active abilities (there are plenty of active abilities for the current game state), which some minor fixes to balancing. 

That being said, the game is super fun and addicting. Hope it gets better.

This is an otherwise great game that is badly hampered by a lack of playtesting. Skills in this game are wildly imbalanced, with some doing 10x the damage of other skills in an average run and many being absolutely mandatory for any of the harder difficulties while others have no utility whatsoever. This is already pretty frustrating when there are such massive discrepancies, but it's not just a matter of huge damage gaps, for example:

-Skill that don't multi-hit (or buff you) are awful because status buildup is all that matters
- Many skills are rendered functionally useless because they completely blanket the screen to the point where you cannot see enemies, targeting circles, and terrain at all
- The majority of aoe skils that the player is not directly aiming are of no use because you have to kite bosses at all times and that means they will not stand in the AOEs
-Several skills lag the game increasingly badly making controlling your character progressively more impossible

Playing very specific optimized builds can be really fun but the frustration of doing anything else really detracts from the experience
What you see is what you get, good fun but hoping they add a bit more too it in the future.

This take on a 'Vampire Survivors' style game emphasizes build diversity and more minute control over your character.

It's high damage enemies don't always gel well with the laser light show that is the presentation, but it doesn't stop the game from being massively compelling.

In it's current early access state, the 'earliest' of its components are its out of combat progression layers which fall off pretty early and will leave you with no way to spend your currencies. If that's a big incentive for you, I'd say the game is currently in 'wishlist and see' territory rather than being an outright purchase.

https://youtu.be/DEJetJgDRF0

30hr Review: The game gets better and better. The developer is extremely interactive on Discord and there is a solid community that shares insights into potential build ideas (both practical and theory-crafting). Additional modes (boss runs, endless mode, etc.) mix up the gameplay formula a bit, and ongoing new skills/weapons add more reasons to try another build. Fantastic value and great longevity so far.

Original Review: I enjoyed this during the Steam Next event and the early access release is even more polished and fun than before. Following on the hot trend of arena survival rogue-lites with numerous unlocks, upgrades, and more. What I love most about the game is it actually plays like a twin-stick shooter, so you can independently aim (for skills that allow aiming - some are radius, random, etc) while moving. 

I love the graphics style and after about 5 runs so far successfully completed two of them, which is done (as far as I can tell) by killing enough enemies for bosses to spawn and then defeating them.

There are numerous types of upgrades, between weapons, skill trees, and runs, but I'm still pretty early and have only unlocked a few that add the usual dmg %, cast speed %, and comparable, so I don't know how game-changing other upgrades are.

Different characters/classes seem to have a specific list of skills (aligning to certain tags) that thematically align with them but also keep it so not every skill is open to every class (again, as far as I can tell).

Really enjoying this so far and will update again at the 10hr mark.

First 15-20 hours are fun and then all progression and variability falls off a cliff. I have three things I would like to see changed to give this a positive.
1. Make it so there are more viable unique builds. I have reverted to going for blood build and status affect over and over. I get every debuff ability and stack them on enemies as quick as I can. I feel like on all the heroes I play I am trying to move back to this build. Maybe add more builds ie: straight defense, HP regen, spike armor, combo of certain styles to be more potent, a way to increase rarity of level up rewards, etc.
2. Endless resource sink for empowerment. I have everything upgrade and all my resources are now just piling up...The only reason I am playing is to get through curse levels to unlock the remaining heroes. Every time I finish a run I look at my resource pile and think "whats the point of collecting these?".
3. Make each hero's unique abilities more pronounced. Just removing certain styles of moves or abilities isn't really defining that hero as powerful. There should be a more drastic difference between each hero, refer to point 1.
Bonus: Differing bosses, mobs, move sets/attacks, decrease range and overwhelming amounts of AOE on field at once. There are some times there is literally no where to run at all due to hundreds of enemy AOE circles on the ground. (usually not a huge issue only occasionally running into this)

Overall I think there is a solid backbone to this game with decent points, I just would like to see a solid endless feedback with more unique builds for each class that are fun to play. Hopefully the devs still give this some more love and turn this into a game that feels rewarding to come back to.

Better than Vampire Survivors imo lol. The only reason I died at the higher levels is because the spells and frequency of it got too big and I just lagged out. Mind you I'm running a 2080ti. 

However I'm not too sure about the balancing just yet because it seems you can just re-use all the player passives and just cheese the hell out of certain builds. The one that made my PC freeze was totems, and all the different types of shockwaves. Nearly 70-80% of the screen was just constant spamming of the skills and eventually I just died to the 1v4 bosses.

Not a bad game out of the box, but you can tell they didn't really do any kind of focused testing when it comes to the Curse levels, which is basically this game's way of trying to extend it's life span; play the same level over again except harder.

Harder means the usual enemies have more HP, do more damage, but it also means more elites. Which basically means all the time. Same with suicide goblins that explode instantly when touching you.  The result ends up being a really jank mechanical and visual mess, where you might be trying to play a melee character, but find yourself unable to actually get within striking range of bosses because there's 8000000000 incoming area damage indicators on your location at all times, and about 300 enemies body blocking you from getting wihin range.  Or, if you are in range, you will be knocked away by one of the suicide goblins that you couldn't see, because of all the area damage indicators and other enemies on the screen at one time. 

This is in stark contrast to vampire survivors, where your main object is simply not get touched at all, with the infrequent ranged attacks.  This game pretty just amps up the ranged attacks, by way of area damage indicators, by whole orders of magnitude as the difficulty goes up. This leads the game to more towards "annoying" difficulty rather than "challenging".  

The skill tree is also pretty small, I've completely filled it out save for one item after like 8 hours of play.  Generally speaking, it does little to combat "+300% boss health" anyways.

If you are a fan of any of the "Survivors" games (vampire survivors, Brotato, Survivor.io etc) then you will not be disappointed here. 

This version offers a mechanic which allows you to choose which direction you would like to fire. Some weapons target randomly, others fire in a line, some shoot repeatedly, and some are AOE that stem from your characters position. 

This is a fun and slightly tweaked style that has given me lots of replays and none of them are ever the same. 

There is an option to turn on curses which modify the difficulty and also rewards you with items upon completion. There is an infinite mode and another mode that increases difficulty by adding more 2 or bosses at a time. Lots to do and lots to explore. 

Well worth the money!

In my opinion this game has the best base to build off of any Survivor/Bullet Heaven game released thus far. Although I will give the disclaimer that to me this game feels less like vampire survivors, and more like an action rpg roguelike- which is probably why I love it so much.

Current amount of content should be about 10+ hours, depending on how much it connects with you, I personally got 40 hours out of it so far. I've put it down for the moment to wait on more content before burning myself out on it, but let me tell you, this is the first game in a while that addicted me as hard as it did for the first week I was playing it- literally every day at work I was itching, counting down the minutes until I could get home to play this more- no other game has given me that feeling in years. I would highly recommend.

Oh, also personal tip- if you find the higher difficulties frustrating, I found it more fun to just play at full t5 curses instead of full t7- still provides a degree of challenge without forcing you into a small selection of builds to clear the content. Remember guys, games are supposed to be fun, challenges can add fun but don't let them get in the way of it.

A survivor game polished to the finest visually and gameplay-wise speaking.
This is the perfect brain-off-game-on kind of title.
Finding different combinations of spells and unlocking new abilities and characters feels rewarding.

My only problem would be the music. It is very repetitive and I would've liked the same amount of polish in the audio as they have in all the other aspects of this game. Dynamic music that aligns with the current amount of enemies, my current damage output, my health or ... anything other than just static background music.

Overall a pretty good entry into the line of survivor-esque games. Like other games in this genre, this one offers many classes and builds, some of which can take a while to master but feel very rewarding once you get there. The effects, environments and character designs are also satisfying and stand out amidst other titles of this genre which largely prefer 2D SNES-like visuals. My biggest gripe is how stupid the difficulty scaling is -- especially at the very final scale of difficulty. Scaling up the difficulty here basically means that you face innumerable random AoE projectiles every second, enemies become insurmountable bullet sponges, the number of bosses gets multiplied (which is annoying because it is clear that none of these were designed to go together and have a bunch of recycled moves between each other), enemy attacks go off before your brain can even process them with near perfect tracking, etc. Moreover, the obstacles mentioned above are made all the more challenging when the screen is being blasted by the myriad of visual effects that are produced by those same obstacles; this is particularly bad because these effects can mask walls or other enemy attacks which can cost you your run. These aspects of the game altogether narrow down the number of viable builds to what I believe is a fairly scant number, which is disappointing because I find the less optimal builds to be substantially funner to play. For example, one of the few viable builds I've found is capable of completing the final difficulty scale relies on saturating your roster of skills with summons which clip on negative effects and damage over time while you stand back and not actually play the game. So in sum, while I recommend this game as a promising alternative to Vampire Survivors, I will be frustrated if the difficulty scaling does not get improved in future patches and more viable build alternatives emerge.

This is the first game I've played of this specific genre so I was wary coming into it but I was not disappointed in the slightest. Its like an addictive endless mobile game that isn't filled with microtransactions or ridden with ads. It's just good simple fun. Unlike RPGs where you scale your character with gear and levels over a very long period of time, think of each game you play as a "run" that you try to get your best build out of random possible upgrades and if you die, it doesn't matter, you just try again and see if you get better abilities or upgrades on your next run. While the gameplay loop is rather simple, learning all the different skill synergies is exciting as you unlock more and more of them which is important if you want to be able to beat maps with higher difficulty settings.  I was incredibly surprised by how much content this game had when I got it and the developers are hard at work adding lots more. Good game, all in all

It's not bad, but where Vampire Survivors swarms you with enemies, this game swarms you with red circles, and exploding enemies. It gets excessive with how much stuff is going after you, to the point where it feels needlessly complicated. 

I think the team has some good ideas on hand with offering certain skills with certain characters, offering a Rune Tree, Skill Tree, Blacksmith, and Achievement unlocks. I think Blacksmith could be fleshed out more than it is, it doesn't feel like changing your weapon, for some characters, really does anything meaningful, since skill you start with can just be replaced anyway. Skill trees look impactful but ends up feeling really basic and could be expanded a bit more. Runes seem like they offer changes to how you play a character, which is nice.

I'm interested to see what this game could be later, but the spam of red circles from enemies gets so excessive that sometimes I feel like I am getting targeted by enemies I can't even see off screen, and I have to snipe them with long range skills to make any progress, and it kills any real tension the game has because you aren't dodging enemies. You're dodging red circles.

The rune system is pretty interesting, but honestly you'll probably end up using 2-3 of the same runes on every character, due to how powerful they are. The difficulty from the curse system can be fairly hard, especially curse VI and VII, although meta builds and proper play does seem to trivialize some of it. Overall, a pretty fun game that easy to get lost in. It also doesn't hurt that it's fairly inexpensive as well.

It sets out to be a fairly uninspired Hoard Survivor and it achieve that but the aesthetic is nonexistent, the vibe is frustrating and cold, and the game is a grind fest. As someone who loves Survivors-likes, you expect a little grind, but the game isn't challenging or engaging enough to warrant that.
To top it all off, the game is a time sink.
The meta upgrades don't carry nearly enough impact to make a dent in the games time sink - i.e. you don't become strong enough to outstrip the games churn of waves of enemies and the rewards for each run aren't enough to merit doing the "one more run" addictive fun that solid Hoard Survivors have.

That BUT at the beginning is the reason I can't recommend this game to pretty much anyone outside of starving Hoard Survivor fanatics, ESPECIALLY at the price. The gall to sell it for its base price of $10 for what's on offer is kind of the most disappointing thing about it.

TLDR: Good game if you want to feel overpowered and don't mind grinding, but have some problem with late game contents(Just like most of EAs).
On lower difficulty(curse level) this game is perfectly playable,but there are some problems as the curse level rises: 
First, health crystal always heal you for a fixed number no matter how many health you have, which makes stacking health very ineffective. 
Second, you only gets to dash twice even with the upgrade, when there is only once boss, two dashes can dodge most of there attacks with no problem, but- spoiler alter- when you am trying to unlock DK, there will be 3 bosses chasing you around, exploding goblins trying to push you all over the place, meteors falling every where. You need to dash 5 times in a row to even think about dodging those.
Also, having different rarities for upgrades kind of defeat the purpose of having 3 upgrade choices, I kind of hope everything is balanced into the same level.

Edit: Finally completed all stage in max difficulty, the bosses are actually not a big problem since there can't be more than 5 of them at once. But the corrupted paladin is easily the most annoying enemy in the game, especially his holy fire attack comes out so fast that is almost undodgeable(or literal unavoidable if you are playing DK) if you are too close and hits for 50+. Seriously, why?

It's an okay enough take on the inverse bullet hell genre. The main issue is it is insanely RNG based. You can generally get through tier 4 through sheer effort of will, but after that if you don't get rolls that improve a type of skill rather than a single skill you're not going to win your run. I feel like the devs really didn't bother play testing the game and instead said "well, what modifier could we add at this point" regardless of how it actually feels to play with it. Also the resource system is very poorly implemented. After tier 3 you'll have everything unlocked and all drops beyond that point are just pointless. Overall it feels pretty unfinished and thoughtless.

Got my moneys worth out of it, but this isnt nearly as good as Vampire Survivors.

First off, this is a twin-stick shooter. So if you arent a fan of those, then dont buy his games. Almost every skill has to be directionally aimed with the right thumb-stick or mouse cursor.

Secondly, enemies CONSTANTLY hit you from off the screen wherre you cannot see them. You'll be doing fine then an elite snake and boss laser will be casted off the screen on oposite sides where you must eat one, and you'll die.

Weapons dont evolve, which means there's zero thought in your loadout, you just grab your 6 weaps and pray to RNG gods for epic buffs. Which makes the game pretty dull, imo.

Characters dont feel unique at all. They have minor stat difference, but none of them have unique character gimmicks and play exactly the same. One may have a little less HP and extra Crit Damage, but thats the extent. None of them get +2 missiles every 20 levels or anything actually game-changing.

You can definitely kill 10+ hours in this. But ultimately, its nowhere near as good as vampire survivors and I'd whole-heartedly reccomend that over this clone.

For an early access title, this game delivers and then some. Fun, replayability, highly tailored difficulty with allowing you to choose curse intensity, and the visuals are great. They've resolved a ton of performance concerns but still some tweaks need to be made.

Pros:

- Music
- Visuals (mind you, this is relative to others in the genre)
- Gameplay loop is fun
- The amount of runes and survivors to choose from means there are many MANY different playstyles
- In depth, or as shallow as you'd like
- Customizable difficulty (curse customization)
- Maps look nice and are (somewhat) diverse
- In-match graphic tweaks are instance, non-laggy, and convenient. I'm impressed honestly

Cons

- lack of weapons (this will be fixed as the game develops, devs are WONDERFUL, so this isn't a deal breaker)
- Difficulty ramp is "enemies have more health, more damage" which...limits a lot of playstyles. You WILL need high damage, you WILL need luck, you WILL need to get a specific rune for the higher curse intensities (+5% damage per negative effect) combined with getting the slow passive and the coveted Hypothermia passive in-match just to stay close to something feasible to beat a 40+ curse intensity round
- Skills are vast, but limited. What I mean is, a dot is a dot and rarely does that include an interesting passive. Other than slight damage value tweaks, dots are more setup for skills that enhance said dots, or vice versa (e.g. you must have a skill that applies a fire dot for there to be a chance that the effect takes place)

If the devs read this, I would LOVE to see difficulty in numbers, and not just damage, health, movement speed (especially the movement speed; forces on-hit slow stacking to be able to process what's going on at level 4+)

Overall, this game is wonderful, and has the potential to be a masterpiece, given the right development priorities. Once new weapons get implemented, I'll probably binge more of it. Just kidding, I'm going to do that anyway.

Welcome to: it's Vampire Survivors! but ... case file #1034

It's Vampire Survivor but there are more RPG elements (skills tree, runes and weapons that you can equip to enhance your) and character diversity.

Pro: 
Huge character diversity. Your death knight might not be the same as your friends 
Long list of skills and synergies. Each skills have tags (projectile, fire, ice etc) that have synergies with other skills and powers

Con:
The hitboxes are horrible in this game. Sometimes your get hit when you shouldn't. Obstacles in this game also have weird hitboxes that makes them more annoying to dodge that it should be.
Visuals clutter. You will end up making skills look 95% invisible once you progress further in the game. Also, red banners appears all the time taking up 1/5 of your screen announcing boss and objectives. 
Ping pong physics. There is a rag doll-ish physics in this game that sends your character flying across the map when you get hit. I don't think it adds anything and it's more of a nuisance.

Took around 50 hours to unlock everything and get all achievements, If you like this genre it is a great game and looks good. Couple downsides to this game. It is so graphic heavy late game you will have to turn them down just to see the ground. BALANCE There seems to be only 2 playstyles to dominate easily Ranged and run or minion army. Proximity based skills and RNG skills are terrible in early game because they are not effective. The game trains a player to use minion stacking or beams, bolts and AOE spin to win tatics.  Movement buffs are almost needed so bad because the AI can target you very quickly and if you use the damage for speed reduction you will just get overwhelmed. The Devs are very active on discord and working on getting the game balanced.  Once they balance out the game more I think it will have more replayability. It is a very good game and worth every penny/per hour of playtime.

And since its around christmas time lets add a recipe for some CHRISTMAS COOKIES here:

- 300 grams ground hazelnuts
- 150 grams marzipan paste (should be warmed up a little)
- 5 egg whites
- 280 grams white sugar
- 15 grams vanilla sugar 
- 1 Tsp cinamon

Mix marzipan paste, sugar, egg whites (not beaten), Vanilla sugar first. Add in Cinamon and ground hazel nuts. 

Make little piles with two teaspoons and let them bake for around 20 min (OR until SLIGHTLY browned, they should still be soft in in the middle) at 150°C (~300° F)

[h1] Like Vampire Survivors but also heats your room [/h1]
This game is a Vampire Survivors clone. It has at the time of this review 14 characters and a small skilltree. Every Character has its own set of traits and attacks.
But it does well in differentiating itself from the original.
A smithing mechanic enables you to craft weapons for characters, the weapon you choose determines your starting Attack.
Runes allow to you to change the gameplay slightly and offer great challenges to unlock them.

[h1] Pros [/h1]
[olist]
[*] Great replayability
[*] Refreshing mechanics
[*] Challenges you to unlock characters and runes
[/olist]

[h1] Cons [/h1]
[olist]
[*] Once you find a meta you tend stick to it
[*] Some Characters are unballanced
[*] Makes my pc cry 
[/olist]

[h1] tl;dr [/h1]
10 Euros is a good investment.

I've played quite a few "Survivors" style games and I'm enjoying the format, but this one makes one of the biggest attempts to be "legit" while simultaneously suffering from the worst visibility issues of any Survivors-style game as you get into higher difficulties (where these games shine IMO). 

Visibility in survivors games is already a challenge because there's inevitably going to be a point, especially at high difficulties, where your screen and character are overwhelmed by enemies, often making character movement a really careful game of trying to balance extreme powers with avoiding a crowd of enemies who will suck your life instantly. 

Well, this game basically takes that problem and says "hey, why don't we go even further with Area of Effect attacks for both the main character and enemies?" At first, this mechanic feels pretty cool, especially if you've played other Survivor games because it seems like a way of adding more complexity to both enemy and player attacks, while still visually communicating this information on the map. But, as you start to get better and add "curses" onto runs, there becomes a point where you literally can't see anything because the entire ground is almost always covered in AoE stuff, projectiles are everywhere, various animations are happening simultaneously, and the game has a ton of collision points, so even if you try to dodge your way out of a clustertruck of visibility issues, there's a chance you'll get stuck on some tiny mob enemy or a piece of scenery. 

I like difficult games and I can respect certain visibility elements of bullet-hell style games, but there's a point where this isn't about skill or real difficulty, but rather about the way the designers chose to structure mechanics and information on screen. It generally feels like right when you're really "getting good" at the game, it hits a point where skill stops being a major focus and it really starts being about your patience of dealing with the most busy explosion effects, projectiles, and other visual distractions ON TOP of the already busy qualities of a Survivor game. Comedically, all of this nonsense actually makes it so that the game's mobs are much smaller than a typical Survivor game as well, despite actually messing up visibility even more.

At this moment in time, I still think games like Vampire Survivors and Rogue Genesia are much better implementations of these mechanics, especially with Rogue Genesia's level system. Yeah, I like the look and number of classes in this game, but I sure as hell don't enjoy playing it as much as other Survivors style games currently.

I came to this game as someone who has completed Vampire Survivors 100% as of 1.0 and if you're looking for a game of this type and haven't played that yet, go play that instead.

As for Soulstone Survivors I was having fun with the first couple of difficulties but they were a little too easy and once you reach Curse VI, it just becomes completely dependent on RNG.

Here's the issues:

1. Leveling system

When you level up you get either a new skill or trait (correspond to weapons and items respectively in Vampire Survivors)

There's a wide variety of weapons but at higher levels ~80% of them are useless. When weapons are offered to you there's three to choose from and you have a limited number of rerolls per run and if you don't get the right weapons you'll get smoked pretty quickly. Arcane Power, Bladestorm, Chaos Missile, Might, and Bloodlust for example stand head and shoulders above so many other skills that unless you roll well, you might as well restart.

Traits follow the same model of being offered three choices per level

For traits they fall into a few categories: boosting one of your stats by a static number (health, block, armor), boosting a specific group or a single skill by a percentage additively, or giving your weapons a chance to proc a damage over time property. 

This means there's no unique progression for each weapon. Each weapon can have a increased cast speed, area, damage, or a chance to cast multiple times but this means that you have to hope to roll good choices otherwise your run is over because you didn't find the trait that gave you enough damage or multicast to continue.

2. Enemies

The basic flow of each stage is that you have to kill x number of enemies and then a boss shows up. Rinse and repeat until you've done this 5 times and then you can enter a portal to end the run or enter a different one to continue.

There's just a handful of bosses (6 or so I think) so you'll see the same ones over and over which wouldn't be a problem but some of them are very similar to the other ones. The ice guy and the poison guy are basically the same and so is the guardian and the fire guy. 

The bosses and most elites have the ability to CC you pretty hard so it's not uncommon to have your run ended by being bounced in the air by getting sideswiped by a random elite and then having every boss and elite aim their huge AoE right where you're going to land essentially one shotting you.

3. Difficulty

Once you've completed a stage on a certain difficulty you can challenge it on the next tier up to 7 tiers. 

With each tier the enemies get stronger, have more health, and your healing is reduced (there's practically no healing available already)

There's also additional factors like towers which start spawning all over the map which can shoot AoE blasts at you, an invincible ghost that chases you and can kill you instantly, and more bosses spawn whenever you reach the enemies killed threshold.

All fine in theory but in practice your run is so dependent on RNG that unless you get near optimal skills and traits you're dead by the time the second set of bosses spawns.

Their health pools become massive and their damage is so high that they can easily take off 60-80% of your health in one hit. So you're stuck kiting a deathball of 3 bosses. Unless you can melt them, it takes forever to kill them and before you can do that you've probably already triggered the next wave of bosses.

So now you have 5 bosses, 10 towers, a million elites, all with the potential to one shot you if you get bounced the wrong way. If you haven't gotten enough stacks of the movement speed trait, you can't even move out of the way of the constant red circles unless you're spamming dodge as soon as it becomes available. 

Vampire Survivors operates in ebbs and flows, there's intense moments and moments where there's just fodder on screen. This game is on all the time so there's no breathing room from the hordes of extremely oppressive mechanics. There's something to be said for that but it just gets frustrating extremely quickly.

Can't recommend in current state. This is dodge red area simulator. But the catch is, even when you dodge the red areas, they still hit you. Some red areas last forever on the ground, and if you stick your toe in them, you'll lose a quarter of your health per tick. This dwindles the amount of non-red areas there are to go to. Agency is taken away if an invisible red area hits you, because now you're bounced between 4 red areas back to back. Will come back each patch to see if they fix red areas.

It's a recommend, but you need to know what you're getting into.

Vampire Survivor's (VS) charm is that it's very silly. Its weapons are silly, its stages are silly, the meta progression stuff is silly; there are a bunch of secret characters and references because it doesn't take itself seriously in the slightest, and I can't overstate how much of a plus that is for it. Conversely, Soulstone Survivors (SS) takes itself way too seriously, which isn't [i]necessarily[/i] bad, but you need to know that it affects the way the game plays out in a number of ways.

Firstly, build design never gets stupid in the same way. All the weapons can be pushed to stupid limits in terms of damage, effect size and multicasting a bunch of times, but fun stuff like the zaniness of evolved weapons creating insane new particle effects and drastically increasing your power level don't exist here. [i]However[/i], build design does feel more meaningful in Soulstone Survivors. In VS (assuming late game meta progression) you can basically slap together whatever weapons you want, and, as long as you line yourself up for some evolutions, you'll be good pretty much whatever you do. SS wants you to take the build crafting more seriously. Even average builds can still struggle past the first endless loop, so you need to ensure you're putting together good synergy every time.

Fortunately, the build design stuff is where Soulstone Survivors is at its best. There're tonnes of weapon choices (actives), and you have the option to replace your current actives if they’re not working, or you find something with better synergy. Each character only has access to specific spheres of actives, which makes swapping characters provide different experiences as the active options change*. Furthermore, you can import skills from outside a character's skillset through the rune system, which gives you some unusual combos if you want. Lastly, the developers are looking to add a ton more skills to the game by full release, so the options are only going to get more varied. Putting together the best combination each run is a moreish experience, though not without faults.

* A criticism that all the actives are ultimately just variations on certain basic ideas might be reductive, but I wouldn’t disagree either.

Being able to replace your actives anytime is great, but after a certain point it's irritatingly difficult to figure out which of your actives are underperforming and need to go. You can't view any damage totals until after the run, and distinguishing which set of damage numbers go with which active is a complete nightmare once the screen starts filling with effects and everything's dying so fast. I'm starting to get a 'feel' for when something isn't good enough but risking changing something in a run that's otherwise going fine at the moment feels painful. It wouldn't really matter all that much, but if you plan to go deep on the endless runs then there isn't really room for underperforming elements in your build after a certain point.

Worth noting here that the challenge of build design drops off a cliff into the first or second loop because you probably have actives you're happy with (or can't tell are bad), and now you're just mashing boring damage upgrades to stay on top of the damage sponge levels. At this point you've basically seen everything your build will do and all that's left is finding out how long it can keep going. 

Also, it might be too early for me to really tell, but some actives just feel a lot worse than others, even when they're played in combinations that seem very synergistic. It's something you can only really learn by playing and then seeing the damage totals at the end, but, having seen it a few times, it's kinda frustrating that some stuff just isn't as good as it seems it should be. There will always be elements that're stronger or weaker because balancing things perfectly is a tall order, but I've seen some actives that strikingly underperform even in builds that seem really tailored to them.

There're several other areas that clearly need improvement too. There're five stages, but they're all functionally identical. The map obstacles vary slightly in look and shape, but the maps are always the same rectangular layout with the same enemies. The only mechanical difference between stages are the meta resources you can get from each, which really don't matter because you only need a small amount of each relative to how grindy the other meta progression goals are.

On that point, meta progression seems poorly paced. You start out picking up meta buffs, and you can get a few at the end of each run, which is nice. But you’ll soon find that a lot of the later levels are tied to boss gems that you only get in limited numbers during runs, but the weighting for a lot of the upgrades is towards the earliest boss gem. This seems nice because you know you’ll likely get some of these in a run, but [i]so many[/i] upgrades need this first boss gem type that you’ll find the later gem types piling up as you only need them for one or two upgrades each, but you’ll be massively bottlenecked by the first gem type the rest of the time.

Lastly, I mentioned earlier that characters’ active choices are dictated by their innate spheres, but, unfortunately, outside of that variance, they’re basically all the same. The character select screen tells you that they have different buffs to one another, but the meaningfulness of those distinctions will be lost after the first few minutes of  play. You get so many options to pick up basic stats buffs that starting with a character starting with an extra 10% crit chance is literally meaningless when you can easily make up that difference in a single level up. Even characters’ base actives, which are unique and could give them some identity, are often very weak compared to the actives you get from level ups, so they often end up being the first thing you overwrite, which I think removes a lot of uniqueness characters could have had if those actives were more central to their build design options.

All in all, the build stuff has merit. I wish there were options to make abilities go completely insane in a VS way, but I'm embracing the more sane approach that SS is taking, and I think it has a rich diversity of build options for people that like to tinker with build design to explore. Everything else is kind of a mess though. Maps are bland, enemies are bland, characters lack identity, the meta progression pacing is fine at first and then just hits a tedious grind wall because of resource bottlenecking. If you liked VS for its charm, quirk and laid back approach then I’d argue that this doesn’t even come close, but if you wanted more from VS from a gameplay perspective then SS delivers in spades.

This game fails in almost every regard. It disrespects the player with braindead AI, same mobs and bosses (Lords of the Void) on each map so that each map only functions as a reskin,  pointless "characters" that solely act as stat modifiers since you discard the weapon skill as soon as a better option appears, and much more nonsense. You can clear pretty much any challenge presented without upgrading anything, just walk in circles and press space as needed. The bosses turn their head so slowly with their cookie cutter beam movesets that you can seriously just keep walking.

The game attempts to obfuscate it's boring gameplay loop with obscene visual clutter to create an unsatisfying and frustrating challenge of seeing past your OWN moves. Sadly, that's the hardest thing about this game once you've upgraded your AOE size and multicast frequency. And even that isn't difficult; it's just annoying, and intended probably to compensate for the lack of any substance or meaningful mechanics to make a player want to reopen the game. When you want to feel the power of your upgrades, instead you feel punished by them on-screen with additional size and frequency.

It's amazing to me how much content the devs plan to release. Currently, there is so much already that it almost feels like a complete game. The balancing is fair. Pyromancer (fire skills) and Assassin (positionals) need a little bit more love for bossing at the highest curse levels, but the best part is how many different builds you can make and the different implementations that are viable.
