So far the game has been a ton of fun and its well worth it's price point, tldr below

*Disclaimer* I did not review any material or news from the publisher or developer

What I enjoyed:
The music is next level, amps me up a lot.
Feels smooth to play and doesn't get any lag on my device.
 (I beat the requirements by a lot though)
General gameplay loop is a lot of fun... smack stuff around, boss event, loot, repeat
Seems pretty well balanced
Graphics are great and skills feel visceral
Interesting abilities and passives

What I dislike:
Character customization is a bit shallow but I'm hoping this is just a symptom of early access
No multiplayer and (I may be wrong) it seems there won't be multiplayer
System progressions have wildly different progression speeds
 - IE: I have almost every talent and will have the remaining few soon, but have unlocked less than a 5th of the runes
UI needs to provide more information, specifically what you will get for spending in game currencies.
 - IE: The blacksmith wont even let you look at what a weapon will get you until you have invested in the character that will use the weapon.
Build diversity is lacking.  So far all the best builds I have found get a bunch of skills with the same type / tags and get things that effect all your abilities.  I don't see any builds so far focusing a smaller subset of abilities or unique interactions
Support skills have wild discrepancies in balance, some being a must have while others aren't worth a slot even if there was multiplayer

Overall the game is definitely worth the price point even if it was the music alone, strongly recommend
Red circle simulator.

After pretty intensive testing, and having completed pretty much every single achievement currently available (as of Nov 30th 2022), I cannot recommend this game enough.

The gameplay is fun, interactive but not a burden, builds are extremely diverse and every run is different thanks to the RNG nature of the upgrade system. For 10€ this game is a steal, the devs have done an amazing job at combining the Roguelike genre with an ARPG twist, something I had not seen before but that just feels right.

There are absolutely NO microtransactions / in-game purchases, this is 100% buy and play, which is refreshing in todays' market where games, even single player oriented ones, try and push in-app purchases down your throat at every turn.

Only negative point, the game can be extremely taxing on your setup, especially if you display all damage numbers, have your graphic settings set to high and use high intensity skills (be it in terms of visuals or in terms of DoT calculations). Hopefully the devs manage to optimize the game to make it run better, however by tweaking the settings you should be able to run it on mid-budget setups just fine.

Thanks a lot to the Soulstone Survivors team for making such a brilliant game, it might just be in early access at the moment but it's already a gem, and it can only get better from here on out !
Fun survivor-like, with interesting build possibilities

The main things I'm looking for in a survivors game are replayability and variance.

Soulstone Survivors offers both in excellent quality while also maintaining a form of balance. There are stuff that are vastly underpowered relative to others but it all comes down to how the build is made alongside it.

I like the ever increasing challenges and curses, as well as the variety of stages. However, they lack creativity in terms of the design. All the stages are big square spaces with bits of obstacles thrown here and there. The curses are either more enemies or some kind of handicap. I think stages need to be overhauled and reshaped such as a rectangular shaped map with narrow bridges connecting islands, or a vertically designed stage where there are mines, or even put traps where extra enemies will spawn, etc. There are also no upgrade pickups that incentive players to explore the map. Instead, you have ores and health crystals but they spawn randomly so you can literally move one screen away and come back to spawn them. Each of the maps also do not have their own "identity". Oh here's a square space with bones, this one is a desert with palm trees, and this one has ice in them. Maybe put a key building of some sort to give them a little personality instead of just bland, generic spaces.

The menus are very cluttered. When I play with my controller (and I always play survivors with controller), I can't even choose curse stages, so for the first 5 hours, I thought you can't roll back the curses. I accidentally found out when I was alt-tabbing between monitors by clicking on the numbers in stage selection. Also, moving from one rune selection to another with a controller is a big pain in the neck. I suggest the devs take a more streamlined approach to menu designs to enable better controller support.

This game is still one of the more exciting survivors I played and hopefully at full release, I will see more content and creativity put into this game. It has a lot of potential with the foundation it has now.

It's still in EA, so I'm not going to give any ratings.

P.S. Replace spell archetypes with icons instead of a long list of words. Make use of colors more between enemy types and please, make audio cues more audible for boss attacks. At 300% or whatever AOE size, I literally can't see the bloody telegraphs.

This is Hades, but minus all the incredible story stuff, and definitely slightly less finessed combat, but it's still in early access, so who knows. Mush in some more wave-defense and deck-building type elements, and you've got yourself a monster-blasting good time. The characters have identity through their skills and particular stat boosts, but I wish they had more personality. 

I'm for a good time, not for a long time. If you like destroying monsters and figuring out how to manipulate damage systems, then this game is 100% worth the spend for the 40-60 hours of content I imagine you'll get out of it. There's not a ton of polish in the game, but it doesn't feel "straight out of alpha" and I experienced no major bugs in my play though. There's definitely a lot of complexity invested in character and skill diversity and mechanics interaction.  The game will feel the same on a run-over-run basis but the goals of your character and what skills they use will change dramatically, and that's where the replayability comes from. Although, I think we need some tuning for the other classes versus the Paladin guy, who's has a self-heal that almost no other classes have access too. One of his default abilities is also absurdly powerful.

If everything on the content road map is added, I'll definitely back for a few more rounds after I 100% the game in its current state. Feels pretty good on the Steam Deck too. My hours were split about 75% deck, 25% desktop. The game feels fine on deck, but menu navigation is a little clunky (mouse over tool-tip stuff from the desktop), but I imagine they may add more controller support.

A short review for 'Soulstone Survivors' (SS for short), an interesting Survivors game, with some skill attached but with some rather bad RNG involved once you get to higher difficulty...

SS is takes (for the most part) bits of Vampire Survivors, and adds some depth, like graphical fidelity, weapon crafting (as far as what it offers for now), both skill tree and runes to make both specific and varried builds.

For what SS offers now, is an abundance of entertainment (when you don't grind out for higher difficulty) with what it has to offer right now, which makes it have a high potential to be a great game in the future. Right now I'd say it's quite good, but can always be improved, considering the maps feel 'samey' alongside the enemy variety and overlords, in addition to the amount of skills that will be put in, I'd say SS has the potential to be a vast game with a lot of builds which could keep a lot of people hooked on its gameplay.

All in all, SS is already quite the decent game, even for a €9.99 priced game... it offers a lot of fun for what it offers, and I certainly do look forward for future updates.

Also, please make the rest of the weapons for the other characters. It's off-putting knowing you have tons of characters and only the 6 from the prologue have weapons.

I enjoy Vampire Survivors. I loathe this game. The skill choices are meaningless and all the passives are boring and meaningless too. Play for 15 minutes and all your abilities just fill the screen with nonsense and you can't even tell what is going on. At the end, you get a breakdown of how each skill performed, but it fails to mention that because of RNG one skill was level 5 and another was level 18. I doubt it even matters since the game is so easy that you could only die by doing it on purpose.

This game cuts away the boring grinding of other games like Path of Exile and gets right into the action. The mechanics are easy to understand but each attempt goes a little different depending on your class. I am glad there is some variable gameplay and challenging modes to test oneself. One can leverage the game to their preference without taking anything away from the game. Even not on sale and still not officially released, I recommend it.

Good fun but in it's current state it will not hold high end runners interest. Not in just progression (as this is early access) but mechanics will/do surpass design. What do I mean by this, well area visibility was a problem in Diablo which is what I would more compare the gameplay to instead of an arena fighter like Vampire Survivors. Area visibility is bad in this game, very bad especially in endgame. Now you could say this is a design feature to make you pick and choose abilities but I say that's lazy and unacceptable an answer. Layer AOE markers ABOVE user abilities at the very least, make it pretty later. Another problem that doesn't feel great to deal with is knockback/dashing. Getting caught on a tree with a hitbox of a football field and not being able to dash through it sucks. Make a feature or ability that allows dashing through scenery (to a point, looking at you line of trees in Desert) or knocking back monsters at the end of the evade. Early access - thus the positive review.

This game is the pretty version of Vampire Survivors.

But it ends there. The majestic chaos of VS and the godlike abilities are not present in this game. Instead, you on a playing field where enemy strikes are falling everywhere. One hits will kill you from across the board. A fun run can end in seconds from a one hit you never saw coming. 

RNG is rarely in your favor. Your build is never going to work how you want it. You cannot claim that one aspect of the build you direly need because it never presents itself. You cannot play with the build and get creative - if you try a silly set up with multiple packs of putrid hounds - you are sure to lose. Your build demands that you follow a rigid set up or you will melt absolutely nothing.

This game has none of the gleeful destruction of VS, you spend ALL of your time trying to disengage and run away from danger and praying your paltry dashes will get you to safety. It isn't a soulslike game of GET GUD it is a punishing roll of the dice and luck. You are nerfed and nothing is going to work in your favor.

EA means there will - hopefully - be balance and fun in the future. I am looking forward to seeing where it goes. I love the genre, but this lacks the fun at the moment.

An excellent evolution of the "Reverse bullet hell" genre that Vampire Survivors (go buy it if you haven't played it) pioneered (or at least popularized).

The dash button changes the game - my skill feels much more relevant than in Vampire Survivors because I can dodge enemy abilities. That's another thing - enemies have abilities that they forecast with red damage zones on the ground. 

There are an incredible amount of skills and I find I have made successful builds with many of them. The devs are very active in balancing and adding new content. The community discord is helpful and active in answering questions. 

I can't wait to see where this game goes in the future. I have 27 hours in and have not completed the current content.

I have sunk a ton of hours into this game already, and I still find myself logging on every day. I enjoy finding new ways to build each character. The skills have a great variance between them, the characters feel different enough to not get stale, and there is so much more planned for this game. There is nothing left to do but wait to see if they deliver on the road map they've released. I can say that I see myself dumping at least another 70 hours into this game, if not more. 10/10 I would recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of the genre, and anyone looking for a good jumping off point for the genre as well.

Quite enjoyable. Unlocks come at a pretty consistent rate, characters feel unique, the ramp up in difficulty is a nice, even curve where you never really hit a hard wall, and the visuals are a nice low poly style that really appeals to me. 
One big negative I've found is that some abilities feel totally useless, even when powered up to max, and you'll never take them. Once you find "the" ability set for a character, you'll gravitate toward it all the time rather than feeling like experimentation between runs will yield success.

This is just an improvement on vampire survivors in every way (at least coming from my playstyle and opinion).

Positives

The gameplay is miles more engaging. 
Weapons/active skills can always be swapped making build variety.  
The unlocks feel more earned.  
To "beat" a round, you can take anywhere from around 10/20 minutes so you don't have to time commit if you don't want to.  Even if you do, the game has 2 types of 'endless' modes that focus on difficulty rather than endurance.
Each character has more identity than just "starts with X weapon & stats/modifier".
You are encouraged to play with difficulty modifiers (more XP for characters = more XP for unlocks).

Negatives

Nothing really. You could say the price tag, but honestly this game is worth it full price imo.

good game

I do recommend this game because it's fun, one of the most entertaining in its genre as of this moment IMO
With added content (more characters, more weapons/skills, more maps, modes...) this will surely be a must buy.
However, there are still flaws which I expect to be addressed in the future
Enemies' attack indicator is still incorrect for some. I get hit way too often at the end of bosses' cone attack or outside the red ring despite the indicator not reaching me. 
Occasionally I get multihit by invisible attacks not shown on screen. Suspect is the flamethrower skill from the boss though I have no way to know (all these are from latest patch which claim them to be fixed already btw).
Dead knight as of right now is very hard to clear 48 curses. His special ability (stun immunity) is useless as they remove stun but don't give him new ability and he already has no dodge. The fixed holy void hunter spawn early is very likely 1 live gone at least since its holy fire skill is so hard to dodge with short cast time and huge AOE, not to mention all those red rings around you. 
With multiple poison and ice boss, your ability as dead knight to traverse terrain also get gimped quite a lot if the poison puddles/ice patch block narrow path (especially on the ice map).
So either you get really lucky in your level up (good skills/upgrade or around 250%+ ms early, all that with good runes) or you have to bring in extra survivability through holy/arcane? skills and that will cost you 2 precious rune slots.
